HEADLINE: An Estate Lives On, Thanks to Apples 

BYLINE:  By DINITIA SMITH 

DATELINE: CLAVERACK, N.Y. 

 BODY:
FROM Route 9H, you can just glimpse Talavera, a yellow, Greek revival mansion with white trim and fluted columns. The house, serenely overlooking the Catskills and the Berkshires, seems deliberately hidden as you wind your way up a long driveway. Only as you reach the foot of the spacious lawn does Talavera reveal itself in all its faded elegance, subject to the inroads of time but occupied in unbroken succession by the Van Ness and Philip families for nearly 200 years. 
 Every fall, some 2,000 city dwellers and suburbanites make their way to the orchards around back, where descendants of the original owners are making ends meet by running a pick-your-own-apple business. Apples cost $14 to $16 a bushel, depending on the variety, which includes McIntoshes, Northern Spy, Mutsu and Jonagolds. The family also sells heritage tomatoes and pears -- among them Anjou, rare on the East Coast, and Harrow Sweet. 
 "My great-great-aunts would have died to see me in pants and down there taking money," said Leila Philip, 40, an English professor at Colgate University in Hamilton, N.Y. "But it's an important job that needs to be done. I enjoy the people, and I feel it connects me to a long history." 
The Philip family's once extensive land holdings in Columbia County -- 294 acres in 1732 -- have diminished to 125 acres. In 1992, when Ms. Philip's father, John Van Ness Philip Jr., died, it looked as though the family might lose the place forever. The cost of labor, machinery and materials had risen drastically in recent years, and apples could be raised more cheaply outside the United States. 
But the family -- five adult siblings and their mother, Julia Willis Philip, 76 -- decided to save Talavera.
"People said, 'You're crazy,' " Ms. Philip said. " 'You should sell it!' " Instead, the siblings agreed to maintain Talavera for agricultural use. They also created a trust fund for the property, a fund to be dipped into in case of calamity. The agreement will last until three years after their mother dies.
To remain competitive, the Philip family had to become modern apple growers. They are replacing the larger trees with smaller ones that will yield more fruit to the acre, a task their father began.
They recognize that just one bad harvest could tip the balance. In 1970, there were 89 apple farms in Columbia County. Today, according to the State Agriculture and Markets Department, there are fewer than half that number. An orchard across Route 9H from Talavera, owned by the Hotaling family, recently went out of business. Today, Philip Orchards is one of the last commercial orchards in town.
Ms. Philip's mother lives at Talavera and manages the farm. The siblings help out on weekends and vacations. At apple picking time, which is just ending, the whole family takes cash from customers. Leila Philip is married to the artist Garth Evans and has a son, Rhys, 4. She comes down from Hamilton regularly to assist with the "bug checks" (looking for pests) and with pruning. Every year, she and her mother attend "fruit school," run by the Cornell Cooperative Extension, where they learn about new apple breeds and pest control regulations.
John Philip, a lawyer and actor in New York, cares for the formal gardens and the heritage tomatoes. In the summer, William Philip, a linguistics professor in the Netherlands, arrives to help out. Thomas Philip, a construction project manager in New York, oversees building projects. Another sibling, Katherine Chansky, a librarian in Saratoga Springs, cares for the main house.
The family has struggled to repair the house and to make the orchards profitable. "Without that kind of involvement, it would be impossible," Leila Philip said.
Her involvement has also included delving into the family's attic -- the diaries, trunks and boxes -- and local records, a search that turned up renegade aunts, ne'er-do-wells, Civil War heroes and a secret love child, the result of a relationship between her grandfather and a maid at Talavera. Ms. Philip, who previously wrote "The Road Through Miyama," about her apprenticeship to a master Korean potter in Japan, then sat down to write "A Family Place: A Hudson Valley Farm, Three Generations, Five Wars, One Family," published by Viking Press. A review in Publishers' Weekly called it "an exquisite rendering of a Hudson Valley family farm, as detailed and colored as a Persian miniature." 
The book begins with a scene that evokes the powerful hold of the house upon the family: "Before me stood Talavera, but all around was darkness," Ms. Philip writes. "Light was spewing out from so many of the tall windows that the house could have been a ship sailing the night sea." 
Elsewhere she calls the house "that grand vessel of the past." Ms. Philip's family arrived in America in 1669, when a Dutch admiral, Adrian Van Ness, settled near Albany. His descendant Willem founded the family farm in Claverack, with a Dutch-style farmhouse. 
Over the years, the Van Nesses married into Hudson Valley aristocracy, the Livingstons, the Philipses of Philmont, the Stottses of Stottville. In 1807, Willem's grandson, William W. Van Ness, a judge in the New York State Supreme Court, built Talavera, named after the Battle of Talavera de la Reina in Spain, Napoleon's famous land defeat by the British.
Talavera was built in the neoclassical style favored by the English, instead of the reigning Dutch style in Claverack. Its formal gardens were laid out like an English estate, with a gradual flowing of park land into farmland. Trees were planted deliberately to create areas of light and dark. A lilac walkway and a cedar walk were added.
Today, the estate has been reduced to less than half its former size. And despite the Philip family's effort to support Talavera through selling apples (and selling off a Gilbert Stuart portrait of Ms. Philip's ancestor Gen. John P. Van Ness), the 15-room house is something of a grand ruin. The wallpaper is peeling, the upholstery on the furniture is torn, the rugs are threadbare. Some parts of the house, including the dining room, still have no electricity.
Ms. Philip rationalizes that doing work on the house could risk destroying Talavera's historical integrity. "Sometimes the worst thing you can do to an old house is repair it," she said. "Everything needs to be done by people who have a historical background. There are not that many carpenters who even know how to put a base on the big columns on the front." 
The house's very authenticity led the New York company of Brunschwig & Fils in the 1980's to copy the 1812 French wallpaper in the dining room. In exchange for the copyright on a design the company called Talavera, it gave the Philip family enough wallpaper to do the dining room. (Beige Talavera wallpaper is still available from Brunschwig for $47 a roll.) Much more remains to be done for Talavera, including rewiring, replastering and new plumbing.
Friends have pitched in to help. In May of last year, at the family's annual apple blossom picnic, one friend presented the family with a copy of the Gilbert Stuart portrait, to hang in the dining room, right where the original once hung.
The family is struggling to decide what to do when Mrs. Philip is unable to run the farm anymore. In the event of her death, "then, we are at a critical juncture," Ms. Philip said. The agreement among the siblings could be broken, the land could be sold.
Still, this year there was a good apple harvest, she said. "The economics are definitely year by year. But we've learned we can get through a really hard time," she said, "and we're still here."

HEADLINE: Afghan Art Dispersed by The Winds Of War; 
A Nation Loses Its Heritage To Smugglers and Dealers

BYLINE:  By CELESTINE BOHLEN 

 BODY:
On a recent visit to a London antique dealer, David Kamansky, director of the Pacific Asia Museum in Pasadena, Calif., was presented with a shoe box. Inside, covered with flimsy paper, were fragments of a 2,000-year-old ivory casket, decorated with intricate Indian carvings, unmistakably part of the famous Begram collection that once belonged to the Kabul Museum in Afghanistan.
 "For someone like me, it was like being handed the 'Mona Lisa' in bits," Mr. Kamansky said. "Here were some of the great treasures of mankind in a shoe box, wrapped in toilet paper." 
 Knowing that trading art from a museum collection is illegal under United States law and a host of international treaties, Mr. Kamansky refused the piece, which was priced at several hundred thousand dollars. That was the last he saw of the Begram ivories. "Where they are now, I don't know," he said. "I've heard they were in New York somewhere for sale, but I have no idea." 
Long before the latest war began, the fabulous art treasures of Afghanistan -- deposited there by overlapping Greek, Buddhist and Islamic civilizations -- were presumed gone, destroyed by 20 years of war, economic desperation and, most recently, by the Taliban's fundamentalist brand of Islam.
And yet during the last decade, much of the art has made its way out of Afghanistan to North America, Western Europe and, in particular, Japan. These places are the end of the road for smuggling pieces that are plundered by the warring factions in Afghanistan, pass into Pakistan or the former Soviet lands to the north, and make their way onto the international art market. 
The Taliban's war on "false idols," which culminated in March in the dramatic destruction of two giant Buddhas at Bamiyan, has added urgency to the trade in antiquities from Afghanistan, heightening demand and prices. Alarmed by the Taliban's actions, Unesco, an important international arbiter on cultural property, relaxed, in the case of Afghanistan, a 30-year policy that discouraged the unsanctioned export of cultural patrimony. The move, however, was intended to safeguard the objects for eventual return, not drive them into the private market.
Edward Wilkinson, an assistant vice president at Sotheby's and an expert in Indian and South Asian art, said that prices for Gandharan sculptures -- representing one of the great civilizations of ancient Afghanistan -- have increased by an average of 30 percent during the last year.
Since March, Mr. Wilkinson said, he has fielded weekly offers, mostly from Pakistan and India, to sell objects from Afghanistan. His standard reply, he said, has been to suggest that the dealers call a museum. "These are not things we can offer for sale," he said he has told callers. "Period." 
"After the destruction of the Bamiyan Buddhas, dealers tried to make a killing," said Nancy Hatch Dupree, a resident of Peshawar, Pakistan, and vice chairwoman of the Society for the Preservation of Afghanistan's Cultural Heritage. "I received offers of 300 statues 'from Bamiyan' for a mere $1.5 million." In an e-mail from Peshawar, Ms. Dupree added that the dealers had had the pieces for years but had been unable to sell them.
Artworks from the region, including ones with uncertain provenance, do make it onto the market. Some come into the United States and Europe via Japan, where collectors and museums have been willing and unquestioning buyers of Buddhist art from Afghanistan. 
A major difficulty in determining the provenance of a piece is that ancient civilizations straddled modern-day borders. One such civilization is the Buddhist Gandharan Empire, from the first century A.D. to the fifth, which stretched into the northern Pakistan of today. Last month, Christie's in New York sold a 38-inch-tall Gandharan figure for $374,000; it had been in a Japanese collection since 1990 according to Christie's. 
"Luckily a lot of Gandharan art has come out to Japan in the last two decades," said Hugo Weihe, an international specialist for Indian and South Asian art for Christie's in New York. "For the Japanese this is very important because it was through the Silk Road that Buddhism came to Japan." He added that the figure sold last month was believed to be from Pakistan.
At the International Asian Art Fair in March in New York, the John Eskenazi gallery of London offered a Gandharan head of Bacchus that was identified as coming from northeast Pakistan but was remarkably similar to stucco heads found in Afghanistan, said Dr. Vishakha N. Desai, director of the Asia Society's museum in New York.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art expressed interest in buying the head, said Kate Cook, a director at John Eskenazi, but the piece eventually went to a private collector.
Only John Eskenazi, the gallery's owner, could answer questions about the provenance of the piece, and he was traveling in Italy, Ms. Cook said.
The smuggling of Afghan antiquities, which experts say has accompanied the trade in weapons and drugs, involves virtually all sides in Afghanistan's complicated and shifting civil wars. Experts say that the illicit trade also has involved high-ranking members of the previous government in Pakistan. 
Robert Puffer, an American who lived in Islamabad, Pakistan's capital, and who by his own admission acted as a go-between for antiquities dealers, said that smugglers routinely did business with Nasirullah Babar, who served as interior minister in the former government of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto.
During the 1990's, Mr. Babar made no effort to hide his rich collection of Afghan art, and even showed it off in 1997 to a visiting correspondent from The New York Times. But Mr. Babar insisted that he was holding the precious ivories, gold coins and Hellenistic heads for safekeeping.
During the Bhutto era, Mr. Puffer said, antiquities from Afghanistan "flowed through Pakistan like a river." Mr. Puffer claimed he once saw a precious bronze bowl from the Kabul Museum holding fruit in one dealer's house, and in another, an animal figure whose legs and antlers had been broken off by rough handling.
According to more recent reports, the antiquities trade has slowed somewhat under Gen. Pervez Musharraf, whose presidency has instituted stricter controls at Pakistan's borders.
The destruction of Afghanistan's cultural heritage is directly linked to the country's wars. Since the 1979 Soviet invasion, hundreds of important archaeological sites have been dug up, some by bulldozers and tanks. The Kabul Museum was hit by a rocket in 1993, and since then it has been overrun by warring clans of mujahedeen. Recent visitors said all that was left of what was once an exquisite collection of centuries of Central Asian culture was a simple one-room exhibition of Islamic art.
One unsolved mystery is the fate of a collection of more than 20,000 gold objects, known as the Hoard of Bactrian Gold, which was excavated by a joint Soviet-Afghan team on the eve of the 1979 Soviet invasion. The gold, which had been found in five tombs at Tillya Tepe, an archaeological site in northern Afghanistan, was taken to Kabul and later stored in a vault at the royal palace. Where it is now, no one seems to know. 
The trade in Afghan art has raised perplexing questions about how best to care for art that has been put under a death sentence in its homeland. "I think in the 21st century, relationships between the world community and national heritage have to be rethought," said Dr. Desai of the Asia Society. "Before Bamiyan, the argument was toward national heritage. Now I am feeling that some new solutions have to be found."
When Unesco relaxed its policy protecting national cultures in their country of origin, the chief beneficiary was the Afghanistan Museum, a small institution in Switzerland. It paradoxically was created by the Taliban government and leaders of its opposition, the Northern Alliance, who in the late 1990's sought a safe haven for Afghanistan's cultural heritage. Supported by donations and a $10,000 Unesco grant, this museum in Bubendorf, a village outside Basel, has been holding the objects for safekeeping and has seen its collection grow from several hundred items to more than 2,000.
Most are historical or ethnographic objects, but Paul Bucherer, a Swiss architect who is the director of the museum, said that during the last six months he had received several donations of items that had once been in the Kabul Museum.
Among the donations were Gandharan relief carvings with Buddhist images, which arrived by mail from Hong Kong; a gravestone from Ghazni; and some fragments of Begram ivories, which were donated by a Western European dealer. All these, Mr. Bucherer said, were being kept in a bank vault, because the museum lacked an adequate security system. The original idea behind the museum, as envisaged by its Afghan sponsors, was to create a place where national treasures could be held until Afghanistan returned to some form of normal life.
Everything has been donated; nothing is bought, Mr. Bucherer said. "We are behaving like a basket," he said. "Everybody who is ready to give can put what they have in the basket, but we are not climbing up a ladder to get the apples out of the tree."
Much art from Afghanistan is being left in limbo -- too hot for the international markets and too valuable to be donated to the museum in Bubendorf. Some works are finding their way back into Pakistan.
Mr. Kamansky, at the Pacific Asia Museum, says he has tried to convince collectors and museums to buy objects on the black market and hold them for a future Afghanistan. 
That approach has worked in some cases. Ms. Dupree says a museum in Tokyo that acquired a marble foot, identified as being from Ai Khanum, a Hellenistic city built by Alexander the Great in what is now Afghanistan, has exhibited it with the pledge to eventually return it to Afghanistan.
But most museums are not willing to acquire artworks on a temporary basis, Mr. Kamansky said. Yet, like others, he believes antiquities belong somewhere other than in a shoe box. "If the museums buy, we were arguing that they should recognize that they belong in a future Afghanistan," he said of the region's art objects. "Nobody wants to hand them back to the Taliban."
In 1989, Afghan officials challenged the Metropolitan Museum of Art, saying that a 1,700-year-old Gandharan head of a Buddha, best known for its garnet eyes, which the museum had acquired in 1985, had been looted from a storeroom of a Jalalabad museum.
The Met argues that the piece is better off in New York. "If it was in the storeroom, then the storeroom was destroyed in the fighting," said Harold Holzer, the museum's vice president for communications. "So in a way, the Met has fulfilled its role of safeguarding treasures of world culture." Besides, Mr. Holzer added, referring to the absence of a credible government in Kabul, "there is no active claim for the piece."

HEADLINE: Anxiety Infuses November Art Sales 

BYLINE:  By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
Christie's offices in Europe began getting panicked telephone calls two weeks ago from alarmed collectors who had received envelopes from Christie's in New York containing a mysterious white powder. A woman from Lausanne, Switzerland, was so concerned she called the police.
 It turned out that the substance was crushed hard candy attached to a promotional announcement of Christie's contemporary art sale. The mailer featured one of the star works, an installation piece by the Cuban-born artist Felix Gonzalez-Torres composed of 325 pounds of candy, the pieces individually wrapped in blue cellophane. 
 The candy had been pulverized going through the mail sorters in Europe. 
The incident was no laughing matter for Christie's amid an already jittery art market worried about the impact of the events of Sept. 11 and a shaky economy on the multimillion-dollar November sales that get under way in New York on Monday night.
Complicating matters, Thursday will bring the opening of the trial of A. Alfred Taubman, Sotheby's former chairman, who was indicted last year on charges that he fixed commission fees to thousands of customers with his counterpart at Christie's. Anxiety levels at Sotheby's, Christie's and Phillips de Pury & Luxembourg are running high. To draw business, all three auction houses have invested millions in guarantees to sellers, but Phillips has the most at stake, because it has invested the most money.
Will the trial and negative publicity surrounding past auction house practices have an effect on business? Will the European collectors who have dominated art buying over the last six months feel like traveling to New York for the sales? And perhaps the question most frequently asked, will people feel like buying art?
"It's impossible to predict the market," said Simon de Pury, chairman of Phillips. "It's like focusing the lens of a camera. At first the image is blurry. But the closer the sales get, the sharper things come into focus. On one hand they're just around the corner. On the other so much can happen before then. Auctions are all about the mood of the moment."
Experts have been comparing these sales to auctions during other troubled times, particularly the early 1990's during the Persian Gulf war, when the real estate market nose-dived and the art world froze.
Bargain hunting will be rife this season, most experts say. Dealers openly admit they hope to cash in on wholesale prices; passionate collectors say they will be on the lookout for undervalued material. To encourage buying this season the auction houses, in most cases, have kept estimates as low as the sellers will allow.
This season features several unusual 20th-century art collections. Christie's may have the surest winner among them on Tuesday, when it offers $40 million worth of art from the estate of Rene Gaffe, a Belgian perfume mogul and newspaper owner. In the 20's and 30's Gaffe bought newly finished works from masters like Picasso, Leger and Miro. Proceeds will go to charity, and everything is being sold without reserves, the secret minimum price generally agreed upon by the seller and the auction house. Most of this high-quality collection has not been seen publicly for 70 to 80 years. 
Gaffe died in 1968, leaving his collection to his wife, Jeanne. Before she died in October, she designated Unicef as the beneficiary. Among the collection's stars is Leger's "Motor" (1918). A post-Cubist painting completed after Leger's return from World War I, it is based on the structure of an engine that drives a propeller of an airplane or ship. It is estimated to sell for $4 million to $6 million.
The collection also features several rare Picassos. A 1908 gouache, "Nude in a Forest," which is expected to sell for $4 million to $6 million, depicts a nymph with her legs spread, drawn in massive, flattened planes. It was once owned by Gertrude Stein and relates closely to Picasso's "Demoiselles d'Avignon." A Picasso sculpture, "Head of a Woman (Fernande)" is one of the great examples of modernist sculpture. The original cast was produced in 1909, and this bronze version is thought to have been made shortly thereafter.
Sculpture has been exceptionally popular for the last several seasons because it is one area of the market that is still undervalued and because buyers have begun to broaden the kinds of art they purchase. This month there will be more sculptures than have been for sale in recent memory. At Phillips, sculpture accounts for half of the 72 works of 20th-century art from the collection of Nathan and Marion Smooke of Los Angeles.
The Smooke collection, which is being auctioned on Monday, was bitterly fought over by the three auction houses. Phillips won, dipping into the deep pockets of its parent company, LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, to offer the Smooke heirs a guarantee, an undisclosed amount promised to a seller regardless of the outcome of the sale. At the time it was announced that the collection would go to Phillips, people close to the negotiations said the auction house had given the Smooke heirs a $185 million guarantee, far more than the $80 million to $100 million estimate experts at Phillips have now put on the collection. 
During the final negotiations, about $15 million worth of the art -- small but rare works by Matisse, Picasso, Ernst and Derain -- were removed from the auction. When the auction catalog came out, rumors began circulating that most of this art had been bought by Bernard Arnault, the chairman of LVMH, for the museum he is building in Paris. 
"It's totally untrue," Mr. de Pury said. "All the works from the collection that are not in the sale have been retained by the family." 
Mr. Smooke, who died in 1991, was the president of Wellman Properties, an industrial real estate concern and a founding board member of the Los Angeles County Museum, where the collection was shown in 1987. The Smookes formed their collection over 25 years, buying art from dealers like John and Paul Herring in New York and the Lefevre Gallery in London as well at auction. 
Known as collectors who were always looking for a bargain, the Smookes often bought works that had failed to sell at an auction, getting the pieces at lower prices. For sale are Picassos from different periods in his career, the work of several major Fauvre artists like Vlaminck, and a number of German Expressionist paintings. 
Among the rarest is a 1916 Modigliani portrait, "Almaisa," depicting one of his favorite models, with large almond-shaped eyes and an elongated nose that recall the facial distortions of an African mask. It is estimated to sell for $6 million to $8 million. There is also a Modigliani sandstone sculpture of a woman's head, one of only 25 sculptures he made, which is expected to fetch $2 million to $3 million. A landscape by Egon Schiele, "Suburban House With Washing," from 1917, is estimated at $8 million to $12 million.
For collectors interested in German art there are several collections spanning the entire 20th century. Early masters by Emil Nolde, Max Liebermann and Karl Schmidt-Rottluff are part of a collection Phillips is selling on Monday. 
These works come from the holdings of Diethelm Hoener, a German investment banker who died this year. One painting in particular comes with an unusual history. Schmidt-Rottluff's "Reader" (1911) was saved from the Nazis in 1937 by a Berlin collector named J. A. Benkert. When Phillips experts removed the painting from its frame, they found the following inscription: "Former possession: Museum Erfurt. Saved from burning in the Kopenicker Street. Exchanged for my Courbet. Proprietor: J. A. Benkert, Berlin, Charlottenburg, Reichs 99."
The painting was held by the Nazis in a depot in Berlin to be burned when Benkert, realizing its importance, traded it for a Courbet in his collection. "It's only one of four portraits of that early period by the artist that survived," said David Breuer-Weil, the international specialist at Phillips. 
More contemporary German art is also up for sale this month. "Germany is one of the strongest collecting countries," said Brett Gorvy, international head of postwar art at Christie's, "and many of these collectors are getting to an age where they want to refine their collections. Other sellers have seen prices rising higher even than those in 1989 during the boom market."
Mr. Gorvy was referring to a $12.5 million collection Christie's is selling on Nov. 13 as part of its postwar sale. This one, spanning 1945 to the present, features contemporary stars like Sigmar Polke, Georg Baselitz and Anselm Kiefer. The collection is being sold by Hans Grothe, a 70-year-old German real estate developer who began collecting in the early 1970's and who is selling some of his 400-work collection in order to develop other art projects. Among the highlights of the collection is "The Shepherd," a Baselitz painting from his hero series. It is estimated to bring $1 million to $1.5 million. 
Like Phillips, Christie's had to give Mr. Grothe a guarantee in order to get the collection. Experts close to the auction house say it is $10 million, although no one at Christie's would comment. 
Sotheby's has also opened its pockets. On Nov. 14 it will sell 31 works from the collection of Douglas S. Cramer, the television and theater producer. Mr. Cramer, who has been buying art for 40 years and has come to know many of the most important American artists. This sale, too, is guaranteed. For sale will be a selection of works by Jasper Johns, Roy Lichtenstein, Ellsworth Kelly and Brice Marden. 
Sotheby's has used the artists even more than the art to promote this collection. The catalog's cover, for instance, is unusual because it features not a single artwork but rather photographs of the artists.

COMPANY: CHRISTIE'S INTERNATIONAL PLC (92%)

HEADLINE: U.S. Imposes a Second Duty On Canadian Lumber Imports 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Oct. 31 

 BODY:
The Commerce Department accused Canadian lumber producers of unfair trade practices today and imposed a double-digit duty on their exports to the United States. 
 The department said today that it would impose antidumping duties averaging 12.6 percent on imports of softwood lumber, flooring and siding from six Canadian producers. The duties, which range from 5.9 percent to 19.2 percent, are the second imposed in the last three months. 
 A countervailing duty of 19.3 percent was imposed on Aug. 17. Canadian lumber, used mainly in housing, has about a third of the American market. Imports last year were valued at $6.38 billion, the Commerce Department said.
The latest duty is a response to complaints by American producers that Canadian companies have flouted international trade rules by exporting lumber at prices below their production costs, a practice known as dumping.
The earlier countervailing duty, the Commerce Department said, was intended to offset the benefits of subsidies to Canadian sawmills, such as low fees for harvesting trees in government-owned forests.
Both duties are preliminary, with final determinations expected next March after further discussions with the affected parties. 
American homebuilders and other lumber users criticized the antidumping duty, saying it raised the cost of material at a time of weakening demand. Michael Carliner, chief economist at the National Association of Home Builders in Washington, said today that the pain that it caused the customer was greater than the benefit to producers in the United States.
The Canfor Corporation, a leading softwood lumber producer in Vancouver, British Columbia, has set aside 11.5 million Canadian dollars ($7.3 million) after taxes in the third quarter to cover its potential liability for countervailing duties. The chief executive of Canfor, David Emerson, said today that the company would be forced to mothballed a third of its sawmilling capacity by the end of the year.
Any assessment of the effect of the duties is complicated by the downturn in the housing sector and the weakening demand for lumber. Prices, as measured by the framing lumber composite price compiled by Random Lengths, a trade publication based in Eugene, Ore., slipped to $275 for a thousand board feet last week, from a high of $402 in May.
Burrle Elmore, editor of Random Lengths, said although the duties have raised costs for Canadian mills, everyone is feeling the pain because of the soft market for lumber. 
Failing a negotiated settlement, the Canadian producers have said they would appeal the Commerce Department decisions to the courts and invoke the dispute settlement provisions of the North American Free Trade agreement and the World Trade Organization. 
The six companies hit by the antidumping duty are Canfor, Abitibi-Consolidated, Tembec, West Fraser Timber, Slocan Forest Products and the Canadian unit of Weyerhaeuser.

HEADLINE: Argentine Leader in Talks to Avert Default on $132 Billion Debt 

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, Oct. 31 

 BODY:
President Fernando de la Rua held intensive negotiations today with opposition governors, national labor leaders and legislative leaders in an effort to find support for a new economic plan and debt restructuring to prevent a default on Argentina's $132 billion public debt.
 The stakes are high. Argentina's debt represents 25 percent of all emerging-market bonds. A financial meltdown here would almost certainly draw neighboring Brazil into a crisis and put severe financial pressure on countries as far away as South Africa and Turkey. 
 "We will not default and we will not devalue," Mr. de la Rua said after reports that the United States Treasury would not seek a new rescue package from the International Monetary Fund to avert what a growing consensus of Wall Street economists view as a likely default.
In recent days, the Argentine bond and stock markets have plummeted, and bank deposits have dropped as the government has delayed policy announcements and appeared to be adrift.
The "zero deficit" policy of cutting deficits by reducing government workers' salaries and pensions has failed to improve finances or bring down interest rates. Declines in tax receipts, consumer sales and manufacturing have quickened at alarming rates over the last two months.
The slowdown has put enormous pressure on local governments to pay teachers and other public workers, forcing Buenos Aires Province to begin printing scrip to meet its bills and other provinces to suspend vital services. 
Economy Minister Domingo Cavallo has assembled a package of policies to stimulate consumer spending, with subsidies for poor families and sales-tax breaks for consumers who buy with credit cards. But the government has delayed announcing the plans until it puts together a broad coalition to support the measures to assure the support of the opposition-controlled Congress. 
The powerful opposition governors of Buenos Aires, Cordoba and Santa Fe have withheld support until there is a settlement with Mr. de la Rua over more than $520 million in central government funds owed to the provinces. Behind closed doors, the governors and president discussed today formulas to distribute the funds in cash and bonds.
"The central government has to find a way to enable the provincial governments to conserve the social peace and comply with their obligations," Gov. Carlos Reutemann of Santa Fe, a leader of the Justicialist Party, said before meeting Mr. de la Rua.
Last weekend, senior officials acknowledged that they would seek to renegotiate payments with foreign and domestic creditors, emphasizing that any swap of bonds for financial instruments with lower interest rates would be strictly voluntary. But international credit agencies have characterized any such renegotiation as effectively a default. 
A renegotiation would probably need international guarantees for investors. Mr. Cavallo traveled to New York last week seeking support from the Bush administration and officials of several lending agencies, but appeared to fall short of his objectives.
The I.M.F. put together a $40 billion rescue package in December and a second package, of $8 billion, in fresh money and loan guarantees in August. A few months ago, Argentina negotiated a complex $30 billion bond swap to push interest payments into the future. But each maneuver won just a few weeks of stability, before a new crisis emerged.

HEADLINE: A Rare Leader Tries to Save Mexico's Fallen Party 

BYLINE:  By GINGER THOMPSON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 30 

 BODY:
Her party may be near collapse, but Beatriz Paredes refuses to indulge in eulogies. 
 In a year in which the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI, is out of power for the first time in seven decades, a recent memorial for the party's founder, Plutarco Elias Calles, felt like a funeral. Battle anthems sounded and wreaths of chrysanthemums adorned the podium. 
 Then Ms. Paredes, the president of Mexico's lower chamber of the Parliament, took the microphone. Blending respect for the PRI's past with reproach for its many misdeeds, this rare woman at the top of Mexican politics said with surprising clarity that if her party wanted to be a credible opposition force, it must embrace calls for change, and not feel threatened by them. 
"Circumstances oblige the party to change its methods," she said. "This is not only about winning elections and taking power. A real party, with ethics and vision, understands that power can bring moral legitimacy when it is exercised for the good of its citizens and for justice." 
Ms. Paredes, 48, has emerged as one of the prominent architects of the reformed PRI. Her politics forged in the trenches of Mexico's peasant movements, she is at once representative of the party's past and its potential future. 
The PRI lost last year's presidential elections when women and young people jettisoned the party in droves, and it has gone down to defeat in most of the state elections since.
The party has been close to collapse, with its factions fighting over everything from whether to give the party a new name to the rules for electing a new leader to replace Dulce Maria Sauri, the current party president. It was on her watch that the PRI lost the presidency, and she is widely associated with the party's past mistakes.
Some analysts have even pronounced the PRI dead, its coffin sealed by a long record of corruption, violent repression and impunity.
Ms. Paredes is trying to rally both the party faithful and potential new supporters, and she is seen as someone who could draw women and young people back to the PRI. 
Her support for feminist causes and her authority in political circles that are still dominated by men have helped raise her popularity among women. Young people see her political style -- marked by colorful Indian clothing that honors her ancestry, speeches infused with references to literature, and a deft sense of decorum -- as a powerful contrast to the conservative, pro-business forces led by President Vicente Fox.
But before the party can expand its base, Ms. Paredes says, it must first end its mourning over losing the presidency and set its sights on winning back Mexico's poor, a traditional power base.
In her current position, roughly equivalent to speaker of the House in the United States, Ms. Paredes is well-placed to try and rally the PRI. She has said that she wants Mexico's Congress to act as a check on the once all-consuming powers of the presidency, and sees the legislature as the perfect staging ground for her mission to reconnect the PRI to the people's causes.
She has drawn attention both for her speeches and her actions, notably unifying her party, which for years had battled the Zapatista uprising in Chiapas, behind an effort to allow the rebels to address Congress last spring.
Recently, she has hinted that she would not support President Fox's sweeping tax reforms, which include new taxes on food and medicine. President Fox has said the reforms are critical to battling recession. But with nearly half of Mexicans living in poverty, the reforms have been widely opposed -- even by legislators from Mr. Fox's own National Action Party. And PRI leaders see the current economic turmoil as a chance to gain support among the poor.
In an interview, Ms. Paredes called herself a center-leftist and a feminist. Some of her priorities include equal rights for Mexico's Indian minorities, higher wages for unskilled workers, financial support for the nation's principal public university and programs to help lift poor farmers out of poverty, malnutrition and illiteracy.
"I believe more in the militants than the elite of the PRI," she said. 
In contrast to Mr. Fox, who is a former marketing executive who once ran Coca-Cola's Mexican operations and a Roman Catholic who puts his faith on display, Ms. Paredes embraces the workers' and peasants' causes on which her party was founded, and staunchly defends her party's traditional insistence on separating church and state. 
She is not, however, an automatic opponent of the president. Since Sept. 11, she has broken with PRI leaders who denounced Mr. Fox for supporting America's war with Afghanistan. A foreign policy adviser to Ms. Paredes, Maria Emilia Farias, said she "understands Mexico's role has to be one of solidarity in the fight against terrorism."
In November, the PRI will hold its first national convention since its defeat in July 2000. Some 11,700 delegates from across the country are to vote on numerous reforms, including rules for electing a new party president. Convention organizers have said they hope half the delegates will be women and 30 percent under 30.
Jose Antonio Crespo, a political analyst, said Ms. Paredes could mend relations between traditional party leaders, known in Mexico as dinosaurs, and Ivy League-educated technocrats, accused of tearing the party away from the poor.
Her long history in the party has won respect from traditional sectors. And in recent years, she has supported the aspirations of technocrats in the PRI, including its defeated presidential candidate, Francisco Labastida.
But perhaps the main reason for Ms. Paredes's popularity in her party is her loyalty to it.
"We have no reason to denigrate ourselves," she said at the memorial ceremony, stirring the crowd to ovation. "We have been builders of this nation."
In the newspaper Reforma, the columnist Guadalupe Loaeza suggested Ms. Paredes would make a "splendid candidate" for the presidency of the PRI.
"Beatriz is not afraid of anything or anyone," Ms. Loaeza wrote. "Her hand never shakes. She always speaks her mind. And she never beats around the bush."
Ms. Paredes has been speaking her mind since she was in high school, when she interrupted her acceptance of a national oratory award to complain about overcrowded classrooms to President Luis Echeverria. It was a moment that not only earned the high school a new classroom, but also set Ms. Paredes on a career path that even she described as meteoric.
She was a legislator in her home state, Tlaxcala, at 21, a member of Congress at 27 and the second woman to serve as a governor in Mexico at 33. From there, she served in several high-level posts, including deputy interior secretary and ambassador to Cuba.
She is the granddaughter of peasant farmers who spoke an Indian language rather than Spanish. Her mother, who came from Mexico City, taught Ms. Paredes to love music and literature. A graduate in sociology from the National Autonomous University of Mexico, Ms. Paredes plays guitar and infuses her public speeches with lines from the poetry of Octavio Paz.
Ms. Paredes is not married, has no children and at times expresses flashes of vulnerability: she is careful about how she is photographed and about saying anything about her private life. In an interview with Mexican journalists, she said that women "are still judged harder on personal issues." 
Some have expressed concern that Ms. Paredes retains bad political habits learned in the years of the PRI's monolithic control of Mexico. She served as secretary general of the National Campesino Confederation, once a part of the PRI political machine more interested in keeping poor farmers under control than in helping them prosper. At times, Ms. Paredes seems so preoccupied with political protocol that she appears rigid and archaic.
"In political circles, she is known as a very capable woman, who understands how to exercise authority," said Raul Jimenez Guillen, a political expert at the Autonomous University of Tlaxcala, recalling her time as governor, "but who can also be authoritarian."
She famously admonished legislators who interrupted Mr. Fox's first State of the Union address and defended the legitimacy of his presidency. "For me, it was important to transmit to my colleagues the dignity of being a legislator," she said, "and to convey to the Mexican people that I understand that they want us to change."

HEADLINE: U.N. Acting to Keep Somalia From Becoming a Terrorist Haven 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 31 

 BODY:
The United Nations, fearful Somalia could deteriorate into a terrorist haven, scrambled today to find ways to help restore peace and security to the deeply splintered northeast African nation.
 A formal statement approved by the Security Council asked Secretary General Kofi Annan to come up with ideas on how the United Nations could help demobilize Somalia's sparring militias and train the police to firm the grip of the transitional national government on the capital, Mogadishu. 
 The council also asked Mr. Annan to carry out an in-depth assessment of the security situation in the hope of clearing the way for the establishment of a political peace-building mission in Somalia. 
To the consternation of many of Somalia's neighbors, Mr. Annan has for the past year declined to set up a mission, concluding from security assessments conducted from nearby Nairobi, Kenya, that the government could not ensure the safety of United Nations staff members.
The object of a failed joint United Nations and United States peacekeeping mission between 1993 and 1995, Somalia has had a transitional government in place since August 2000.
But the government controls only sections of Mogadishu, with most of the country still dominated by warlords and clans, who have been fighting each other since ousting President Muhammad Siad Barre in 1991.
Diplomats speculate that Somalia's lawlessness makes it a potential hide-out for Osama bin Laden, the top suspect in the Sept. 11 terror attacks against the United States, should American bombing raids make it impossible for him and his backers to stay in Afghanistan.
Earlier this month, Ali Khalif Galaid, Somalia's prime minister, came to United Nations headquarters to urge the organization to help put his country together again and help fight terrorism in an effort to prevent Somalia from becoming a haven for clandestine networks.
But on Monday, Somalia's Parliament passed a vote of no confidence in the transitional national government, giving President Abdiqassim Salad Hassan 30 days to nominate a new prime minister.
Members of Parliament said they were unhappy over the government's failure to bring security to the country and bring down rampant inflation after a year in office.
In its statement approved today, the Security Council urged world governments to scrupulously comply with a United Nations embargo on arms sales to Somalia and to help it combat international terrorism.
The statement also urged neighboring countries to help Somalia rebuild its shattered governmental institutions while keeping out of its internal affairs.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
Rich nations have been too insensitive to poverty for too long; the situation can no longer be ignored.

BYLINE:  By Jeff Madrick; Jeff Madrick is the editor of Challenge Magazine and a collection of essays, "Unconventional Wisdom: Alternative Perspectives on the New Economy." He teaches at Cooper Union and the New School. E-mail: challenge@mesharpe.com.

 BODY:
FEW would dispute that terrorism and violent religious fundamentalism, however complex their causes, grow best in the soil of poverty. The Sept. 11 attacks raise this issue to a new level of importance. More than any other single event, the attacks show how interconnected the world truly is. High on the new agenda has to be attention to the world's poor.
 But in recent years, a sense of futility has developed. Despite glowing optimism 20 years ago, the rich nations' record in raising the developing world to a minimal level of material well-being has been nothing short of disaster. In 1983, the World Bank predicted that developing nations' average gross domestic product would grow 3.3 percent a year over 15 years. In fact, it barely grew at all. 
 The extent of poverty remains shocking. There has been a modest decline in the portion of those who are poor, but in absolute numbers, they have risen sharply. About a third of the world lives on the equivalent of about $2 a day. In 1820, the richest country had only three times as much income per person as the poorest; today, the richest nation has 30 times the income.
Rich nations are shamefully stingy about aiding the poor, but none more so than the United States. In 1999, the World Bank reported that the United States gave 0.1 percent of its economic output for development, or $9.1 billion, the lowest proportion among the 30 or so wealthiest nations. Japan gave more than $15 billion -- still skimpy, but 0.35 percent of its output. Moreover, America stipulates that about two-thirds of the $9 billion must be spent on American products.
Some critics say that money is not the issue, that the record of poor nations is an inevitable result of debilitating cultural attitudes. Time and again, such cultural stereotypes have been defied. Malaysia, a Muslim nation, is a great economic success. Catholic France has a higher standard of living than Anglican England, with its celebrated Protestant work ethic. China has grown rapidly, but it essentially eschews private property.
Far more likely, development policies in the last few decades have repeatedly been wrongheaded. In a recent controversial book, "The Elusive Quest for Growth" (MIT Press), William Easterly, a World Bank economist, traces the history of these failures.
To take just one of Mr. Easterly's many examples, capital investment in plant and equipment was once thought to be the main source of growth for developing economies. Both Nigeria and Hong Kong dutifully raised their investment in capital stock per worker by 250 percent from 1960 to 1985. But Nigeria's output per worker, or productivity, rose only 12 percent, while Hong Kong's soared 328 percent. Clearly, something else was also driving growth.
About that something else, however, economists have long been divided. In the early 1980's, the World Bank insisted the failures had to do with inflationary and protectionist policies. They insisted that countries to which it lent adopt reforms -- "neo-liberal" policies like restrained government spending to control inflation, free trade to foster competition and deregulation to allow free markets to allocate resources.
The average record of success was poor. Mr. Easterly says the reason is largely that the bank lent money regardless of whether the reforms were made. Nations that adopted reforms, he maintains, did fairly well.
But there is an alternative body of literature that asserts that neo-liberal policies are at best only part of the answer. A new book, "The Rise of 'the Rest' " (Oxford University Press), by Alice H. Amsden, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, asserts that the recent success of many developing countries required an extensive role for government in supporting business.
Similarly, neo-liberal policies have done damage. Lance Taylor, a professor at New School University, has edited a new volume of case studies, "External Liberalization, Economic Performance, and Social Policy" (Oxford University Press), which says that neo-liberal policies have not merely had mixed results but almost invariably led to more income inequality.
Indeed, Argentina was a textbook example of a country that adopted neo-liberal policies a decade or so ago. For a while, they seemed to work, but now the country is reeling from recession and is in danger of defaulting on its international debt.
Perhaps the best-known critic of overreliance on market policies to stimulate economic growth has been Joseph E. Stiglitz, the former chief economist of the World Bank and one of three winners of this year's Nobel in economic science. In a series of speeches at the World Bank, many of which are collected in a new volume, "The Rebel Within" (Anthem WorldEconomics), Mr. Stiglitz argues that a broad range of factors affect economic growth, including education and the quality of financial institutions, which often require financing and regulation by government.
What is important, however, is that even though all these critics now acknowledge that economic development is harder than many once thought it was, none think it is futile. Rather, two important lessons have been learned in the last two decades. Sound economic development cannot depend solely on markets or solely on government. Mr. Easterly agrees. Both effective market incentives and social programs supporting health, education, infrastructure and poverty reduction are usually required.
Second, each country is different. There is no fixed recipe of ingredients that will assure growth. In some, an investment in education is a priority, in others investment in health or transportation infrastructure, in still others a reduction in taxes or government policies to promote export industries will matter most at a given moment.
The real danger is not a lack of good ideas, but a refusal to try them. Here there are two important limitations. First, although both the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund have tempered their advocacy of neo-liberal policies, they are still inclined to demand a single set of reforms from most nations. This lock on policy must be broken.
And, second, finance. Those who think that money for development cannot be spent wisely, says Mr. Easterly, merely lack imagination -- tragically so, I would add.
It's time for the rich world to cough up some serious money for the poor.

HEADLINE: Tokyo Journal; 
The Minister's Misfortune: Not-So-Civil Servants

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 31 

 BODY:
After the headaches of being Japan's foreign minister, Makiko Tanaka was looking forward to a perk: attending the annual fall garden party held at a palace here on Thursday by Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko. 
 Then Ms. Tanaka, the first woman to run the ministry, discovered that her personnel director had failed to put aside tickets to the event for her and her husband, a congressman. 
 Furious, Ms. Tanaka locked herself in an office of the offending bureaucrat, Akitaka Saiki, for 90 minutes Monday night and tried to badger one of his secretaries into typing her boss's letter of transfer. 
After the secretary wailed, "I do not have the authority to do that," a reporter listening outside the door heard the minister rail: "Idiot! Idiot! Type now what I order! Fool!"
Once again, Japanese were front-row spectators in one of their more entertaining real-life dramas: a political minister wrestling with mandarin bureaucrats. 
The fiery Ms. Tanaka managed to alienate much of the Foreign Ministry staff shortly after taking over in April. After snubbing visiting envoys of major powers, the neophyte minister then committed the truly capital crime of interfering with ambassadorial appointments. The bureaucrats then plotted slow political death by 1,000 leaks. 
Snippets of the minister's confidential conversations appeared in front-page newspaper articles. Skipped meetings and perceived slights were similarly fed to reporters by ministry insiders.
After the Sept. 11 attacks on New York and Washington, the Japanese press criticized her for talking publicly about United States State Department security measures, a minor slip that did not seem to bother American diplomats here. 
Although Mrs. Tanaka is a happily married 57-year-old, newspapers here have run rumors, some attributed to Foreign Ministry "sources," suggesting her amorous interest in various Western foreign ministers. Mysteriously, a photo of Mrs. Tanaka and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell emerged last summer from a foreign ministers' skit in Hanoi that was closed to the press.
"This series of so-called blunders have been prepared by groups opposed to her," said one supporter, Noriko Kimoto, a television commentator. 
As the bureaucratic intrigue continues, Ms. Tanaka has complained about being reduced to a figurehead, getting information late and going into meetings poorly briefed or missing meetings entirely. 
In the Parliament, enemies within her Liberal Democratic Party forced her to let a career diplomat replace her at meetings of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation group in Shanghai. Similar maneuvers are being prepared to keep her from going to New York for a United Nations general debate session.
"I think it is a problem that the vice minister has told me I should not go to these meetings," Ms. Tanaka complained, baring to reporters a deep split with one of her top civil servants, Vice Foreign Minister Yoshiiji Nogami. Ikuo Kabashima, a political science professor at Tokyo University, said, "She is stressed and frustrated."
In the latest highly public spat, the incident on Monday, Ms. Tanaka told reporters, "The personnel division director is making mischief."
After the secretary refused to follow her orders to type a transfer document, Ms. Tanaka appealed to her ministry's top two bureaucrats at a news conference on Tuesday, adding the word "please." Once again, the public saw that bureaucratic mandarins rule supreme over their nominal superior, an elected congresswoman.
Later that day, she told reporters that she had been trying to get the personnel director switched to another job for 10 weeks.
Tonight, the Foreign Mnistry spokesman, Norio Hattori, expressed skepticism that the transfer would go through. Briefing reporters about his nominal boss, he said, "The document she prepared is not according to the standard format."
With Ms. Tanaka's powerlessness in her ministry as clear as the fall weather in Tokyo, the prime minister, Junichiro Koizumi, stepped in today, saying of both sides in this highly public battle, "I feel that one is as bad as the other."
"This kind of conflict should be settled as soon as possible," continued Mr. Koizumi, who partly owes his election last spring to Ms. Tanaka's supporters. The minister and her bureaucrats "must create right away a framework in which the focus would be on diplomatic affairs."
Lost in the shuffle is the fact that little progress has been made by the Koizumi administration to improve Japan's chronically poor relations with neighboring countries that are still resentful of Japan, almost six decades after World War II. 
Japan's career diplomats may tout their smooth and harmonious ways, but Japan has no diplomatic relations with North Korea, and has yet to sign a World War II peace treaty with Russia. In September, Mr. Koizumi, leader of Asia's largest economy, was publicly snubbed in attempts to meet with leaders of China and South Korea, the second and third largest economies of Asia. The meetings took place only after Japan made repeated, and open, requests.
After watching six months of leaked memos, public outbursts and bureaucratic intrigue, Japanese public opinion of the first woman to be foreign minister still seems to split along gender lines.
"I don't like her, she is too noisy," Satoshi Yoshimura, 58, a self-employed man, said of Ms. Tanaka, whose father, Kakuei Tanaka, was prime minister in the early 1970's. "How can a woman living in that huge house with a pond filled with colorful carp share the feelings of wives with unemployed husbands? Ha ha. She was brought up like a princess. The problem is she still is a princess." 
Chieko Okuno, a 75-year-old who leads a physical education course for older homemakers, had another view. "I like her because she discloses what is happening behind the scenes at the Foreign Ministry," she said, referring toa series of financial scandals unearthed over the summer. "I like her because she speaks directly."

HEADLINE: Pushing Limits, Finding None; 
Bold Rising Star at Lockheed Is Point Man on Prize Contract

BYLINE:  By LAURA M. HOLSON 

DATELINE: FORT WORTH, Oct. 28 

 BODY:
To some of his colleagues at the Lockheed Martin Corporation, Charles Thomas Burbage seems to have come right out of the pages of "The Right Stuff," Tom Wolfe's homage to the test pilots who broke the sound barrier and took the United States into space.
 Mr. Burbage, after all, used to push Navy fighter jets to the limit just to see how much stress they could take as they landed on a swaying, sleet-encrusted aircraft carrier. And the tall and trim Mr. Burbage, 54, is still striking enough to turn heads as he confidently walked though the lobby of the Worthington Hotel here for an interview. 
 What really makes him a hero these days at Lockheed Martin, though, is his leading role in snaring the richest prize ever awarded by the Pentagon. With a $19 billion down payment to oversee the development of the next generation of combat fighter jets -- in a project expected to total more than $200 billion in the next four decades -- Mr. Burbage, director of Lockheed's Joint Strike Fighter program, has become one of the most important executives to watch among military suppliers today. 
And with good reason. The Pentagon has finally cast aside its failure four decades ago to develop a single plane to serve different roles for the military branches, and it is counting on Mr. Burbage and Lockheed to produce 3,000 or more cost-effective, workhorse fighters for the Navy, Marines and Air Force based on a common design.
"He is a rising star," said Vance Coffman, Lockheed's chief executive. "We wanted Tom's leadership."
Needed it may be more to the point. Only a year ago, Mr. Burbage -- a 21-year Lockheed veteran whose father was a career Navy pilot who survived the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor -- was asked to take over the four-year-old Joint Strike Fighter project for Lockheed.
"They asked me to go over to J.S.F. and make sure we won," Mr. Burbage said matter of factly over the clatter of breakfast dishes being washed in the kitchen of the Worthington's cafe.
Last year, as the deadline approached, Lockheed executives suspected that they had trumped their competitor, the Boeing Company, on the jet's design. But the overall management of the Lockheed project was foundering, a notion since reinforced in interviews with Boeing and Lockheed executives as well as Pentagon officials since the decision was announced on Friday.
Enter Mr. Burbage. A graduate of the Naval Academy in Annapolis, he not only served as a Navy officer for 10 years but also worked at Lockheed's corporate offices in Washington. There he made a considerable number of contacts among important lawmakers on Capitol Hill and at the Pentagon. And Mr. Burbage already got along well with procurement officials at the Air Force, including Darleen A. Druyun, its tough-minded chief of acquisition. He worked closely with her on Lockheed's F-22 fighter jet program in the mid-1990's.
Since starting the job, Mr. Burbage has spent barely two weeks in the tiny apartment he keeps in Fort Worth, where the joint strike fighter will be built.
"I'm either always in Washington or on international travel," Mr. Burbage said. "I'm just not here that much."
What distinguishes Mr. Burbage, though, from the typical fighter jock or military executive is a kind of "new economy" sensibility he brings to an industry defined by a molasses-like pace of change and an unyielding hierarchy that mirrors the military itself.
Mr. Burbage has taken to calling a trio of particularly bright executives on the Joint Strike Fighter team the wizards -- despite their eye rolling and shoulder shrugging.
"They haven't accepted me calling them the wizards yet," Mr. Burbage said with a laugh. "We told them we were going to put all their offices together and call it Oz. That's kind of foreign. It's foreign to this business. You don't know if you should talk about it, but that is the image you want to project."
On the evening of Oct. 16, 10 days before the Pentagon planned to announce the fighter contract winner, Mr. Burbage gathered from around the world more than 80 project leaders for Lockheed and its key partners, Northrop and BAE Systems. Before a two-day management retreat, he wanted his team to relax at a Mexican restaurant near Fort Worth's stockyards. But he also invited representatives from the Air Force, a break with tradition that sent shivers down the spines of some executives, he said, "who did not want to bare their souls in front of the customer."
After dinner, Mr. Burbage pulled out an oversize mock cover of Fast Company, a new-era management magazine favored mostly by young high-technology executives. Dated January 2005 and adorned with photographs of the three versions of the plane, the cover's main headline read, "The Joint Strike Fighter Program Takes Off." There were other headlines, too, including "How Did They Do It?" and "Stock Market: Defense Is In."
Mr. Burbage said he was trying to get the team leaders to consider the project's legacy and their role in it. What would such an article say, Mr. Burbage asked them. How would it be written? What did they want to be remembered for?
"His openness is refreshing in the defense industry," said Byron Callan, a Merrill Lynch aerospace analyst.
Born in San Diego in 1947, Mr. Burbage was the second of six children. He grew up there and in Virginia as his father moved to different stations. "All I wanted to do was to play football or fly airplanes," he said. "That's all I wanted to do."
At the Naval Academy, he did both. He met his wife, Ellen, then, too, and after graduating in 1969, he married her the next year. In 1971 he received a master's degree in aeronautical systems from the University of West Florida.
Mr. Burbage, who was nicknamed Boomer at the academy, specialized in testing the limits of Navy fighters. One test required stopping a jet in midflight, its underside caught on a thin wire, then slamming into the tarmac to see how much damage the plane could withstand. Tracing an "X" on his chest, Mr. Burbage showed exactly where the safety straps he wore had left bruises.
"It's fairly violent," he said. "If you're the co-pilot and you are not actually controlling the plane, it's a high-anxiety event."
He officially left the Navy in 1980, staying in the reserves for another 14 years. His three daughters "were getting to the point they didn't know who I was because I was gone so much," he said. Continuing the family tradition, one of his daughters attended the Naval Academy, too.
A friend suggested that he apply for a pilot's position at Lockheed's test center in Palmdale, Calif. But no flight jobs were available so Mr. Burbage instead joined the marketing and business development team in Burbank, a suburb of Los Angeles. Despite the demands of his job, he found time to earn an M.B.A. from the University of California at Los Angeles.
Almost from the start, Mr. Burbage had an aptitude for navigating political minefields, both at the Pentagon and closer to home. In 1988, Mr. Burbage said, he got his break when he was asked to move to Washington to reorganize Lockheed's offices there. The staff was rife with infighting and petty jealousies. No one welcomed the new boss, he said. So Mr. Burbage invited the feuding executives to a secluded country retreat in West Virginia for a weekend of arguments and bonding. Within a few weeks, morale improved.
He moved to Lockheed's Atlanta office in 1990, taking over the troubled F-22 fighter jet program in 1995. At that time, it was dangerously close to being canceled by the Air Force because of huge cost overruns. That is where Mr. Burbage honed his reputation as a persuasive negotiator.
"I don't want to say he's a fix-it guy," said Mr. Callan, of Merrill Lynch. "But Tom's kind of been through the disaster areas of Lockheed. It's nice to know how not to do things in order to understand how they should be done."
John J. Young Jr., assistant secretary of the Navy for research, development and acquisitions, remembers sparring with Mr. Burbage in the 1990's over the F-22's price tag when Mr. Young was an aide on the Senate Appropriations Committee. "He was able to articulate why the costs were what they were and how they planned to achieve savings," Mr. Young said. "Tom helped me gain a greater confidence they were getting it under control."
Lockheed was the clear favorite in the winner-take-all contest to build the joint strike fighter, but its program was plagued by the same problems the F-22 had faced: cost overruns and grumbling at the Pentagon that Lockheed was not listening to its concerns. So last November Frank J. Cappuccio, who was then heading the team for Lockheed, stepped aside. He continued to work on the company's overall proposal but made way for Mr. Burbage to manage the project.
"Frank brought a level of order and structure that maybe wasn't perfect, process-wise," Mr. Young said. "Tom added to that because he had a next-step vision, a next-step maturity that made the program have a more confident feel."
Mr. Burbage will not say how long he expects to lead the joint strike fighter team. But he is a logical candidate for a future appointment to a high-level position at the Pentagon or elsewhere in government, predicted Ted Samples, a longtime friend who works with Mr. Burbage at Lockheed. "He would like that," Mr. Samples said.

HEADLINE: OPEC President Says Cartel to Cut Output Starting on Jan. 1 

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 31 

 BODY:
Underscoring the growing resolve among the largest oil-producing nations to shore up declining prices, Chekib Khelil, the president of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries, said today that the group would reduce daily oil output starting on Jan. 1.
 Mr. Khelil, at the United States-Africa Business Summit here, confirmed comments by other OPEC oil ministers over the weekend and Monday that OPEC would move to decrease exports at its next meeting, on Nov. 14 in Vienna. Those ministers, however, declined to say when such a reduction would go into effect. 
 Mr. Khelil, who is also Algeria's oil minister, could not specify how great the reduction would be, but he left no doubt one was imminent. Most industry analysts expect OPEC, which produces about 35 percent of the world's oil, to pare back exports by 700,000 to a million barrels a day. The group has already pulled back production three times this year by a total of 3.5 million barrels a day, or about 13 percent.
"It will be the same haggle," Mr. Khelil said, when asked whether the decrease would be a million barrels. "We will want to decrease a little, others will want to decrease a lot. If there is a cut, it will go into effect 40 days or so after; so, Jan. 1."
Oil industry analysts said Mr. Khelil's estimate was credible, given that as president of OPEC he is in constant contact with all 10 voting members. Waiting until Jan. 1 would permit OPEC to monitor what Iraq will do in December, when the United Nations oil-for-food program undergoes periodic review. Typically, Iraq has halted its exports of 2.1 million barrels a day during such talks to press the United Nations, and if that were to happen again, OPEC would need to gauge how to respond.
After the Sept. 11 attacks sent the global economy into a tailspin, oil demand dwindled rapidly and prices plummeted. OPEC has so far refrained from cutting production despite the millions of dollars members have lost because of lower prices. But prices have stabilized at about $21 a barrel, and Mr. Khelil said OPEC was determined to nudge them up to $25 a barrel by reducing output and restraining the rampant overproduction among its members. OPEC countries have been pumping far more than their official quotas to take advantage of current prices, but recent data show that such cheating has been trimmed.
Some economists worry that oil at $25 a barrel may prolong the global downturn. But Mr. Khelil reiterated the conviction within OPEC that much lower prices for oil would not accelerate an economic recovery.
"I don't think $25, $20, $30 oil is damaging to the world economy," he said. "I don't think a reduction of oil prices by 10 percent will have the same effect as reducing taxes by 10 percent. I think President Bush is doing the right thing by putting money back into consumers' pockets."
It remains to be seen whether OPEC will succeed in bolstering prices. Besides the overproduction within its own ranks, major non-OPEC producers like Mexico, Russia and Angola have said they will not reduce exports to bolster prices, despite OPEC's entreaties. Mr. Khelil said he hoped they would come around once they realize that greater supplies of oil would drive prices down for everyone and ultimately diminish revenue. But when pressed, he conceded that OPEC had little control over the decisions of others.
"We can't go on trying to convince people to help out if they don't want to," Mr. Khelil said. "We have to make our own decision at some point."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
Wall Street is stunned and angered by the Treasury's action on long-term bonds.

BYLINE:  By Gretchen Morgenson 

 BODY:
WITH fears mounting that nine interest rate cuts in almost as many months may not be enough to rev up the United States economy, the Treasury Department added some high-test yesterday to the Federal Reserve's fuel mix. Unfortunately, Wall Street got run over in the process. 
 Treasury officials said that their decision to halt the issuance of 30-year bonds was intended to save the government money. But traders scoffed at that explanation, viewing the move as an almost desperate effort to push down long-term interest rates, which had remained stubbornly high, and prod both corporate and individual borrowers to spend again. 
 "Without a doubt the thing that the Fed really wants to do is get mortgage rates and corporate rates down," said Peter McTeague, government bond market strategist at Greenwich Capital Markets, a brokerage firm in Greenwich, Conn. "But mortgage rates weren't falling as much as people hoped because they are more driven by the long end of the yield curve. So they're trying every little trick in the basket. If the Fed funds rate isn't going to do it, let's see if we can do something else."
The predicament for the Fed has been that even as it slashed interest rates from 6.5 percent at the beginning of the year to 2.5 percent last month, longer-term borrowing costs for corporations and individuals had not fallen as hard. For example, yields on the 10-year note, the benchmark for many mortgage rates and corporate bond issues, began the year at 5.1 percent and fell only to 4.5 percent by the time the Fed lowered rates for the ninth time on Oct. 2. By last week, 10-year yields had actually risen to 4.64 percent.
Yields on the 30-year bond rose even as the Fed cut short-term rates. Starting the year at 5.45 percent, yields on the long bond hit 5.9 percent in May. 
In an interview yesterday, Peter Fisher, the Treasury's undersecretary for domestic finance, said that "today's decision is in no way an attempt to manage long-term interest rates. That is not what motivated us."
But there is no doubt that the sticky nature of longer-term rates has exasperated policy makers. This is especially the case with mortgage rates, since consumer spending has been the only prop supporting the economy in recent months. Keeping consumers feeling flush has, therefore, become a top priority. One way to do this is by lowering mortgage rates, encouraging people to refinance their home loans and put more money in their pockets. 
The case may have become even more compelling after the report on Tuesday of a plunge in consumer confidence and other recent reports that home buying has started to slip. While mortgage refinancing activity has soared since Sept. 11, the Mortgage Bankers Association's index of home buying activity has instead stumbled. Existing home sales dropped 5.2 percent in September from a year earlier and 11.7 percent from August. But the plunge yesterday in yields on government securities will bring mortgage rates down significantly and soon.
The Treasury's announcement stunned Wall Street firms. To be sure, the government had been reducing the amount of long-term bonds in the market by buying back issues periodically and not issuing new ones. But traders had come to believe that because the federal budget surpluses have all but vanished, the government would have to resume heavy borrowings to finance deficit spending. And the Treasury gave Wall Street none of the usual warning signs that come in the form of trial balloons floated before a policy shift as big as this one. 
When Treasury prices surged on the news of the bond's demise, most major brokerage firms were caught with significant losses. Investors rushed to buy soon-to-be extinct issues. Prices of long-term bonds soared, and their yields plunged, falling from 5.21 percent on Tuesday to 4.88 percent yesterday. It was the biggest single-day move since investors fled to the safety of government securities during the stock market crash of 1987. 
Traders who had sold long-term Treasuries short to hedge their holdings in corporate bonds and mortgage-backed securities got crushed. "This was a complete blind siding," one trader said. "They would have accomplished the same thing just by signaling it. But they decide not to signal it, and everybody on the Street got slammed."
