HEADLINE: Restoring Confidence in Air Travel 

 BODY:
With many Americans still too worried about the level of airport security to resume flying, and Transportation Secretary Norman Mineta acknowledging "intolerable" lapses nationwide, the House of Representatives has an opportunity today to help restore the public's confidence in the nation's aviation system. It ought to pass legislation identical to the aviation security measure passed unanimously by the Senate on Oct. 11. 
 The House Republican leadership is pushing for a weaker alternative that allows private companies to continue staffing airport security checkpoints. The Senate version would make airport screeners federal employees, akin to Border Patrol and Customs agents. Only the Senate approach will reassure Americans that Congress is willing to set aside partisan politics to protect them. 
 Making the screeners federal employees got bipartisan support in the Senate, where the bill passed 100 to 0 three weeks ago. That was not surprising. Contrary to assertions by House Republican leaders, charging the government with the vital law enforcement task of keeping terrorists off airplanes is hardly a controversial, left-wing notion. 
Lobbyists on both sides of the issue have been engaged in a bizarre debate over the extent to which private companies are involved in airport security everywhere from the Netherlands to Israel, with some conservatives revealing a newfound admiration of foreign ways. But Senator John McCain got it right when he said that Americans properly viewed keeping air travel safe as a law enforcement function that the government must assume. 
Except for the issue of airport screeners, the two competing bills scheduled for consideration today are similar. They expand the sky marshal program, require the fortification of cockpits and impose other security measures, to be paid for by a new surcharge on ticket prices. 
Today's House vote is expected to be a close one, due to the leadership's arm-twisting and White House lobbying for the weaker bill. It is understandable that members of Congress do not want to cross their president during wartime, particularly on a matter related to national security, but moderate Republican congressmen should not be deterred from backing the stronger measure. Voters will applaud them for insisting that the White House do more, not less, to protect the aviation system. And to his credit, President Bush has not said he will veto the Senate version if it prevails.
Secretary Mineta was properly forceful on Tuesday when he vowed that federal inspectors would crack down on continued security lapses at airports, even if it means closing down terminals and grounding flights for a time. Unfortunately, on the same day the administration was lobbying for a continued reliance on the same security companies that have proved so inadequate. 
Seven weeks after the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington, it is time for Congress to act decisively to restore confidence in the aviation system, an economic lifeline of crucial importance to the nation. Creating a federal force to protect it is not the whole solution to the security challenge, but it is certainly a part of any meaningful one.

HEADLINE: U.S. Will End Regular Sale Of Long Bond 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The United States retired the old faithful of the bond market yesterday, ending the regular sale of 30-year bonds after a quarter of a century.
 The Treasury Department said that despite the prospect of federal budget deficits this year and next, it expects surpluses to return soon. With that in mind, borrowing for 30 years is too costly and imprudent, it said, because shorter-term debt can be issued to cover its needs at lower rates. 
 The announcement, which inadvertently appeared on the Treasury Web site 10 minutes before the planned release at 10 a.m., caught bond traders and analysts flat-footed. With the economy slowing and the government spending more in the war on terrorism, they had anticipated the return of deficits and generally concluded that the 30-year bond would survive a while longer even though it had been slated for extinction when budget surpluses were growing. 
Many traders and dealers were angry about the lack of warning from the Treasury. Others suggested that the Treasury might be trying to push down long-term interest rates, which plunged yesterday, in an effort to encourage mortgage refinancing and aid an economic recovery.
Though fewer bonds had been issued the last few years, the elimination of 30-year bonds will require changes by bond professionals, institutions and individual investors. Investment alternatives include government agency and corporate bonds. Corporate bonds served investors quite well before regular sales of the 30-year bond began in February 1977.
In explaining the Treasury's decision, Peter Fisher, the undersecretary for domestic finance, said, "We do not need the 30-year bond to meet the government's current financing needs, nor those that we expect to face in coming years."
"The 30-year bond," he said, "no longer maintains a position of significance in the financial markets." 
Mr. Fisher added that "today's decision is in no way an attempt to manage long-term interest rates."
Reflecting the fact that 30-year bonds will now be scarce, the price jumped 58/32 points, about seven times more than a normal daily move. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, plunged from 5.20 percent Tuesday to 4.87 percent, the lowest since the bonds were regularly issued.
The demise of 30-year bonds, including those indexed for inflation, will increase demand for the 10-year note. Its price rose sharply yesterday, while the yield fell to 4.23 percent, near its record low in 1998.
The sharp moves in the bond market were exacerbated by investors and dealers who scrambled to reverse trades that suddenly became losers after the announcement.
"I think injecting this change into the market, particularly in a time of crisis, is not smart," said Charles Parkhurst, managing director of government bond trading at Salomon Smith Barney. "If the Treasury said that the February bond would have been the last and the market would get to to bid on it, the decision would have been more acceptable."
The outside committee of bond market professionals that advises the Treasury on policy had recommended the retirement of the 30-year bond. Those advisers met with Treasury officials on Tuesday about other decisions that the Treasury announced this morning at its regularly scheduled quarterly announcement. But the committee was not consulted on the 30-year decision.
When asked why the Treasury did not instead decide to cancel the 30-year bond after the next scheduled sale in February, the chairman of the committee, James R. Capra, said "that's a good question."
Micah Green, the president of the Bond Market Association, supported the Treasury's decision, although the association opposed the elimination of the 30-year bond in a statement in January.
"The Treasury Department's decision today to suspend issuance of the 30-year bond is reasonable and understandable based on its conclusion that the cost of continuing issuance of these bonds in the current market is not justifiable," he said.
Since 1977, $564.4 billion of regular 30-year bonds have been sold to the public. About $40 billion of inflation-protected 30-year bonds have been sold since 1998. The 30-year yield quickly became the benchmark interest rate for the U.S. bond market and for other countries' markets.
But as government budget deficits shrank and then gave way to surprisingly large surpluses, the Treasury scaled back the amount of securities it sold and wondered if the cost of 30-year bonds was just to high.
Though the 30-year bond is cherished by many bond dealers at the core of the Treasury market, the advisory committee recommended its retirement in January and repeated the recommendation in July. The issuance had already been cut to $15 billion a year, from almost $47 billion in 1991.
With the diminishing role of the 30-year bond, the 10-year note has become the benchmark for the Treasury market. Longer-term debt of government agencies, like Fannie Mae, is vying for the role previously served by the 30-year bond. Dealers were already adjusting how they traded and how they hedged against risk, some using bond futures instead of Treasury bonds. Investors will probably substitute agency debt or corporate debt for 30-year Treasuries, though there is additional risk in such securities. Long-term corporate debt, like that of AT&T, filled that role in the past.
The issue of savings for the taxpayer, one reason for the elimination of the 30-year bond, is simple. The yield on the 30-year bond, before yesterday's announcement, was 5.20 percent. The comparable yields were 4.41 percent on the 10-year note, 3.58 on the five-year note and 2.44 percent on the two-year note.
Louis Crandall, chief economist at Wrightson Associates, has advocated the demise of the 30-year bond for some time. His analysis of borrowing in the early 1990's showed that the government made significant savings in interest costs by choosing to sell more short-term debt, even with 30-year bond yields near historic lows.
The Treasury's decision seems to be an implicit bet that the budget will move back into surplus soon. Mr. Fisher said that if deficits persist, it would be easy for the government to return to selling 30-year bonds. In the interim, he added, "it is still likely that our decision to suspend 30-year borrowing at this time will have saved the taxpayers money."
Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at Hoenig & Company, has criticized the Bush administration's surplus projections as being too optimistic but still supports the decision to shift to shorter-term debt. "I can understand the logic of doing this even if I disagree with the administration's 10-year budget projections," he said.
The Treasury also announced yesterday that it would curtail, but not discontinue, its program of buying back higher-interest rate debt with 20 or more years to maturity. Since March 2000, the Treasury has bought back $57.5 billion in old debt. It will proceed with the scheduled buybacks of $6.5 billion of debt in November and December but do none in January. Beginning with February, it will announce each quarter whether it will do buybacks, depending on its cash flow and borrowing needs. Mr. Fisher said this meant there would be buybacks in some quarters and not in others.
The Treasury also said it would sell next week $16 billion of new five-year notes and $7 billion of the existing 10-year note, which matures in August 2011.

HEADLINE: Bridgeport Mayor Indicted on Corruption Charges 

BYLINE:  By PAUL ZIELBAUER 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Oct. 31 

 BODY:
Joseph P. Ganim, the mayor of Bridgeport and until recently a leading Democratic candidate for governor of Connecticut, was indicted today on a raft of federal bribery, extortion, mail fraud and racketeering charges. 
 Specifically, the government's 24-count indictment charges Mr. Ganim, for 10 years the popular mayor of Connecticut's largest city, with receiving more than $425,000 in cash, meals, tailored suits, jewelry, home landscaping services and bottles of what the United States attorney, John A. Danaher III, called "investment quality wine" -- all from friends and former members of his administration over the last six years. 
 In return, the government said, he pressed businesses that received hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of city contracts to pay small fortunes in "consulting fees" to those friends and associates, including his former chief of staff and his former campaign manager. 
Minutes after Mr. Danaher announced the charges at the federal court building here, Mr. Ganim, 42, appeared behind a lectern outside his office at Bridgeport City Hall and, eyes afire and finger pointing, denied all of them. He characterized the indictment as a conspiracy concocted by those he knew to blame him for the corrupt practices of his current and former associates. 
"I have done nothing wrong, I have not taken one dime as part of any conspiracy," Mr. Ganim said, glaring into a sea of reporters, cameras and, behind them, 100 or so city workers who repeatedly cheered him like a winning candidate.
"Like you," Mr. Ganim went on, "I have sadly learned that people who were close to me used that relationship for their own gain, and in doing so, betrayed me and betrayed the City of Bridgeport."
Although Gov. John G. Rowland, a Republican, issued a statement today calling for the mayor's resignation, Mr. Ganim rejected any notion of stepping down.
Since June, nine people and one Connecticut trucking company have pleaded guilty to federal charges that they either paid or received bribes connected to the scheme that prosecutors now say Mr. Ganim orchestrated. 
In 1999, according to today's indictment, Mr. Ganim and Paul J. Pinto, his close friend and former political fund-raiser, were each paid about $156,000 after the mayor awarded a contract to a company to manage the city's wastewater treatment plants. The payments were from Mr. Ganim's former campaign manager, Leonard J. Grimaldi, who paid the two men from the consulting fee he received, the indictment says. 
Mr. Pinto and Mr. Grimaldi rewarded Mr. Ganim with wine, clothing, a $1,600 pair of diamond earrings and $4,450 worth of kitchen appliances, among other items, for awarding the contracts, according to the indictment.
Prosecutors said Mr. Ganim also used city funds to buy himself a $1 million life insurance policy, and approved a plan to extend the city's sewer lines to his newly built house in the city's affluent Black Rock section.
Among those who pleaded guilty this year to cashing in on the scheme are Patrick O. Coyne, the mayor's former chief of staff; Frank W. Sullivan, who was a vice president at Salomon Smith Barney; and Mark Trinkley, a project manager in Connecticut's Department of Economic and Community Development. 
Mr. Ganim has tried his best to keep the downfall of his associates from destroying his own public image as a mayor who had helped revive Bridgeport, a gritty city with a long history of municipal corruption. As the guilty pleas began to accumulate this summer, tightening the investigative noose around him, the mayor took the unusual step of naming himself as the man Mr. Danaher was ultimately after, though prosecutors had long refrained from identifying the "top elected official" referred to in court documents. And on Tuesday, Mr. Ganim even told reporters that he expected to be charged at any time.
Mr. Ganim's defiance has also prevented him from giving up the idea of running for governor in 2002. 
"He's not withdrawn his name," said Connecticut's Democratic Party chairman, John W. Olsen. "He's kind of suspended his fund-raising, but he has not indicated to me that he is not a candidate."
Mr. Olsen said the indictment of Mr. Ganim, a rising political star who sat next to Vice President Al Gore at the state Democratic Party's annual fund-raiser last year, would not hurt his party's efforts to wrest control of the Capitol from Mr. Rowland, a popular two-term governor. "Democrats don't have to walk around with our heads down," Mr. Olsen said. "I mean, look, Phil Giordano is still the mayor of Waterbury."
Mr. Giordano, a Republican who ran against Joseph I. Lieberman for United States Senate last year, was charged in September with raping two girls, ages 9 and 10, but, proclaiming his innocence, refused to give up his job as mayor. He negotiated a deal with the City Council to serve the remainder of his term, which expires in December, from the prison where he is being held.
But few of Mr. Ganim's supporters expect him to go to jail. Though he has not received a single campaign contribution in the last three months, Mr. Ganim remains popular in some quarters. 
"The man has given me no indication that he was corrupt or anything else," said Bridgeport's Democratic committee chairman, Mario Testa, at his family-owned Italian restaurant today. "He still has my total support, personally and politically."
Before his appearance today, Mr. Ganim had staff members deliver thick packages to reporters that included the results of a recent independent poll, paid by the city, reporting that more than half of 306 registered city voters who were questioned still thought highly of the mayor, and only 16 percent thought he was guilty of "criminal wrongdoing." 
Mr. Ganim is scheduled to be arraigned in Federal District Court in New Haven Friday at 2 p.m. before Judge Janet Bond Arterton. 
At today's rally, waving a copy of the government's indictment, Mr. Ganim's lawyer, Richard Meehan Jr., dismissed it as "nothing more than circumstantial evidence." 
"You can be assured," Mr. Meehan added, "that Mr. Ganim will plead not guilty."

HEADLINE: Amid Trade Agenda Talks, Sharpened Focus on Rich-Poor Disputes 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 

 BODY:
With only a week to go before trade ministers are scheduled to gather in Doha, Qatar, to try to set the agenda for a worldwide trade accord, actions the United States has taken since the terrorist attacks appear to have widened the gap between rich and poor nations and persuaded some negotiators that the meeting could become a casualty of war.
 The Bush administration's tussle with Bayer A.G. -- in which Washington forced the company to sharply reduce the price of its anthrax drug Cipro -- has emboldened developing countries to insist on a broad "public health" exception to international patent rules for other drugs, like those used to keep AIDS victims alive. 
 India, Nigeria and many others are also arguing that if the United States can cede special trading rights to Pakistan's textile and apparel makers to help a frontline ally, it should ease barriers for clothing makers in all poor countries.
Disputes over patent rules and textile quotas have been around for years. But the exigencies of fighting terrorism have cast the matter into stark relief and set off a heated debate in Geneva, where negotiators for 142 nations in the World Trade Organization had hoped to be narrowing their differences ahead of the meeting. 
The 11th-hour standoff has raised the possibility that trade ministers will converge on Qatar only to have the talks collapse, as they did in Seattle two years ago. Such a failure would be especially bitter because many officials say they fear for their safety by convening in the Persian Gulf region even as war rages in Afghanistan.
Still, Bush administration officials expressed confidence that the trade talks would conclude successfully, meaning that ministers would agree to a new, several-year round of negotiations to eliminate barriers and unify rules of global trade.
But the risks are arguably greater than they were in Seattle. The leading industrial nations are experiencing a rare simultaneous economic slump. World trade flows are shrinking for the first time in two decades. A trade agreement has been viewed as vital to opening new markets and spurring business investment.
Moreover, some analysts say the future of the World Trade Organization, formed six years ago to promote trade and resolve disputes with more authority than previously allowed, would be in doubt if its second attempt to advance global trade talks is again stillborn.
Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, said this week that liberalizing trade was an urgent priority to avoid giving nations an excuse to revert to protectionism. "The meeting in Doha needs to get the W.T.O. back on track," he said.
Like any trade negotiation, the coming talks depend on resolving a number of disputes under a single umbrella. Removing barriers to trade in farm products is a top American priority while limiting the use of antidumping rules to block low-price imports has become a major concern of Japan and many developing nations. Both matters are proving especially hard to resolve.
At the same time, tensions are rising between rich and poor. Brazil and India are leading a coalition that wants trade rules rewritten to make it clear that nations can violate patents and save money on, for example, AIDS or malaria drugs when they face an acute health crisis.
They argue that poor countries often cannot afford vital medicine. Industrial nations, they say, often seek to punish them if they buy or produce knockoff versions of the drugs.
Paulo Teixeira, director of Brazil's anti-AIDS program, told reporters this week that the United States' efforts to reduce the price of Cipro, under threat of breaking Bayer's patent, mimics similar strong-arm tactics that Brazil has used. Washington threatened at one point to file a W.T.O. case against Brazil on behalf of American drug makers.
"They are doing exactly what we did," Mr. Teixeira said of the Bush administration's position on Cipro. "It is inconsistent to then oppose making that an option on a global level."
But that argument has run into stiff opposition from delegates representing Switzerland, Canada and Japan, as well as the United States, who are fighting hard to preserve protection of intellectual property. The two sides are still far apart.
The Bush administration has proposed a compromise that it says ensures that poor countries could gain access to drugs during emergencies. Mr. Zoellick said he supports giving developing countries more time to come into compliance with intellectual property rules. 
But the administration has dug in its heels on amending patent protection. Officials argue that Brazil and India, which both make generic versions of leading drugs, have used the American response to terrorism as an excuse to increase sales.
"They want a huge 'get out of jail free' card any time you use the words 'public health,' " an American trade official said.
Disputes on textiles have also become more pointed since Sept. 11. Developing countries have been arguing for years that industrial nations, especially the United States, have been unwilling to open their doors to clothing and textile products, which along with farm products are the leading exports of many poor countries.
When the Bush administration last week broached the possibility of reducing tariffs or increasing the quota allocations on Pakistani textiles, the concession to a war ally resonated loudly in Geneva. There, American negotiators have been fighting to preserve the right to shelter the politically powerful domestic textile industry. 
Developing countries have been arguing that they will not compromise on other issues until they see more evidence that barriers to the textile trade are being eliminated.
The negotiations, the Nigerian trade delegation said in a statement today, "are empty of contents on the issues of interest to developing countries."

HEADLINE: Casino Bill Was Passed After Big Push By Lobbyists 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA and JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 31 

 BODY:
Gambling interests mounted one of the broadest, most expensive lobbying campaigns in the state's history this year, pressing for the aggressive expansion of gambling that Gov. George E. Pataki made law today.
 That campaign included dozens of different interests hoping to grab a piece of what they expect will be billions of dollars wagered each year -- Indian tribes seeking to build casinos, developers and casino managers who want to become the tribes' partners, makers of gambling machinery and various elements of the horse-racing industry. 
 Together, they have spent well over $2 million so far this year to lobby the Legislature and the governor, far above the $1.5 million spent in all of last year, according to records filed with the state's Temporary Commission on Lobbying, and some of the interests were heavy campaign contributors. Six of the top seven lobbying firms in Albany represented major gambling interests. 
"This was probably the biggest lobbying effort I've ever seen, and I've been around a long time," said James Featherstonhaugh, one of Albany's most influential lobbyists. From January to August, the period covered by the most recent lobbying reports, Mr. Featherstonhaugh's firm received more than $300,000 from clients supporting the gambling bill, including Park Place Entertainment, the Mohawk Indians' partner in a Catskills casino project; Gtech Corporation, the world's largest supplier of computerized gambling systems for lotteries and casinos; the Western Regional Off-Track Betting Corporation; and the Thoroughbred Horsemen's Association, the major horse owners' group.
The most striking evidence of this year's climate is the large number of groups that did little or no lobbying last year, then became major Capitol players this year, including several racetracks and off-track betting corporations.
The Seneca Nation of Indians, who stand to gain three casinos in western New York, had no lobbyist as recently as January. But through August of this year, the tribe had spent $400,000 on lobbying, seeking passage of the gambling bill here and regulatory approval in Washington for its casinos. 
The tribe signed Akin Gump Strauss Hauer & Feld, the top Washington firm that includes former Representative Bill Paxon of western New York, to represent it for more than $500,000 a year, the biggest lobbying contract ever registered with the state lobbying commission. The Senecas also hired as lobbyists Patricia Lynch, a former top aide to Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, and Clarence Rappleyea, former Republican leader in the Assembly and former chairman of the New York Power Authority.
The list of lobbyists illustrates the revolving-door nature of power here, where former officials often become lobbyists, trading on their closeness to decision-makers. Mr. Rappleyea and Ms. Lynch left state service just last year, as did David Dudley, former chief counsel to the Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, and now a lobbyist for Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts and a company that owns racetracks. Among the other lobbyists this year for gambling interests were Arthur J. Kremer, once a powerful assemblyman; Paul D'Onofrio, a former lawyer for the Assembly on gambling issues; and Frank Sanzillo, a former top Senate aide.
Since taking office in 1995, Mr. Pataki has repeatedly promoted legalized gambling but has usually been thwarted by the Legislature. Since the spring, when waning state revenue persuaded many lawmakers to take a second look at gambling and the governor announced the outlines of a deal with the Senecas, it seemed that this year the dam would break. The destruction of the World Trade Center helped the package sail through, 52 to 8 in the Senate, and 92 to 41 in the Assembly.
The stunning breadth of the bill would make New York the Eastern state with the most legal gambling if it all survives the expected legal challenges. The law allows for three Seneca casinos, three more Indian-run casinos in the Catskills, video lottery terminals at racetracks, and New York's enlistment in the Powerball multistate lottery.
Mr. Pataki, joined by Mr. Silver and Mr. Bruno, held bill-signing ceremonies today in Niagara Falls, Syracuse and Monticello. "We fought for this new measure because it will provide a major boost to the western New York economy, bringing new jobs, thousands of tourists and new private-sector investment to the area," he said in Niagara Falls.
The governor supported new forms of gambling long before the lobbying campaign geared up. Mr. Bruno and Mr. Silver gave their support more recently and more reluctantly, but they insisted that it was the state's need for revenue, not lobbyists and campaign contributions, that persuaded them. 
While pro-gambling forces were on the march this year, the bill's most potent foe, Donald J. Trump, largely retreated from the field. He spent $150,000 on lobbying in Albany the first eight months of this year, a far cry from the $540,000 he spent last year. He spent less than $14,000 on campaign contributions in the first six months of this year -- big numbers for most donors, but small for Mr. Trump, who has sometimes contributed more than $100,000 a year.
Mr. Trump does not want competition in New York for his three Atlantic City casinos, and he has used his influence and his deep pockets to help defeat past gambling efforts here. In an interview last week, Mr. Trump declined to explain the decline in his lobbying and campaign contributions. Some of his associates say that because his company, Trump Hotels and Casino Resorts, is experiencing financial trouble, he was distracted.
Several companies that stand to gain from gambling spent generously on political campaigns as well as lobbying, often giving more than they did last year, though 2001 is not a state election year.
From November through July, Park Place Entertainment, the Mohawk casino partner, gave $15,000 to the Assembly Democrats, $15,000 to the state Republican Party and $10,000 to the Assembly Republicans. The company also paid several lobbyists a total of $250,000 over the first eight months of this year.
Gtech, whose systems run the state's electronic lottery games, gave $35,000 in the first six months of this year, including $25,000 to the state Republican Party, and spent $160,000 on lobbying in the first eight months of the year. Robert K. Vincent, vice president of Gtech Holdings Inc., the parent company, said that as the year began, its primary interest was in the renewal of Quick Draw, the electronic lottery game. 
The Delaware North Companies of Buffalo, owner of several racetracks and a betting equipment firm, is seeking to develop a casino with the Senecas, and along with its subsidiaries spent $75,000 on lobbying through August. The companies and their owners, the Jacobs family, gave $19,000 to state campaigns the first half of this year, including $8,000 to Mr. Pataki.
David M. Flaum, a Rochester developer who said he was close to a deal with an Indian tribe to develop a casino in Sullivan County, gave Mr. Pataki $12,000 this spring.
"This bill wasn't just one issue, it was a dozen different issues, all wrapped together," said Michael Vacek, a lobbyist for Yonkers Raceway. "It was one of those rare occurrences when the sun, the moon and the stars were lined up, and everybody got involved, from the Indian tribes to the harness tracks to the casino developers."

HEADLINE: In America; 
Hungry and Jobless

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
"Our members," said John Turchiano, "have never been in this position before."
 Mr. Turchiano is a spokesman for the Hotel and Restaurant Workers union in New York City. On Monday four tractor-trailer trucks from the group Feed the Children pulled up outside the union's health center in Elmhurst, Queens. Nearly 500 union members and their families lined up for canned goods, baby food, toothpaste and other items that might be helpful for families suddenly thrown into an economic crisis. Worried expressions were the norm. Some of the union members wept. 
 Even as they boldly confront each daunting new day with whatever reserves of toughness and cockiness remain, New Yorkers are struggling with two particularly debilitating kinds of fear. The first is the continuing terror associated with the attack on the World Trade Center and the anthrax attacks that have followed. (I watched a woman break down on the subway yesterday when an announcement was made that, because of a police action, the Sixth Avenue line was temporarily shut down. And there were reports of New Yorkers bursting into tears when they learned that Kathy Nguyen, a 61-year-old employee of the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital, had died from inhalation anthrax.)
The second type of fear is linked to the growing economic insecurity that is spreading in hideous waves across the entire city. New Yorkers by the hundreds of thousands are either out of work or are saddled with the realistic expectation that they will soon be out of work. Mr. Turchiano said nearly 4,500 members of his union had been laid off, and 1,000 others are working reduced hours. He said nearly all the layoffs were directly or indirectly related to the trade center attack. 
We are only beginning to glimpse the economic toll. An enormous number of low-wage workers, many without health or unemployment benefits, have been caught in the downdraft. In the worst cases, families that until recently were enthusiastic, if not highly paid, participants in a remarkably high-flying economy are finding themselves confronted by the horrifying parlay of hunger and imminent eviction from their homes.
I think an awful lot of people are underestimating the extent of the disaster in New York City. All income groups are affected, but in the days and weeks and years to come the impact on the working classes and the poor is likely to be horrific.
There are no guidebooks available on the best way to bring a city back from the combination of emotional and economic devastation. We'll be winging it, just as we're winging it (with disappointing results) in the fight against terrorism at home and abroad. 
Estimates of the budget deficit the city will face next year are staggering -- $4 billion to $6 billion. And the state will be faced with its own multibillion-dollar deficit. If you assume that the city will not be skimping on public safety expenditures (an absolutely safe assumption in this atmosphere), and that it will be doing all it can to rebuild Lower Manhattan as swiftly as possible (another safe assumption), and that it will meet its minimal obligations to the school system and other mandated services, you quickly come to the conclusion that there will be precious little money left over for anything else.
Felix Rohatyn has said he believes the city is in greater economic jeopardy now than during the fiscal crisis of the mid-70's, and that "New York does not have the resources to recover on its own."
The fiscal crisis of the 70's resulted in horrendous service cuts that left their grim imprint on the city for many years. The danger ahead for New York -- psychologically as well as physically and economically damaged -- is potentially much greater.
In a conversation Tuesday Mr. Rohatyn stressed the need for long-term assistance from the federal government. "One of the things worth underlining is that the city and the state are essentially like Siamese twins," he said, "and if the city gets into deep trouble, so will the state. In 1975, when the city almost defaulted on its bonds, the state lost access to the public financing markets. I think most people forget that."
New York is functioning, but in a radically altered state. It's a big town in big trouble. And it could use some help with the heavy lifting ahead.

HEADLINE: Former Congressman's Son Opposes Councilman's Aide 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
Campaigning outside a supermarket in a Queens neighborhood in the backyard of Kennedy International Airport, Joseph P. Addabbo Jr. seemed to have no trouble being recognized by a large number of shoppers. Many stopped to wish him well in his race for a City Council seat against Joann Ariola.
 "Occasionally, they even remember my father, which really makes me feel good," Mr. Addabbo said, smiling. He is a 37-year-old real estate lawyer; his father served in Congress a generation ago. "I think people know that I have a close link with this area. They know I understand the issues in this community." 
 That Mr. Addabbo has a family name with strong roots in the southern tier of Queens is clear. But less certain is whether that name and its history in Democratic politics will help propel him to victory in a close race in a district that has been represented for the last eight years by Alfonso Stabile, a Republican who is barred by term limits from running again.
In this highly competitive race in the 32nd Council District, Mr. Addabbo is facing Ms. Ariola, a onetime aide to Mr. Stabile who is also a Republican Party official in Queens. Ms. Ariola recently stepped down as an aide to City Councilman Noach Dear, a Democrat, to run for the Council seat.
Another factor in the race is Mr. Stabile himself, who, after some disagreements with his former aide, Ms. Ariola, decided to endorse Mr. Addabbo instead. "I only wish he had endorsed me four years ago," Mr. Addabbo said of an earlier, unsuccessful, campaign -- against Mr. Stabile.
The 32nd Council District includes a number of neighborhoods along Jamaica Bay, from the neat single-family homes of Howard Beach and Ozone Park, on what residents refer to as the "mainland," to the western half of the Rockaway Peninsula, extending out to Breezy Point.
Registered Democrats outnumber Republicans in the district by a margin of more than two to one. But it is also a district that has often voted overwhelmingly for Republicans, most recently for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki. Mr. Stabile himself won in 1993 by ousting Walter Ward, a Democrat who was then the Council's longest-serving member.
Ms. Ariola, 43, is clearly aiming to enlist the support of the so-called Giuliani Democrats by pointing to a career in which she has worked with both Republicans and Democrats.
"I have worked with everyone, regardless of party," she said. "I have firsthand knowledge of how city government works and how to make it work for the people of this district. I am extremely familiar with every issue of importance to the people of his district."
Ms. Ariola emphasizes issues that are highly neighborhood-oriented. She would seek, she said, to find ways to eliminate the $1.75 toll on the bridges linking the peninsula with the mainland. She would seek to find ways to restore economic vitality to such commercial thoroughfares as 101st, Jamaica and Liberty Avenues.
"And we need road-restoration work in many parts of the district, particularly in Ozone Park," she said. "Some of the potholes have not been repaired since 1993." She also would seek to place pressure on the federal government to prevent the supersonic Concorde jet from landing at Kennedy Airport, citing the increased pollution she said was caused by those flights.
Mr. Addabbo spends much time discussing his proposals for the city's schools, saying that the Board of Education should be restructured to provide for "more accountability and accessibility to the funding for each and every school." He talks about stricter oversight over school construction.
He has also advocated subsidized ferry service between the Rockaway Peninsula and Lower Manhattan and express bus service from the Rockaways to Manhattan. "It takes residents much too long to get to any other part of Queens, let alone going into Manhattan," he said.
This year's campaign represents Mr. Addabbo's second attempt to win the Council seat, after he lost to Mr. Stabile in 1997. He attributes that loss to the high popularity of Mr. Giuliani, saying that most voters stayed in the Republican column as they moved down the ballot and that many Democrats, anticipating a Giuliani landslide, simply stayed home.
"This year is different," Mr. Addabbo said. "The Giuliani coattails are not a factor, and Republicans might stay home if they perceive that Mark Green will win easily over Michael Bloomberg."
That is not particularly daunting, Ms. Ariola said, explaining that Democratic voters often vote for Republican and Conservative Party candidates (she is the candidate of both parties).
"People in this district will cross party lines," she said. "They don't go straight down any particular line, no matter what anyone tells you. They are well-informed voters. And, I think that helps me."

HEADLINE: Let the Cars Squeal 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "It's the Cars, Not the Tires, That Squeal" (Oct. 25): Electronic means of monitoring car use and driver behavior are to be welcomed, not feared. Automotive "black boxes" have reduced crash rates on fleet vehicles in Germany by more than one-third by making drivers accountable for speeding and other unsafe behavior. 
Deploying this technology here could save thousands of lives and make the streets less lethal for pedestrians and cyclists. 
 Similarly, mileage recorders could let municipalities switch road financing from "dumb" levies like sales and property taxes, which actually subsidize driving, to "smart" charges on vehicle miles traveled. Since fewer miles would mean lower taxes, many drivers would economize on car travel, cutting pollution, congestion and petroleum use.

CHARLES KOMANOFF
New York

The writer is a member of Right of Way, a pedestrian-rights organization based in New York.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: MEDICATIONS; 
Bioterrorism And Anxiety Are Swelling Prescriptions

BYLINE:  By TAMAR LEWIN 

 BODY:
In the period of anxiety and bioterrorism after the attacks of Sept. 11, many Americans have turned to prescription drugs, according to new data from IMS Health, the nation's leading supplier of pharmaceutical information. 
 The numbers bear out what became plain to many harried pharmacists: The run on Cipro and other antibiotics used to treat anthrax began in late September, even before the first case was announced in Florida on Oct. 4. 
 The IMS figures, reflecting activity through Oct. 19, show that sales both of sedatives and of antidepressants like Prozac and Zoloft also increased, although not so markedly as those of antibiotics. 
In the first full week after the attacks, the number of prescriptions filled for sedatives, like Ambien and Halcion, was up 4 percent nationally over the IMS benchmark, an average of the prescription volume from eight weeks this summer. And by the first week in October, sedative prescriptions were up 11 percent.
Prescriptions for antidepressants also peaked in early October, up 5 percent over the benchmark. 
Prescriptions for sedatives and antidepressants both declined afterward, though not to the benchmark level.
"Right after the attacks, a lot of our patients were very worried and scared, with all their old anxieties stirred up," said Dr. Vicki Lopachin, a Manhattan physician. "It seemed like nobody was sleeping. It's much better now. With the new bioterrorism, people are a little more anxious again, but nothing like those first couple of weeks." 
Much of the anxiety was funneled into demand for Cipro, even before anthrax attacks became a reality. In the week ended Sept. 28, the number of prescriptions for Cipro had increased 6 percent nationally and 37 percent in the New York area. 
And the following week, when the first case was announced in Florida, Cipro prescriptions were up 16 percent nationwide, 73 percent in New York and 53 percent in the West Palm Beach area, the location of the Florida infection.
The week after that, as other anthrax cases were identified, the numbers grew even faster. For that week, ended Oct. 12, Cipro prescriptions were up 45 percent across the country and more than 160 percent in New York and West Palm Beach.
In the early weeks, prescriptions for other drugs in the same therapeutic class, quinolones, rose even faster than those for Cipro. In the last week of September, prescriptions for other quinolones, like Levaquin, Avelox and Tequin, were 25 percent higher than over the summer, and the following week they were 32 percent higher. 
"The reason the other quinolones went up," Dr. Lopachin said, "is probably that as soon as there were reports of a run on Cipro, many doctors did what I did, which was to write prescriptions for one of the other quinolones in all the cases where they'd normally have written Cipro. You want to make sure it will be available."

HEADLINE: Technology Briefing Hardware: Chip Outlook Remains Dull 

BYLINE:  By Chris Gaither (NYT) (Compiled by Alan Krauss) 

 BODY:
 The Sept. 11 terrorist attacks deepened an already steep slide in chip sales for 2001, and any recovery in 2002 will be slight, a market research firm predicted. The firm, Gartner Dataquest, which is based in San Jose, Calif., said worldwide semiconductor revenue would be $147 billion this year, a 35 percent decline from last year, the industry's sharpest downturn ever. 
Even if demand improves, the report said, the average selling price of chips will continue to cut into sales through year's end. Gartner forecast mild growth next year of 3 percent, to $152 billion. An improved economy, pent-up demand for electronics and personal computers, and new technologies like next-generation cellular networks will lead the chip industry to 30 percent growth in 2003, Gartner said. HEADLINE: N.F.L.: ROUNDUP; 
Owners Approve Labor Agreement

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
N.F.L. owners wrapped up their talks yesterday by ratifying a three-year extension of their labor agreement. The extension would push the salary cap through 2006 and would carry beyond the N.F.L.'s $17.6 billion television contract, which has four more years to run past this season. 
 The labor deal, worked out by the N.F.L. Management Council and the Players Association in June, still must be approved by the players union. Among the unresolved issues before the players can ratify it are how financial losses would be divided if games are canceled, and how the 2006 salary cap would be adjusted if the economy is in a downturn and TV revenues have decreased. 
 Owners also approved the latest deal to keep the Saints in New Orleans for the next 10 years and the roster-stocking plan for the Houston Texans as they enter the league.

49ERS RE-SIGN MIRER: Quarterback Rick Mirer, the former No. 2 overall draft pick out of Notre Dame who was cut by the San Francisco 49ers shortly before the regular season, re-signed with the club yesterday.
 Eight weeks after the 49ers released him in a cost-cutting move, Mirer was back at the team's training complex. He backed up Jeff Garcia last season, but San Francisco chose to drop him in favor of the second-year pro Tim Rattay, who has thrown one N.F.L. pass.

MINOR FINALLY GETS CREDIT: Miami Dolphins running back Travis Minor was credited with a touchdown yesterday, three days after the whistle blew.
 The Elias Sports Bureau changed the statistical ruling on a play in Sunday's victory at Seattle, when Jay Fiedler fumbled at the goal line and Minor recovered in the end zone. Fiedler was initially credited with the score, but it was changed after the game.

HEADLINE: Shopping Lists for Troubled Times 

BYLINE:  By LISA GUERNSEY 

 BODY:
THE day after the terrorist attacks in Manhattan, Ilene Walerstein, a 40-year-old marketing manager, was evacuated from her apartment because of a bomb threat at the Empire State Building nearby. Since then, Ms. Walerstein has made a few decisions about the technology she wants to purchase. "Larger electronics and appliances are just not a priority right now," she said. 
 But putting together a survival kit is. So last week Ms. Walerstein visited the AT&T Wireless store near Bryant Park to add an extra cellphone battery to the list of essentials she has recently decided to keep handy. 
 "I wanted an extra battery in case my cellphone dies," said Ms. Walerstein, whose family has set up a phone tree to keep in touch during crises. "I want to make sure the phone's available in case of emergencies." 
After the attacks of Sept. 11, there was speculation, and some evidence, that electronics shoppers were focusing on gadgets like cellphones that might offer them a lifeline. Now, with a continuing stream of unsettling news -- anthrax scares, military action, an economic downturn, the prospect of being homebound for the holiday season -- industry analysts, manufacturers and store owners are watching for signs of a longer-term impact on consumers' tastes and buying behavior. 
Are they going to shop as Ms. Walerstein is, buying small necessities and holding back on larger purchases? Are they going to spend the money they might have used for travel on items like cellphones, radios and computers, to help them stay better connected or better informed? Or are they going to shake off their anxieties and, with the holiday shopping season approaching, pull out their wallets as readily as they might have before? 
Interviews with shoppers suggest that all of these impulses might be in play at once, though perhaps anxieties are more pronounced around New York City than elsewhere. In Denver, for example, some shoppers appeared inclined to shrug off the uneasy climate and carry on as usual. "The Sept. 11 attacks haven't really affected me that much, or affected what I'm buying," said Dillard Rollison, a 44-year-old engineer who stopped at a Radio Shack in Denver on Monday to buy a 3.5-inch disk drive. 
On Friday afternoon on Fifth Avenue in New York, Joseph and Shelley Brooks of Manhattan said they were inclined to buy more electronics than usual because they thought the economy would slow further and their own finances would tighten after December. Ms. Brooks had just bought a fax machine for her home office, and a few weeks ago she bought cellphones for her two sons to give herself more peace of mind about their safety. (Her sons are adults, but that does not stop her, she said, from buying what she thinks they need.) Now, she added, she is thinking about getting them DVD players for Christmas. 
In the recent past, national crises have had a strong impact on sales of technology, and the historical data may argue against an optimistic forecast. During the Persian Gulf war in 1991, for example, the economy took a dive and the information technology market went with it, until jumping back to its previous levels in 1992. IDC, a market research company in Framingham, Mass., used that conflict as a model for examining what might happen to the technology industry in the coming months. Taking into account the technology slump that was already in progress before Sept. 11, the company concluded that consumers and businesses would proceed so cautiously that they would not purchase items like computers and software.
"I just can't really see any good news," said John Gantz, chief research officer at IDC.
Britt Beemer, the founder of America's Research Group in Charleston, S.C., said he was predicting that sales of consumer electronics would show a decline of about 3.5 percent to 4 percent from a year ago. Part of his research is based on national telephone surveys of consumers and store owners. His latest surveys, he said, lead him to believe that fewer people will be shopping and that many will avoid department stores and traditional retail shops in favor of discount stores.
"Sept. 11 may establish new normal levels," Mr. Beemer said, referring to sales at retail stores. "And I think the new normal level may be only 95 percent" of the levels seen before that day, he said.
Cellphones, however, may follow their own market trajectory. In the weeks since the attacks, many people have talked about finally buying a cellphone, or purchasing a second or third phone for family members as a backup. Before Sept. 11, the Yankee Group, a research group based in Boston, expected that the number of cellphone users in the United States would rise from 109 million in December 2000 to 128 million by the end of this year. Now the company expects an additional 2 million people, or 130 million in all, to subscribe to cellphone plans. 
In two surveys conducted after Sept. 11, America's Research Group asked parents what they might consider buying their children for Christmas. About 6 percent of parents said that cellphones were on their list. "When we've asked that in previous years," Mr. Beemer said, "cellphones barely make 1 percent of responses."
Those who already have cellphones say they are upgrading their services or repairing problems. "My phone broke last week," said Lauren Borish, a buyer for a department store in Manhattan, "and I literally ran to the phone store that day, instead of waiting a few days to get it fixed."
Large wireless companies like Verizon Wireless and Sprint PCS are not releasing figures on how many people signed up for cellphone plans after the attacks -- possibly because they want to avoid giving the impression of profiting from them. But Strategis Group, a telecommunications consulting company in Washington, said that several retailers around the country had told researchers that they were selling more phones -- in some cases three times as many as before Sept. 11. 
Purchases of a few other kinds of consumer electronics also jumped after Sept. 11, although some sales representatives said they expected the increases to be short-lived. In the first few days after the attacks, for example, technology shops in New York saw a surge in sales of pocket AM-FM radios. "We sold out," said Sunny Khan, a salesman at Video Camera City on 32nd Street at Avenue of the Americas. Sales clerks at other shops said that television sets were also a hot item as news watchers decided to upgrade. 
People who wanted even more information bought high-frequency radios and police scanners that pick up conversations between law enforcement officials. Radio Shack sales representatives said that the scanners were suddenly popular at their stores in New York City and around the country. So far, the same uptick in sales has not hit fax machines and computers, some sales representatives say, even though both are obvious alternatives to relying on the postal service amid fears of anthrax.
A few shoppers in New York are determined not to be swayed by recent events. George Majao, a pastry chef who lives in Brooklyn, said he bought a sports CD player on impulse last week, a move that would probably warm the heart of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has urged people to go out and shop. 
Tim Oxborough-Powell, a principal in I.B.M.'s security services division, said he had been "following Rudy's advice" and bought a few DVD's from The Wiz last week. "We are going out and spending money." 
The Consumer Electronics Association, an industry group of manufacturers, sees healthy demand ahead. "We've definitely seen an increase in interest in consumer electronics, which surprised us," said Sean Wargo, a senior analyst at the association. He said he expected a single-digit increase in holiday sales.
Predictions are always just that, of course. This year many shoppers say they are simply unable to gauge how they will handle the holiday shopping season given the news that is occupying their attention. 
Thomas Haddad, an art director from Cedar Grove, N.J., is feeling the weight of the news more than most. He and five of his colleagues were on the 89th floor of 1 World Trade Center that morning, and somehow they all escaped. Last week, he was at a Radio Shack in Manhattan, replacing lost items. He bought headphone splitters, for example, so that he and his wife could carry on their tradition of listening to music together on the bus ride home each evening. 
But in general, he said, he is just taking things slowly, hardly even thinking ahead to the holidays. "I can't even think that far in advance," he said.

HEADLINE: Carnegie Delays Opening of Additional Hall 

 BODY:
The opening of Judy and Arthur Zankel Hall, the new underground 650-seat concert space at Carnegie Hall, has been postponed nine months until September 2003, when it is hoped that the city's economic climate will be more receptive to it, Robert Harth, the executive and artistic director of Carnegie Hall, announced yesterday.
The opening had been set for the fall season next year, but Mr. 
Harth said that the economic aftermath of the terrorist attacks had made Carnegie Hall rethink its plans.
 "The landscape has changed significantly since Sept. 11, and the issue of ticket sales in the current economic climate is a significant consideration for all arts organizations right now," he said. "The introduction of 50,000 new tickets annually, which would result from a concert series in the new hall, would mean we would be marketing as soon as February for the subsequent season." 
 Originally budgeted at $50 million, the new hall is now expected to cost $69 million, or the bulk of Carnegie Hall's nearly completed $100 million fund-raising campaign. The rest of the money will go toward education and endowment.
The cost of building Zankel Hall increased as soon as excavation of the bedrock beneath Carnegie Hall began. "When you go down, you don't know what you are going to find until you uncover it," Mr. Harth said.
He said that the construction of the new hall under the 2,804-seat Isaac Stern Auditorium was more or less on schedule. The delayed opening will give Carnegie Hall time to prepare a 10-day festival to open it, he added.
With the addition of Zankel Hall, the original 1891 plan by Andrew Carnegie, which had three stages under one roof, will be restored.

HEADLINE: Left in Nasser's Exhaust at Ford 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 31 

 BODY:
Jacques A. Nasser, Detroit's New Economy chief executive officer, lasted longer than the new economy. But not much. 
 Mr. Nasser, who resigned as chief executive of the Ford Motor Company on Monday, had bold ideas, and many good ones. He worked his way up through Ford's international divisions and was a turnaround expert nicknamed Jac the Knife for his cost cutting. He presented himself as a chief executive in the mold of John F. Welch Jr., with a dash of Michael S. Dell. Like those men, he had no chief operating officer and chafed at delegating authority. 
 But he was undone by a tin ear for the politicking necessary to run a company of Ford's size -- with revenue last year of $170 billion -- and by a struggling economy that has unmasked the auto industry as an increasingly cluttered and difficult business that has passed its sales peak for the foreseeable future.
For William Clay Ford Jr., the 44-year-old chairman and Ford family scion who has assumed the role of chief executive, that means scaling back Mr. Nasser's ambitions and marshaling Ford Motor dealers, suppliers, managers and union workers for a difficult road ahead. Mr. Nasser's departure, which followed a meeting on Monday with Mr. Ford, came earlier than some had expected. Ford Motor has what will probably be a painful turnaround plan in the works. Why not let Mr. Nasser deliver the cuts before he left?
Part of the reason is that Mr. Nasser's presence could have made a bitter pill taste even worse. Mr. Nasser managed to anger almost every core relationship Ford Motor has.
The United Automobile Workers bristled when he tried to force a spin-off of the company's auto supply operation, Visteon, on terms that would match the deal the union had carefully negotiated with General Motors when it spun off Delphi Automotive. Mr. Nasser ended up getting a much less favorable deal.
"Ford at that time was making record profits and paying record bonuses and here was Nasser, who wanted to dump Visteon off the bus," said Sean P. McAlinden, director of the economics group at the Center for Automotive Research in Ann Arbor, Mich. "It created a political, grass-roots firestorm," he added. 
Relations with the union will be critical to the turnaround plan, since real cost savings are achieved when factories are closed, but the current union contract forbids plant closings.
Ford dealers took it quite personally when Mr. Nasser championed the introduction of a dealership group that was run by Ford Motor, an idea also tried by General Motors. This was a good idea on paper. Most money made on cars is made after they leave the manufacturer, when they are sold, resold, leased, repaired and insured. But convincing the ranks of existing Ford dealers that Ford Motor should get a piece of their pie was not popular, to put it mildly. Neither was Mr. Nasser's initiative to sell cars on the Web. 
"That was the beginning of the dealer relation problems," said Jerry Reynolds, chairman of the Ford National Dealer Council and a dealer in Garland, Tex. 
"I begged him not to do this," he added. "He told me: 'We're going to do this. We think we can learn from this and it can be profitable.' Luckily, it failed."
A letter from the council, made public last month, said that a majority of dealers surveyed wanted change at Ford Motor to start with the departure of Mr. Nasser. 
Perhaps most important, Mr. Nasser appears to have thought that he could rule Ford Motor without sharing information with Mr. Ford, the representative of the Ford family, which controls 40 percent of the voting stock. Mr. Ford felt he was cut off from the flow of information and, in July, created a special office to share some power with Mr. Nasser. 
"This is an old school industrial company," said Rod Lache, an analyst with Deutsche Bank. "You have to be diplomatic. This is a big organization, and there are politics you have to deal with."
Mr. Ford said Tuesday that the time for barnstorming and changing the world had passed and that it was time to "get back to basics." 
"We have relationships that are very important to us, and a lot of those are either broken are not healthy," he said.
"I'm going to spend a lot of my personal time on those relationships: our dealers, the U.A.W., our white-collar employees, suppliers -- on throughout the constituencies -- Wall Street, government." 
Ford is in a weakened condition at a bad time. G.M. is leading a price war in which it, Ford Motor and Chrysler are all offering interest-free financing on their vehicles, inflating sales but narrowing profit at a time when there is no shortage of red ink. G.M. has a new lineup of sport utility vehicles and trucks, and foreign automakers like Toyota are already flooding that market. 
The turnaround plan, which is being devised by Nicholas V. Scheele, newly appointed as Ford Motor's president and chief operating officer, has already been delayed several times and might not be fully assembled until January. But cuts have been under way all year. No more free computers for Ford workers. No bonuses for executives this year. A reduction of about 10 percent of the white-collar staff, or 5,000 workers. Production cuts in the first quarter and again after Sept. 11, and other cuts, including more than 800 jobs at a truck assembly plant in Wayne, Mich. 
One might think that Ford Motor's bitter dispute with the Bridgestone/ Firestone Company was the beginning of the end for Mr. Nasser. But Mr. Ford said it was not a factor, and many analysts agree. 
"It's a combination of factors, but I don't think Firestone was even two or three," Mr. Lache said. He pointed to increased competition in the market for sport utilities and trucks, declining quality and the fact that Mr. Nasser "alienated many people with the choices he made, even if they were well intentioned." 
Mr. Reynolds of the Ford National Dealer Council said Mr. Nasser "did a fantastic job on the Firestone thing."
It was all the varied initiatives that took the focus off building good Ford cars that troubled the dealers, he said. 
"I wouldn't have said a word," he added, "if we had kept our house in order."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED -- AN OVERVIEW: OCT. 31, 2001; 
Plan for More G.I.'s on the Ground, Economic Slump, Anthrax Unease

BYLINE:  By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
 The United States shifted gears in its military campaign against Osama bin Laden and his Taliban protectors. Officials said that more teams of American advisers will be slipped into Afghanistan to work with rebel militias like the anti-Taliban Northern Alliance.

MORE HELP ON THE GROUND -- With some United States allies beginning to squirm at the relatively slow pace of events, the Pentagon seemed newly determined to help the rebels seize territory rather than leaving them to their own devices. Some American teams were already on the ground, and military officers credited them with allowing warplanes, especially warhorse B-52 bombers, to hit their targets with much greater precision.
 The latest bombings were called the most intense to date against Taliban forces in the field. Air strikes hit them both north and south, including Kandahar, the Taliban stronghold. One target in the round-the-clock operation was a building where Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Taliban leader, had been recently seen. Whether he stuck around for the bombs was not clear, though.
Taliban officials said that a nearby Red Crescent dispensary was hit, and they took foreign journalists (with women conspicuously uninvited) to inspect the damage. But there was no way to tell if anyone had been killed there, let alone the 11 people the Taliban said had died in the attack. The tour also did not include a hospital visit that might have shed light on how many were wounded, if any.
Some elements of this young war -- B-52's, the arrival of American advisers, Pentagon warnings about a tough and resourceful enemy -- carried echoes of the Vietnam War. So did the unhappy word "quagmire," which has entered some conversations in Washington and in European capitals. No one ever promised anything but a difficult fight against terrorism, administration officials said. Still, there were signs of European unease with the course of the war, even among staunch American allies like the Conservative Party in Britain.

CONTRACTING ECONOMY -- At home, to amend a famous remark by former President Gerald R. Ford, our long national sweet dream is over. Government figures confirmed what most people suspected: the longest economic expansion in the country's history seemed finished, and the Sept. 11 attacks had played a part.
From July to September, the economy shrank for the first time in more than eight years, at an annual rate of 0.4 percent. An accepted view among experts was that terrorism pushed an already-tottering economy over the brink. If that news wasn't grim enough, some analysts predicted that the last three months of 2001 would fare even worse. Indeed, times are tough all over, not just in the United States. "The global economy is slipping precariously toward recession," the World Bank warned.
For President Bush, the sorry statistics offered an opportunity to demand that Congress break a partisan deadlock and pass an economic recovery package before the end of November. The Republican-controlled House has approved a $99 billion stimulus plan, but the Democrats in charge of the Senate dismiss it as top-heavy with corporate tax cuts they deem ineffectual. Any package that they endorse, the Democrats told Mr. Bush, must include expanded unemployment benefits and money to help laid-off workers keep their health insurance. In turn, the Republicans bristled at the extra government spending. Simply put, the vaunted bipartisan spirit of the last seven weeks, while not tattered, seemed frayed at the edges.

ANTHRAX DREAD -- On the anthrax front, hope was in short supply. A 61-year-old New Yorker, Kathy T. Nguyen, died several days after becoming infected with inhalation anthrax, the most lethal form. She was the fourth fatality -- the others were in Washington and Florida -- and especially troubling was the mystery surrounding how she caught the germ.
Virtually all the other anthrax victims fell into a pattern. They were either government employees, notably postal workers, or they handled mail in the offices of news organizations. But Ms. Nguyen worked in the stockroom at Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital. Because she was too ill to speak, it is not known what happened to her, and because she lived alone, investigators had a hard time retracing her steps.
So there were only questions. Did she have contact with tainted mail, somehow, somewhere? Or, more worrisome from a public-health vantage, was she a harbinger of a new and scary turn in the anthrax threat? CLYDE HABERMAN

HEADLINE: Justice Department and Microsoft Are Seen in Tentative Settlement 

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON with STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 

 BODY:
The Justice Department and the Microsoft Corporation have reached a tentative agreement to settle the long-running antitrust suit against the company, people involved in the talks said today.
 The proposed agreement, some details of which were being resolved late this evening, was presented by Charles A. James, the assistant attorney general in charge of the antitrust division, to a group of state attorneys general meeting in Washington for their consideration. In meetings expected to last through the evening, the state officials were pressing the Bush administration to impose tougher conditions on Microsoft than it had proposed. State officials were also assessing whether they would agree to a deal or break with the Justice Department and try to upset the preliminary agreement. 
 The agreement, which came after three weeks of mediation, cannot become effective unless it is approved by a federal court. Rival companies and consumer groups said tonight that they were certain to oppose it as ineffective.
A crucial issue is whether the 18 states that joined the Microsoft suit can be persuaded to agree to any settlement or will oppose it. The states have taken the hardest line against Microsoft, especially after the Bush administration inherited the case. An earlier effort under the Clinton administration to settle the case was scuttled under pressure from the states.
The tentative settlement calls for a five-year consent decree between the government and Microsoft governing the company's conduct, according to people involved in the talks, with the possibility of a two-year extension if the company violates the agreement. To try to ensure enforcement, a three-member advisory committee of independent experts would be set up.
But the people involved in the talks said some state officials were dissatisfied with the proposed settlement because it did not have adequate enforcement mechanisms. They were also concerned that the deal would not effectively prevent Microsoft from leveraging its monopoly in the operating systems market into computer servers and hand-held devices.
As part of the deal, Microsoft has agreed to eliminate restrictive contract terms and pricing deals with personal computer makers that in the past have effectively left the manufacturers little choice but to favor Microsoft products over rival software.
In theory, such a settlement would restrain Microsoft's use of its monopoly power and foster increased competition in the software business, thus benefiting consumers and the economy.
A Justice Department spokeswoman, Gina Talamona, declined to comment on the settlement talks.
Some of the states in the antitrust case, according to people involved in the talks, and Microsoft's competitors are concerned that the Justice Department has been moving toward too narrow a settlement. The opponents say any deal would have only limited effect on Microsoft's monopoly power and its ability to use its market power to gain an unfair advantage in the new markets of Internet services and commerce, from online shopping to music.
In pursuing a settlement, the Bush administration appears to have rejected proposals made recently by some Microsoft rivals, consumer groups and industry groups for other sanctions against the company. The recommendations, presented in papers and in meetings with Justice Department officials, included requiring Microsoft to "unbundle" software products like its Internet browser and media player from the Windows operating system; forcing Microsoft to place its browsing software in the public domain; and requiring licensing of Microsoft's monopoly product, Windows, to other companies that want to combine it with their products.
The intent of each of these industry proposals would be to make it more difficult for Microsoft to use its market power from Windows as a lever to gain advantage over rivals in new markets. Microsoft has strenuously resisted such steps, saying they would constitute an unwarranted confiscation of its intellectual property and inhibit the company's right to design its products as it sees fit.
The states are a party to this latest round of settlement talks, begun three weeks ago and overseen by a court-appointed mediator, Eric D. Green, a Boston University law professor.
If the states reject the deal, they can challenge it when it is presented to the federal court for public hearings, as required under the law. They can also attempt to continue their antitrust lawsuits against the company, although that could become difficult as a matter of legal procedure if the federal judge accepts the settlement first. California announced last week that it was retaining Brendan Sullivan, a prominent trial lawyer, on behalf of the 18 states in the Microsoft case. That move was widely seen as foreshadowing of a possible split between the Justice Department and the states.
The most significant element in the settlement proposal, industry executives said, is the requirement that Microsoft share the technical information needed for other software or hardware products to work smoothly with Windows. Microsoft's Windows runs on 400 million desktops today, and it interacts with multitudes of other software and devices. That list includes big data-serving computers and software made by I.B.M., Sun Microsystems and Hewlett-Packard, hand-held devices made by Palm and Handspring, and all kinds of software that runs on top of Windows, from AOL's online service to Real Networks' media player.
In the antitrust case, Microsoft was found to have used technical information or the threat of withholding such information to protect its monopoly and disadvantage competitors. Requiring the company to share that technical information, industry executives say, could protect competition -- if effectively carried out and enforced.
Under the settlement proposal, Microsoft would be required to make that information available in a "secure facility," where representatives of software makers, computer manufacturers and others deemed qualified could study the Windows programming code and ask questions.
Carrying out the technology-sharing provision remains one of the sticking points in the settlement talks. The government wants to make sure it is effective, while Microsoft wants to make sure it can protect its intellectual property.
Previous attempts to resolve the case through settlement talks have met with stiff resistance from the states, industry rivals and consumer groups. They regard the consent decree that Microsoft signed with the Justice Department in 1994 as ineffective and easily sidestepped by the company.
"The issue is that Microsoft should not be allowed to use its Windows monopoly as a vehicle for dominating other markets," said Ken Wasch, president of the Software and Information Industry Association, a trade group with many Microsoft rivals as members.
Mr. Wasch, who has met with Justice Department officials four times in the last two months, said: "The one thing that is clear is that they want remedies that are going to work. But a settlement has to be comprehensive because there is no single silver bullet that is going to solve this problem."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; 
Technology Shares Rebound, With the Nasdaq Up 22.79

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
Desperate for good news, the stock market at first rallied yesterday after the Commerce Department reported that the nation's gross domestic product declined in the third quarter, but less than Wall Street economists and analysts had feared.
 Most of the gains, though, proved to be fleeting. "It's the kind of a market that's more of a wait-and-see type thing than anything else," said John O'Donoghue, co-head of listed trading at Credit Suisse First Boston. "There's no theme or huge direction one way or the other. The market is range-bound, and it will move up or down not on fundamentals, but based on hearsay and rumors. It's either a trader's paradise or a trader's nightmare." 
 Technology stocks, hurt the two previous days, managed to hold on to some of their early gains, and the Nasdaq composite index closed up 22.79 points, or 1.37 percent, at 1,690.20.
But the Dow Jones industrial average, which was up 100 points in early trading, closed down 46.84 points, or 0.51 percent, at 9,075.14. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index ended virtually unchanged, down 0.01 point, at 1,059.78. 
Market breadth was positive, with 1,940 issues higher and 1,182 lower on the New York Stock Exchange. Volume was 1.367 million shares.
Investors initially took hope from the economic data. From July to September, the gross domestic product -- the total value of goods and services in the United States -- shrank at an annual pace of 0.4 percent, the sharpest decline in a decade, the Commerce Department's report said. Economists had expected a decline of about 1 percent. The decrease in consumer and business spending reflected some of the effects of the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, although they occurred late in the third quarter.
In addition, the National Association of Purchasing Management in Chicago said its October index fell to 46.2 from 46.6 in September, a drop far smaller than to the 43.0 level some economists had expected. 
"It's a pleasant surprise that both the Chicago purchasing management index and the third-quarter G.D.P. were not as bad as expected," said Jack Shaughnessy, chief investment strategist at Advest. "It really just underscores how the market responds to good news or the lack of bad news."
Moderate interest in technology stocks was sustained in part by Sun Microsystems, which said that sales for its second fiscal quarter were still expected to be higher than in the first quarter. The company's shares rose 61 cents, to $10.15.
Some big computer-related stocks ended mixed. Microsoft fell 73 cents, to $58.15; Dell Computer closed up 74 cents, at $23.98; and I.B.M. declined 58 cents, to $108.07. 
Semiconductor and related stocks advanced briskly, with Intel up 88 cents, to $24.42; Maxim Integrated Products up $2.59, to $45.75; Xilinx up $2.04, to $30.42; and Linear Technology up $2.46, to $38.80. Texas Instruments, despite forecasting a decline in its fourth-quarter revenue, rose 72 cents, to $27.99. The Philadelphia Stock Exchange's semiconductor index climbed 18.34 points, or 4.27 percent, to 448.02.
Communications equipment stocks were modestly higher, with Cisco Systems gaining 35 cents, to $16.92; Qualcomm up 43 cents, to $49.12; and JDS Uniphase adding 20 cents, to $7.99.
But Qwest Communications fell $3.05, to $12.95. The company posted a third-quarter loss on lower-than-expected revenue and warned that it would fall short of analysts' projections this quarter.
The Dow industrials were pulled down in large part by Eastman Kodak, which fell $2.23, to $25.57. Moody's Investors Service on Tuesday cut its debt rating for Kodak and warned it may lower the long-term rating again because of weak profits.
Among other Dow stocks, Philip Morris fell 90 cents, to $46.80, and Alcoa fell 75 cents, to $32.27.
