PERSON: William M. Smith 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
Union Chief's Battle Is With the Postal Service

BYLINE:  By ROBIN FINN 

 BODY:
WILLIAM M. SMITH, president of the New York Metro Area Postal Union, squints hard behind his aviator glasses and confirms that disgruntled is just the half of what he's feeling these days. George W. Bush is not, he huffs, the only president at war with "evildoers." 
 Middle-aged but hanging tough to a middle linebacker's frame that took him as far as semipro ball with the Philadelphia Bulldogs before the draft got him in 1968, Mr. Smith, a bearded brimstone Baptist, Sunday deacon and ex-Carolina farmhand, suspects he has a sort of jihad on his hands. 
 His enemy? Make that enemies. First, the United States Postal Service: Mr. Smith, 57, is suing his perennial foe, alleging that it is undermining the safety of its city employees. Also the United States government, and now those wishy-washy physicians at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. "They've changed their tune 50 times," he complains of their much-revised anthrax policy. Rain, snow, heat, gloom: Mr. Smith's constituency of 10,000 workers is sworn to slog through them all, but nobody ever mentioned anything about weathering anthrax. 
Ask him if he thinks the postmaster general, John E. Potter, has any kind of handle on making the mails safe for messengers and recipients and his scowl becomes a smirk. "He's one confused man. He doesn't know an apple from an orange." 
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the city's post-disaster guardian angel, has let Mr. Smith down, too. "He's on the side of the Postal Service!" he hollers. It is apparent that if you're not with President Smith, you're against him. Sounds familiar.
He doesn't mean to yell, yet wishes his interviewer would: in the heat of "the big battlefield" with the Postal Service, he hasn't had time to get new batteries for his hearing aid. (Both eardrums were punctured in Vietnam.) He hasn't had time to get to his doctor to have his sugar diabetes checked, or to take an anthrax test, either. He can't be in two places at once, and suing the government in federal court this week to shut down the contaminated Morgan Station, where four sorting machines tested positive for anthrax last week, takes precedence. 
Nor has he had time to open the mail in his studiedly impersonal office at 350 West 31st Street -- bare walls, zero memorabilia, a banquet-sized desk completely covered by neatly stacked paperwork. Hence the postal pileup on a circular table where two union workers wearing see-through blue gloves are attempting to reduce the clutter. Some is pressing business, some not. 
There's even "junk mail" (his description) addressed to his predecessor, Josie McMillan, ousted by Mr. Smith in 1999 after a challenge that began in 1997 and went to court in 1998. Mr. Smith sold the last of his family property in Scotland Neck, N.C., to come up with the $13,000 required to finance his campaign. After running on an anti-fat-cat, anti-establishment platform, the first thing he did was cut the presidential salary from $142,000 to $95,000.
"The president of the union is nothing but a servant," asserts Mr. Smith, a postal worker since 1976. (He was in maintenance, never a mail carrier.) "I made $47,000 when I was on the work floor, and if I can't live off $95,000, then I need to starve."
MORNINGS he hauls himself out of bed in pitch blackness in Linden, N.J., where he lives with his wife, Barbara, catches the 4:36, clocks in by 5:15, runs a quick broom across the employees' lounge if he spies any crumbs (he's a neatnik), then puts on protective gloves and a surgical mask before getting a jump on his correspondence. That last bit is a recent addition to his routine. 
"I don't take chances," he deadpans. "The Postal Service might send some anthrax to me, the way they hate my guts."
Even before the machines at Morgan tested positive for anthrax spores, Mr. Smith demanded that the station be shut down. He has advised Morgan's 5,500 workers not to report until their building is certified anthrax-free and scoffed at the Postal Service's offer to supply 7,000 employees with antibiotics without first testing them for anthrax exposure. So far, there have been no reports of a Morgan employee testing positive. He claims the economics of keeping open a station that moves 12 million pieces of mail daily is taking precedence over human lives. 
"I realize that Morgan employees are not Supreme Court justices or senators or Congress, but they are God's children; they have the same right to life as the a-ris-to-crats," he says, each syllable a mini-indictment. "No one piece of mail is worth a human life." 
Mr. Smith grew up poor in rural North Carolina, where his grandparents owned the family farm and his father hired out as a sharecropper. There was always more work than money. He hoed the fields at age 6, and by 12 tended the livestock, hogs and cattle; he remembers winning blue ribbons at the local 4-H fairs with his cows. His mother was a disciplinarian who thumped more than just her Bible. "Spare the rod, spoil the child; she believed that," he says.
After high school, he followed his older brothers to New Jersey, stoked the furnaces in a refinery, played football whenever and wherever. He was closing in on a pro tryout when the Army sent him to Vietnam. Injured three times, he came home after nine months with scars and a medical discharge. He joined the postal system in Jersey City at the behest of the Veterans Administration; he recalls it as a "take the job or lose your benefits proposition." 
He took it.

HEADLINE: Tough Economic Times Ahead 

 BODY:
Yesterday President Bush bluntly encouraged Congress to "get to work" on an economic stimulus package and bring a bill to his desk by the end of this month. The matter is indeed urgent, and the combination of quick action by Congress and steady rates from the Federal Reserve offer the best hope for turning the economy around.
 Gross domestic product shrank by 0.4 percent in the third quarter of this year. That performance was better than most analysts expected, but still the worst in a decade. The economy is probably contracting even faster now, and the recovery many had hoped to see by year's end is not likely to arrive until well into 2002. 
 During most of this year, consumers were the engine that propelled the economy while businesses drew down inventories and pared unneeded output. Yet even before Sept. 11 that lone pillar had started to crumble. Personal bankruptcies reportedly jumped in August. Late payments and write-offs of credit card debt had been rising for seven months.
The trend will almost certainly continue, since the terrorist attacks alone may have drained as many as 500,000 jobs from the economy. Companies not directly affected by Sept. 11, including almost all the telecom giants, have also let thousands of workers go. Claims for unemployment benefits have reached levels not seen since 1991.
Those lost jobs and security fears sank consumers' confidence to its lowest level in seven years last month. Even without worrying about anthrax or hijackings, consumers would still be facing disheartening signs. Credit-rating firms expect a rash of bankruptcies among transport, travel and leisure companies over the next few months. Industrial production shows no sign of ending its long decline. Another potential problem is the housing market. Home sales fell more than expected last month, and further slackness would bring down prices. Because housing makes up the lion's share of most Americans' wealth, lower home values would badly hurt their willingness to commit to new spending.
The Federal Reserve can best help the economy with a long period of loose credit at stable rates. Short-term rates have already been cut drastically. If the Fed signals its intention to keep rates steady after any action at next Tuesday's meeting, it would encourage long-term interest rates to fall. That could enliven the housing market and make consumers more eager to purchase big-ticket items. 
For maximum effect, Washington's fiscal stimulus package should target those most in need, who are most likely to spend any money they receive from the federal government. Yesterday the president rightly called for rebates for low-income tax filers, expanded unemployment benefits and aid for laid-off workers who want to keep their health insurance. Help for the jobless who do not qualify for benefits, or whose companies did not offer health insurance, would also be welcome.

HEADLINE: Bloomberg Stresses Private Business As Key to Revival 

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

 BODY:
Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city's looming financial crisis, while serious, was not unmanageable and that private businesses, not aid from the federal government, would ultimately determine how well the city comes through it.
 Mr. Bloomberg, the Republican nominee for mayor, referred repeatedly to his experience running Bloomberg L.P., the big communications company that he founded in 1981, as his main preparation for the top job at City Hall. 
 In a breakfast interview with reporters and editors of The New York Times, Mr. Bloomberg frequently framed his view of New York City and its problems through the constructs of a successful entrepreneur who would approach the mayor's work with pragmatism and salesmanship gleaned from private enterprise. 
At one point, he even spoke about "the message I am selling" when he compared his record with that of the public advocate, Mark Green, his Democratic opponent.
Among the city's richest residents, Mr. Bloomberg, who is 59, spoke about his first attempt to enter public service in the context of some of New York's most storied political families. He expressed surprise with people who have accused him of trying to buy the election with his private fortune, which is estimated in the billions. According to the most recent campaign finance filing, Mr. Bloomberg has spent a record $41 million on his campaign. "It was an obligation to do public service in those days," Mr. Bloomberg said. "I don't know that Harriman or Lehman or Rockefeller needed more publicity or needed prestige or status."
Though acknowledging that he did not always communicate skillfully, he said he was taken aback by criticism of his candidacy in the news media. He said his campaign had been greeted with more suspicion than good will, unlike similar efforts by those other wealthy men from an earlier era.
"You asked what I've learned," he said. "What I haven't quite figured out is why I believe that the scrutiny of my campaign and everything I say has been different."
He went on to say, "And somehow or other, we're getting -- trying to turn it around where anybody that is willing to go and take time out of their lives to do something for others is -- vilified, isn't quite the right word -- but is looked at with suspicion and questioning their motives."
Citing the open-door policy at his company (Mr. Bloomberg and other executives there have no private offices), he pledged that his administration at City Hall would be accessible to the public and would be candid about everything from anthrax infections to possible cutbacks in the municipal work force.
"I would err on the side of disclosure," he said. "I've always done it in my company; I've always done it in my life."
Mr. Bloomberg provided some clues about what his style of mayoral management might be like. He indicated that he would rely heavily on the advice and expertise of people holding the city's highest-level jobs. In the recent case of anthrax found at a postal center, for example, he said he would not second-guess decisions made by the health authorities about whether to close it.
"You have professionals there to assess the risks and make decisions," he said. "That's what you have experts for. And if all of us think that we have the detailed knowledge, you're just wrong."
Mr. Bloomberg revealed the names of a few people that he would like to appoint to important posts at City Hall. Those included Bernard B. Kerik, the police commissioner; Edward Skyler, his campaign press secretary, and Patricia E. Harris, who oversees philanthropic operations at Bloomberg L.P.
He also mentioned Raymond W. Kelly, who was police commissioner under Mayor David N. Dinkins and commissioner of the United States Customs Service in the Clinton administration, as one of his advisers.
But he said he did not expect to bring many business executives into city government.
"You are not going to get a lot of people from the private sector," he said. "Private-sector people tend to have a lifestyle that they could not continue to support in the public sector."
In discussing the city's economic forecast, Mr. Bloomberg said he doubted that the city and state would get much more than the $20 billion in emergency relief already approved by Washington for New York, Virginia and Pennsylvania. But he did not criticize Gov. George E. Pataki's request for $53 billion or second-guess the governor for seeking the larger amount.
He predicted that beyond money for cleanup and transit repairs, the city would have to depend on private financing for most projects.
"I don't want to be a pessimist, but I think you have to be realistic," he said. "When it comes to rebuilding, that is much more likely to be done with insurance company money and with insurance payoff for the damage done, and with other private investment."
He also said it was unrealistic to expect the financial services industry to serve as the anchor of a revitalized downtown. Until new businesses are recruited, he said, reconstruction is unlikely.
"Nobody is going to build buildings on spec," he said. "You've got to find an industry that is going to be willing to go to the site, and they are going to have to sign leases before people start building."
Though he prefaced his remarks by saying there was really no way of knowing what next year might bring, Mr. Bloomberg appeared less pessimistic about the depth of the city's financial crisis than did Mr. Green in an interview on Tuesday. Mr. Bloomberg said next year's deficit would probably be comparable to the deficits of the early 1990's. Mr. Green had referred to the 1970's, when the city experienced its worst financial problems and nearly went bankrupt.
"I don't think we should declare bankruptcy, throw up our hands and say there's no solution to this problem," he said.
In coming up with suggestions about dealing with the expected deficit, Mr. Bloomberg said there would be a municipal hiring freeze that would apply to all city employees, including teachers, police officers and firefighters.
In some areas of law enforcement, he said, greater use of technology, like video surveillance cameras in parks, would help make up for the lack of additional police officers. But he left no opening for hiring more police.
Instead, he said the city's payroll should be directed at increasing the wages of those people already working for the city so that they do not leave for jobs in private business. He said he was particularly worried about losing police officers.
"My first priority would be to try to protect those that are already working for the city under the theory that they're the ones that can work you out of the problem," he said. "I think that you have to pay them more, but the savings have got to come through efficiencies and attrition. Because there just isn't any more money."
In that regard, Mr. Bloomberg said that he expected the city's unions to cooperate with his cost-cutting efforts because they realize there is nowhere else for the budget to give. 
He indicated that despite Mr. Green's long list of union endorsements, the union leadership privately recognizes that he would be a better mayor because "they need good management" in city government.
"I don't suggest for a second you're going to get very many labor leaders to look you in the eye and say that, and agree to that," he said. "But I think deep down inside that is the case."
Mr. Bloomberg, who trails Mr. Green in the polls, predicted that he would be elected the next mayor because voters recognized that Mr. Green's "experience in government is not germane to this job."
"I believe that the public is becoming convinced that the job retention and creation, the managing a city budget, providing security is best done by somebody with managerial and leadership experience," he said.

HEADLINE: Sizing Up Budget Cuts and Answering Criticism About Experience 

 BODY:
 Following are excerpts from an interview with Michael R. Bloomberg, the Republican mayoral candidate, conducted yesterday by reporters and editors of The New York Times. 

Q. If you're mayor of New York today, what are you telling the city about anthrax?

MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG -- We have to depend on the federal government for most of our information. We have to better coordinate with the federal government. We will keep you posted. In the meantime, go about your lives. We are taking the appropriate measures. Then, of course, we have to make sure that the city and the federal government are taking the appropriate actions. But in terms of the outreach to the public, you should not be -- but the problem you have is you don't have a lot of information. The public has a right to know. And the balance between cautioning them and urging them to exercise prudence in terms of what to look for in their day-in and day-out lives, has to be balanced with the potential to scare people so badly that they start staying home, not participating, not going on with a normal life. . . .

Q. Given that anthrax was found, and traces of it were found at the Morgan postal station here in Manhattan, do you think it should have been shut down?

MR. BLOOMBERG -- I'm not in a position to make that judgment, and I don't think any outsider is. You have professionals there to assess the risks and make decisions. That's not -- that's what you have experts for. And if all of us think that we have the detailed knowledge, you're just wrong.

Q. But say if you were the mayor today and you ----

MR. BLOOMBERG -- It's a federal facility, No. 1. . . . So I don't think the mayor can walk in and say the post office should be closed. . . . You certainly want to talk to the federal government and assure yourself that the federal government is taking what steps that they think are appropriate, because the mayor is going to be on television communicating with the public. But in terms of running the post office, in terms of tracking down anthrax in the post office, that's what we have professionals for. And if you have absolutely no confidence in them, then maybe we should replace them. But you can't sit there and second-guess every single security decision. I am in favor of disclosure to the public right up to the point where, for valid security reasons, in the middle of an ongoing investigation, you have to say government does withhold certain information. . . .

Q. The city that you inherit if you win this election is headed for all kinds of financial trouble. What should New Yorkers expect about their government?

MR. BLOOMBERG -- Well, No. 1, nobody's really sure how serious the economic downturn, how protracted it is going to be. Some facts are already in. Commercial vacancies in midtown are going up, and downtown it's a little bit harder to measure because of the severity of the disaster. But there's an enormous amount of space downtown. The great danger that we face is companies deciding just to leave, and the collateral damage, if you will, of any kind of downturn, particularly companies leaving, on small businesses. The people that are really getting hurt here -- and I'll come back to this -- are small companies where, when they can't withstand a temporary economic downturn, they lay off people. . . . But for the city as a whole, sales tax down, personal income tax down, companies leaving. Next year, Office of Management and Budget says $2.3 billion deficit. There are numbers in the paper . . . 4 billion, 6 billion. The bottom line is that nobody knows. Some things are coming back quicker than forecast, and some things are just not. . . .

Q. Is it possible the city is inflating or hyping the number to try to make a better case in Washington? You think that's what's going on?

MR. BLOOMBERG -- Well, the city always underestimates revenues because they have to negotiate with the unions. So there is that. I think that the outlook for federal aid is problematic. . . . I don't think we should declare bankruptcy, throw up our hands and say there's no solution to this problem. You cannot raise taxes. That is clear. If you raise taxes you will drive enough business and people out of this city. Your total tax revenues over a period of time would probably decline rather than go up. There are some efficiencies you can get. But the city is not so poorly run that there are enormous pockets of corruption or waste that you can say well better management will cut back. Yes, in a $40 billion budget you can certainly cut some things. You can find some efficiencies. And I've thought what you do is you have to get the unions involved in some kind of a saving-sharing plan where -- because other than that you will not get the cooperation you need. But you can do that to some extent. And there are also some revenue sources that we haven't tapped. If you could get the federal government to change the law, which you might be able to do, actually, so that we can refinance our debt more than once, we can save a little over $100 million in just that. . . . But then you get down to the either-or. We've got to go and say that if we don't have the money, we have to cut back what we're spending. And cutting back what we're spending . . . where half of it is in salaries and pension, there's just no question what has to give. . . .
My first priority would be to try to protect those that are already working for the city under the theory that they're the ones that can work you out of the problem. They are the ones you really need to have cooperate. And they are the ones we should have loyalty to. . . . And you put a hiring freeze in to try to hope that attrition will cut it down. . . . 

Q. So you think the teachers and firefighters and police should also be subject to a hiring freeze and salary freeze?

MR. BLOOMBERG -- . . . If you don't apply it to them, what are you talking about? . . . I think that you have to pay them more, but the savings have got to come through efficiencies and attrition. Because there just isn't any more money. But you have to stop the loss of the work force that you need. When it comes to teachers, probably the most disruptive thing in a classroom is the loss of the teacher in midyear. It would be nice to have smaller classroom sizes. We don't have enough wherewithal to keep the existing classroom size. So, you know, saying you'd like it is great. But you have to be realistic about what you can afford. And teachers are leaving . . . after two, three years because the job is very tough. They don't feel they get support, and they don't make enough money to live. And a young person, in the end, will want to go and say, "I've done my teaching for a while. I'd love to continue, I love kids, but I can get a job in the commercial sector." And that is also -- that exact same phenomenon is going to devastate the Police Department unless we do something. The police pension system is designed to force you out if you have a very good year. And the overhead this year -- the overtime this year -- is going to create an enormous incentive for anybody with experience that's been there a long time to go and to leave at the very same time that the demand on the commercial side for police officers is skyrocketing. What's the one business that everybody wants to hire people? The one part of their operation? Security. What better than hiring an N.Y.P.D.-trained guy with 20 years? So we're going to have a very big problem. . . .

Q. Your company is a privately owned company. You've talked about how you might distance yourself from that company once you're mayor. Could you talk a little bit about that?

MR. BLOOMBERG -- Just don't go -- I mean I'll put it in the private trust. . . . But short of that, we don't do any business to the city. I don't know what else I can do. As Mark Green said, he can't get rid of his brother. But you know, maybe he'd like to. I mean you put it in the private trust. We don't do business with the city other than it is a taxpayer in the city. There is no other contact. . . . I don't see any real conflict any more or less than me as a taxpayer in the city. I mean even if I were to sell it, I'm still going to be a taxpayer in the city. You just disclose what you're doing. . . .
What I haven't quite figured out is why -- I believe that the scrutiny of my campaign and everything I say has been different. You know, if you go back, it used to be that it was people were encouraged to go from private service to public service -- Leahman, Harriman, Rockefeller. It was an obligation to do public service in those days. And some how or other, we're getting -- trying to turn it around where anybody that is willing to go and take time out of their lives to do something for others is -- vilified isn't quite the right word -- but is looked at with suspicion and questioning their motives. I don't know that Harriman or Leahman or Rockefeller needed more publicity or needed prestige or status. That's not why they went into public service. . . . And I think more people should do it. I said from Day 1, somebody asked me at the beginning, why did you go into public service? And I said, everybody I've ever met who had worked in public service for a period -- whether I thought they were successful or not -- they all, when they recalled those days, had a gleam in their eye that they had done something wonderful. That they were a part of making government and the system and our civilization better. And I said back then, I had never had that experience. And that's more than anything what I wanted. I wanted the chance to go and do it. And I had the ability to do it. Why not go do it?

Q. But are you saying that you're being subjected to closer scrutiny?

MR. BLOOMBERG -- Well, everybody is fixated on where my money comes from. Just go take a look at where -- whatever candidate I happen to be running against -- where his money comes from. I don't see any stories about all that. Not any. But there are not a lot about sources of money and potential conflicts. You ask about the potential conflict with my company . . . and yet you don't focus on conflicts that others have where they take funds, refuse to disclose who even works for him. . . .

Q. I know this is not exactly what you're talking about when you talk about a closer scrutiny, but I have to ask you what your reaction is to this women in the workplace stuff that has bubbled up. Do you see that as an example of what you're talking about? And what's your reaction to that?

MR. BLOOMBERG -- We, in 20 years, have a record that I don't think you will ever find a company can match.

Q. Not we, I think probably you personally is what this stuff has been bubbling up about, isn't it?

MR. BLOOMBERG -- Well, it's just before the election, all of a sudden stuff bubbles up. I think you've got to put in perspective. Hopefully, the public understands that that's, you know, that's the same thing that happened in the runoff. At the last moment, all of a sudden, things come out, stories are spread, rumors are promoted.

Q. Are you saying it's not true?

MR. BLOOMBERG -- Oh no, no. I think that the case that you're talking about -- The Village Voice piece?

Q. Yes.

MR. BLOOMBERG -- The Village Voice piece was plain and simple. One of our employees alleged an event had taken place a year and a half before. Our H.R. department -- run by a woman who I have an enormous amount of confidence in, she's as professional as you can find -- tried to investigate. The complainant would not cooperate. There was a lot of evidence to the contrary. She then without ever talking to us filed a lawsuit. And the judge dismissed it with no evidence whatsoever. The story -- I haven't read it, but what was told to me -- the story in the Village Voice is they take one line out of a deposition, which if asked that -- I forget exactly how the question was phrased, but if you're asked what is the -- do you automatically believe any allegation? No, you have to -- everybody has rights. And you try to do a fair investigation. I didn't personally do it, our H.R. department did. And as I said, as far as I remember checking, they did exactly what was appropriate, exactly what was advised by all of the consultants that we use to ensure that we are a company where everybody can work safely and happily together. And the judge thought it was ridiculous.
But, you know, could I have made -- if you ask what you could do differently -- I suppose if I were running for office, I just would have paid some money up front even though we did nothing wrong. But I don't know how I would have lived with myself. We did nothing wrong, and we conducted ourselves honorably. . . . I couldn't be prouder of the ways that we have conducted ourselves and the environment that we have created for our employees. And the fact that we have 8,000 people and 100 offices and have less than 10 percent turnover says that it's a pretty good place to work. And what we do is appropriate. I don't know what else you can say to those things.

 CORRECTION:
A transcript of excerpts yesterday from an interview with Michael R. Bloomberg, the Republican mayoral candidate, misspelled the surname of a former New York governor he cited as a politician who moved from private business to public service. It was Herbert H. Lehman, not Leahman.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE WORLD ECONOMY; 
Entangled With War on Terror, Threat of Global Recession

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 

 BODY:
For seven weeks now, President Bush has been preoccupied with managing a global war on terrorism. With the announcement today that the American economy shrank in the third quarter, he is faced with managing another complex and often intertwined crisis: The prospect of a global recession.
 The world's two largest economies -- the United States and Japan -- are in simultaneous retreat. Germany appears headed into the same morass, and Europe's growth is paltry. And one of the chief lessons of the 1990's, when successive economic crises rippled quickly around the world, was a simple one: the weakest economies are often the first pushed off the edge of the cliff. 
 So it is notable that in Pakistan, America's uneasy ally, exports to the developed world have nearly ground to a stop. Plunging world output means lower oil prices, which mean trouble for the Middle East, especially Saudi Arabia. At the Asian summit meeting in Shanghai 10 days ago, the hallways were filled with speculation about whether economic downturn could worsen social unrest, particularly in the Islamic world.
"This is a global recession, and the worst is yet to come," said Allen Sinai, the chief global economist of Decision Economics in Boston, who advises global corporations on trouble in the offing. "The stresses will be felt the most in the developing world and the emerging markets, which are the most fragile, and where frustrated workers and their governments will be looking for scapegoats. And you can see that the leading scapegoat is already the United States."
That may be unfair. In stronger times, the American economy pulled the world out of three major economic jolts in the last seven years, the first originating in Mexico, the second in Asia, the third in Russia. 
But in global economics, like global politics, perception is everything. And as one of Mr. Bush's senior foreign policy advisers noted a few days ago, the fact that America is no longer sucking in the world's goods the way it once did is making it "far harder for us to offer the salve of economic good times." 
How that plays into the politics of keeping together the fragile counterterrorism coalition is anyone's guess. But consider what has happened in recent days with Pakistan. Mr. Bush's foreign policy aides want to cut tariffs on Pakistan's main product, textiles. But the effort is hung up here, after complaints by American companies that they are already being savaged by the downturn, and that Mr. Bush should not be putting American workers out of jobs to keep his coalition together. The result is stalemate.
Mr. Bush has not uttered the words "global recession," and he has insisted that what is good for America -- quick Congressional passage of an economic stimulus package, and new authority for him to negotiate trade agreements -- will be good for the world. He may be right. But what is missing is a coordinated, global approach to what increasingly looks like a three-continent recession, a sharp departure from the way similar downturns have been dealt with in the past.
That is particularly worrisome because the evidence now is that the bad news will get worse and that America's troubles will spread. That message was reinforced today by the World Bank, which issued a troubling report about where things are headed.
"As 2001 draws to a close, the global economy is slipping precariously toward recession," the World Bank report said.
"The terrorist attacks in the United States, although it is still too early to evaluate them fully, have unleashed new and unpredictable forces that have substantially raised the risk of a global downturn." 
The crucial word there is "unpredictable." For if there was a lesson in the economic crises of the past few years, it was that a badly timed economic downturn could have both economic and political ramifications that no one could foresee.
At the State Department these days, some of those examining the staying power of the president of Pakistan, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, refer ominously to what they call "the Suharto factor" and wonder how it could play into Mr. Bush's war effort. When the Asian economic crisis started in 1997, President Suharto of Indonesia seemed like an unlikely victim. Yet once it became clear to his people that he had no control over the economy, his power base eroded rapidly. He was gone in months, and ever since there has been political chaos in Indonesia.
No one is predicting General Musharraf's fate. But in a world more attuned than ever to avoiding risk, Pakistan's export troubles, its political uncertainties and the bombing next door in Afghanistan may make it a poor choice for investors. So just as Mr. Bush is making the case that the new alliance with the United States can bring economic benefits for Pakistan, those benefits could be disappearing.
"You can lift sanctions and reduce tariffs every month," one of Mr. Bush's economic advisers said, "but under current conditions you can't convince Motorola, or anyone else, to build a plant."
Another unpredictable element of the equation is whether ordinary workers around the globe will blame their troubles on America either because it is bombing Afghanistan, or because it is not buying what they make. "Our slowdown has been exported," Jim Glassman, a senior economist for J. P. Morgan Chase, said today. "The irony is that the terrorist attack may boomerang worse for those who trade with us than for the United States itself."
Mr. Bush's other problem may be one of divided attention span. Even if his administration was more attuned to international economic trends, the need to conduct the war abroad and at home does not leave much time to think long and hard about how the economic problems of the United States, Japan and Europe may be feeding off one another, or radiating elsewhere around the globe. Moreover, this has never been Mr. Bush's favorite topic. Some other leaders at the Asian summit said they found Mr. Bush's arguments on terrorism to be impassioned and well grounded but that his discussion of the global economy was brief and shallow. 
But if the world is truly headed into a global recession, Mr. Bush may find that his current priority -- the war first and foremost -- may be involuntarily amended.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE PRESIDENT; 
Bush Sets Nov. 30 Deadline For Economic Stimulus Plan

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 

 BODY:
Confronted with the firmest evidence yet that the country has slipped into recession, President Bush demanded today that Congress break a partisan deadlock and send him an economic recovery package within the next month.
 Speaking to business executives at the White House after the government reported that the economy shrank in the third quarter -- the first quarterly downturn since 1993 -- Mr. Bush said he was "deeply concerned" about rising unemployment, declining consumer confidence and deteriorating business conditions. 
 "It's time for our government to act in a positive and constructive way," Mr. Bush said. "The Congress needs to pass a stimulus package and get it to my desk before the end of November." 
The president offered no new ideas about how to bridge the widening gap between Democrats and Republicans over how best to reverse a slowdown that began a year ago and intensified after the Sept. 11 attacks.
Instead, he used his speech to defend his approach, which is made up largely of tax cuts for individuals and businesses that Democrats have repeatedly rejected. Democrats said they would insist that any recovery plan be focused on helping low-income working people and the unemployed, proposals that Republicans have opposed as expensive and unwarranted expansions of government.
Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the majority leader, said he had told Mr. Bush at a breakfast this morning that his party would not compromise on its call for the package to center on expanded unemployment benefits and financial help to allow laid-off workers to maintain their health insurance.
"I think I would go so far as to say we will not pass a bill that does not address those two critical needs," Mr. Daschle said. 
Mr. Daschle said that with efforts to reach a bipartisan agreement not getting anywhere, he planned to try to bring a Democratic stimulus package to the floor next week.
Saying they feared that partisan differences might keep Congress from agreeing on any stimulus plan this year, a bipartisan group of centrist senators met today to see if they could develop a compromise.
They discussed a proposal to deal with the issue of health insurance for the unemployed in a way that would be acceptable to Democrats and Republicans alike. Their proposal would create a temporary tax credit that unemployed people could claim to pay for as much as half of their health insurance premiums, up to $110 a month for single people and $290 a month for families.
The plan is intended to assure Democrats that adequate money would be available to deal with the problem without raising objections from Republicans about creating a permanent new welfare program.
But administration officials signaled on Tuesday that Mr. Bush would probably veto any bill that included a Democratic proposal to subsidize health insurance premiums under an existing government program that allows laid-off workers to maintain employer-provided health coverage.
The Democratic proposal "was a huge reach and change in policy, putting the federal government into a position where it's now going to create a new entitlement class," Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said in an interview.
Democrats appeared intent on pressing forward, with the Senate Finance Committee set to take up the party's own proposal, introduced last week by Senator Max Baucus of Montana, the committee's chairman, as early as Tuesday.
Mr. Baucus's plan would provide $16 billion this year to expand unemployment insurance to many part-time workers, extend benefits 13 weeks beyond the current 26-week maximum and increase the weekly payments. The plan calls for $17 billion this year to pay half of health-insurance premiums for unemployed workers.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AID; 
U.S. Will Buy Asian Wheat to Give Afghans

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 31 

 BODY:
The Bush administration said today that it would spend $11.2 million on wheat and other food supplies from Central Asian countries for immediate shipment to Afghanistan to avert a worsening hunger crisis there. 
 With more than seven million people at risk of starvation, the United States Agency for International Development said it would buy $6 million in wheat from Kazakhstan through the United Nations' World Food Program rather than shipping wheat from the United States, which would take longer. 
 The rest of the aid package will be spent by other organizations on wheat and other commodities from Central Asian nations, also to be shipped to Afghanistan. 
The Office of Management and Budget had held up $50 million in disaster relief requested by the agency to buy food in the region, telling lawmakers that since the war was making it difficult to transport food into Afghanistan it would make little difference if relief groups waited for wheat from American farmers.
But lawmakers in Congress protested, saying the food was needed immediately and should be bought locally. Then last week, American warplanes bombed Red Cross warehouses outside Kabul for a second time, destroying enough food to feed 55,000 people for 200 days.
This morning, President Bush gave his final approval for the purchase of local wheat during a briefing by Andrew S. Natsios, the administrator for the Agency for International Development. 
"We're using every available means and every available route to get food to needy Afghans before the winter sets in," said Mr. Natsios after the meeting.
The money is part of the $320 million in aid promised by Mr. Bush.
Representative Jim Kolbe, Republican of Arizona, pushed the administration last week to buy local wheat, saying speed was of the essence if the administration was to keep its promise to feed the Afghan people while waging war.
"I'm glad it's happening," Mr. Kolbe said today. "It's a step in the right direction."
Officials of the domestic wheat industry supported the emergency food effort. 
"We do not oppose using U.S. funds to alleviate the immediate crisis in that manner," said Alan Tracy, president of U.S. Wheat Associates. "The needs of starving people come before any parochial concerns." 
The United States was the largest foreign aid donor to Afghanistan even before the Sept. 11 attacks, providing more than 80 percent of all of the food aid for Afghans through the World Food Program. 
"We would encourage the administration to make good on their generous commitment as quickly as possible," said George Devendorf, of Mercy Corps, an American relief organization working in Afghanistan and refugee camps on its borders. "We are on the clock here and delays will translate into lives." 
Even by buying wheat from Kazakhstan, relief groups will be hard pressed to transport the 28,000 metric tons of grain into the country. Banditry has become commonplace in the Taliban-controlled areas. And the bombing campaign has blocked access to some of the more remote areas.
But the Pentagon is working with relief groups to avoid further accidents like the bombing of Red Cross warehouse and to insure clearer routes into the country.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: BELT-TIGHTENING; 
Numbers Prove U.S. Economy Has Retreated

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
The longest economic expansion in American history has ended.
 The nation's economy shrank this summer for the first time in more than eight years, the government said yesterday, with businesses further cutting investment while consumers increased their purchases only slightly. The terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 played a key role, pushing an already-weak economy over the brink, analysts said, as travel temporarily stopped and spending briefly froze. 
 "The recession has begun," Stuart Hoffman, the chief economist of the PNC Financial Services Group in Pittsburgh, declared. "The fourth quarter will show an even deeper drop than the third quarter." 
President Bush, speaking to manufacturing executives yesterday, said the new evidence provided yet another reason for Washington to act quickly to pump money into the weakening economy. "People are having tough times in America," Mr. Bush said. "People are losing their jobs, and I'm concerned about that."
"My call to Congress is, get to work and get something done," he added. Page B6. 
In the three months that ended Sept. 30, the economy contracted at an annual rate of 0.4 percent, after adjusting for inflation. That is the only significant quarterly decline since early 1991, when the last recession ended, and the first drop other than a one-quarter downward blip of 0.1 percent in the spring of 1993.
While the nation will not officially be considered in a recession until the downturn has continued for another quarter, most analysts are now preparing obituaries for what turned out to be the broadest and most enduring expansion on record.
Ten years of essentially uninterrupted growth, including a boom in the second half of the 1990's, sent the stock market to record levels, pushed the unemployment rate to its lowest point in 30 years, produced unprecedented budget surpluses, and caused some starry-eyed executives and consultants to predict that recessions were a relic of the past.
In the last year, however, the economy has barely advanced, and few analysts believe healthy growth will return within the next few months because many companies still have more machines and employees than they can profitably use.
In hopes of shortening the downturn, the Republican-led House last week narrowly passed a $99 billion stimulus package, consisting mainly of tax cuts for businesses and more affluent taxpayers. Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill yesterday used the latest economic data to press the administration case for passing the stimulus measures.
But Democratic leaders in the Senate, who met with the president at the White House yesterday, say the House bill will not adequately stimulate the economy because many of the corporate tax cuts simply return money to companies, rather than providing them with new incentives to invest.
The Democrats hope to win Senate approval next week for their own plan, which would offer greater benefits to lower-income taxpayers and people who have lost their jobs.
The contraction in the third-quarter was less severe than the 1 percent rate of decline many analysts had expected. Stocks shrugged off the report.
Bond prices soared yesterday, but that was attributed to the Treasury Department's announcement that it would no longer issue 30-year bonds, causing investors to scramble to buy the existing supply. Page C1. 
Consumer spending -- which accounts for about two-thirds of gross domestic output -- rose slightly in the third quarter, as pre-Sept. 11 increases outweighed the fall after the attacks. Business investment in new buildings and equipment fell sharply, but not as dramatically as in the second quarter.
Still, the overall economic picture looked grim.
The value of exports and imports each fell more than 15 percent in the third quarter, for the first time since 1975, when all of the world's largest economies were struggling at once and companies were failing to find any healthy markets eager to buy their goods.
Since the beginning of 2000, the growth rate of consumer spending in the United States has fallen to a meager 1.2 percent from a robust 5 percent, as layoffs and falling stocks have left people with more worries and less money.
In the third quarter, spending on durable goods -- expensive, long-lasting items like cars and appliances -- grew just 1.7 percent, down from 7 percent in the previous quarter.
Even as consumers were cutting back, they received more income largely because of the tax rebates the government mailed over the summer. But most of that was saved rather than spent.
Meanwhile, business spending on equipment and software fell 11.8 percent in the third quarter, placing the level below where it was at the end of 1999. In the late 1990's, such spending was growing more than 10 percent a year. Most economists now blame companies' misplaced optimism and zealous overinvestment during the final years of the boom for the current collapse.
The rapid cutbacks do offer one potential bright spot, however, since many companies have already reduced their costs and excess stockpiles significantly, clearing the way for an eventual upturn. 
"We've had nothing but declining production, employment, wealth and living standards all year long," Steven Wieting, a senior economist at Salomon Smith Barney, said. "The only good news is that we're fairly far along in the process."
In all, the American economy produced $10.2 trillion worth of goods and services in the quarter, the Commerce Department said.
Most economists do not expect growth to resume until next year, with many predicting that it will be weak until at least the middle of 2002, according to a survey by Blue Chip Economic Indicators, a newsletter based in Kansas City, Mo.
The National Bureau of Economic Research, a group of academics based in Cambridge, Mass., is generally considered the official judge of the business cycle. With employment having peaked in March, some analysts believe that the bureau's recession-dating committee, when it eventually meets to review month-by-month data, will declare that a recession actually began before this summer.
Whatever the eventual date, the expansion of the last decade will surpass the previous record of eight years and two months in the 1960's.

HEADLINE: Even Now, A Skyline Of Twins 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
They were the two. But they were not the only.
While New York City lost its most famous twin towers on Sept. 11, the skyline is still punctuated with doubles. Twin towers are the defining feature of Central Park West and, in the spires of St. Patrick's Cathedral and the minarets of Central Synagogue, the glory of Midtown. They serve as a gateway to Harlem and frame the broad lawns of the United Nations.
 And more are on the way. In a remarkable coincidence, even as the remains of the World Trade Center are being cleared downtown, construction crews at Columbus Circle are building the most prominent twin-towered development in a generation: the 750-foot-tall AOL Time Warner Center. 
 New York, New York, has a penchant for saying things twice.
That is not to deny the sturdy, singular majesty of the Empire State Building, once again the city's tallest building. (Can you believe it?) But there is a certain loneliness to its solitary stature.
By contrast, the 110-story Trade Center towers were practically fraternal. Indeed, at the time of their construction in the early 70's, they were even dubbed Nelson and David, though disparagingly, after the Rockefeller brothers who championed their development, one as governor of New York, the other as chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank.
Anthropomorphism is irresistible when contemplating twin towers, as the term itself suggests.
They may be discerned as sturdy legs, like the Colossus of Rhodes. They may be imagined as arms raised to the heavens. They may be thought of as siblings or partners or husband and wife.
Or as sentinels.
That is one impression of the 35-story Schomburg Plaza apartments, built at Fifth Avenue and 110th Street in 1975, two years after the World Trade Center was dedicated. This octagonal, concrete pair can also be read as a pivot between black and Hispanic Harlem or as a monumental gateway to Harlem itself.
Despite many obvious differences, Schomburg Plaza, designed by Gruzen & Partners and Castro-Blanco, Piscioneri & Feder, bears similarities to the World Trade Center. Its slender towers rise straight up without setbacks and are offset from one another in both directions.
The offset enhances their visibility. The south tower, 1295 Fifth Avenue, is the visual anchor along 110th Street and Central Park North. The north tower, 1309 Fifth Avenue, plays the same role up and down the avenue.
Seen together, across Duke Ellington Circle or the Harlem Meer in Central Park, through a pale autumn haze that makes them appear far taller than they are, they inspire a gasp of recognition, recalling their lost cousins downtown.

Looking West
The actual inspiration was closer by, said Jordan Gruzen, one of the architects. "We were really looking across Central Park at the El Dorado and the Century and all the wonderful double-towered buildings," he recalled.
Unlike Schomburg Plaza, the Central Park West twins rise from substantial base buildings that account for about two-thirds of the overall height, with side-by-side towers to complete the composition.
They were shaped by the Multiple Dwelling Act of 1929, Steven Ruttenbaum wrote in "Mansions in the Clouds: The Skyscraper Palazzi of Emery Roth" (Balsam Press, 1986). That law capped apartment buildings at 19 stories but permitted extra floors if the building site was large enough and the tower portion occupied no more than 20 percent of the site.
Roth was the architect of the first Central Park West twin, the San Remo, between 74th and 75th Streets. "I do not think that there was any mystical design thought, just very good architecture based on the existing building code," his grandson, Richard Roth Jr., said recently. Emery Roth & Sons also worked with Minoru Yamasaki & Associates on the World Trade Center.

'A Lighter Skyline'
The San Remo was followed by the El Dorado, between 90th and 91st Streets, by Margon & Holder, with Roth as adviser; the Majestic, between 71st and 72nd Streets, by Irwin S. Chanin and Jacques L. Delamarre; and the Century, between 62nd and 63rd Streets, also by Chanin and Delamarre.
"The towers duplicated make a lighter skyline that a solid tower would not provide," Diana Agrest wrote in "A Romance With the City: Irwin S. Chanin" (Cooper Union Press, 1982). "In fact this helps make a skyline by generating a rhythm along the avenue, addressing now not the avenue but the city at large, creating a point of reference and visual link between the east and west side."
Mr. Ruttenbaum was equally celebratory, saying that the San Remo towers "convey a lyrical, uplifting feeling, similar to the religious aura of a medieval cathedral."

Spires to God
Not just any cathedral, though. Some of the most celebrated Gothic cathedrals had a single tower, while others had distinctly asymmetrical pairs.
The cathedral of Cologne, on the other hand, had truly twin towers. And after a 282-year hiatus, construction resumed in 1842, a project that fired the imagination of architects on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean, including James Renwick Jr., who was working on St. Patrick's Cathedral. Its 330-foot spires were completed in 1888.
"The twin-towered facade differentiated it from New York's single-towered Protestant Gothic Revival churches," Edward F. Bergman wrote in "The Spiritual Traveler: New York City" (HiddenSpring, 2001). As envisioned by Archbishop John Hughes, St. Patrick's was to serve as a proud declaration of both faith and ethnic identity at a time of considerable anti-Catholic, anti-Irish sentiment in New York City.
Renwick lived to see the day in the early 1890's when St. Patrick's was on the verge of being overshadowed by office buildings. He proposed a 400-foot spire over a Lady chapel at the east end of the cathedral on Madison Avenue. A Lady chapel was eventually built, but with no spire.
Successor tower builders borrowed from the Gothic vocabulary, however. Pointed arches, finials and buttresses appeared in the Trinity and United States Realty Buildings of 1907 by Francis Hatch Kimball. These twins, not entirely identical, are massed like two monumental slices of toast, popping up over either side of Thames Street on lower Broadway.
In much the same way, the Hudson Terminal Buildings once rose along Church Street on either side of Dey Street. Designed by Clinton & Russell and completed in 1908, these twins were razed 60 years later to make way for another pair: the World Trade Center.
Between the era of the Central Park West towers and the construction of the World Trade Center, the most distinctive twins were probably 860 and 870 United Nations Plaza in 1965, designed by Harrison & Abramovitz.
These two steel-and-glass slabs, aligned along their wide axis, overlook the United Nations from across 48th Street. In many respects indistinguishable from the speculative office buildings of the same era, they illustrate the notion that even banal structures can sometimes be made more compelling by the act of multiplication.

The Synergy of Twos
There is no need to wonder what a single World Trade Center tower would have looked like. Something quite like it exists in Chicago: a square, straight, slender shaft, more than 1,000 feet tall, with strongly articulated vertical bays. Known as the Aon Center, it is nowhere near as iconic as the Sears Tower or the John Hancock Building, both of comparable height and vintage.
"One rather cynical view is that if a tower is really ugly, it's useful to have another just like it nearby," said Neil Harris, a history professor at the University of Chicago and the author of "Building Lives: Constructing Rites and Passages" (Yale University Press, 1999).
"It conventionalizes what might be seen as the extreme," Mr. Harris said. "There's something comforting about having a twin. They share values. And abnormality is lessened by the fact that there are two of them."
Twins possess a kind of energy, like the rods of a tuning fork, that seems to dissipate when the multiplication continues to three or four buildings.
They also incorporate thin air into architecture, since the void in the middle becomes integral to the design. "Two parallels that meet in the infinite" is how Ms. Agrest, an architect and a professor at Cooper Union, described the World Trade Center.
"The whole symbolic meaning of the skyscraper is displaced onto the space between them," she said.

The Latest Addition
At the AOL Time Warner Center, which straddles a 3.4-acre, two-block site between 58th and 60th Streets, the void carries an additional meaning: it is the "view corridor" over the discontinued portion of 59th Street.
This was required by guidelines under which the New York Coliseum site was awarded for development to Stephen M. Ross, Kenneth A. Himmel and William L. Mack. (Arguments are to be heard today in State Supreme Court in a lawsuit brought against the project by the Committee for Environmentally Sound Development, which contends that the building is much larger than the one contemplated by the environmental impact review four years ago.)
The design guidelines called for open space of at least 65 feet centered on 59th Street, or Central Park South. "You need two towers to create the space between them," said David M. Childs of Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, the architects of the AOL Time Warner Center.
The Columbus Circle towers will emerge from a very large base that includes stores, restaurants, Jazz at Lincoln Center, AOL Time Warner headquarters and CNN studios. The spires will be given over to condominium apartments known as 1 Central Park and a Mandarin Oriental Hotel.
No thought was given to altering the design of the towers after the Sept. 11 attack, said Mr. Ross, who dismissed out of hand the idea that his project bore any kinship to the World Trade Center towers. "It has no relevance at all," he said. "They didn't have a common base."
There are other differences, Mr. Childs noted. The Columbus Circle towers will be handed -- that is, as distinct as the left hand is from the right, more like mirror images than doppelgangers. Rather than having square floor plans, they will be parallelograms that align along their diagonal axes, which in turn will echo the angle of Broadway down below.
"They're not two candelabra standing on a plaza," Mr. Childs said.
Promotional literature for the AOL Time Warner Center refers to the "twin towers" and acknowledges the project's spiritual debt to the Century, Majestic, San Remo and El Dorado.
But Mr. Ross said the deciding factor was economic, not aesthetic. "You have twin towers because you have sites that are too big to feasibly accommodate one building," he said. "You build them because the site dictates that they be built."
