HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "BRAZIL: BODY AND SOUL," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 27). The rotunda is black and half filled by an immense altar. The French architect Jean Nouvel's installation is aptly over the top, considering that the show is about a culture gloriously, self-consciously excessive. A sampler of Brazilian culture, the show divides attention between the Baroque and the modern. Physicality, spectacle, eroticism and pleasure: the cliches of Brazilian culture are all leitmotifs, in stunning objects mixing indigenous, African and European roots. These include the works of genius eccentrics like Aleijadinho, Brazil's Bernini, and Arthur Bispo do Rosario, a seaman, boxer, doorman, bodyguard, jailbird and mental patient who died in 1989 at the age of 78. He sewed banners out of bed sheets and embroidered them with long incantatory lists of places and people, including a presentation mantle he made for himself to wear before God on Judgment Day. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $8, students and 65+ (Michael Kimmelman)

* "PIETER BRUEGEL THE ELDER: DRAWINGS AND PRINTS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Dec. 2). We could all do worse right now than to lose ourselves for a while in this show of drawings and prints by Bruegel, who knew a thing or two about vice and virtue. The world is anarchic and cruel and can drive all of us to despair sometimes, but good art is a realm unto itself, he tells us, and thankfully we can escape into it from time to time when we need to regain our senses. Against the narcissism of our fin-de-siecle milieu, the mysterious figure of the elder Bruegel comes as a small and fortuitous counterpoint. To judge from his pictures of the deadly vices, or his Everyman as a greedy, nearsighted merchant, or some of the nimbler drawings like "The Beekeepers," an image of lumbering, faceless figures in woven masks and bulky clothes, Bruegel doesn't come across as a compassionate artist, never mind his beloved pictures of peasants and ice skaters. Instead, his dark-humored viewpoint seems strangely moving and modern. Solace, he implies, comes only from the integrity of the artist's effort, not a bad lesson today. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

* "TOM FRIEDMAN," New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Feb. 3). A suitably diverse survey of one of the less predictable artists of the 1990's, who has made his name by transforming common objects and materials into one-of-a-kind feats of sculpture, drawing or photography. Toothpicks, toothpaste, sugar, a pencil, a dictionary and soap are among the materials subjected to Mr. Friedman's carefully plotted, meticulously executed methods. The results can be engagingly manic or meditative -- and sometimes nearly invisible, in which case the work becomes a minimally accessorized punchline. But when Mr. Friedman changes an artwork in a way that keeps the before, the after and the intervening transformation equally clear, he stops time for a few luxurious instants. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays, to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, artists, students and 65+ (Roberta Smith).

* "CASPAR DAVID FRIEDRICH: MOONWATCHERS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Nov. 11). Think of this exquisite, 19-work exhibition as a bit of fanfare played pianissimo. It heralds the arrival of "Two Men Contemplating the Moon," the museum's first painting by the supreme German painter of the Romantic era, who made nature his cathedral and placed figures before it as before an altar. Concentrating on paintings of figures transfixed by the moon, it brings out the more intimate and serene side of Friedrich's temperament. The show also includes a few paintings and drawings by his contemporaries and disciples. One result is a surprisingly vivid sketch of the artist and his circle, which offers the opportunity to get a sharper sense of his extraordinary achievement. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

* "ALBERTO GIACOMETTI," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, (212) 708-9480 (through Jan. 8). Giacometti as the Sartre of sculpture might lead you to imagine him the right subject for troubled times. But that would be the wrong reason to see this exhibition. The right reason is that like all perceptive and eloquent art, it tells you why it is good to be alive. It investigates the pleasure of thinking and looking long and hard, which is never as simple as it sounds. The work is more varied than you may think -- sometimes black-humored, playful, sensual, even devoutly tender -- and includes plasters, painted bronzes and even a clunky stone garden sculpture, a splendid oddity, that demonstrate the material virtuosity and subtle coloration of an artist too often presumed to be pretty much just dark and heavy. Spread chronologically across two floors, compressed then open, like the art they contain, the show has as its unnecessary excuse the centenary of Giacometti's birth. We don't learn much that isn't already known, but it is a thorough, serious, very elegant exhibition, and there is nothing the matter with being reacquainted from time to time with what great art looks like. Hours: Thursdays through Tuesdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays, to 8:15 p.m. Admission: $10; $6.50, students and 65+ (Kimmelman).

RED GROOMS, "Selections From the Graphic Work," National Academy of Design Museum, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 369-4880 (through Nov. 11). For all its ebullience, the art of Mr. Grooms as represented in this 100-piece print retrospective is curiously tedious. He produces teeming, riotously colored cartoons of metropolitan life and affectionately satiric portraits of artists from Courbet to Pollock to Chuck Berry. Many prints are made to be cut and folded into children's-book-style pop-up scenes or three-dimensional volumes, as in a boxy portrait of Gertrude Stein that looks like a parade balloon. But lacking the weird darkness of, say, James Ensor or the philosophical complexity of Saul Steinberg, Mr. Grooms's art remains psychologically if not formally one-dimensional. Hours: Wednesdays and Thursdays, noon to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $8; $4.50, students and 65+ (Ken Johnson).

* "HIRSCHFELD'S NEW YORK," Museum of the City of New York, 1220 Fifth Avenue, near 103rd Street, (212) 534-1672 (through Jan. 27). Few members of New York's culturati have escaped entrapment by Al Hirschfeld's line, a spare but incredibly flexible instrument that captures face and body language with far more accuracy than a camera. Following the performing arts for nearly 80 years, he did his first newspaper drawing, a head of the French actor Sacha Guitry, for The New York Herald Tribune in 1926; among his recent subjects have been Tina Brown, Jerry Seinfeld and the leading lights of the musical revival, "42nd Street." Manhattan itself and its institutions have sat for many a Hirschfeld portrait, from Harlem to Central Park to Greenwich Village. He has looked with an affectionate but beady eye at the Algonquin Round Table, the Savoy Ballroom, Trinity Churchyard, the Empire State Building, the subway at rush hour and the feeding frenzy of Upper West Side cognoscenti at Zabar's. At a time of shaken confidence, this show is more than a reminder of Mr. Hirschfeld's place in New York's cultural history: it is a welcome affirmation of its vitality as an arts and entertainment capital, and a tribute to the elan of those who continue to make it happen. Hours: Wednesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $4, students and 62+ (Grace Glueck).

* "INTO THE LIGHT: THE PROJECTED IMAGE IN AMERICAN ART 1964-1977," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Jan. 27). Contrary to what you may think, this show isn't about the roots of today's ubiquitous video installations, although it deserves credit anyway as an act of historical rectitude, recovering pioneering examples of experimental film, video, slide projections and even holography from an era before anybody heard of Bill Viola or Sam Taylor-Wood. But the show's true goal is to demonstrate how sculpture expanded its purview partly thanks to film and video. In American art 30 or 40 years ago, projected images altered, enlarged and otherwise disturbed our sense of space and of objects in space, which after all is what we mean in one respect when we say sculpture. There are 19 works in the show. Some are prankish. Some are comical. Provocation, to the point of frustration, and a taste for the absurd are also motifs, the flip side to the spirit of optimistic experimentation. The exhibition is especially admirable for reminding us of artists overlooked by a public focused more on stars. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $8, students and 62+ (Kimmelman)

* "TREASURY OF THE WORLD: JEWELED ARTS OF INDIA IN THE AGE OF THE MUGHALS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 13). The opulent lifestyles of the emperors and kings of the Mughal age (1526-1858) are dazzlingly evoked in this pioneering exhibition. The first of its kind, it surveys the jewelry and jeweled objects with which imperial Muslims and Hindus adorned themselves, decorated their palaces and paid tribute to one another. The medium's technical and creative growth from the early 1600's to the early 1900's is traced by more than 300 works, including necklaces, bracelets, anklets, weapons, small boxes, flywhisks and even an elephant goad. Rubies, emeralds and diamonds are the main staples here, while the distinctive kundan technique of setting stones in extremely pure malleable gold gives each gem its due and each object a crisply patterned clarity that is almost architectural. The exhibition also includes inlaid hardstone, exquisite enamels and gemstones inscribed with Persian poetry. Altogether it reveals the mixing of Islamic and indigenous styles that gave Mughal art much of its special power and delivers that power at full strength. Hours and admission: See above (Smith)

* "VITAL FORMS: AMERICAN ART AND DESIGN IN THE ATOMIC AGE, 1940-1960," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Jan. 6). The use of organic forms in the visual arts exploded after World War II, drawn from the human figure and its components along with plant, teardrop, amoeboid, cellular and molecular shapes. This ambitious display of more than 250 fine art and design objects tracks the use of these "vital" forms in mediums from highbrow painting to popular consumer products. The organizers argue that the artists were expressing humanism and humane values at a time of worldwide cataclysm, but not enough is made of the role that Surrealism and its dream imagery played. Still, the exhibition does a good job in demonstrating that by the mid-1950's the hard-edged machine esthetic of the prewar years had given way to a visual language centered more on natural forms, helped along by more flexible materials. There's some enlightening and enjoyable looking here, but in the show's broad coverage some of the work -- particularly the paintings -- gets a little lost. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (to 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $6; $3 for students and 62+ (Glueck).

Galleries: Uptown

ERNEST BRIGGS, Anita Shapolsky Gallery, 152 East 65th Street, (212) 452-1094 (through Nov. 10). A second-generation member of the New York School, Briggs (1923-1984) was most impressed with the painterly rhetoric of his teacher, Clyfford Still, at the California School of Fine Arts in the early 1950's. His style (if not his titles) varied, from Still-influenced works like "Untitled" (1955), a dramatic upward rush of dense, dark treelike forms against a background of pale dawny light, to "Untitled" (1959), a wonderful farrago of black and brightly colored rivulets that leave lively pools of light as they flow in all directions. If not all that innovative, Briggs's juicy work still merits attention (Glueck).

"EXQUISITE MOMENTS: WEST LAKE AND SOUTHERN SONG ART," China Institute, 125 East 65th Street, (212) 744-8181 (through Dec. 9). New York's big fall show of Chinese painting is installed in a very small space: two galleries at the China Institute that together could fit in a coat-check room at the Met. But square footage doesn't matter. Scale and quality do. Most of the 40 or so paintings in the show, on loan from premier American museums, are also small. Created in the form of album pages and fans, they are a one-on-one sort of art, meant to be brought out every now and then and savored, like love letters, in private. And as with love letters, the emotions conveyed are sweet, intense and sometimes deep (Holland Cotter).

* "NUMISMATICS IN THE AGE OF GROLIER," Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street, (212) 838-6690 (through Nov. 17). A handsome show about an obscure subject: Renaissance illustrated books about ancient coins, with many of the coins and Renaissance medals they helped inspire. The illustrations, like the coins, are elegant and refined; the history offered in lengthy wall texts is a trove of obscure information. The larger fascination, for those not drawn to its elaborate scholarship, is the dialogue between media: how sculpture, in the form of these coins, influenced book illustration, which influenced sculpture, and so on. A curio: 16th-century prints of all the Roman emperors lined up in profile, with spaces left at the end, just in case, for future monarchs (Kimmelman).

GEORGIA O'KEEFFE, Gerald Peters, 24 East 78th Street, (212) 628-9760 (through Nov. 10). This modest selection of works by the legendary American painter includes a small watercolor of grapes and oranges, painted in 1904 when the artist was just 17; atmospheric abstractions in watercolor, made with deft economy in 1916; and, best, two small oils, one a picture of a single dark purple fig on pearlescent gray cloth and the other of an almost supernaturally glowing red flower in a white glass (Johnson).

FAIRFIELD PORTER, "Drawings From the Estate," Hirschl & Adler, 21 East 70th Street, (212) 535-8810 (through Nov. 10). None of the 83 drawings assembled for this well-produced show are nearly as memorable as Porter's best paintings. Sketchy and loose, they look hastily generalized rather than uniquely observant. Nevertheless, many have diaristic charm -- portraits of the artist's daughter playing guitar, for example, or views of small town streets populated by cars and trucks. Some pictures of ocean waves could be mistaken for Cy Twomblys (Johnson).

Galleries: 57th Street

* DAVID HOCKNEY AND HENRI MATISSE, "Line Drawings," Artemis Greenberg Van Doren, 730 Fifth Avenue, (212) 445-0442 (through Nov. 10). Not a few artists of the last half-century or so owe much to the wizardly draftsmanship of Matisse, and Mr. Hockney is a pretty good example. This show tries to suggest through their works on paper -- Matisse's from 1918 to 1948; Mr. Hockney's from the 1960's and 70's -- the effect of Matisse's spare but supremely articulate line on the younger artist. At its best, Matisse's sprightly drawing is a lesson in the eloquence of brevity. Mr. Hockney's work is tighter and fussier, his line more broken, his subjects more particularized by detail. Still, as his later portraits make clear (particularly of Vera Russell in 1983), he has learned much from Matisse's willful looseness, his ability to imply by the sketchiest of suggestion elements of hair, clothes and body language. The playing off of one's work against the other's makes an intriguing exhibition (Glueck).

SOPHIA VARI, Nohra Haime, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 888-3550 (through Nov. 17). This Paris-based sculptor makes pedestal-scale bronzes in classic Cubist style but with a playful, contemporary feel. Selected planes of Ms. Vari's compacted, jumbled towers of spheres, ovoids, box shapes, pie sections and other sorts of volumes are painted in bright primary colors, which stand out against the near black sheen of the patinated bronze. The sculptures have a cheerfully decorative, slightly cartoonish appeal (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

TERENCE LA NOUE, David Beitzel, 102 Prince Street, (212) 219-2863 (through Nov. 10). This veteran abstract painter creates dense, colorful crazy-quilt collages of Cubist and biomorphic shapes, Expressionist gesture and quirky symbols on irregularly shaped unstretched canvases. Driven by playful hedonism and cosmic intuitions, Mr. La Noue's paintings have a richly sensuous presence, but feel, ultimately, more tastefully decorative than adventurously imaginative (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

"A PRIVATE READING: THE BOOK AS IMAGE AND OBJECT," Senior & Shopmaker, 21 East 26th Street, (212) 213-6767 (through Nov. 10). Along with a few fancy real books, this entertaining exhibition offers all kinds of witty or poetic representations of books. Highlights include an open tome in faux-wood Formica, by Richard Artschwager; a copy of a Donald Judd catalogue raisonne in a Juddesque aluminum case, by Rodney Graham; skillful trompe l'oeil pictures of old book covers, by both Ian Everard and Steve Wolfe; and Marcel Duchamp's famous Surrealist catalog with a foam-rubber breast on a field of black velvet (Johnson).

MARK COHEN, "Trespass," Bruce Silverstein Gallery, 504 West 22nd Street, (212) 627-3930 (through Nov. 10). Mr. Cohen zeros in on an arm, a leg, a foot, a shoulder tattoo, even a gum bubble so huge that it replaces the face of the young girl blowing it. Taken out of bodily context, these fragmentary (but uncropped) pictures often make fine street poetry. His use of strobe can lend a surreality to his shots, making light as much a part of the impact as the image itself. The head of a young boy, brightly silhouetted by light against the background of a dark street takes on a visionary aspect. Through the eloquence of Mr. Cohen's laconic lens, a town gradually reveals itself (Glueck).

ANNA GASKELL, "Resemblance," Casey Kaplan, 416 West 14th Street, (212) 645-7335 (through Nov. 10). Ms. Gaskell continues to produce the staged, dreamlike photographs of young girls engaged in mysterious, vaguely sinister activities for which she is well known. More surprising, and in some ways more imaginative, are her spidery cartoon fantasy drawings; she'd be a good illustrator for a new edition of Grimm's Fairy Tales (Johnson).

JAMES GOBEL, Kravets/Wehby, 529 West 21st Street, (212) 352-2238 (through Nov. 10). This young California-based artist makes pictures using the folk art-style technique of neatly puzzling together pieces of colored felt and yarn. He favors homoerotic pictures of big, bearded men, but an impressively complex image of an antique public fountain spurting white water with multicolored bushes and trees in the background steals this show (Johnson).

MORRIS LOUIS, Paul Kasmin, 293 10th Avenue, at 27th Street, (212) 563-4474 (through Nov. 24). This excellent selection of canvases by the pioneering Color Field painter includes darkly glowing works from the "Veils" series; light-as-air examples of the "Unfurled" series; candy-colored stripes; and, most arresting, "Para III," which with its flowing pools of liquid red, green, orange and yellow is like a hallucinogenic light show (Johnson).

STEPHEN MUELLER AND DION JOHNSON, Bill Maynes, 529 West 20th Street, (212) 741-3318 (through Nov. 17). Glowing watery plaids, candy-colored stripes and checks and emblematic shapes that look Middle Eastern are playfully layered by Mr. Mueller in canvases both optically riveting and mystically suggestive. Mr. Johnson combines thick paint -- troweled, combed, smeared and dribbled -- schematic diagrams of machinery, furniture and architecture and neatly painted images in a child's picture book style to dreamy and sensuous effect (Johnson).

JORGE PARDO, "Pinhole Cameras," Friedrich Petzel, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 680-9467 (through Nov. 10). In a curious departure from his usual elegant and witty cliches of modern design, Mr. Pardo here presents a set of unbecoming gray crystalline sculptures that turn out to be pinhole cameras. Given a few hours of exposure, film placed inside each records a blurry black-and-white image of the gallery and its contents. It's a silly idea, but on the other hand, maybe it's a metaphor about perception and consciousness (Johnson).

* JAMES SIENA, Gorney Bravin & Lee, 534 West 26th Street, (212) 352-8372 (through Nov. 10). Mr. Siena's captivating abstract paintings look as though they were created by someone in an altered, mildly ecstatic state of consciousness. Spiraling lines, nesting boxes, complicated lattices and other patterns are executed by a patient but eccentric hand in glossy, richly colored enamels on smallish aluminum panels. The results are a combination of systematic complexity, comic style and seductive sensuality that is mesmerizing and irresistibly delightful (Johnson).

JESS VON DER AHE, Jay Grimm, 505 West 28th Street, (212) 564-7662 (through Nov. 10). This painter uses her own blood along with gold leaf to create abstracted images of waves, clouds and bubbles that call to mind Japanese screens and turn-of-the-last-century Viennese design. Under thick coats of clear, glossy resin, Ms. von der Ahe's works have a sumptuous decorative appeal that overrides any sensationalistic associations with her sanguinary medium (Johnson).

Other Galleries

* "EXPANDING ON A LEGACY: AMERICAN ART FROM THE MONTCLAIR ART MUSEUM," UBS Paine Webber Art Gallery, 1285 Avenue of the Americas, near 51st Street, (212) 713-2885 (through Nov. 30). In the 19th century Montclair, N.J., was a thriving art colony whose best known member was the landscapist George Inness (1825-1894), and it had high-minded citizens with cultural aspirations. A splendid result was the Montclair Art Museum, which opened in 1914 and today is one of the country's leading small museums of American art. This sampler of some 80 paintings, sculptures and American Indian art is meant to bring its treasures to a larger audience while it completes a renovation. A 1782 portrait by Gilbert Stuart; a major Inness landscape; realist canvases by John Sloan and Edward Hopper; a good slice of early Modernist work by Arthur Dove, Stuart Davis and Morgan Russell; an early Abstract Expressionist theme by Adolph Gottlieb; a group of sculptures by names like Daniel Chester Frency, Louise Nevelson, Man Ray and George Rickey, and an elegant Tlingit totem pole from the Northwest Coast make this an appetizing prelude to the feast across the river (Glueck).

"LARGER THAN LIFE," Center for Figurative Painting, 115 West 30th Street, (212) 868-3452 (through Nov. 30). The standouts in this five-artist show are two painters of opposite but equally ambitious sensibility: Leland Bell, whose large, perfectly composed figure compositions project an Apollonian love of order and clarity, and Paul Georges, a passionate hedonist whose big, recklessly vigorous painting of wild pink roses under a bright blue sky evokes a summer day to almost unbearably delightful effect (Johnson).

Last Chance

KEVIN APPEL, Marianne Boesky, 535 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 680-9889 (through tomorrow). With a subtly ironic twist, Mr. Appel paints sleek, white-on-white pictures of a Modernist architectural heaven. On large horizontal canvases, the young Los Angeles-based artist organizes parallelograms and vertical white bands, suggesting the walls, floors and columns of some floating, ultimately purified modern interior, a Mies ghost world (Johnson).

WILLIAM BAZIOTES, Joseph Helman, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 245-2888 (through tomorrow). A charter member of the first-generation New York School, Baziotes (1912-1963) painted mysterious, amorphous beings that reflected his search for the primordial and the primitive in his own psyche. Like many of his colleagues, he was intrigued by the Surrealist use of automatic writing to plumb the unconscious. His blobby, jagged and serpentine shapes and his fine, thready lines, floating or swimming on misty, runny grounds, evoke the gods and monsters depicted in the classical sculpture that he admired. But finned and clawed creatures also swam up from his inner depths. He seems to have reached the height of his powers in work from the mid-1940's to the late 1970's, producing imagery of fluid, poetic eloquence. In this display of works on paper, Baziotes's lyrical talent makes a strong showing (Glueck).

DAISY CRADDOCK, "Two Places," Cheryl Pelavin, 13 Jay Street, TriBeCa, (212) 925-9424, (through tomorrow). In a gallery just a short walk from the ruins of the World Trade Center, it's hard not to experience Ms. Craddock's luminous land and seascapes as images of grief and consolation. There is a funereal sadness in her Impressionistic pictures of old trees draped with Spanish moss, bowing low over glassy pools of water. In the imperturbable immensity and timeless rhythm evoked by her pictures of foamy waves washing up on flat sand, one may feel a comforting Emersonian divinity (Johnson).

"EPIC PHOTOGRAPHY OF THE CUBAN REVOLUTION," Cuban Art Space, 124 West 23rd Street, (212) 242-0559 (through tomorrow). For a brief time before the Cuban Revolution turned catastrophic, it had a kind of Hollywood glamour, with troops in scruffy-chic beards and berets and the baby-faced Fidel Castro and the Byronic Che Guevara as superstar leaders. A handful of Cuban photographers, including Raul Corrales and Osvaldo Salas, were responsible for promoting that image, and some of their signature work is on view. The leading image maker, though, was Alberto Diaz Gutierrez, or Korda, who came to the job through a career in fashion photography and advertising and created the image of Che as "Heroic Guerrilla" (Cotter).

ANYA GALLACCIO, Lehmann Maupin, 35 Greene Street, SoHo, (212) 965-0753 (through tomorrow). A plain of scorched black plywood, a full-size tortured bronze tree and wasp-nest clusters of bright red ceramic apples form a haunting image of nature out of balance that dominates the first New York show of this well-known young British artist. Several smaller sculptures cast from organic forms reflect a routine high-end realism; a large color photograph of the melodramatic girl-in-landscape genre is best overlooked (Smith).

* ALMA W. THOMAS, "Phantasmagoria: Major Paintings From the 1970'S," Michael Rosenfeld Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 247-0082 (through tomorrow). With each new showing, Thomas's paintings look fresher and livelier, their totally abstract vocabulary of color markings conveying the spirit of a vibrant inner life. As a practicing artist who lived from 1891 to 1978, she had a late start: After decades of teaching art in the public schools of Washington while doing realist still lifes on her own, she found her voice as an abstract color painter. She pared down her style from tight realist brushwork to geometric, mosaiclike dabs and patches of high-energy hues. Laid down in irregular allover patterns on solid grounds that show through in webs and networks, her late works are sophisticated color structures that still reveal a debt to the natural world. Joy may be in short supply elsewhere, but it resonates in these paintings (Glueck).

HEADLINE: Drug Issue Casts a Shadow on Trade Talks 

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, Nov. 1 

 BODY:
Boniface Chidyausiku does not remember exactly when the dispute over setting aside patents that limit cheap drug supplies grew so contentious that it began threatening to derail a new round of global trade talks set to begin next week.
 "It's been a gradual process, a gradual hardening, partly because the views remained so opposed," said Mr. Chidyausiku, Zimbabwe's delegate to the World Trade Organization and the leader of a council that has tried for months to work out a compromise. 
From his other vantage point -- his country leads a group of 38 African nations seeking more leeway under the trade group's intellectual property agreement -- Mr. Chidyausiku said: "This is quite an emotional issue for African countries. In Zimbabwe, we are losing 3,000 people a week." 
In the numerous meetings he has presided over this year, poorer countries have wrangled mainly with the United States and Switzerland, the homes of many of the world's largest pharmaceutical companies. Both nations argue that the existing Trips agreement -- the name is shorthand for trade-related aspects of intellectual property -- already ensures adequate supplies of drugs when there is a health crisis.
Simmering tensions started to boil over about two weeks ago, when Canada overrode the patent held by Bayer for the antibiotic Cipro and ordered the generic version from a Canadian company. The Bush administration followed with threats of taking similar action, and Bayer responded by agreeing to sell it bulk supplies at a deep discount.
"No one mentioned it formally -- that's not diplomatic," one trade delegate said. "But there was anger that there is a double standard at work here." 
Francisco Cannabrava, a trade negotiator for Brazil, said the Canadian and American moves had provoked "a lot of talk in the corridors."
Brazil has been at the center of the drug patent issue since it threatened earlier this year to set aside patent protections and buy generic versions of AIDS drugs from local makers because it said the name-brand versions cost too much, a step that drew the ire of the United States. Mr. Cannabrava said Washington's moves on Cipro "added a lot of weight to our argument."
Tempers are high in Geneva because of pressure to strike a last-minute compromise among some 30 countries in time for the trade group's biennial conference in Doha, Qatar, next week.
Last weekend, Hong Kong's delegate, Stuart Harbinson, who has been organizing documents for next week's meeting, decided to issue two papers on the issue, one spelling out each viewpoint. Unless a compromise is found, drug patents will be the only issue on the Doha agenda with "brackets" -- a choice of competing views. The last attempt to start a new trade round, in Seattle, collapsed amid a welter of brackets indicating numerous disagreements, and the trade group has tried to avoid them at Doha.
The American-backed version acknowledges a right "to take measures necessary to address these public health crises, in particular to secure affordable access to medicines," but it insists that the Trips agreement takes precedence. The version backed by developing countries reverses the priority, saying that "nothing in the Trips agreement shall prevent members from taking measures to protect public health."
Developing nations have repeatedly assailed the pharmaceutical industry for charging too much, while industrialized nations have accused generic drug makers in Brazil and India of cashing in unfairly on other companies' research.
American delegates here have said that the developing countries' proposed language would eviscerate patent protection. For sub-Saharan African countries hit hard by AIDS and other diseases, the United States has offered instead to extend by 10 years the deadline for them to comply with the Trips agreement.
"This isn't about Africa," said Mark E. Grayson, a spokesman for a trade group for big American drug companies. "The issue has been hijacked by India, Brazil and Egypt to further their own economic agendas." 
As Federico Cuello Camilo of the Dominican Republic emerged from one of the trade body's final meetings before Doha, he said, speaking of drug patents, that among the outstanding issues, "probably the deal breaker is going to be that one."

HEADLINE: For the First Time Since Ike, a Whiff of U.S. Deflation 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
DEFLATION. To a generation raised to fear inflation, the opposite -- prices falling across the economy -- has a certain attraction. Paying less must be good.
 There is a catch, of course. Your costs are someone else's income. And when income is falling it creates all kinds of problems for the economy and makes it harder for monetary policy to stimulate growth. Prices fell during the Depression, and they are falling now in Japan. Neither provides a model that anyone wants to emulate. 
 And now one measure shows deflation is here.
The government's quarterly growth report, which showed that the economy shrank in the third quarter, reported a decline of 0.4 percent, at an annual rate, in prices for personal consumption expenditures. It was the first quarterly fall in nearly half a century, since the second quarter of 1954, at the end of a recession. 
The number is calculated in a more sophisticated way than the more widely followed consumer price index, and it is a figure that the Federal Reserve watches. Fed chairman Alan Greenspan prefers the core figure for personal consumption expenditures, which excludes food and energy. It is still barely positive, at 0.3 percent.
To be sure, part of the collapse in inflation reflects recession-induced price cutting, which is normal. But there have been seven recessions since 1954, none of which brought deflation.
What is new here is that deflation is spreading from the industrial world to consumers. The Commodity Research Bureau index of raw industrial prices peaked in 1995 and now is at a 15-year low, off 16 percent this year and 40 percent from its high. Yesterday's report from the National Association of Purchasing Management showed the pricing power of manufacturing companies is at its lowest level since 1949.
There are winners from deflation. The fall in gasoline prices amounts to a tax cut, which the economy can certainly use. But as the Japanese experience shows, enduring deflation can lead to a big drop in consumption, as consumers conclude that prices will only get cheaper. Cutting wages is very hard to do, so corporate profits get squeezed, leading to more layoffs and more drops in consumer purchases, which lead to more layoffs and on and on.
The classic way to fight such a weakening economy is by easing monetary policy. But to be stimulative, the Fed needs to get short-term interest rates below the inflation rate. "The liquidity trap in economic theory arrives if the inflation rate falls below zero," said Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company. "You run out of bullets before the inflation rate hits zero."
Lower interest rates this year have kept the housing and auto sectors from collapsing, as they usually do early in economic downturns. But housing has started to weaken. "It now appears that a downward path of housing prices will accentuate the negative wealth effect from the stock market's decline," said Dean Baker, co-director of the Center for Economic and Policy Research in Washington.
A decade ago, Japan's central bank was slow to loosen credit after its bubble burst. There is no way to prove its reticence was the cause of Japan's malaise, but it did not help. It is a precedent that Mr. Greenspan surely recalls.
The whiff of deflation is just one more reason that rates need to fall further. When the Fed meets next week, anything smaller than a half-point cut in the Federal funds rate, now 2.5 percent, would send the wrong signal. Another cut in December will probably be wise as well.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 3, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A column on Page 1 of Business Day yesterday about the specter of deflation misstated the last time the quarterly change in prices for personal consumption spending was negative. It was the second quarter of 1961, not 1954.

HEADLINE: Cantor Survivors on a Mission; 
Rebuilding the Firm, and Remembering Those Lost

BYLINE:  By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
Almost every day, Chris Crosby turns in his chair at Cantor Fitzgerald's technical center in Rochelle Park, N.J., to ask his buddy for help -- for one sweet instant forgetting his friend is dead.
 Philip Marber, a Cantor division president in Manhattan, still wakes up at 3 most mornings, worrying about how to turn his new stock trading desk into the "well-oiled machine" he once ran. 
 John Law, one of a handful of surviving Cantor stock traders, now works with 50 newly hired employees on a trading desk unlike any he's known before. The raucous, knowing banter he once shared with his lost friends is gone, replaced by the slightly formal ceremony of well-meaning people who do not yet use each others' nicknames or know each others' pet peeves.
These men are among the roughly 340 surviving employees in Cantor's New York headquarters, working together on an almost unimaginable task -- saving a business in which three colleagues out of every four, around 660 people, died in the attacks on the World Trade Center. In a world that thrived on a smooth, familiar routine, every aspect of the workday environment is strange, and much harder. 
Office space, new equipment, telephone and computer links, market data and even basic office supplies had to be conjured out of the chaos so the firm could reopen with the national markets. Veterans took on new jobs -- from the Dallas trader who now reads market tidbits over the squawk-box to his New York colleagues because they do not yet have a full news service, to the public relations executives who helped build the firm's memorial Web site.
In this struggle, Cantor's survivors -- the firm now employs roughly 1,450 people, about 350 of them in the New York area -- have become what Mr. Crosby called a band of brothers. People who had once been, at most, a face in the cafeteria quickly became foxhole friends. Help has come from unexpected quarters, like the administrator who left the firm six months ago and has now returned to help organize its equity operations.
In the process, the survivors have found unsuspected strengths and a shared sense of altruism that has produced an added mission: to deliver on the firm's promise to contribute 25 percent of its profits over the next five years to the Cantor families who lost loved ones.
The impulse to rebuild came naturally to Cantor's surviving executives, Mr. Marber said. Surviving partners in New York had a substantial investment in the firm, and partners and employees working in branch offices around the country and in London "needed a place to make a living," he said.
It may well be an uphill battle. However loyal and sympathetic, longtime customers will stay with Cantor only if the badly bruised firm can deliver the service they demand. Rivals are trying to capitalize on any sign of disarray or confusion at the firm, as a weak economy shrinks the pie for everyone.
Indeed, even before Sept. 11, Cantor was in flux. Its traditional business -- handling government bond trades for giant institutional investors wary of revealing their trades to one another -- was giving way to modern electronic trading systems, including its own eSpeed operation. Its stock-trading business was booming, but its bond traders faced an uncertain future. Layoffs had left the usual scars, a residual uneasiness in some departments; resumes were circulating and resentments were brewing.
Then came the terrorist attacks, which doomed all Cantor employees working on four floors near the top of the World Trade Center's north tower. Overnight, the magnitude of Cantor's losses transformed the firm from an obscure specialty trader to a national symbol of the awesome human and business devastation caused by the attacks.
For Mr. Law, now working in a makeshift trading room in a Park Avenue building, each day is a new reminder of "how good I had it before." In the world of "before," where everything he needed was at his fingertips, he had time to read the papers and check the news wires, to tease his colleagues, to nurture about two dozen clients. Now, he has many more client accounts, the jokes have vanished, and none of his tools are where he expects them to be. And almost every person around him is an unknown quantity.
"It's a scramble every morning," he said. "I just keep repeating two little words: 'It's temporary.' Each day, the pain doesn't hurt so much. Every day we get a little better organized."
Mr. Crosby, one of a handful of technology staff members to survive, has found work to be the best treatment for a pain that prompts him to refer to his lost colleagues, once known as the guys, as gentlemen. Since about 3 a.m. on the day after the attacks, Mr. Crosby has poured himself into his job, a job that now requires him to shuttle between computer centers in Weehawken and Rochelle Park.
"I used to be managing the development of our large-scale databases," he said. "Now? Oh, I've got a whole bag of tricks." He has taken on projects that lost colleagues left behind.
Work has been "helpful and therapeutic," said James Talvy, a young technical architect at the firm, and it has also forged new bonds.
"We group together more," he added. "We're all trying as a group to rebuild this business -- not only for the sake of keeping busy, but to rebuild it for those who were left."
As at many financial firms displaced from Lower Manhattan, Cantor executives are struggling to coordinate a business that is scattered across Manhattan, New Jersey and Connecticut. Although executives say a new office home will eventually pull the firm together again, for now the surviving employees work alongside newly hired traders in Manhattan and unfamiliar sales and technology colleagues in Darien, Conn., and Rochelle Park and Weehawken.
"The first day here we didn't even have pens," sighed Heidi Olson, the chief administrative officer in the equities division, as she sat outside one of the firm's temporary Park Avenue trading rooms.
Ms. Olson left Cantor last April, after more than five years in corporate development. But after the disaster -- "I could not believe my friends were on fire," she said with a shudder -- she called and volunteered to help. Chores were handed to her, and then more chores.
Bank accounts had to be opened for Cantor's new relief fund. Supplies had to be ordered for the temporary trading room. Computers and phones had to be installed. Someone had to buy the machines that stamp the time and date on each order. There were no job descriptions -- just jobs, many of them utterly unfamiliar to Ms. Olson.
"Everything we ever took for granted was gone," Ms. Olson said. "So I just did whatever had to be done. It is like being a mom -- in that spiritual sense of doing whatever is needed for the good of the family."
Throughout the firm she senses a greater patience, a quiet pride in enduring the daily inconveniences of having "absolutely no routine at all."
At the beginning, there were moments when things fell apart. "People had breakdowns, people fainted," Ms. Olson said. "You sobbed, and then you got on with it."
But she still doesn't sleep very well, she said. "The ghosts come to get you at night. There's so much to think about: what you miss and all that needs to be done here."
She finds considerable comfort at work, she says. "This was a tribal event -- something happened to our tribe. And it helps to be here with people who feel the same pain."
But for Scott Wall, one of the few surviving Cantor bond traders, about the only thing in his work life that is unchanged is Cantor's name on his business card. He once traded corporate bonds in Manhattan, surrounded by people he'd known for almost a decade. He now sells convertible bonds from an office in Darien, among people he had barely met before Sept. 11.
"I remember hearing the president say that we should all go back to work, and thinking that I didn't have any work to go back to," Mr. Wall said. "I'm 38. I just hope it's not too late to make a change."
Cantor's chairman, Howard Lutnick, has also found his workday much changed. Once known for his combative arm-wrestling in a competitive business, Mr. Lutnick was suddenly surrounded by hundreds of grieving families who needed gentle handling. He took a self-taught crash course in the politics of philanthropy, meeting with the head of the American Red Cross to argue successfully for immediate cash assistance for families who lost breadwinners in the attacks.
Mr. Lutnick lost his only brother, Gary, in the attacks. His grief and shock were apparent right after the disaster in a spate of tearful media interviews. But in recent weeks, after public criticism from some victims' relatives, Mr. Lutnick has pulled out of the spotlight, refusing interviews and spending time talking quietly with families at a series of informational gatherings Cantor has held around New York City.
Mr. Marber was stranded at a golf resort in Ohio when the attack occurred. Otherwise, he almost certainly would have perished along with 130 others on the stock trading desk he ran. Isolated in his hotel room, he coped with his hopeless, impotent grief by making lists of what the firm would need to reopen.
When he got back to New York on Sept. 13, after a 12-hour van trip, he slept for a few hours and went to work. By Sept. 17, when the stock markets reopened, his jury-rigged trading team was ready.
The trading line held, and the work was done. But it is not like any trading desk he's ever run, Mr. Marber said. The easy laughter, the teasing banter that lubricated the tension, is gone.
"We had such a well-oiled machine," he said, with a tone of almost palpable longing. "Everything was in its place and everything worked, and if it didn't, we got it fixed in five minutes and got back to work. I want that back."
The only way to get it back is to build it again, he said. He is hopeful -- he expects the firm to hold its own for the rest of this year and be ready to grow again next year.
Peter DaPuzzo, a Wall Street veteran who is a senior Cantor partner, has attended 32 funerals, and his wife has been to 18 more. Seeing the young widows and solemn toddlers breaks his heart, he said.
The whole firm is wrestling with survivor guilt, by Mr. DaPuzzo's account. He wonders aloud whether, if he'd been a less persuasive recruiter, many of his lost employees would still be alive.
An optimist by nature, Mr. DaPuzzo says he can usually now make it through an entire day at Cantor's Darien office without tears. "You have to have strength for the others," he said.
But sometimes, he said, "I stumble. A friend came in to see me from Seattle -- someone who hadn't heard it all yet. He came in, we hugged, and we cried."

HEADLINE: More Gloomy Economic News as Consumer Spending Slumps 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 1 

 BODY:
Manufacturing last month turned in its worst performance since the 1990-1991 recession after consumer spending showed the biggest drop in almost 15 years, an industry report showed today.
 The National Association of Purchasing Management's factory index fell to 39.8 in October from 47 in September. The October reading was the lowest since February 1991, and the index shows the slump in manufacturing is 15 months old. New orders and production sank, making a recovery unlikely this year. 
 In a separate report, consumer spending fell 1.8 percent in September, the Commerce Department said. The drop occurred as the terrorist attacks kept Americans away from malls, restaurants and airports. The attacks also hurt orders for factory goods.
Manufacturing "is indeed in a deep, prolonged slump," said Steven Wood, chief economist at FinancialOxygen Inc. in Walnut Creek, Calif. "There is little prospect for an imminent turnaround."
The number of workers continuing to collect unemployment benefits rose to 3.69 million in the third week of October, the most in more than 18 years, the Labor Department reported. The number of people filing initial claims for benefits fell by 10,000 last week, to 499,000, still the third-highest weekly total this year.
The Commerce Department also reported that construction spending declined 0.4 percent in September, the fifth consecutive monthly drop. The decline brought spending to $843.1 billion at an annual rate, the slowest this year. Spending fell 1.2 percent in August. The string of declines is also the longest since the period of August 1990 to January 1991, during the last recession.
Analysts had expected a reading of 44.5 in the purchasing managers' index. The drop in consumer spending, after a rise of 0.3 percent in August, was larger than expected and the sharpest since January 1987, when blizzards kept shoppers at home. Growth in personal incomes, which rose less than 0.1 percent in September after a gain of 0.1 percent in August, was the weakest since incomes fell 3.9 percent in January 1994.
The purchasing managers' new-orders component, which accounts for 30 percent of the index, fell to 38.3 in October from 50.3 in September. The drop was the largest since the orders index fell 14.1 points in December 1980.
The production index, a gauge of current work being performed, fell to 40.9 last month from 51.3. The drop is the largest since the index fell 20.7 points in January 1984.
Manufacturers say they are also being hampered by the strength of the dollar and tougher lending standards at banks.
The National Association of Manufacturers called on Federal Reserve policy makers to lower the benchmark overnight bank lending rate half a percentage point, to 2 percent, when they meet on Tuesday. Central bankers have reduced the target rate four percentage points since the start of the year to prevent manufacturing and the rest of the economy from slumping into recession.
The rate is now the lowest in four decades. Investors are expecting a quarter-point cut next week and another quarter-point decrease by the end of the year, based on trading in federal funds futures contracts.
The factory report today showed little threat from inflation, making it easier for the Fed to lower rates. The index of prices paid for raw materials fell to 32.5 in October, the lowest in more than 50 years, from 36.3 the previous month.

HEADLINE: Fed by Low Rates, Refinancing Surge Is Helping Economy 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
Home mortgage rates have fallen sharply in recent weeks to the lowest levels in several years and are expected to drop further this month to rates not seen since the 1960's.
 Americans are taking advantage of the opportunity by refinancing their mortgages in record numbers. Since Sept. 11, about one million people have applied to refinance their home loans, roughly six times as many as did during the comparable period last year. 
 Average 30-year mortgage rates fell to about 6.5 percent at the beginning of this week, from a high of 8.7 percent last year. The Treasury Department's announcement on Wednesday that it would stop selling 30-year bonds should create additional demand for long-term bonds and send the interest rates on these issues lower, pushing down the long-term rates on home loans, if only slightly, economists said. Rates will probably remain low for at least the next few months, they add, because of the continued weakness of the global economy. 
The surge in refinancings -- effectively giving extra cash to families by lowering their monthly house payments -- is providing important support to an economy that is struggling in nearly every other way. The typical family that has refinanced in the last month has lowered its monthly payments by $150 to $200, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association of America.
Though that additional money makes it easier for consumers to pay their bills and perhaps even save some, it may stimulate the economy less than it has in the past. Because many people are worried about layoffs and recent declines in stock prices, fewer are freeing up money to remodel their homes or buy other goods, economists said. Instead, more are shoring up their own finances by paying credit card bills and other loans with high interest rates.
"There's clearly a shift toward a little more conservatism," said Douglas Duncan, the chief economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association.
That conservative shift is complicating the Federal Reserve's attempt to encourage consumer spending by lowering short-term interest rates, which affect mortgage rates. Similarly, Americans saved about 80 percent of the tax rebates sent out this summer.
The slowdown in consumer spending, which accounts for about two-thirds of the country's output, has helped halt a 10-year economic boom, the longest in recorded United States history. In the third quarter of this year, the economy shrank at an annual rate of 0.4 percent, after adjusting for inflation, the government said this week.
Even as people are postponing many other financial decisions because of widespread uncertainty, they are overwhelming banks with requests to refinance their mortgages. Of the million or so people who have applied to refinance their mortgages since Sept. 11, about two-thirds have already done so or will soon.
"We are in the biggest month of the biggest quarter of the biggest year in the history of the mortgage industry," Thomas M. Garvey, an executive vice president in the mortgage division of J. P. Morgan Chase, said at the end of October. "Every mortgage production shop in the industry is bursting at the seams."
Many people calling banks have had to wait an unusually long time before speaking to an employee. Countrywide Home Loans, one of the nation's largest home lenders, plans to double the size of its sales force, to 2,400 people, over the next 15 months, in part because of the heavy demand, said Brian Hale, an executive vice president at Countrywide.
Interest rates have fallen this year as the Federal Reserve has cut its target for short-term interest rates nine times and as lending demand has slowed with the economy. But longer-term rates, including those on many mortgages, have not dropped as much as short-term rates, partly because bond investors feared earlier this year that the Fed's aggressive rate cuts would lead to a rise in inflation, eroding investment returns. Some investors are also concerned that federal budget deficits could return.
The Treasury Department's decision to stop selling 30-year bonds could help push longer-term rates lower for reasons that have less to do with the economy than with the mechanics of the bond market. With no new 30-year bonds, more investors who want to own long-term bonds backed by the government will buy the Treasury's 10-year note, which influences the interest rates on home mortgages. The added demand will push the price of the 10-year bond higher, and the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, lower. With the 10-year rate and related rates falling, mortgage rates will fall, too.
Although most economists expect the Treasury's decision to have a relatively small effect, they say mortgage rates will remain near their current levels, or decline slightly, during the rest of the year. "There is no sign of mortgage rates shooting up because there is no sign of economic recovery," said Greg McBride, a Bankrate.com analyst.
The fees that banks charge and the payment schedules they require vary widely, but analysts say that refinancing a mortgage often makes sense when rates are are at least one-and-a-half or two percentage points -- or sometimes lower -- below a person's existing loan. That means many people who took out a new mortgage only 18 months ago may benefit by refinancing now.
People who expect to move soon generally should not refinance their loans, since it may take many months to recoup the associated costs. 
During the 1990's, when home prices were rising steadily and consumers were confident, many families who refinanced their home loans took cash out at the closing, either by increasing the size of their mortgage or by taking out some of the equity that had risen with home prices. Much of the cash was spent on second homes, cars, kitchen appliances and other expensive items, providing an economic boost. In recent months, though, the percentage of people doing so has declined, said Mr. Duncan, of the bankers' association.
These cash-out refinancings, as they are known in the industry, have declined since Sept. 11, said three of the five biggest mortgage banks. The other two said they had noticed no change.
Because home prices are no longer rising steadily in some parts of the country, people find it harder remove equity from their homes, said Joe Rogers, a national sales manager at Wells Fargo Home Mortgage.
Mr. Duncan estimates people will take out enough money in their refinancings to increase consumer spending by $50 billion this year, boosting the nation's economic growth by half a percentage point. But more than two-thirds of that infusion can be attributed to refinancings before Sept. 11, when far fewer people were applying for new loans but a greater share were taking cash out, he added.
Bob Munson, who lives in a suburb of Cleveland, is taking out a new loan in an effort to be more conservative with his money. Mr. Munson, 48, works at a small computer company that he and his partners recently sold, and he plans to leave the company soon and begin a second career as a teacher.
With the economic future uncertain, and interest rates low, he decided to refinance his loan. Rather than lower his monthly payments, though, he shortened the term of his loan, putting him and his wife in better financial condition once they reach their 60's.
"The economy started pushing me down this thought process," Mr. Munson said. "Sept. 11 just confirmed it."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Mortgage Rates Decline, Igniting a Refinancing Wave
Home mortgage rates have fallen sharply in recent weeks to the lowest levels in several years and are expected to drop further this month to rates not seen since the 1960's.
 Americans are taking advantage of the opportunity by refinancing their mortgages in record numbers. Since Sept. 11, about one million people have applied to refinance their home loans, six times as many as did during the comparable period last year. Page A1. 

Rivera to Leave CNBC for Fox News
Geraldo Rivera will leave his top-rated talk show on the business news cable channel CNBC to join the Fox News Channel as a war correspondent, he said. The move will touch off a shift at CNBC away from talk shows in the prime-time hours and toward more of the business-related programming that it carries during the day. It will also give Fox News a foreign correspondent with higher name recognition than anyone else at that network. C3.

Auto Sales Set a Monthly Record
Sales of cars and trucks in the United States soared to the highest monthly level ever in October, automakers reported, but they were spurred by deep discounts that foreshadow trouble in the months ahead. C2.

Debt Restructuring in Argentina
In a last-ditch effort to avert a costly debt default, the president of Argentina announced a partial restructuring of the nation's $132 billion debt and a package of subsidies for the poor and tax breaks for businesses. A6.

Enron Shares Continue to Slide
Shares of Enron fell 13.7 percent as investors absorbed news of a formal Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into the company's finances and Standard & Poor's downgraded Enron's credit rating. C11.

More Gloomy Reports on Economy
The National Association of Purchasing Management's factory index fell to 39.8 in October from 47 in September, the worst performance since the 1990-1991 recession. In other reports, consumer spending fell 1.8 percent in September, and the number of workers continuing to collect unemployment benefits rose to 3.69 million in the third week of October, the most in more than 18 years. C6.

UAL Posts Record Quarterly Loss
UAL, the parent of United Airlines, reported a record loss for the third quarter in the wake of the terrorist attacks and predicted that the current quarter would be even worse. C2.

Stocks Rally, Led by Microsoft
Stocks rose sharply as Wall Street anticipated a settlement in the Microsoft antitrust case. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 56.10 points, or 3.3 percent, to 1,746.30. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 188.76 points, or 2.1 percent, to 9,263.90. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 24.32 points, or 2.3 percent, to 1,084.10. C6.

AOL Replaces Top Financial Officer
AOL Time Warner replaced its chief financial officer, J. Michael Kelly, transferring him to the company's America Online unit, where he will become chief operating officer. He will be succeeded by Wayne Pace, who has been chief financial officer of Turner Broadcasting. C3.

Stem-Cell Patent Fight Intensifies
The University of Wisconsin's patent-licensing foundation is threatening to revoke at least part of Geron's exclusive commercial rights related to human embryonic stem cells. C12.

PERSON: Dr. Jeffrey M. Isner 

HEADLINE: Dr. Jeffrey Isner, 53, Creator Of Cardiovascular Procedure 

BYLINE:  By ERIC NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Dr. Jeffrey M. Isner, who wedded gene therapy and cardiovascular medicine to create promising treatments for heart and circulatory disease, died on Wednesday at his home in Weston, Mass., near Boston. He was 53.
 The cause was a heart attack, said St. Elizabeth's Medical Center in Boston, where he had worked for two decades. 
 Dr. Isner, who also taught at Tufts University, was an interventional cardiologist, a member of a relatively new medical field whose practitioners try to remove arterial obstructions to restore the flow of blood to the heart. He also treated patients who had blocked blood vessels in the legs, a painful, disabling and potentially fatal condition that can require amputation.
Interventional cardiologists are accustomed to thinking small. They typically do their work through angioplasty, a procedure in which a miniature balloon is threaded into a coronary or other artery and then inflated to clear away a blockage. Often the procedure entails inserting a tiny metal tube, called a stent, into the artery after inflation in an effort to prevent the blockage's recurrence.
But a decade or so ago, Dr. Isner began thinking much smaller still. That was when other researchers discovered a protein they called vascular endothelial growth factor, or VEGF (pronounced VEJ-eff), which signals the body that it is time to grow new blood vessels. Could the substance, he wondered, be used to induce patients to grow new vessels that would bypass a blockage?
In 1994, Dr. Isner put the idea to the test, becoming the first to use genes to treat people with vascular disease. In the very first case, to treat a leg blockage, his team of surgeons coated an angioplasty balloon with trillions of genes that produce VEGF and then threaded it several times to a site near the patient's blockage.
The procedure came to be called angiogenesis, and while it remains experimental, preliminary studies have been promising, indicating that it may indeed help people who have vascular disease of the leg or who are suffering from angina, chest pain that results from coronary blockage.
Still, experts say, many questions remain before gene therapy can become standard treatment for vascular disease.
"The results were promising," said Dr. Valentin Fuster, director of cardiovascular medicine at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York, who was a friend of Dr. Isner. "The thing that he was trying to answer was for how long this increased flow would last. He didn't have the answer for that."
Jeffrey Michael Isner was born on Dec. 11, 1947, in Uhrichsville, Ohio, the son of Justin and Lilli Isner. He earned his bachelor's degree at the University of Maryland and his medical degree at Tufts.
In a 1997 interview, he attributed some of his early successes to simple good fortune.
"When we began our study," he said, "we had no idea what dose of gene therapy was going to work, or if the way we were injecting the genes was appropriate, of if the sites we were injecting were really appropriate."
Those successes also placed him in the middle of the debate over whether the increased blurring of industry and medical research raised ethical questions for doctors. Like a growing number of physicians, Dr. Isner was involved not only in medicine but also in business, as founder of Vascular Genetics and a major stockholder in the company, which is based in North Carolina.
Some critics have raised questions about whether such relationships can affect a doctor's medical judgment, but Dr. Isner rejected those suggestions.
"I'm not trying to dismiss this out of hand," he once said, "but I'm not going to be a wimp and roll over because someone is projecting a concern. I understand what the arguments are, but frankly I don't agree with most of them."
Last year the Food and Drug Administration temporarily suspended research by Dr. Isner, Vascular Genetics and St. Elizabeth's, criticizing the researchers on grounds that they had failed to report properly the death of two patients participating in a study and might have endangered the health of another. That suspension followed the much-publicized death of an 18-year-old man in an unrelated University of Pennsylvania gene therapy experiment.
Dr. Isner said the two patients had died of their underlying cardiovascular condition, not the treatment. But his company acknowledged administrative problems with the research and promised to correct them. Last spring he was permitted to resume his studies, and he recently received a $10 million grant from federal health officials.
He is survived by his wife, Linda Hajjar Isner, and three children: Joshua, Jessica and Matthew, all of Weston.

HEADLINE: State Budgets Facing a Fall In Revenues 

BYLINE:  By KEVIN SACK 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Nov. 1 

 BODY:
Even before accounting for the fiscal devastation caused by the Sept. 11 attacks, state governments were facing the deepest budget shortfalls in at least a decade, according to a survey released today by the National Conference of State Legislatures. 
 As governors and lawmakers prepare to cut billions of dollars in spending, they are girding for more bad news in coming weeks as the first reports on tax collections after Sept. 11 arrive. Complicating the uncertainty in some states is the need to spend substantial sums on public safety and counterterrorism efforts without knowing how much will be reimbursed by Congress. 
 "I think every state thinks it's going to be severe," said Gov. Jane Dee Hull of Arizona, a Republican who has called a special legislative session this month to address a projected $1.6 billion shortfall in her state's $15 billion budget for 2002 and 2003. "People just aren't moving around and they're not buying, and those are sales-tax issues," Ms. Hull said. "And the layoffs that are occurring in every state will hurt income taxes." 
The National Conference of State Legislatures found that state revenue growth had slowed substantially, with 44 states reporting that collections had dropped below forecasts made only four months ago. Nineteen states were spending more than they had budgeted, with Medicaid the primary expense, and seven other states predicted that overspending was likely. At least 28 states are imposing or considering budget cuts, and many are turning to reserve funds that were fattened during the economic expansion.
"The last time states were in this kind of situation was in the early 1990's," said Corina L. Eckl, the group's fiscal programs director. "The concern now is that there is this added uncertainty from the economic impact of the terrorism attacks. And that unknown is causing considerable anxiety among lawmakers."
Steve Peace, a San Diego Democrat who is chairman of the California Senate's budget committee, predicted that the shortfall in his state's $80 billion general-fund budget, which was forecast at $8 billion before Sept. 11, would now grow to at least $12 billion.
Because more than half of California's general fund is spent on education, lawmakers will face the prospect of making deep cuts in aid to schools in an election year, Mr. Peace said. "There's no way to do it without touching schools," he said. "It's a total, absolute impossibility."
On Wednesday, the federal government announced that the gross domestic product contracted in the third quarter at an annual rate of 0.4 percent, the first such decline in eight years. A recession is traditionally defined as two consecutive quarters of economic contraction, and few economists question that the country is headed in that direction.
The report by the National Conference of State Legislatures said state fiscal problems began to emerge late last year when collections of sales and income taxes slowed and failed to meet projections. Governors and legislatures took account of the decline and passed budgets that called for average revenue growth of 2.3 percent in the 2002 fiscal year, which began in most states on July 1. That was half of the actual revenue growth of 4.5 percent in 2001.
But as revenue data for July, August and September came in, states realized that their forecasts for even modest revenue growth were far too optimistic, the group found.
"Across the nation, forecasters are reporting declines in most major tax sources, especially the sales and use tax and personal and corporate income taxes," the report says. "In some states, the drops are significant."
Because there is typically a lag of about six weeks in the reporting of sales tax collections, the economic effect of Sept. 11 on state budgets is only now being measured. In Mississippi, for instance, state officials disclosed on Wednesday that tax collections for October fell below estimates by $22.1 million, or 7 percent. 
Here in Georgia, Gov. Roy Barnes, a Democrat, has asked his agency heads to outline possible cuts of 2.5 percent in their budgets this year and of 5 percent for next year. Those amounts, Mr. Barnes said, should buffer the state from the impact of the economic downturn and the aftermath of Sept. 11.
The terrorist attacks, he said, "did not cause the recession, but it quickened it and it may have deepened it." he added, "The problem is we don't know what the future holds."

HEADLINE: City Offering Work for Some On Welfare 

BYLINE:  By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
The Giuliani administration is quietly offering thousands of city jobs paying more than $9 an hour to welfare recipients who are reaching their five-year limit on federal cash assistance just as the city's economy sinks into recession.
 The workers' hourly wages -- well above minimum wage -- are to be paid out of New York State's $1.5 billion annual welfare windfall, money allocated by the federal government at the same level since 1995, but unspent because the welfare rolls have shrunk by almost half, state officials said. Many of the jobs are as seasonal laborers in the city's Parks Department, where city and union officials said they were prepared to absorb as many workers as the city's Human Resources Administration sends. 
 As 32,800 New York City families confront their five-year federal welfare limit on Dec. 2, more than 3,000 additional recipients who faced the same deadline are already working in the parks, officials from the parks workers' union said. 
Job offers apparently have been made to many of the thousands of recipients called in by the Human Resources Administration in the past month. 
"I can confirm that they are offering those jobs for the families that are coming up against those time limits," said John B. Madden, a spokesman for the State Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance. "The state is very supportive of the city's efforts. But who and how many are getting the job offers -- that's really up to H.R.A." He added, "I can't give you the numbers because I don't have the numbers."
Neither the Human Resources Administration nor the mayor's office returned calls seeking information about the program. Lawyers who have won federal court injunctions against some of the city's recent welfare practices said they had been frustrated in efforts to learn details of the job offers and conditions presented to recipients.
But Mark Rosenthal, president of the union local that represents seasonal parks workers, said 3,100 former welfare recipients are already in jobs that last 11 months and 2 weeks and can be renewed. They are doing work like cleaning parks and supervising playgrounds, he said, and most began in March in a test of the project. At least 1,000 more new hires are expected over the next four weeks.
"As many as they send, we'll take," he said. "We could have 10,000 very easy." He added, "You can have 20,000 in the park -- we had that in the W.P.A.," referring to a public works program of the New Deal.
Under state law, recipients who run out their federal welfare clock are still eligible to apply for a state aid program known as Safety Net Assistance, financed without federal money. But any able-bodied person who refuses a specific job without good cause is to be denied that aid.
The financial advantages to the city are evident. After Dec. 2, aid to the 32,800 city recipients who run out the federal welfare clock would have to come from the state and city treasuries, rather than from the federal welfare block grant created when welfare legislation was overhauled in 1996. And at a time when city agencies are facing steep budget cuts and a hiring freeze, a corps of temporary, federally-subsidized workers could take up the slack.
But the federal grant is up for reauthorization next September, and the surplus could melt away if Congress reduces the grant, or if the welfare rolls climb in a recession, cautioned Douglas Turetsky, spokesman for the city's Independent Budget Office.
Most of the 32,800 who face the December deadline are single mothers. Some may not be suitable for available jobs because of health problems, or because of family responsibilities like caring for a disabled relative, Mr. Madden said. About 11,000 are working already, but earn so little that they still qualify for public assistance. Many others have worked at so-called workfare assignments -- often in city parks -- in exchange for their welfare checks. 
"We're delighted that they're coming back with paychecks," said Mr. Rosenthal, whose union local successfully sued the city to get full pay for workfare recipients doing the same jobs as city parks workers. He noted that the new jobs were even better paid than those in a transitional jobs bill vetoed by the mayor. 
In a city office on Schermerhorn Street in Brooklyn, where many of the recipients have been summoned since Oct. 1, three women emerging from interviews this week had absorbed different, even contradictory, information about their options, and showed widely divergent reactions.
Nancy Flores was near tears over the pressure to take a full-time job. "Sick child, autistic child," she said in broken English, gesturing at her 7-year-old daughter, and then turning to her 10-year-old, Erica, to translate. "They want her to leave the welfare and go to work," Erica said, tugging at one of her tightly braided pigtails. No one mentioned safety net assistance, they said.
In the same waiting room, Tanya Jolly was overjoyed to be offered a job in a park near her home in the Bronx paying $9.38 an hour. Ms. Jolly, a mother of three, said she had spent two years working at clerical tasks in exchange for a meager welfare check and had come in expecting to be cut off without a dime. 
"This is forever." she exulted, waving the sheet of instructions like a flag. "This depends solely on you."
A friend, Tawana McMillan, who also has three children, looked on with envy. She, too, is still on welfare, though she has been working for the last year and a half for a Nordstrom department store in White Plains. On Oct. 1 she was laid off, and so far has been unable to restore full public assistance or get unemployment benefits.
"I want them to call me in for one of those city jobs," she said.
