HEADLINE: Bloomberg and Green Clash Over Capability in Debate 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Mark Green and Michael R. Bloomberg tore into each other's character and credentials in an often fierce debate last night that laid out differences between the two mayoral candidates over how the city should rebuild downtown, and the best way to repair New York's troubled public school system.
 For 60 minutes, in the second and last debate of the mayoral campaign, Mr. Green, the Democrat, and Mr. Bloomberg, the Republican, hammered and needled each other as each sought -- not subtly -- to portray the other as unprepared to take over at a time when New York may be heading into one of the most severe fiscal crises in its history. 
 At one point, Mr. Bloomberg accused Mr. Green of "smearing" him by quoting "out of context" remarks he had made on, among other things, the need for a third-party witness to corroborate a rape allegation involving an employee of his company. At another moment, Mr. Green asserted that Mr. Bloomberg was being "despicable" and racially divisive for criticizing Mr. Green's intense campaign against Fernando Ferrer to win the Democratic nomination. 
By midway into last night's debate, there was little doubt about what each man was trying to accomplish in what is certainly their final joint appearance. At every opportunity, Mr. Bloomberg set out to mock his opponent, the public advocate, as a careerist government official who, running an office of 40 people, was ill-prepared to take over for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Excerpts, Page D5. 
"My opponent has not had any experience in managing a large organization, in leading a large number of people, in setting large budgets, and in actually doing things," Mr. Bloomberg said. "My opponent's experience is as an analyst and as a public advocate."
Mr. Green sought to paint his rival, the billionaire founder of a communications company, as insensitive to women and minorities, disloyal to the Democratic Party, from which he resigned to run as a Republican for mayor, and as completely unfamiliar with the way government works. Again and again, Mr. Green mentioned the neighborhoods he had visited in New York, in an attempt to paint the wealthy Mr. Bloomberg as out of touch. 
"I don't have your experience in selling computers to businessmen, but you don't have my experience in running a government," Mr. Green declared. He added: "You don't understand the city just by spending a lot of private wealth in ads in an election year. You understand the city by going to where people live and asking what they need and then reflecting it."
The debate between the two men came as the candidates entered the final weekend of a contest that has repeatedly been overshadowed by world events. Last night, in a fitting turn of scheduling for this contest, the fifth game of the World Series began just half an hour after the two candidates finished debating at the studios of WABC-TV.
It also came at a time when some private polls by politicians have suggested that the race might be getting tight. That might account for the decision by Mr. Bloomberg and Mr. Green to attack each other so intensely -- and often personally.
That became particularly clear when the two men were given an opportunity to pose questions to each other. It was a moment they had been anticipating, as evidenced by the glee each man displayed before firing off questions that he had prepared for this moment.
"Mark, the way the runoff turned out between you and Freddy Ferrer, isn't it time to say we're going to conduct, you should conduct a real investigation of what happened?" Mr. Bloomberg asked. "Isn't it time that you apologize for the smearing of Freddy Ferrer, saying that he was borderline irresponsible?"
Mr. Bloomberg, who has been making a particular attempt to win over Hispanic voters angered by Mr. Ferrer's loss, continued: "And will you promise right now to stop this politics of personal destruction that you seem to do every time you get close in an election?"
Mr. Green responded by noting that Mr. Ferrer had endorsed Mr. Green's campaign, and asserted that he knew nothing about the telephone calls and leaflets distributed on his behalf that Mr. Ferrer's supporters had denounced as racially divisive.
"What's despicable is the hypocrisy you just heard," Mr. Green said. "This is a man who runs six to seven negative ads, which I haven't whined about. Now he's whining."
He added: "How can I apologize for something that we weren't responsible for?"
When it was Mr. Green's turn to question Mr. Bloomberg, he went through four of what had proved to be problematic remarks attributed to Mr. Bloomberg in the campaign, among them that it was more dangerous to work as a sanitation officer than as a police officer or firefighter, and describing domestic violence as a quality of life crime.
"Would you like now to apologize for or recant any of these four very interesting statements?" Mr. Green said. Mr. Bloomberg responded, "Mark, you've taken them all out of context."
He than proceeded to discuss each of the statements that Mr. Green had raised, as his opponent grinned at the image of Mr. Bloomberg giving the remarks even more exposure. Mr. Bloomberg concluded: "It's the typical smear when the time gets close."
Mr. Green said that the reconstruction of downtown should be overseen by an agency that included city and state officials "to cut through the red tape and the bureaucracy and immediately start digging and rebuilding."
Mr. Bloomberg said the city should run it alone. He said that given the amount of time it would take to clean up the site, the city should not rush in rebuilding. "Adding a level of bureaucracy adds absolutely nothing," he said, adding, "The city should be responsible for its own destiny."
Mr. Green used the exchange to question whether Mr. Bloomberg's years as a business leader had prepared him for government. "If you're in a private company, you can say, 'I'm going to run it all,' " he said. "This is not a private company."
On schools, Mr. Green disagreed with Mr. Bloomberg's opposition to placing computers in every classroom, and to his openness to the use of vouchers in public education. "On these issues, we couldn't be farther apart," Mr. Green said.
Mr. Green called for a reduction in class size. But Mr. Bloomberg said that scarce city resources should go to pay teachers more. "In terms of reducing class size, it is just not a viable option today. We don't have the classrooms and we don't have the money."
A day after Gov. George E. Pataki signed legislation allowing for the opening of six more casinos upstate, Mr. Bloomberg said he opposed such a move for New York City. Mr. Green, who two weeks ago had said he would be open to casinos in the city as a way of bringing in revenues, backed off that position last night. "I'm against it, for now, anywhere in the city," he said.
Mr. Bloomberg was measured and reserved, almost seeming fatigued. By contrast, Mr. Green was peppy, perhaps even overenthused. In his repeated attempt to boast about the communities he had visited, he proclaimed: "There are 200 different groups, 200 neighborhoods from Flushing to Forest Hills from Bayside to Bay Shore, I have been to every community."
Mr. Bloomberg's spokesman, Edward Skyler, issued a statement after the debate questioning, sarcastically, why it was that Mr. Green had been campaigning for mayor of New York City on Long Island.
At another point, Mr. Green was disparaging Mr. Bloomberg for criticizing him as a career politician, noting that he had described politics as an honorable profession in his book. "My rival, on page 232 of his book, 'Bloomberg by Bloomberg'. . ." Mr. Green stopped and considered the title of the book. "And they call me arrogant!" he said, laughing at his own joke.
Mr. Bloomberg said: "I don't remember what's on page 220, it's not the sort of thing that I spend time. . ."
Mr. Green broke in with a correction. "Two thirty two."
"Or 232," Mr. Bloomberg said. "I'm also pleased that you're able to describe yourself, I think a lot of people would agree with your characterization of yourself."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
CHARTER COMMUNICATIONS CUTS 2001 SALES FORECAST

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 Charter Communications, the cable television operator controlled by the billionaire Paul Allen, cut its 2001 sales forecast yesterday and posted a wider third-quarter loss. Sales are expected to rise 12.5 percent to 13.5 percent, down from 15.5 percent, as consumers cut spending amid a slowing economy. The company's third-quarter loss widened to $317.4 million, or $1.08 a share, from $210 million, or 93 cents, a year earlier. Carl Vogel, Charter's chief executive, pledged to help stem the decline and said customer demand for new services was strong. The company has systems in St. Louis, Boston, Fort Worth and Los Angeles.

HEADLINE: Mayor Pleads Not Guilty To Charges Of Corruption 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, Nov. 2 

 BODY:
Moments before pleading not guilty to a host of corruption charges in Federal District Court here, Mayor Joseph P. Ganim of Bridgeport was relaxed enough this afternoon to work the courtroom, warmly greeting supporters and members of the press and pantomiming to the courtroom artist to sketch him with more hair.
 But he was solemn as he answered, "Not guilty, Your Honor," to the 24 counts -- including bribery, extortion, racketeering and tax fraud -- read to him by Judge Janet Bond Arterton. 
 Mr. Ganim, the mayor of the state's largest city and not long ago a leading Democratic contender for governor, was arraigned and released on $100,000 bond after surrendering his passport. His next court appearance is set for Dec. 10. 
After the arraignment, Mr. Ganim, 42, appeared on the courthouse steps with his wife, Jennifer, his parents and all seven of his brothers and sisters. His address to the crowd, a few of whom held signs aloft offering encouraging words, echoed the defiant tone of the two prior news conferences he has held since his indictment on Wednesday.
"This isn't the news conference I imagined having in November," he said. "I expected to announce my candidacy for governor. Let me say once again, I am innocent of the charges. I have been betrayed by the people I trusted."
Since June, a trucking company and nine people who were close associates or friends of the mayor have pleaded guilty to various corruption charges in an exhaustive investigation that federal prosecutors say leads to Mr. Ganim.
The indictment charges Mr. Ganim with receiving more than $425,000 in cash, meals, clothing, jewelry, "investment quality" wine and home landscaping services, in exchange for pressuring businesses that received thousands of dollars in city contracts to pay small fortunes in consulting fees to friends and associates, including his former chief of staff and former campaign manager.
After the indictment, Gov. John G. Rowland and United States Representative Christopher Shays, both Republicans, said Mr. Ganim should step down because he must focus on his defense. But the mayor vowed today to remain in office and govern without interruption -- even though his lawyer, Richard Meehan Jr., had just asked the judge for more time before their next court appearance so he and his client can review the voluminous papers and hours of recordings supporting the indictment.
In the meantime, the state and the city are tightening their policies to ensure fiscal accountability in a City Hall still led by Mr. Ganim.
In September, the State Department of Economic and Community Development informed Bridgeport of more stringent controls on state aid. Bridgeport will be reimbursed quarterly for its expenses, rather than receiving the money upfront. Since 1995, the state has given $120 million to Bridgeport for infrastructure-related projects, including the Seaview Avenue and Lacey Manufacturing industrial parks still under construction.
Governor Rowland's spokesman, Dean Pagani, said today that state and federal reviews have so far turned up no indication that state money was used in any of the Bridgeport bribery or kickback schemes.
"We've performed several reviews of state projects and state accounts as these developments have unfolded," Mr. Pagani said. "If it turns out state funds were misused, we'll address it." 
The state is conducting internal audits of the money given Bridgeport since 1995, and plans to keep auditing the city's books. Additional project managers and accountants were recently hired on a contract basis to perform a more intensive review to ensure that no state funds were misspent by Bridgeport, said Rita Zangari, deputy commissioner of the Department of Economic and Community Development.
In addition, the City Council has started a more rigorous review of its budget and purchasing policies, said John M. Fabrizi, council president and the man who would, according to City Charter, replace Mr. Ganim should he resign or be removed from office. Next week, the Council will vote to establish a new oversight committee, separate from its ethics committee, to investigate any formal complaints from city employees or vendors who seek work from the city.
"We've learned from this," said Mr. Fabrizi, referring to the municipal corruption scandal. "The City Council is absolutely determined to change city government and make sure things like this can't happen again."

HEADLINE: A Mainstay of U.S. Job Creation Is Hit Hard by Sept. 11 

BYLINE:  By MARY WILLIAMS WALSH 

 BODY:
The services sector, which has been America's main engine of job creation since World War II, has been dealt a powerful blow by the events of Sept. 11.
Of the 619,000 jobs that disappeared from September to October, 111,000 were counted by the government as service positions. The decline was the sector's largest since the Bureau of Labor Statistics began keeping track. 
 Travel-related businesses in particular cut their staffs as the terrorist attacks made Americans reluctant to fly. The number of jobs in hotels fell by 46,000, compared with an average monthly decline of 5,000 from July to September. 
 The number of jobs defined as "auto services" -- a category that includes jobs at car-rental agencies and in parking lots -- fell by 13,000. Normally the category does not change significantly from month to month. 
"We know that car rentals in airports are in very bad shape with the big cutback in air-transportation use," said Lois Plunkert, a senior economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "And perhaps the auto parking at airports would have been affected, too."
About 81,000 jobs in the retail trade, which includes car dealerships and restaurants, disappeared from September to October. Government data also suggested that stores are not hiring holiday help this year as much as usual. 
But economists counseled against concluding that the whole services sector suddenly nose-dived. They said that for statistical reasons, a large number of jobs that the government counts as services actually involve manufacturing duties. Because of this, they said, a portion of the services sector's job losses were attributable to the decline of American manufacturing, which has been going on for years.
John Stinson, a labor economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, said the line separating service and manufacturing jobs has been blurred in recent years by the sharp increase in the number of contingency workers, known as temps. Such workers are officially defined as service employees because they are hired and paid by temporary agencies, Mr. Stinson said. But many temps are sent to perform manufacturing jobs by their agencies. 
Since temps are usually the first to be laid off in a downturn, their growing presence throughout the economy has made the services sector more prone to the cyclical ups and downs that used to afflict mainly the construction and manufacturing sectors.
"There has been a lot of weakness in the temporary-help agencies," Mr. Stinson said. "It's not just a one-month thing at all. A lot of it is related to manufacturing."
Jeffrey A. Joerres, the chief executive of Manpower, the large temporary-help concern, said the company had found recession-level demand for temps in August, when it conducted its most recent quarterly survey.
But demand had been tapering off even before that, he said, adding that Manpower gets about 40 percent of its revenues from placing people in light manufacturing jobs.
The new public concerns about security did swell the ranks of one kind of services-sector job, however: detective, guard and armored-car services employment increased by 8,000 jobs in September and 22,000 jobs in October. Before the terrorist attacks, the category had not been growing at all.
Employment in mortgage banking also appeared to be expanding, spurred by the recent declines in interest rates. Mortgage banks added employees from September to October, even as other financial-services firms were laying people off.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Analysts Worry of Ripple Effect In Argentina's Latest Debt Plan

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Argentina's newest proposal to reduce its debt burden might lead to a default that could make it very difficult for emerging-market countries to borrow in the future.
 So far, there have not been too many ripples beyond the impact on Argentina's neighbor, Brazil. 
 But the longer-term outlook depends a lot on how the debt is restructured to lower Argentina's financial burden and on whether investors are forced to accept a package they are unhappy with.
Problems with the restructuring program are already appearing. 
"In the short run, this has been telegraphed so long that the knock-on effect is going to be muted," said Carl Ross, senior managing director for emerging markets at Bear, Stearns. "I am concerned about the long-term contagion. If Argentina defaults, there will not be an immediate cascading of countries defaulting. But over time there could be.
"In the future," he added, "countries looking at Argentina's experience might conclude that if this is where we are going to end up anyway, why put our populations through the pain?" Argentina has already suffered through four years of recession and large budget cuts to meet its debt payments.
The issue of whether Argentina defaults during its effort to restructure as much as $95 billion in bonds held by Argentinian banks and institutions and foreigners is complicated by the definition of what is a default. But definition aside, a restructuring that leaves many investors unhappy with the deal will not be positive, Mr. Ross said.
An investor in emerging market debt, who spoke on the condition of not being named, said that a drawn out and messy restructuring of Argentina's debt, especially if it were repeated in other countries, could dry up the lending pool for emerging-market countries.
Argentina faces other tough problems that could undermine its effort to reach a deal with its creditors. Problems include declining tax revenue as the global economic slowdown drags Argentina's economy lower; the need to meet a zero deficit target to comply with terms for additional aid from the International Monetary Fund; difficult negotiations with the country's provinces on cutting spending; the withdrawal of money from the banking system by frightened investors; and obtaining the additional cash needed to offer its creditors a debt swap that is attractive to them while also reducing the country's debt burden enough to ease the pressure on the government and the economy.
Beyond all of that, any recovery for Argentina depends on turning the economy around, a task that has become even more difficult since the terrorist attack on the United States.
"There is a lot of uncertainty right now," said Joyce Chang, global head of international fixed income research at J. P. Morgan. She said that the prices of Argentina's bonds in the market already showed that investors "are pricing in an effective default."
The fact that the fallout from the current stage of Argentina's crisis has been limited is seen in the performance of bond prices this week. While Argentina's floating rate bond maturing in 2005 fell 17.5 points, or 27.6 percent, to $46, the popular Brazilian C bond maturing in 2014 dropped just 1.75 points, or 2.5 percent.
Bond prices in the rest of Latin America fell even less, with a popular bond in Mexico down just three-tenths of a point. And the Brazilian real, which has fallen 27 percent this year as the Argentine crisis deepened, has been in a mild rally since Sept. 21, rising 6 percent.
One reason for the moderate reaction is that many investors have already pulled out of Argentina and the countries they think could be hurt by its crisis. In addition, there are fewer big bettors in emerging markets since Russia defaulted on its debt in 1998.
Four large American banks have significant exposure to Argentine and other Latin American debt, and a new Lehman Brothers analysis says they "have been under pressure on renewed concerns about Argentina's debt woes." The four are FleetBoston, Citigroup, Bank of America and J. P. Morgan Chase. Lehman Brothers said that FleetBoston's Latin American loans accounted for about 10 percent of net income and noted that Citigroup said in the second quarter that Argentine loans contributed less than 2 percent to earnings. J. P. Morgan Chase and Bank of America each have about $900 million in loans in Argentina.
Problems with Argentina's plan to reduce its debt burden arose as soon as the country issued the barest of details. In a statement of economic policy changes to deal with the crisis, the government said Thursday that it wanted to save about $4 billion a year in debt service costs by cutting the aggregate interest rate on its debt to 7 percent from about 11 percent now. That is a reduction of nearly 40 percent. In exchange, the government has said it will offer guarantees of payment of principle and interest.
"It is difficult to believe that they have enough credit enhancements to go from 11 percent to 7 percent," Mr. Ross of Bear Stearns said, referring to the sweeteners the government would need to offer investors. "This is why the market is a little confused right now."
Because there are no details, investors are assuming a debt restructuring would be something like the famous Brady bonds used in the late 1980's and early 1990's to restructure Latin American debt, including that of Argentina. All those deals included significant debt reduction in exchange for guarantees of principle and interest payments.
The trader in emerging market debt who asked not to be named said there was a 50 percent chance now that the restructuring of Argentina's debt would be "a long, drawn-out messy process."
On the issue of default, the major credit rating agencies have already indicated that they will give a default rating to the new bonds in a debt exchange like the one Argentina is contemplating. That is because the value of the new bonds will be less than the value of the old bonds. A legal default, according to analysts, is more complicated, requiring a triggering event, like missing an interest or principle payment, followed by a vote of a majority or more of the bondholders to force the default.
Argentina says that it wants its exchange to be voluntary and that if enough bondholders agree to it, a legal default could be avoided, analysts said. But there will be a lot of pressure on investors, including banks and pension funds in Argentina, to agree, so a voluntary agreement may be less voluntary than it appears. And one may not be able to be reached.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Jobless Rate Rises to 5.4% As 400,000 Are Dismissed
More than 400,000 Americans lost their jobs last month, the most for a single month in nearly two decades, and the unemployment rate jumped to 5.4 percent, its highest level since 1996, from 4.9 percent in September.
 Analysts believe the economy is clearly in a recession and even though they expect the Federal Reserve to cut short-term interest rates in another attempt to stimulate the economy, they say the question now is how deep will the recession be? Page A1. 

Microsoft Antitrust Case Advances
Microsoft and the federal government finalized their settlement of the antitrust case, agreeing to a number of covenants that give more flexibility to computer makers installing the company's Windows software while restricting pricing agreements that Microsoft can impose. The company, run by Bill Gates, also will have to form a three-member committee to monitor compliance with the agreement. But state prosecutors declined to endorse the deal and persuaded a judge to hold off approval until they can review it. A1.

Air Travel Security Gaps Persist
Major gaps remain in aviation security nearly two months after the terrorist attacks. With Congress stalemated over whether to federalize airport screening workers, some airlines and airports are taking steps to improve security on their own, but passengers still encounter lapses they find alarming. B7.

Analysts Warn of Argentine Default
Wall Street economists and analysts portrayed a new Argentine effort to restructure its $132 billion national debt as tantamount to a default and the largest financial collapse of any country in history. Argentine bond prices plummeted and interest rates soared in anticipation of a default on nearly $95 billion in bonds, more than twice the amount that Russia failed to honor three years ago. A4.

Cigna's Third-Quarter Profit Falls
Cigna, a provider of health insurance, said that its third-quarter profit fell 2.9 percent, to $270 million, as the cost of medical care rose and life and disability insurance claims increased after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. C2.

Tiffany Plans Store in Beijing
Tiffany, the luxury goods retailer, plans to open a store in Beijing to cater to the growing number of affluent customers in China. C4.

Stocks Gain Despite Gloomy Data
Stocks picked up some modest gains as investors looked beyond bleak economic news. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index edged up 3.10 points, or 0.3 percent, to 1,087.20. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 59.64 points, or 0.6 percent, to 9,323.54. The Nasdaq composite slipped 0.57 points, to 1,745.73. C4.

Prudential of Britain to Cut Jobs
Prudential, Britain's second-largest insurer, said it would cut 2,100 jobs and sell its property and casualty unit to the Credit Suisse Group for $517 million. C2.

Marathon Buys West African Assets
USX-Marathon agreed to buy CMS Energy's stakes in oil and natural-gas fields and methanol and gas-processing plants in West Africa's Equatorial Guinea for $993 million doubling the company's West African output. C4.

Security Company's Profit Declines
Wackenhut, a provider of security guards, said that its profit fell 71 percent to $900,000 in the third quarter even as revenue rose at all of its businesses. C3.

Italy's Tourism Industry Fears Crisis
Italy's tourism industry is suffering its worst crisis in half a century and needs emergency aid from the government, a business group said. C3.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: RELIEF; 
U.S. Orders New Aid to Help Avert Famine in Afghanistan

BYLINE:  By ELIZABETH BECKER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 

 BODY:
The Bush administration said today that it was spending $8.2 million in emergency aid for Afghanistan, most of which would be used to buy trucks to transport 30,000 tons of wheat immediately to northern Afghanistan. It was the second emergency purchase this week intended to avert what the administration is now calling famine conditions.
 With only days before the first snows fall in Afghanistan's central mountains, Andrew S. Natsios, the administrator for the Agency for International Development, said relief officials were buying the trucks in central Asia this week and would begin using them immediately to deliver the food. 
 The new trucks will be loaded with $6 million worth of wheat being purchased in Kazakhstan this week. Because of its increasing concern over a food crisis in Afghanistan, the administration approved the local wheat purchase on Wednesday, saying there was not enough time to buy American wheat and then ship it to the region. 
"With these trucks we're buying time; we'll be able to move the food in within days and not have to wait for shipments that are already on the move but won't arrive for weeks," Mr. Natsios said.
The announcement was part of a ceremony marking the 40th anniversary of A.I.D., which was founded by President Kennedy and inspired by Gen. George C. Marshall and his plan to rebuild Europe. 
In an address to more than 1,000 A.I.D. staffers, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell invoked the spirit of General Marshall and promised that the United States would rebuild Afghanistan when the war was over.
"We will help them rebuild, we will not abandon them," he said. "We've made that geopolitical decision, and you are the ones who will make sure that happens."
After months of hearing conflicting views from the administration on the advisability of rebuilding devastated nations and installing friendly governments in them, the agency with that task cheered the secretary of state. 
Secretary Powell also told them their largely unheralded work in Afghanistan would become more difficult but more essential to a victory over terrorism.
"Osama bin Laden launched that attack from Afghanistan, a place where you have been helping people for years," he said. "What you have done in Afghanistan and will continue to do is an important part of our foreign policy." 
It is the job of the A.I.D. to ensure that 250,000 tons of food are transported into the country by the end of the year, according to Mr. Natsios, who called the effort a crucial part of the campaign to convince the Afghan people that the United States is their friend, not their enemy.
While the Pentagon issues daily reports of food rations the military is dropping into Afghanistan by air -- to date it has dropped roughly 500 tons -- A.I.D. has been working with the United Nations and private relief organizations to ship in the bulk of the food and supplies.
In the last week, relief groups said they were afraid they were losing the race to bring enough food to prevent widespread starvation in Afghanistan this winter.
Even before the United States began its campaign in October, A.I.D. had warned that Afghanistan was "on the verge of widespread and precipitous famine" after 22 years of war and conflict and three years of drought.
After the bombing began, officials said relief agencies had increasing difficulty trucking in wheat. Taliban officials and bandits have stolen food stocks and are charging taxes for passage. Truck drivers were reluctant to drive from Pakistan into Taliban-controlled areas and the Pentagon and British Defense Ministry had to set up a coordination cell in Islamabad to prevent airstrikes from hitting relief convoys.
Now, most of the trucks with new food shipments will enter Afghanistan from the north -- through Iran, Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan and Tajikistan -- and transport shipments to what is called the "famine belt."
With the prospect of subzero temperatures, relief officials worry that the weak and the young could die as easily from the cold as from hunger, making it imperative to ship in clothing, medicine and building materials as well as food.
"The good news is that three-quarters of the population at risk for starvation live in the northern half of Afghanistan, outside of the war zones," Mr. Natsios said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Afghans loading sacks of relief aid onto rafts to ferry them across the Pyandzh River, which separates Tajikistan from Afghanistan. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: ASSESSING THE THREAT; 
As Troops Guard Major Bridges, a Warning Is Debated

BYLINE:  By BERNARD WEINRAUB with NEIL A. LEWIS 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Nov. 2 

 BODY:
Caravans of armed National Guard troops and Highway Patrol officers fanned out across bridges in California's largest cities today to guard against potential terrorist attacks that Gov. Gray Davis suggested on Thursday might be imminent.
 But the severity of the threat remained a subject of debate, and Mr. Davis's decision to disclose it served as a source of irritation, if not anger, among some state and federal law enforcement officials. 
 On a clear sunlit day across the state, the governor's warning made some drivers nervous, but not reluctant to cross the four bridges that were, he said, under threat. Traffic was only slightly less than normal for a Friday, and slowed down only as drivers gawked at the troops and officers guarding the bridges and the helicopters that hovered above. "Traffic during our morning rush hour was down about 7 percent for a Friday, but now it's about the same," said Kary Witt, manager of the Golden Gate Bridge, as he drove north this afternoon. Speaking on his car phone. Mr. Witt said, "I see the Coast Guard beneath the bridge and a lot of troops on the bridge. It's business as usual." 
Mr. Davis announced on Thursday that federal officials had "credible evidence" that terrorists might be targetting four California bridges. Mr. Davis listed the Golden Gate and Bay Bridge in the San Francisco Bay area, the Coronado Bridge connecting San Diego and Coronado and the Vincent Thomas Bridge at the Port of Los Angeles as possible targets in the next few days. The announcement and its aftermath dominated local television news and startled Californians, especially in the San Francisco area. 
After Mr. Davis issued the warning, federal authorities took the unusual step of releasing a copy of a threat advisory sent earlier in the week to officials and law enforcement agencies in the West. "Reportedly, unspecified groups are targeting suspension bridges on the West Coast," the advisory said.
Today, F.B.I. officials said they still had not been able to corroborate the threat, describing the information as "somewhat credible."
At a news conference today, Mr. Davis said he went public with the information after receiving information about potential attacks from the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the United States Customs Service. He said he believed it was important to announce the warning because it specifically mentioned suspension bridges in the West and covered a specific span of time, Nov. 2 through Nov. 7. "I'm confident I made the right decision," he said. "I have no regrets."
In public comments, Bush administration officials seemed to choose their words carefully in responding to Mr. Davis. "I respect the decision that Governor Davis made: he exercised his judgment," said Tom Ridge, the homeland security director. "Had he chosen not to reveal, I would have respected that as well." 
Mr. Ridge said, "Obviously Governor Davis thought that one thing that he could do to enhance the security of people using those bridges was to make a public announcement. We did not encourage him to do so."
But Mr. Ridge said the information sent to Mr. Davis and others made plain that it was "uncorroborated."
Attorney General John Ashcroft also said that the F.B.I. warning about the possible attack on bridges on the West Coast was based on a threat that authorities believed had "relative credibility."
President Bush, too, seemed supportive of Mr. Davis. "Part of the homeland defense is active and strong communications so that governors and/or local authorities can harden targets, respond to uncorroborated evidence and to protect their people," Mr. Bush said in a Rose Garden appearance.
Privately, F.B.I. officials on both coasts remained critical of Mr. Davis, and they rebutted his contention that he had apprised the bureau of his intention to publicize the threat at a press conference on Thursday naming a new terrorism czar. In fact, bureau officials said, Ron Iden, the assistant director for the F.B.I.'s Los Angeles office, was just as surprised as the reporters around when Mr. Davis revealed the warning. 
Some authorities were bluntly critical of Mr. Davis. Charles Plummer, the sheriff of Alameda County, whose officers cover a swath of the California coast from the Oregon border to Monterey Bay, said that Mr. Davis's decision was harmful and that it violated the implicit trust between federal and state law-enforcement agencies. 
"Do you think the F.B.I. is going to tell the governor anything in the future? I don't think so," Mr. Plummer said.
Other prominent West Coast officials, like Mayor James K. Hahn of Los Angeles, Gov. John Kitzhaber of Oregon, and Gov. Gary Locke of Washington had also been notified of the F.B.I. alert. But these officials and others decided not to go public.
"If we received a corroborated and credible threat, we would notify the public of an impending danger," said Dana Middleton, a spokeswoman for Governor Locke. "This was neither."
Mr. Davis, who is up for re-election in 2002, has been under political pressure to reverse his plunging poll numbers brought on by the statewide energy crisis earlier in the year and made worse by a severe economic slowdown in recent months. 
Some analysts suggested that Mr. Davis's aggressive response to the F.B.I.'s warning was prompted in part by a desire to lift his image.
"Every politician, including Gray Davis, wants to be Rudy Giuliani," said Sherry Bebitch Jeffe, a political analyst here, referring to the New York mayor. "Davis is an incumbent running for re-election. He wants to be perceived as being in control of a crisis. He wants to be able to resonate with his constituency."
But Mr. Davis's decision to issue the warning may have had a downside, too. "The bad part for Gray is that the last thing you want to be is controversial," said Bill Carrick, a Democratic political strategist here. "He looks like he could have said things there were exaggerated. And that puts him in a bad spot. He may be well-intentioned, but I don't think you want to have a debate in the media about whether or not this was the right way to handle it. And that's what's happening."
Steve Maviglio, a spokesman for Mr. Davis, denied that politics was in any way related to the decision. "The governor's top priority is to make sure Californians are safe," Mr. Maviglio said. "He feels it's his responsibility to inform the citizens of when there is a credible threat. As the president said, if he were in the governor's shoes he might have done the same thing." Mr Maviglio added that quick polls taken after Mr. Davis's announcement found that an overwhelming majority of Californians believed it should have been made.
Even so, most commuters seemed to take the warning in stride. "I haven't heard a blooming thing, nothing much is happening," said Fern Cooper, a spokeswoman with the San Diego police. An official at the Golden Gate Bridge Authority said that between 6 a.m. and 9 a.m., a total of 13,750 vehicles crossed the bridge. Over the last four Fridays, an average of 14,700 vehicles crossed the bridge between those hours.
Robert Kim, a spokesman for the California Highway Patrol in San Diego, said that the 11,179-foot Coronado Bridge handled about 75,000 cars a day, and that today seemed perfectly normal. Nancy David, 52, on vacation on Coronado Island with her husband, David, a retired store manager from San Bernardino, Calif., said she and her friends had initially decided to stay at their hotel and not cross the bridge. "Then we decided that was silly," Ms. David said. "But I'll probably hold my breath all the way across."
Nathan Hiedo, a clerk in a liquor store on Orange Avenue who lives 25 miles north of San Diego, said he considered taking a roundabout way this morning. But then he decided to cross the bridge to Coronado, a town of 26,000.
"You know, the U.S. Army, there are fighting over there, in Afghanistan, and we are fighting here, in America, by not being afraid and driving across that bridge," Mr. Hiedo said. "When I think of what they are doing over there, I know that I must do my part here, too. Let's face it. Our job is easier than theirs."

HEADLINE: Cincinnati's Revival Sags Under Weight of Falling Revenue 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: CINCINNATI 

 BODY:
The two new stadiums along the Ohio River in downtown Cincinnati are supposed to anchor a complex of condominiums, stores, offices, restaurants, parks and a world-class history museum. But between the stadiums, the six-block stretch of riverfront is barren and paved over, serving only as a makeshift parking lot.
 Downtown redevelopment, the great hope of urban planners for reviving older cities, has been delayed in Cincinnati, a casualty of the gathering recession. The sales tax revenue that supports construction has fallen this year, and city officials are seeking ways to keep the project going. 
 Other cities are facing similar tax revenue shortfalls, restricting the financing for downtown redevelopment for the first time since the early 1990's.
"The sales tax is a big, big chunk of state and local funding everywhere in America for these projects," said Martin Regalia, chief economist at the United States Chamber of Commerce.
The slowdown in the national economy, entering its 16th month in November, has already dried up investment, reduced consumer spending and led to hundreds of thousands of layoffs. In recent months, it has hit states and municipalities.
With recent federal administrations bent on shrinking government, public spending has shifted to states and localities. Together, in 1999, they spent an amount equal to 62 percent of federal spending -- up from 54 percent in 1990 and 42 percent in 1960, according to a University of Michigan study. 
Some of this spending went into downtown redevelopment. Erecting stadiums to retain or lure professional sports teams became the focus in cities like Cincinnati, Cleveland, Los Angeles and Baltimore. 
Beyond stadiums, public money is going into the roads, parking garages, parks and other infrastructure so private developers can put up commercial buildings, apartments and theaters near the ballparks. 
As long as the economy boomed, there was tax revenue to finance downtown redevelopment, whose cost in Cincinnati is approaching $1 billion. Even now, officials here talk of a delay, but never cancellation.
"If we bail out now, the momentum may be lost forever," said Thomas L. Neyer Jr., one of the three elected commissioners who govern Hamilton County, which includes Cincinnati. "If the economy requires us to wait a year or two, so be it."
No company is a bigger supporter of downtown redevelopment than Procter & Gamble, whose headquarters, factories and research centers here are a huge presence. Charlotte Otto, a senior executive there, resists even a short delay. She speaks of "creative financing" -- a bridge loan, for example, that would be repaid when the recession ends and tax revenue rises again -- to keep the riverfront project going.
"Given the challenges, it would be easier to say, 'Let's put off redevelopment for a year,' " Ms. Otto said. "But we can't; the riverfront project is really the catalyst for a vital downtown." 
But some experts take a different view of the value of such redevelopment projects. Where such projects have seemed to work -- Faneuil Hall in Boston and South Street Seaport in New York, for example -- the real generators of jobs and growth were Boston's appeal as a high-tech center and New York's role as a financial powerhouse, said Edward Glaeser, a Harvard economist and urban specialist.
"These cities would have prospered without redevelopment projects," Mr. Glaeser said. "They were only an added attraction."
That is an argument largely ignored in many cities. Driven by a yearning for urban revival -- and the political and commercial success it seemed to promise -- local governments have channeled hundreds of millions of dollars into the new projects.
In Cincinnati's case, revenue from the sales tax, which is levied by the state, pays the monthly installments on the bonds floated to build the stadiums, at a cost of more than $700 million. Hamilton County has traditionally received half a percentage point of the 5.5 percent state sales tax collected in the county. While the economy was booming, the county's voters agreed in 1996 to add half a percentage point to the state levy, bringing it to 6 percent here, to help finance the riverfront construction. To quiet opposition, however, part is paid out for education and for rebates on property taxes.
Opponents of redevelopment argue that the money should have been spent on schools or on rebuilding commercial districts in ghetto areas. 
"The riverfront complex becomes the playground of people in the suburbs," said the Rev. Damon Lynch 3rd, pastor of the New Prospect Baptist Church, in a downtown ghetto neighborhood. "They want to drive in, enjoy the arts, the fine dining, the riverfront, the ballet, the symphony, and drive home."
Now the slowing economy, aggravated by the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, is doing what the opposition could not: forcing postponement of another major bond offering, this one to build six blocks of underground parking garages between the stadiums, at a cost of at least $60 million. They are needed to lift the river's flood level. The complex of commercial establishments and cultural centers could then be built atop the garages.
The financing for this construction was based on the assumption that the sales tax revenue would continue to increase at an annual rate of 5 percent to 7 percent, as it did in the 1990's. Instead, sales tax revenue began to fall this year and through September was 3.5 percent below last year's collections.
Only one small part of the vast underground garage -- the only part financed under the existing bonds -- is being built. A single orange construction crane, swinging gracefully back and forth, marks the site along the otherwise inactive riverbank, cleared now of the industrial structures that once marked Cincinnati as a thriving city. That section of the garage is to be the foundation for a privately financed museum celebrating the underground railroad, which brought slaves to freedom in Cincinnati, across the river from Kentucky.
The hope is that the elaborate exhibitions will rival Washington's Holocaust museum in attracting visitors from all over the world. Construction is to start early next year.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED -- AN OVERVIEW: NOV 2, 2001; 
Bad Economic News, Troops on the Golden Gate, Angry Firefighters

BYLINE:  By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
 There was more economic fallout from Sept. 11, none of it good. The government had already reported that the economy shrank over the summer, for the first time in eight years. Now, the word from the Labor Department was that 415,000 Americans had lost their jobs in October, the most for a single month since 1980. The unemployment rate jumped half a percentage point, to 5.4 percent, well above the 3.9 percent rate just 13 months before.

AN ECONOMIC STIMULUS -- Not that the economy was going like gangbusters before the terrorist strikes. But the attacks seem to have dashed hopes among business leaders for a speedy recovery after a mild recession. Estimates were that one-fourth of the jobs that were lost was a result of September's terrorism. "It is not good news for America," President Bush acknowledged.
 His proposed solution is a stimulus package approved by the House, one that relies mainly on tax cuts, especially for businesses. But the Democrats who control the Senate want a greater emphasis on public spending. Tax cuts, they say, are unlikely to persuade businesses to hire and to spend, not when profits are shrinking in a weak economy. Mr. Bush says he wants a final bill on his desk by Nov. 30, but it was far from clear if Congress would meet his deadline.

PATROLLING THE GOLDEN GATE -- As the economy turned down, security worries bumped up, most visibly in California. There, armed troops patrolled the Golden Gate and several other bridges after Gov. Gray Davis warned of "credible evidence" pointing to an imminent terrorist attack. Traffic seemed close to normal, though. And some law enforcement officials, local and federal, were annoyed with Mr. Davis. They were not as sure as he seemed to be about the credibility of his evidence.

ANTHRAX MYSTERY -- Nor did any hard proof emerge in the anthrax threat. The director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Robert S. Mueller III, acknowledged that the government had no clue who was responsible -- a foreign terrorist cell, a domestic hate group or perhaps a deranged loner with scientific know-how. In effect, Mr. Mueller deputized all Americans, urging them to do amateur sleuthing of their own. They could, for example, study the handwriting on anthrax letters that have been made public to see if it looks familiar.
One hopeful glimmer was the absence of evidence of any more bioterrorism beyond the mail-borne anthrax seen in recent weeks. There were fears of possibly new attacks after the death of Kathy T. Nguyen, a New York hospital worker, who did not fit the dominant victim profile: postal workers and employees of news organizations. Now, health investigators suspect that Ms. Nguyen's infection was linked somehow to anthrax-contaminated mail, same as the other cases. But exactly how she caught the disease was still a puzzle.

A WIDER NET -- Anger over terrorism impelled the Bush administration to expand the list of suspected terrorists beyond a few groups like Al Qaeda, Osama bin Laden's network. Tough financial sanctions were imposed on 22 organizations, including Hamas, Hezbollah and others with broad support in the Arab world. Irish and Spanish groups were also named. The action pleased Israel's allies and disappointed supporters of Arab countries, which wanted to keep the spotlight only on Al Qaeda.
For all the brave attempts at stiff upper lips, the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks rubbed emotions raw, nowhere more so than in New York, and among no group more brutally than the city's firefighters. They lost 343 of their colleagues in the World Trade Center. Many still have trouble coming to grips with that staggering number.

A PROTEST IN GRIEF -- Frustrations boiled over at ground zero, where firefighters marched in anger over a City Hall order reducing their numbers at the site for safety reasons. The ruins had become too unstable to have a lot of people gathered around, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said. But firefighters, focused on the search for buried colleagues, insisted on being allowed to remain in force on what they consider hallowed ground. So they protested. A dozen of them were arrested after they broke through barricades and scuffled with police officers (who lost 23 of their own on Sept. 11).
It was a painful coda to a tragedy already hard enough to bear. He understood the firefighters' anguish, Mr. Giuliani said. But no one is above the law, he said, and the safety experts must be heeded "even if our hearts may tell us something different." CLYDE HABERMAN

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE GOVERNOR; 
Talk About Terrorism Puts Heat on Gov. Davis

BYLINE:  By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: BURBANK, Calif., Nov. 2 

 BODY:
Gov. Gray Davis presided today over a feel-good session on how to right the badly listing California economy, but no matter how hard the business and labor leaders here tried to focus on tax credits and accelerated spending, the talk inevitably veered toward terrorism -- and Mr. Davis's sudden, ticklish problem with that issue.
 By announcing on Thursday that terrorists might try to attack California's major bridges, Mr. Davis created a stir. But the attention was focused more intensely on him than on the bridges, underscoring the complex problems he faces as he prepares to run for re-election next year. 
 While Mr. Davis managed to get through the summer without the rolling power blackouts that many experts had predicted, he has since had to deal with a sour state economy, potentially tough Republican challengers and now the threat of terrorist attacks.
Politicians might say it is better to be called an alarmist than to be the one who failed to alert the public to a genuine threat. But the Federal Bureau of Investigation has expressed surprise and annoyance that Mr. Davis had passed on an "uncorroborated" threat, one that the agency had never intended to become public.
Mr. Davis's political opponents then added to his mounting troubles by suggesting he had been trying to gain political advantage, or by questioning his judgment. 
Dave Cox, for example, the head of the Republican caucus in the State Assembly, said the decision to publicize the threat had been a tough call for the governor, a Democrat, and then added, "I think the American public needs to know, but we need to be cautious about not frightening it."
A Republican investment banker, William E. Simon Jr., who announced his candidacy for governor today, put it bluntly: "When you come out and make blanket statements that bridges might be attacked, that sends a certain level of panic and fear in people."
And while Mr. Davis's longtime allies expressed support, it was conspicuously tepid.
The issue touched directly on a proposal made repeatedly at this conference: that the state should sharply increase spending for a tourism campaign. Restaurants, hotels and theme parks have suffered steep declines since the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11.
But if the campaign were to rely on famous attractions, one would clearly be the Golden Gate Bridge. Kathleen Connell, the state controller, said that such images could not be used now, and that any campaign would now be tougher to mount.
"His comments had a short-term negative impact," said Ms. Connell, a Democrat, "but it could be even worse in the long term . That image of the bridges being so vulnerable is going to remain in people's minds." 
The overall issue -- security versus full disclosure -- was summed up by Ed Leamers, an economic forecaster at the University of California at Los Angeles, who criticized the heavy police presence at the Los Angeles International Airport, calling it "more alarming than secure."
The same F.B.I. warning Mr. Davis received went to other Western governors and local law enforcement officials, and none disclosed it -- a fact that some politicians tacked on to what otherwise sounded like votes of confidence.
"I support whatever decision the governor made, and do not want to second-guess him," said Bill Jones, California's secretary of state and a Republican candidate for governor. "But, having said that, it seems strange that the governor of Washington State got the same threat and chose not to release it."
The criticism is something Mr. Davis, who sailed through two years in office with strong public support, has been hearing a lot of lately. The volume of the attacks seemed a reflection of the sudden vulnerability of a politician who had appeared likely to glide into a second term.
Mr. Davis has rejected that view. In an interview today at the conference he insisted, "I made the call that I know is right." He denied there was any political influence over his decision. 
But Democrats expressed little support. Robert M. Hertzberg, the Democratic speaker of the Assembly and usually a strong ally, said he could not judge because he did not know all the facts that Mr. Davis had relied on.
John Burton, the Democratic president of the State Senate, said he wondered why, if the threat was that great, traffic on the big bridges was not halted.
"We have word that terrorists are going to blow up the bridge, but that people should keep crossing it?" Mr. Burton asked.
The governor said he would consider many of the suggestions made at the economic conference, and repeated that, since this was only the second specific threat the F.B.I. had received since Sept. 11, it seemed better to tell people than keep them in the dark.
"There is no playbook for these times," Mr. Davis said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Gray Davis at an economic conference yesterday. (Misha Erwitt for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
KPMG CONSULTING WILL CUT ITS WORK FORCE BY 3%

BYLINE:  Reuters 

 BODY:
 KPMG Consulting Inc., a top consulting firm, said yesterday that it would cut up to 400 jobs, or 3 percent of its work force, and take a second-quarter charge of $15 million to $20 million as it copes with the economic slowdown. KPMG, based in McLean, Va., also said 300 employees had chosen to take voluntary leaves of absence as part of a work force alternative program. The job cuts will be spread across the company's global work force with "very small impacts in any one area," the company said. KPMG is part of a large number of financial services companies cutting costs as the threat of recession looms.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
CAR MAKER'S ATLANTA PLANT TO IDLE 2,100 WORKERS

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
 The Ford Motor Company will close an Atlanta car plant for a week starting on Monday, idling about 2,100 workers, to reduce production because of lower orders from rental-car companies and businesses. The plant makes the Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable sedans. United States auto sales surged 24 percent last month, and Ford's sales nationwide rose 36 percent in October, helped by no-interest loans. Orders from rental-car companies and businesses looking to add to fleets slid 30 percent last month and have been declining since July as a slowing economy reduces travel demand and prompts companies to scale back on purchasing, a Ford sales analyst, George Pipas, said.

HEADLINE: Suddenly, Americans Trust Uncle Sam 

BYLINE:  By ALEXANDER STILLE 

 BODY:
The titles of the new releases say it all: "The Trouble with Government," "Disaffected Democracies" and "Why People Don't Trust Government." This fall a host of new books with a variety of new theories tried to explain a well-established, generation-long trend: Americans' steadily declining trust in government. Then September's terrorist attacks turned prevailing ideas about people's faith in their political institutions upside down, along with so much else.
 The public's reactions to the events of the last two months have been so extreme and apparently contradictory that they have sent social scientists back to the drawing boards, providing them with a real-life, real-time laboratory in which to measure the complex and often ambivalent relationship Americans have with their government. 
 After the attacks, arguably a result of an enormous government failure in intelligence and airport security, many Americans turned to government and found a renewed faith in some institutions that have not been held in high regard in recent decades, like Congress and the media. Within weeks, the number of people who said they trusted the government to do what is right most of the time hit its highest levels in 30 years, rising to 55 percent in a recent New York Times/CBS News poll. And suddenly a majority of Americans felt that the country was moving in the right direction, even though the stock market was falling precipitately and hundreds of thousands of workers were losing their jobs. At the same time, growing numbers of people have expressed concern about the government's muddled reaction to the recent anthrax attacks and the uneven progress of the war. And a majority of Americans, 52 percent, still favor a smaller government providing fewer services, although the percentage of Americans who say they want a bigger government providing more services has jumped to 43 from 32.
"Trauma and war bring out communal solidarity and remind people of why we have government," said Francis Fukuyama, professor of international affairs at Johns Hopkins University. "But the fact that the numbers keep moving around shows that it can be quite ephemeral. Foreign policy crises and national security threats are generally times of state-building, but only if government is seen as being effective. If we screw up the military side of things and the anthrax problem, things could change a lot."
Pollsters are used to presidential approval ratings going up and down, but trust in government has been a much less volatile index and one that social scientists consider a more useful barometer of the public's attitude toward government. Trust in government went up during the 1991 Persian Gulf war, but by only about 7 percentage points in a Washington Post/ABC News poll, a fraction of the recent 22-point rise.
"Part of it is rallying around the flag in a time of crisis," said Robert Putnam, a professor of political science at Harvard University who has written extensively about the decline of trust in his book "Bowling Alone" and as editor of a recent volume titled "Disaffected Democracies," "but part of it reflects something deeper: the only people going up the stairs of the World Trade Center while everyone else was going down were government officials. The events made us all realize the government does important work." He was quick to add: "This is a big jump, and if it should persist, it would change the whole political climate. But no one knows how the country would react to repeated terrorist attacks."
Mr. Putnam and other researchers say the subtler long-term effect could be a realignment of people's attitude toward government, the beginnings of which can be seen in recent government actions: the bailout of the airline and insurance industries, disaster aid for New York City, the extension of unemployment benefits and an increased federal role in airport security.
"All of a sudden you have Republicans sounding like liberals," said C. W. Brands, a historian at Texas A&M University and the author of a recent book, "The Strange Death of American Liberalism," which ascribed the decline of liberalism and of trust in government to the waning of the cold war. "A crisis makes liberals out of everyone, in the sense of people seeing a positive role for government. My theory is that if this crisis persists, people will get used to the idea of looking to government to solve problems and it will spill over into other areas."
Whatever the long-term political consequences, the events since Sept. 11 have upset the conventional thinking about Americans' faith in their government.
When public opinion surveys began testing trust in government in the 1950's, three-quarters of Americans responded that they expected the federal government to do the right thing most or pretty much all of the time. It was one of the highest levels in the world. Trust remained high until the early 1970's and then dropped steadily until only one in four Americans expressed faith in their government by 1980. There have been brief rises since then -- during the first Reagan administration, the second Clinton administration and in the gulf war in 1991 -- but faith in government has generally remained low, dropping to 26 percent as recently as 1998, well below the most recent level of 55 percent.
The phenomenon persisted for more than a generation, and a whole industry of scholarship cropped up to try to solve the mystery of what caused Americans to distrust government. Early suggestions were the Vietnam War, the civil rights protests of the 1960's, the Watergate scandal and economic stagnation of the 1970's, feminism and the sexual revolution. As Garry R. Orren, a professor of public policy at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, wrote in a 1997 book, "Why People Don't Trust Government," "All told, the level of mistrust nearly tripled in the decade after 1964."
But since Watergate, surveys have detected growing distrust in government in very different parts of the world, from Western Europe and Canada to South Korea and Japan. So scholars began to look for a more general explanation, a single master theory.
"This trend is pervasive in all the industrialized nations and goes hand in hand with democratization," Ronald Inglehart, a professor of sociology at the University of Michigan, said in a telephone interview.
So in just the past year, social scientists have begun to advance a host of new theories to account for the post-Watergate declines in the United States and elsewhere: the end of the cold war, television, the expanded role of government, globalization, growing income inequality and a shift in values.
Mr. Inglehart, for example, has been conducting something called the World Values Survey for nearly 30 years, trying to measure shifting public attitudes in dozens of countries around the world. 
"Insecure people who are struggling with basic necessities like strong leaders and tend to idealize authority," he said. "In the richer and more secure societies, there is a declining deference to authority. Having achieved a level of prosperity, people push for autonomy, self-expression and democracy -- postindustrial values."
Indeed, some scholars have turned the problem around and argue that the real surprise is not the low level of trust but the high degree of faith in government in the recent past. Mr. Fukuyama at Johns Hopkins said, "Most of these studies use as their base line the 1940's and 1950's, when the United States was just coming out of the Depression and World War II, a time when there was a lot of national unity and in which the federal government had performed very well."
In his new book Mr. Brands of Texas A&M argues that except in periods of war -- like now -- Americans have always had high degrees of distrust of government. "As I studied the question," he said in an interview, "I came to feel that distrust of government was the basic default position for the United States and that the cold war kept faith in government high and made it possible to maintain a consensus for big government."
To conservatives like Mr. Fukuyama, government wore out people's trust by extending its sphere of actions beyond essential functions like national defense to thorny social problems like poverty and racial injustice, which were much harder to solve through government action.
Derek Bok, former president of Harvard University, argues in his new book, "The Trouble with Government," that the American government simply did not perform as well as other large welfare states. "I think there is a real problem in terms of the government not delivering what people want," in terms of providing good health care and education and alleviating poverty and crime, Mr. Bok said in a telephone interview.
For now, however, the expanded role of the government is likely to be most conspicuous in the area of national defense. "The creation of an Office of Homeland Security would have, a month ago, seemed to the Republican right like an Orwellian invention," Mr. Brands said. "But in the cold war, national defense became national security and the scope broadened. Cold war liberals' argument for the war on poverty was that it was needed to make America's message to the world credible."
Mr. Putnam said: "World War I and World War II made people more sympathetic to the idea of government in public policy. It created the climate for the civil rights bill and the Great Society."
The recent volatility of the polling numbers, Mr. Fukuyama said, shows that a national crisis alone does not create trust in government: "It's a combination of external threats and government effectiveness. The government was seen as being effective during the Depression and World War II, less so during the 1960's."
Moreover, Mr. Putnam said, other factors that accounted for the general decline of trust in government among industrialized nations may come back into play: "I think globalization has made it harder for any single government to achieve what its citizens want. The problems are global, but the problem-solving mechanisms at our disposals are local or national." So if global terrorism proves beyond the scope of national government and international cooperation, it could cause trust in government to crash.

CORRECTION-DATE: November 9, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about the rise and fall of public trust in government misstated the name of a historian at Texas A&M University who is the author of a recent book, "The Strange Death of American Liberalism." He is H. W. Brands, not C. W. Brands.

HEADLINE: Tourism Industry Seeks Aid in Italy 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: ROME, Nov. 2 

 BODY:
Italy's tourism industry is suffering its worst crisis in half a century and needs emergency aid, the business group Confindustria said today.
 The number of tourists has plummeted since the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States, with some tour operators reporting a 70 percent slump. 
 "This is the most serious collapse the industry has seen in 50 years," Confindustria said in a statement. "We are calling on the government to provide the necessary funds for urgent intervention to prop up the sector."
The tourism group Confturismo said in a separate statement that 2.5 million expected visitors would be staying away from Italy in the weeks leading up to Christmas, depriving the trade of an estimated 610 billion lire ($285 million).
Italy's tourism industry generates some $66 billion a year, 8 percent of the country's gross domestic product.

HEADLINE: In a Breakthrough, of Sorts, Arafat and Peres Shake Hands 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: FORMENTOR, Majorca, Nov. 2 

 BODY:
It is a measure of the stagnation of the Middle East peace process that a handshake today between the Israeli foreign minister, Shimon Peres, and the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, should be regarded as progress.
 But it was the first real contact between the two men in more than a month, and in that time the Middle East has burned. With pressure from Washington for the Israelis and the Palestinians to cool it for the sake of the international coalition against terrorism, officials from both sides chose to see a ray of light at this sunny Spanish resort town. 
 Mr. Arafat and Mr. Peres may yet have a substantive meeting here, with Mr. Peres talking of preparing a peace plan and the Israeli prime minister, Ariel Sharon, talking of leading talks based on a pledge to stop new Israeli settlements. 
But the single handshake, at a lunch together with the Spanish prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, and the Egyptian president, Hosni Mubarak, completely overshadowed an economic conference devoted to the Mediterranean and the European Union.
Mr. Arafat's advisers talked up the idea of a meeting; Mr. Peres's advisers played one down, saying he had no mandate yet for negotiations. "We haven't prepared for a serious discussion, and if we have a major public meeting we'll just raise expectations too high," said Yoram Dori, a senior Peres aide.
Of more importance, he said, was Mr. Peres's meeting today with Mr. Mubarak. "It was the first Israeli-Egyptian meeting in two or three months," Mr. Dori said.
In a speech to the conference, Mr. Mubarak, himself vulnerable to an attack by Islamic fundamentalists, said the Middle East was deteriorating "one day after another without the slightest hope that there will be a peaceful end to the conflict."
He blamed the violence on "a lack of clear vision needed to reach peace" on the part of the Israeli government, charging that "its use of violence, blockades and closing of borders in an attempt to oppress the Palestinian people leads to a vicious circle of indefinite violence and counterviolence."
Indirectly, Mr. Mubarak called on the United States to become actively involved with the Israelis and the Palestinians to halt the slide to further bloodshed.
While the attacks of Sept. 11 are not the outcome of the troubles in the peace process or a result of American support for Israel, Mr. Mubarak stressed, "the deterioration of the peace process to the current regrettable stage and the lack of an active international leadership of the peace process have created a general public opinion in the Arab street that is antagonistic to the peace process."
Mr. Mubarak called on Israelis and Palestinians to "exit as quickly as possible from this cycle of violence and to move toward political negotiations as the only means to reach security and guarantee peace and stability."
Egypt is one of America's most steadfast Arab allies, but the war in Afghanistan, coupled with television pictures of Palestinian suffering, is placing significant pressure on Mr. Mubarak and other moderate Arab rulers of semi-autocratic states, American officials believe.
Still, there was no evident American diplomatic presence here, and no senior American official has been to the Middle East since Secretary of State Colin L. Powell was there in June.
Osama el-Baz, a senior Mubarak adviser, said that Mr. Peres and Mr. Arafat could not make any breakthrough here. "But we expect a step that can move the stagnant waters of the peace process," Mr. Baz said in an interview. "If things are left as they are, it will be bad for both the Israelis and the Palestinians, and for all who seek peace in the Mideast, and this will be reflected, however unfortunately, in the attitudes of the Arab people vis-a-vis the war against terrorism."
Martin Indyk, former United States ambassador to Israel, also called for a high-level American mission to the Middle East, to try to bang Israeli and Palestinian heads together.
"After Sept. 11, we at least need quiet in the region," Mr. Indyk said in a telephone interview. "We don't need pictures in the Arab world of Israeli tanks moving on Palestinians. We're going to have pictures of B-52's bombing Afghanistan, but we don't need both."
Mr. Sharon has made it clear that he first wants to see tougher action by Mr. Arafat to restrain militant Palestinian groups like Hamas. Since Sept. 11, Mr. Arafat has worked to hamper Hamas, American officials have said, but Mr. Sharon wants more.
Mr. Peres and Mr. Sharon appear to be engaged in a good cop-bad cop routine, with the aim of getting Mr. Arafat to crack down on his militants and make it easier for Israel to stop new settlement activity, as called for under the Mitchell Report, which Mr. Sharon has accepted as a basis for new talks.
While Mr. Peres says he would open peace negotiations and even evacuate some easily selected settlements now, Mr. Sharon wants to hold Mr. Arafat to earlier promises to arrest Hamas militants and work to stop suicide bombings.
While Mr. Sharon made a show of toughness for his conservative supporters at home, he also supported Mr. Peres's decision to come here to see Mr. Arafat. Whether directly or through Mr. Mubarak, officials of both sides say, Mr. Peres and Mr. Arafat have questions to ask each other, if only to prepare the ground for a more serious effort later.
