HEADLINE: U.S. and Microsoft in Deal, but States Hold Back 

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON with STEVE LOHR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 

 BODY:
Microsoft and the federal government, long bitter legal enemies, walked into a federal court together today and announced that they had settled their epic antitrust dispute. State prosecutors who had filed a parallel antitrust lawsuit declined for now to endorse the deal and persuaded a federal judge to give them until early next week to formulate a response.
 Outlining the details of the proposed settlement publicly for the first time, the Justice Department and Microsoft described a set of business restrictions that appeared to fall considerably short of what the judge who tried the case, Thomas Penfield Jackson, tried to impose on Microsoft last year. The company had already adopted some of those restrictions last summer after it was found to have engaged in illegal monopolistic practices. 
 The proposed settlement gives computer makers more flexibility to install icons and menu entries of their choosing into Microsoft's Windows operating system. It prevents Microsoft from entering into certain restrictive and discriminatory pricing agreements. It requires the company to make some disclosures about its software code to encourage competition. And it restricts the company from retaliating against competitors. 
It also creates a three-person technical committee to monitor compliance with the agreement. The committee is to have offices on the Microsoft campus, access to Microsoft's computer code and the ability to interrogate its employees.
But the proposed settlement does not restrict Microsoft from putting anything into its primary monopoly product, the Windows operating system, that could drive out rivals and help it extend its monopoly into new products and software areas. Moreover, the agreement expressly does not require the company to acknowledge that it committed any antitrust violations, despite the findings of Judge Jackson and a seven-judge appeals court that Microsoft had repeatedly violated the Sherman Antitrust Act by bullying rivals and engaging in a wide range of anticompetitive practices over a period of years.
Critics said the settlement offer was also less than what Microsoft was reportedly willing to accept during a previous round of mediation efforts that failed. They also said the offer was riddled with loopholes that could be exploited by Microsoft.
Those complaints were rejected today by senior government officials and Microsoft executives, who hailed the proposed agreement as a landmark in antitrust law.
"This settlement is the right result for consumers and for businesses, the right result for the economy and the right result for government," Attorney General John Ashcroft told reporters shortly after the government filed the proposed settlement in Federal District Court here. "It provides prompt, effective, certain relief for consumers and removes the uncertainty in the computer market, a critical factor in today's economy."
Mr. Ashcroft said the criticism by some of Microsoft's competitors that the deal was a sell-out to a company with strong ties to the Republican administration was "totally false."
"We believe that this settlement is a very strong settlement, that it not only encompasses the relief that was signaled by the court of appeals, but that this has additional safeguards," Mr. Ashcroft added. He said that "in no respect did the White House seek to shape or influence the outcome."
Senior Microsoft executives applauded the deal at a news conference at the company's headquarters in Redmond, Wash.
"The settlement will help strengthen our economy during this difficult time and ensure that our industry can continue delivering innovations to the marketplace," said Bill Gates, the company's co-founder and chairman.
Industry competitors, both large and small, disagreed, with some recalling the earlier consent decree that resulted after they first brought their complaints to the Justice Department nearly a decade ago.
"In its current form, today's proposed consent decree, like the one entered in 1994, does too little to promote competition and protect consumers, and can too easily be evaded by a determined monopolist like Microsoft," said Paul T. Cappuccio, executive vice president and general counsel of AOL Time Warner. 
Another executive, who did not want to be named because his company does business with Microsoft, asserted that some of the company's concessions were not as generous as they seemed. For example, he said, although personal computer companies can load non-Microsoft products and icons to competing software on a new computer's Windows desktop, Microsoft would be permitted under the settlement to install software that asks users after 14 days if they want to change the PC maker's selections, presumably to Microsoft's preferred offerings. "Microsoft can present that choice to the user any way it wants and offer any kind of incentives it wants," the executive said.
But some industry analysts said the government had done a solid job of trying to restrain Microsoft without hobbling it.
"It looks to me as if this settlement evens the playing field as much as you can when you're dealing with an 800-pound gorilla," said Michael Cusumano, a professor at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Sloan School of Management. He said the three-person compliance committee "should prevent Microsoft from manipulating the technology in the Windows operating system to disadvantage competitors."
The settlement cannot take effect unless it is found by a federal district judge to be in the public interest. A major potential obstacle to such a finding is the view of the states that filed their own parallel lawsuit and have been reluctant to join the agreement.
Today those 18 states, plus the District of Columbia, persuaded the judge now overseeing the case, Colleen Kollar-Kotelly of the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia, to give them until Tuesday to study the proposed settlement and decide whether they will join it or challenge it.
The states' new lawyer, Brendan Sullivan, told Judge Kollar-Kotelly that the extra time was necessary "to assure that this is a good agreement, and that we are not trading a settlement of litigation today for a decade of litigation tomorrow."
After the brief hearing today, some of the state prosecutors praised aspects of the deal. They said they were uncertain how they would proceed and whether they would be able to get any tougher restrictions imposed on Microsoft.
Briefing reporters on the courthouse steps this morning, one of the lead attorneys general in the case, Tom Miller of Iowa, stopped short of endorsing the deal but said it "represents some progress."
Another leader of the group, Richard Blumenthal, the attorney general of Connecticut, said it was essential that the states carefully consider the proposed settlement.
"The decree contains some significant remedies, but we need to do our due diligence and parse all the provisions carefully because we have a lot invested in this case and the public has a lot at stake," he said, adding that it was impossible to predict now whether the states would sign onto the deal or try to seek a tougher remedy.
Microsoft has established a group of state-level lobbying and political organizations aimed at pressing the states to settle, and some lawyers involved in the case said they would expect that, at the least, by Tuesday some of the states would yield to the Justice Department deal.
Justice Department officials, sounding many of the same notes about the antitrust lawsuit that had been expressed by Microsoft's legal team, said they felt obliged to accept the deal because their case was never really as strong in important respects as it had been presented by the Clinton administration. They also said they felt it was time to put an end to the uncertainties of litigation in a rapidly changing technology industry.
Microsoft embraced the settlement as a pragmatic compromise. "While the settlement goes further than we might have wanted," Mr. Gates said, "we believe that settling this case now is the right thing to do to help the industry, and the economy, to move forward."
In the news conference at Microsoft headquarters, Mr. Gates, in a subdued mood, conceded that the case had had "a profound impact on me personally and on our company."
One legacy of the case, Mr. Gates said, is that "we will focus more on how our activities affect other companies."
In his view, Microsoft went "the extra mile" in settlement talks and agreed to conditions, especially on the disclosure of technical information, that went beyond the scope of the rulings against it.
Mr. Gates added that he hoped the states, after studying the settlement proposal, would "agree that it's the right way forward."
Yet Mr. Gates and Steven M. Ballmer, the chief executive, stopped short of admitting that Microsoft had broken the law or done things wrong. When asked that question specifically, Mr. Gates said that Microsoft was "accepting a broad set of new requirements on the company" and that it was doing so because of "concerns" about competition in the industry.
Echoing that sentiment, Mr. Ballmer said that "with the success of our products there came a number of competition concerns."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Charles A. James, right, head of the Justice Department's antitrust division, with state attorneys general yesterday: Tom Miller of Iowa, left; Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut; and Eliot L. Spitzer of New York. (David Scull for The New York Times)(pg. C3) Chart: "The Proposed Settlement"Highlights of the proposed antitrust settlement between Microsoft and the Justice Department: Microsoft can add anything it wants to its monopoly product, the Windows operating system. Microsoft cannot restrict the freedom of PC makers to install non-Microsoft software, and is prohibited from retaliating against PC makers for shipping machines with competing software. Microsoft must sell Windows under the same terms to all PC makers, though it can offer discounts for volume purchase agreements. Its pricing terms must be published on a Web site accessible by PC makers and the government. Microsoft must disclose technical information to software rivals so that their products run smoothly on Windows. But sharing the information gives the companies no rights to Microsoft's intellectual property. Microsoft cannot retaliate against any software or hardware company for developing software that competes with Microsoft. A three-person technical committee will monitor compliance, with the Justice Department and Microsoft each choosing one member and the third selected by those two. The team members will serve renewable terms of 30 months and will have offices on the Microsoft campus. They will be given broad powers with access to Microsoft technical information and the authority to interrogate company employees. Microsoft rivals and customers may submit complaints anonymously to the independent committee. After review, the committee will inform the company and the government of serious complaints, which can result in an enforcement hearing in federal court. Microsoft will appoint an internal compliance officer. This person will make sure that all Microsoft officers and board members have read the settlement and are given yearly briefings on its requirements. The conditions of the settlement will be in place for five years. If Microsoft is found to willfully and systematically violate the agreement, the settlement terms will remain in force for an additional two years. (pg. C3)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Air Canada Puts Best Face On a Big Loss

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON 

DATELINE: TORONTO, Nov. 2 

 BODY:
It's bad, Air Canada said today, but not quite as bad as we thought.
 Costs are falling and its finances are stabilizing, the airline said, putting a positive gloss on the loss of 160 million Canadian dollars ($100 million) that it reported today for the third quarter. 
 The airline, which dominates Canadian air travel and has far more extensive operations in the United States than does any other foreign carrier, earned 184 million Canadian dollars ($115 million) in the comparable quarter a year earlier. Figures for both years are before taxes, and the 2001 figure does not include 71 million Canadian dollars ($45 million) in government assistance received earlier this week to compensate for the sharp loss of business in the days after the Sept. 11 terror attacks. 
Air Canada did not release net after-tax earnings figures because it is reviewing the value of intangible assets on its books, like good will, and will probably make "significant downward adjustments," the company said. Operating revenue for the quarter was down 15.6 percent.
Air Canada officials said today that the airline no longer expected to reduce capacity nearly as sharply as the 20 percent cuts it forecast in mid-September. Robert Milton, the chief executive, said, "I feel better than I did," though the outlook remained "murky," with unusually high volatility in traffic from week to week, especially on short-haul routes.
Glenn Engel, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs in New York, said Air Canada "did a better job than the rest of the world in the third quarter, and they seem to be doing a better job in the fourth quarter."
In particular, Mr. Engel cited Air Canada's success in bringing down costs. American carriers' average costs per passenger have risen about 6 percent because of the falloff in traffic, he said, but Air Canada's costs have fallen by 5 percent over the last year, and the airline expects further improvement.
Air Canada has focused increasingly on accommodating a rapid migration of cost-conscious passengers from business and full-economy fares to discount services. "The market is saying they want Wal-Mart," Mr. Milton said, as he announced that the airline would shrink business-class cabins and add 5 to 6 percent more seats on its jets.
The move also reflects competition on some domestic routes from fast-growing no-frills carriers, notably Canada 3000 and WestJet. Air Canada's share of available seats fell to 65 percent in July from 77 percent two years earlier, while WestJet doubled its share to 14 percent and Canada 3000's share rose to 9 percent from 4 percent, according to a government report.
On Thursday, WestJet reported a 32 percent rise in third-quarter net income and a 41 percent rise in revenue from a year earlier.
Air Canada's own new discount airline, Tango, began service on Thursday, with a plan to take over as many as 20 of Air Canada's aircraft. But Tango made a slow start, with some flights canceled almost immediately for want of passengers. Mr. Milton said today that people booked on canceled Tango flights could be accommodated on Air Canada flights instead, but Mr. Engel of Goldman, Sachs said, "Generally, an airline within an airline is confusing with customers."
Mr. Milton also criticized Canadian authorities for providing less generous financial assistance to Air Canada than airlines south of the border have received from Washington.
"Every time you see a U.S. airline landing here, those seats are subsidized by the U.S. government," he said. Air Canada estimates that it would have received $290 million if the same criteria had been applied to it.
Air Canada's stock rose slightly in Toronto, to 2.89 Canadian dollars ($1.81) a share. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Air Canada said yesterday that it lost $100 million in the recent quarter. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: Twin Towers At the Center Of Legal Brawl 

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON and JONATHAN D. GLATER 

 BODY:
The battle over who will bear the costs of the destruction of the World Trade Center and who will control the reconstruction of lower Manhattan -- already a full-blown brawl involving legions of lawyers and lobbyists -- is continuing to escalate.
 On Thursday, lobbyists for Larry A. Silverstein, the developer who holds the lease on the World Trade Center, and for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the property, helped ensure that a bill passed by the House on airplane security included broad language protecting them from claims by victims of the Sept. 11 attacks and their families. 
 That came as a group of investors led by Mr. Silverstein prepared to answer a lawsuit that the Swiss Reinsurance Company filed against them last week in Federal District Court in Manhattan. In the suit, the insurer, known as Swiss Re, seeks to limit how much it will have to pay to cover the destruction of the twin towers. Lawyers representing the various parties involved agree that more lawsuits are likely to follow. 
The issues are clear. No one wants to be left facing a mountain of claims from victims and their families; no insurer wants to be part of what could be a $7.2 billion payment to cover the loss of the buildings; and no lender, investor or developer wants to miss out on a piece of what may be one of the biggest insurance payouts ever.
Resolving those issues is anything but clear. The effort to sort out who will pay and who will profit involves fragile alliances, conflicting interests, and charges and countercharges of hypocrisy as Mr. Silverstein tries to limit his liability while maximizing the obligations of insurers, at least one of which -- Swiss Re -- is already fighting back.
Time is short. Mr. Silverstein paid about $6 million on his mortgage last month; the next payment is due next week, according to G.M.A.C. Commercial Mortgage, the General Motors subsidiary that lent him $564 million. For now, he can cover that and other expenses -- including $10 million a month in ground rent to the Port Authority -- out of a pool of lease payments and security deposits paid in advance by Trade Center tenants. But even with the fund he can probably afford to hold out for no more than four months without receiving insurance payments, others close to the matter said.
To plead his case in Washington, Mr. Silverstein -- who has the least to lose financially and the most to gain -- retained Jack Quinn, the former White House counsel who last January engineered an Inauguration Day pardon issued by President Bill Clinton for Marc Rich. Mr. Quinn lobbied Congress and the Bush administration to limit how much money victims can obtain from Mr. Silverstein's real estate companies, which drew criticism from another powerful lobbying group, trial lawyers.
"This guy is trying to get $7.2 billion in insurance, and he wants to limit his liability to $1 billion," said Carlton Carl, director of media relations for the Association of Trial Lawyers of America. "Why? If you start limiting everybody's liability, then nobody is accountable to anyone. It subverts our entire legal system, which calls for personal and corporate responsibility for harms that one causes."
In New York, Mr. Silverstein is relying on Herbert Wachtell and his partners at the law firm of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz to force his insurers to pay $7.2 billion, twice the amount they argue they are obligated to pay for the destruction of the trade center. Mr. Silverstein says he is entitled to the larger sum, and needs all of it to finance reconstruction.
The dispute turns on an arcane legal question of whether the crash of two hijacked airliners into the twin towers of the World Trade Center was a single insurable event, entitling Mr. Silverstein's group to $3.6 billion in coverage, or two distinct events for which the group can file separate claims of $3.6 billion apiece. Mr. Wachtell's team is up against Simpson Thacher & Bartlett, the law firm that represents Swiss Re.
For his public relations, Mr. Silverstein has turned to Howard Rubinstein, who in the past has represented Rupert Murdoch, George Steinbrenner and the Empire State Building. Mr. Rubinstein will try to make the case that Mr. Silverstein should be a central player in rebuilding a version of the World Trade Center, phoenixlike, at ground zero. A battery of architects, engineers and cultural experts is being consulted to draw up plans and blunt efforts by rivals to control reconstruction.
At the same time, Mr. Silverstein is trying to hold together a coalition that includes the Port Authority, which owns the site, and his lenders and co-investors in the buildings that have been destroyed. It is a tenuous alliance, one which is certain to fracture should some members begin to sense that they will not be repaid by Mr. Silverstein or come to believe that he cannot get all the money he claims that the insurers owe him and cannot cap his liability.
For its part, the Port Authority, a political body, has moved cautiously to sort out its plans and interests. So far, said Lewis M. Eisenberg, its chairman, the agency is focused on two short-term goals: rebuilding the transportation hub that was under the trade center and trying to limit the authority's liability.
The suit by Swiss Re, the insurer with the most at stake in the Trade Center disaster, is a clear effort to put pressure on the alliance and possibly prompt some of the investors or lenders to pressure Mr. Silverstein to walk away from a rebuilding effort, experts say.
Like many developers, Mr. Silverstein was highly leveraged. By some estimates, he put up only about $12 million of his group's $3.2 billion bid for a 99-year lease of the World Trade Center earlier this year. Other less visible lenders and investors have considerably more at stake.
Nevertheless, Mr. Silverstein, who lost four employees in the attack, speaks of rebuilding lower Manhattan with almost religious zeal. "There's no way I could not go forward and build this thing," he said in an interview on Wednesday. "What these terrorists have tried to do is destroy the symbol of New York, destroy the symbol of our economic progress, our strength, our way of life, and I can't handle that."
He dismissed criticism of his effort to limit his group's liability to the $1 billion covered by insurance, saying he just wants to put a quick end to what could become decades of litigation that would enrich lawyers at the expense of their clients.
"Look at what's happened from the 1993 incident," he said, referring to the earlier bombing of one of the World Trade Center towers. "Hundreds of millions of dollars in claims are still outstanding. This is designed to avoid what's happened there."
Mr. Silverstein has pledged to continue to pay his mortgage and ground rent, a promise that is crucial to maintaining the coalition of lenders and investors who financed his bid for the complex.
But Mr. Silverstein's position is beset by uncertainties. Chief among them is the fact that there was no final insurance policy in place when the trade center was attacked. The policies were still under negotiation, and the coverage included the disputed terms of the so-called "binders," or promises by insurance carriers to provide coverage. A policy was formally issued by Travelers, a Citigroup subsidiary, on Sept. 14, after a flurry of e-mails and phone calls among the lawyers negotiating the terms of the policy, but other carriers are keeping quiet about whether they will agree to be bound by those terms or by others.
Swiss Re executives say that the case turns on a tightly scrawled note on one of the binders that strikes some language and replaces it with the phrase "subject to wording to be agreed." In its complaint, the insurance company asserts that the crashes are a single event under the language in effect on Sept. 11.
Mr. Silverstein's lawyers maintain that New York state law, which governs the case, makes clear that each crash and collapse was a separate insurable event. In 1959, they note, the New York Court of Appeals found that the collapse of two walls in adjoining buildings owned by one person, 50 minutes apart, were distinct events.
Swiss Re contends that the developers underinsured the buildings, but several lawyers said that $3.6 billion was seen as more than enough to cover what before Sept. 11 was judged to be any likely disaster. "It was considered by many people who looked at it as far in excess of what should be bought," said one person with knowledge of the insurance negotiations. "No one ever, ever considered you could have an event as horrific as what happened."
Besides, the lawyers added, the $3.6 billion worth of insurance was about as much as insurers were willing to underwrite; any more than than would have been prohibitively expensive. As it was, to get so much coverage required policies written by 22 carriers.
When the Port Authority ran the trade center, it had $1.5 billion of insurance coverage. The Silverstein group of investors initially sought $2.3 billion in coverage, but lenders wanted more. So Mr. Silverstein's partnership raised the coverage to $3.25 billion and then, about a week after the closing, to $3.6 billion.
If Mr. Silverstein's insurers pay him only $3.6 billion, his desire to rebuild could be frustrated. The value of the Silverstein group's remaining lease payments to the Port Authority is about $2.6 billion. The developer also owes about $30 million annually to the city in lieu of real estate taxes, and several hundred million dollars more to lenders.
At least one lender, though, transferred much of its risk elsewhere. G.M.A.C. sold most of its $564 million mortgage to other investors, and currently stands to lose just $80 million if it is not repaid. Wells Fargo, the trustee for holders of bonds backed by the mortgage, would not provide a list of investors.
Westfield America, a real estate investment trust controlled by a major Australian developer that owns several shopping malls in the United States, invested $120 million along with Mr. Silverstein; $100 million of that was borrowed from UBS Warburg. It is unlikely that a large company like Westfield would default on the loan, say people familiar with the financing of the lease.
Even if Mr. Silverstein ultimately wins the money he wants, any effort to rebuild inevitably comes back to the Port Authority and the governments of the states of New York and New Jersey and of New York City.
They may not be interested in supporting Mr. Silverstein's ambitious desire to replace all of the trade center's 10 million square feet of office space and 500,000 square feet of retail space just now because of the slowing economy and potential tenants' concern about further terrorist attacks. If he duplicated the twin towers' size -- whether in two 110-story towers or a combination of shorter buildings -- many people involved in ongoing negotiations worry privately that no one would rent the space.
Such decisions are still a way off, in any case. Swiss Re's lawsuit would have to be resolved long before any rebuilding could begin. For now, the fate of the case rests with Federal District Court Judge Denny Chin, who was randomly assigned to the case when it was filed last month. Judge Chin, a 1994 Clinton appointee, is both soft-spoken and demanding, and lawyers who have been before him say he is willing to defy powerful interests in reaching his decisions
But the case could be settled before it is decided by Judge Chin, and it would not be surprising if the parties reached a deal requiring the insurers to pay a figure of $3.6 billion to $7.2 billion. The prospect of such a settlement does not seem to deter Mr. Silverstein from fulfilling his latest ambition.
"I have my health, my life, my family, my people less the four who died, and the ability to say, 'Let's regroup and show these terrorists what we'll do, what we need to do,' " Mr. Silverstein said. "Life is for the living."

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN; 
Trying to Show Who's Better Suited to Inherit a Legacy

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

 BODY:
 The mayoral campaign of Michael R. Bloomberg, the Republican candidate, began broadcasting a television advertisement on Thursday called "Every Step," which suggests the election of his Democratic opponent, Mark Green, would jeopardize the legacy of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.

PRODUCER -- Squier Knapp Dunn Communications, in consultation with David Garth.

ON THE SCREEN -- The ad begins with various scenes of a safe and vibrant city, including officers frisking suspects, bustling shops and smiling people on the street. It then splits to include a picture of Mr. Green next to the scenes, which change from color to black and white as they become increasingly bleak: an image of City Hall; a long line of garbage trucks; closed businesses; and buildings covered in graffiti. The announcer's criticisms of Mr. Green are splashed across the screen in white letters, including a reference to an unspecified article in The New York Times on Sept. 5, 2001. The ad closes with shots of Mr. Bloomberg hard at work.

THE SCRIPT -- Announcer: "Our quality of life is better. Police successfully fighting crime. Waste cut. Corruption no longer tolerated. Taxes down. Every step of the way, Mark Green attacked and criticized the changes that made life better. He will tear apart Giuliani's City Hall and turn our city back. Back to when our neighborhoods were ignored. Mike Bloomberg will build on what Mayor Giuliani accomplished. Fight crime. Cut waste. Use his experience to strengthen our economy. Mike Bloomberg. A leader, not a politician."

ACCURACY -- As public advocate, Mr. Green was actively involved in questioning and challenging some policies of the Giuliani administration. Tensions between the two men were well known. Mr. Green was particularly aggressive in pursuing allegations of police misconduct and he was outspoken on issues of racial profiling, suggesting Mr. Giuliani's law enforcement approach had undermined the Police Department's relationship with blacks and Hispanics. But Mr. Green, who has been endorsed by Mr. Giuliani's first police commissioner, William J. Bratton, has not suggested that he would turn back the clock on the mayor's achievements. Mr. Green has said he will keep Compstat, the intensive data collection system used by the Police Department; precinct accountability; and quality-of-life policing.

SCORECARD -- This is an ad that uses scare tactics rather than specifics to raise doubts about Mr. Green's credentials. It does not substantiate its most damaging claims -- that Mr. Green would "tear apart" Mr. Giuliani's City Hall and "turn our city back." It is in keeping with Mr. Bloomberg's central theme late in this race, that he, and not Mr. Green, is the best steward of Mr. Giuliani's legacy. But unlike other ads that use the Giuliani references effectively, it risks turning off viewers. DEAN E. MURPHY

GRAPHIC: Photo

HEADLINE: Unemployment Jumps to 5.4%, A 5-Year High 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Over 400,000 Americans lost jobs last month, the most for a single month in more than two decades, as businesses responded to a deteriorating economy with a surge in layoffs.
 The unemployment rate jumped to 5.4 percent in October from 4.9 percent, its highest level since 1996, the Labor Department said yesterday. 
 The question among analysts is no longer whether the United States is in a recession, but how deep it will be and how many months will pass before jobs become plentiful again. 
"There is almost like a national hiring freeze," said Chris Varvares, president of Macroeconomic Advisers, in St. Louis. 
Roughly a quarter of the lost jobs were a direct result of the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, according to Thomas L. Nardone, chief of the division in the Bureau of Labor Statistics that compiles the monthly job numbers. The attacks apparently dashed the hopes of many executives for a quick recovery after a mild recession, and they stepped up layoffs to prepare for hard times.
The Federal Reserve is expected to respond to the October numbers by cutting short-term interest rates half a percentage point, to 2 percent, when its policy makers meet in Washington on Tuesday. It would be the 10th rate cut since Jan. 1, reducing rates by 4.5 percentage points.
The 415,000 lost jobs, almost double the number most forecasters had expected, intensified a debate over how Congress and the administration should deal with the sinking economy, given that Fed rate cuts are having so little effect and that the upturn often forecast for early next year seems less and less likely.
"It is not good news for America," President Bush said yesterday of the October job numbers. He urged the Senate to approve by Nov. 30 a House-passed bill that relies mainly on tax cuts, particularly for business, to stimulate the economy. The terrorist attacks, the president said, have "threatened the livelihoods of thousands of American workers."
The Democrats are putting much more emphasis on public spending to jump-start the economy, particularly in the form of subsidies paid out to the rising number of unemployed workers. They argue that the subsidies will encourage spending, while the tax cuts will not persuade business to hire and spend in a weak economy with profits shrinking.
The debate brings into public view the two parties' divergent views over the role of government in the economy. "The government is not a creator of economic growth; the private sector does that," Secretary of Labor Elaine Chao said yesterday in an interview. "Government has to help business create more jobs, and they do that through tax cuts."
The Commerce Department, in a separate report, provided further evidence that the economy was under stress. Orders for merchandise placed with American manufacturers plunged by 5.8 percent in September, to $313.1 billion, the lowest level since March 1997.
The booming economy created millions of jobs in the late 1990's. The peak came last March, and then as the economy weakened, the work force steadily contracted. Nearly 900,000 jobs have disappeared since March, nearly half of them in October alone, when total employment stood at 131.77 million.
The decline of nearly 900,000 is the largest in so few months since the 1990-1991 recession -- suggesting to economists that last March will eventually be officially designated as the start of the current recession. It began gradually and picked up considerable speed last month, particularly in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks. Mr. Nardone said the terrorism triggered job cuts at airlines, travel agencies, hotels, restaurants and car rental agencies that exceeded by 100,000 the average declines in those industries in recent months.
"People are asking, 'What would the economy look like if the terrorist attacks had not occurred,' " Mr. Nardone said. "But they did occur and that has had an impact on people's decisions that continues to multiply the damage to the economy."
Retailers provided evidence. Christmas hiring normally begins in October, but the upturn did not materialize and retailing lost 81,000 jobs in the Labor Department's seasonally adjusted numbers.
The 415,000 lost jobs in the nation as a whole and the half-a-percentage point jump in the unemployment rate were the largest in each category since May 1980, in the midst of a recession. Just 13 months ago, the unemployment rate was only 3.9 percent. Unemployment rose among every group, but African-Americans suffered the most: a 1 percentage point increase in their jobless rate in October alone, to 9.7 percent. Just last fall, black unemployment had fallen to a record low of 7.2 percent.
The cutback in labor costs took more than one form. Aside from eliminating jobs, employers reduced overtime and trimmed scheduled work, so that average weekly pay for production workers, who represent 75 percent of the work force, fell by 77 cents, to $491.98 -- the first decline in nominal weekly pay in years.
Part-time work also surged among people who either wanted full-time jobs and could not get them, or had their hours cut back by their employers against their wishes. That number jumped 1.1 million in September and October, to a total of 4.5 million. "That is a very big number," Mr. Nardone said. "The demand for labor is clearly contracting." 
Most of the employment decline since last March has come in manufacturing, but the service sector made a huge contribution last month, shedding 111,000 jobs, the largest cut on record. These are the nation's office workers. They work in health services, private schools, hotels and temporary help agencies. Nearly all of the loss was among the temporary workers, who are the easiest to shed and the first to go, economists say, when companies are bent on cutting labor costs.
"The falloff in the employment of temporary workers is a good indicator of the labor market's weakness," said Dean Baker, an economist at the Center for Economic and Policy Research, "because firms can cut back with basically no cost."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE PRESIDENT; 
G.O.P. Moderates See Dangers in Bush's Stance on Aviation Security

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 2 

 BODY:
Shouts of victory rose up in the West Wing on Thursday night as the House passed a Republican aviation security bill that President Bush had battled for, even as he fought his broader war against terrorism.
 But in the morning's clearer light, some moderates in the president's party warned that Mr. Bush might have lost by winning. At the least, they said, he had handed the Democrats a potent campaign issue by siding so powerfully on a bill pushed by his party's conservative wing that rejected the complete federalization of airport security that many polls suggest Americans want. 
"I simply do not understand it," said Representative Marge Roukema, a moderate New Jersey Republican who did not vote the president's way. "I just have to shake my head. The Democrats will beat us up and down on it, no question about that. But besides the politics, we'll be inviting more airline disasters and putting more lives at risk."
Mr. Bush, others said, was still haunted by the specter of his father, who defied his party's conservative wing on taxes and then lost the White House. For that reason, Democrats said, Mr. Bush is fearful about standing up to the two House conservative leaders, Representatives Tom DeLay and Dick Armey of Texas, who worked hand in hand with the White House to push through the Republican version of the bill. 
"The ideologues have taken over, and they're out of touch with America," said Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, who voted with 99 other senators in approving an opposing bill that would make all 28,000 airport baggage and passenger screeners federal employees. "Just as Bill Clinton's job was to face down some of the ideologues on the left, President Bush's job is to face down the ideologues on the right." 
The White House said the president was acting on principle, not politics.
"Basically what passed the House was the president's original proposal," said Nicholas E. Calio, the president's Congressional liaison. "So what was not to like about it?"
At issue is the security, both physical and psychological, of millions of airline passengers who will crowd American airports in the holiday season and beyond. Air travel has been down sharply since the Sept. 11 suicide hijackings as the White House and Congress have struggled to make flying safer and to lure nervous passengers back into the air. 
On Oct. 11, the Senate passed its version of an airline security bill by 100 to 0. The bill's authors argued that aviation safety was now a matter of national security and could not be left in the hands of often inexperienced and underpaid employees hired by the lowest-bidding private contractor.
Mr. Bush and House Republican leaders balked at adding tens of thousands of people to the federal payroll, and instead promoted a plan to leave the work in the hands of the private contractors, but under government supervision, with higher pay and stricter standards.
Nonetheless, White House advisers have signaled that Mr. Bush would sign either bill in the interest of moving quickly to offer air travelers reassurance.
That seeming agnosticism apparently drove Mr. DeLay to distraction. Earlier this week, he said, he told the White House that if the president wanted the House bill, he would have to start a personal lobbying campaign.
The president soon began calling and meeting with dozens of Republican and Democratic fence-sitters -- although not, one White House official pointedly said, only because Mr. DeLay had told him to do so. Still, Mr. Calio parked himself in Mr. DeLay's office during the vote in the House.
Whatever the reasons for the lobbying campaign, many Republicans said the president had a far different style of persuasion than what were described as the hardball tactics of Mr. DeLay.
Representative Jim Ramstad, a Republican from Minnesota who ultimately voted against the president, said he got a call from Mr. Bush at 8:30 a.m. Thursday while he was out jogging, but when he called back he spent most of his conversation with Mr. Bush discussing how fast each man could run a mile.
"I got no pressure at all from the president," Mr. Ramstad said. "He said he understood that I was supporting the Senate bill and he asked if I were locked into that position, and I said yes, and he said, 'Well, I certainly respect your position.' "
In contrast, Mr. Ramstad said, "we are still hearing the bones crunching" from Mr. DeLay's "pressure job."
Democrats and moderate Republicans said the president would now have the difficult political task of promoting a compromise bill out of the competing House and Senate versions in time for the heavy travel season that starts at the end of this month. Many said that even in a supposed era of bipartisanship, Democrats would quickly blame Mr. Bush if a bill was languishing in Congress when Americans were fearful of flying or if there was another terrorist attack on an airline.
"I think that he made a decision that the difference between federalizing and not federalizing airline security was not worth the political capital to buck DeLay," said Representative Robert Menendez, a prominent House Democrat from New Jersey, who voted for the Senate version of the bill. "I think that's going to come back to haunt him."
The White House, perhaps mindful of that, was moving quickly today to try to reconcile the two bills.
"We're prepared to take an active role to make sure that an airline security bill comes out of conference as quickly as possible," Mr. Bush said.
He added that if he could sign such a bill, "it will say to the American people that we are doing everything we possibly can to recover from the aftermath of Sept. 11."

HEADLINE: Correspondent; 
Up With Moguls! Exploit the Rich!

BYLINE:  By BILL KELLER 

 BODY:
This is not an endorsement of the candidacy of Michael Bloomberg in next Tuesday's New York City mayoral election. For endorsements you have to go next door to the editorial page, where, if you are a candidate encumbered by great wealth, you may be subjected to the biblical eye-of-the-needle test. This is an endorsement of the idea of Michael Bloomberg, meaning the idea that it would not kill us to have a few self-made billionaires in our political life.
 For a country that idealizes opportunity, dotes on celebrity and frequently confuses the ability to make vast sums of money with wisdom, it is remarkable how indignant the discourse gets when a rich person runs for public office. We'll propel Jack Welch's astoundingly tedious memoir of corporate life to the top of the best-seller list, but if Mr. Welch decided to invest some of his bounty running for governor of Connecticut, the knives would surely come out. 
 Mark Green's campaign chant against Mr. Bloomberg -- "Message beats money!" -- is descended from a long line of populist derision wielded by candidates who feel it's nobler to spend someone else's money pursuing public office. Supporters of Arch Moore famously caught the spirit in the 1980 campaign against Gov. John D. Rockefeller IV of West Virginia. The bumper stickers read, "Make Him Spend It All, Arch!" (Rockefeller supporters' bumpers retorted, "At Least It's His," which seemed particularly apt a few years later when Mr. Moore was sent to prison for mail fraud.)
Candidacies of the rich are a curiously neglected subject in political science. Alan Ehrenhalt, editor of Governing magazine and a student of American politics for more than 30 years, says that as near as he can tell, voters don't care if a candidate is rich. In some cases, he says, particularly where the political climate has been tainted by special-interest money, the customary rich candidate's plea that he can't be bought may work to his advantage.
Jon S. Corzine, who spent $63 million acquiring a Senate seat from New Jersey, a state acquainted with political scandal, thinks the beholden-to-no-one argument worked powerfully for him. On the other hand, a candidate whose wealth appears to have kept him out of touch with real life -- think of George Bush puzzling over the novelty of a grocery-store scanner -- may be punished. But in general, voters seem not to regard enormous wealth as a stigma. The latest Times polling, completed on Thursday, found that 75 percent of New Yorkers care "not at all" if a wealthy candidate pays for his campaign, and they find that less worrisome, by 2 to 1, than being bankrolled by special interests.
Mr. Bloomberg says the only people who hold his money against him are journalists, and loyal though I am to my fraternity of skeptics, I suspect he is onto something. Journalists find it difficult to think of a legitimate reason that anyone who had not already lapsed into the dubious career of politics would give up respectable work (or a life of leisure) for a job that requires being polite to strangers, compromising with idiots and reading your every unguarded remark in tabloid headlines. We are wary of people who believe in things, and dubious of reformers. Partly this is cynicism born of exposure to politicians who don't believe in anything and reforms that didn't reform, partly it is a reluctance to seem overly credulous, partly it is the sense of detachment that draws people to a career on the sidelines. I can think of just a handful of working journalists who have actually run for public office themselves, and to get that many I have to stretch the category of "working journalist" to include Al Gore and the category of serious candidate to include Jimmy Breslin.
Our suspicion of politics is nearly matched by our suspicion of the rich. If getting rich were a matter of intelligence or judgment, we believe in our envious hearts, surely reporters would be in life's E-ZPass lane. This creates an oddly contradictory stance toward candidates like Mr. Bloomberg: We don't hold the office in great esteem, but hold on a second, Mr. Moneybags, what makes you think you're qualified? If only Mr. Bloomberg had debased himself doing the kind of spotlight-chasing Mr. Green has done, he might be worthy to be mayor.
Here are a few reasons not to disparage the political aspirations of people like Mr. Bloomberg.
Why shouldn't the rich work for us? Noblesse oblige, the notion that those enriched by the system should repay it with public service, has fallen into serious disrepair, if not disrepute. The idea of an elite that is not motivated by personal gain has a venerable history in our land, dating to gentlemen politicians like Washington and Jefferson and continuing through the progressive reformers and industrialist philanthropists of a century ago, the Harrimans and Roosevelts and Rockefellers. 
Somewhere, perhaps in the Vietnam-era repudiation of the best and brightest, perhaps in the Reagan-era backlash of the right, perhaps in the greed-is-good prosperity of the 80's, the notion of common interest seems to have been smothered by special interests. We keep a token Kennedy and a token Rockefeller in the Senate, as if to remind us that there was a time when public service was actually taught in the homes of the rich, but more often we see noblesse oblige turned inside out. Nowadays those who have spent a few terms as public servants in Congress or the cabinet expect to be repaid for their sacrifice by peddling their credibility in the high-priced bordellos of K Street. When someone comes along who talks about "giving back," and seems to believe it, why is that not cause for celebration? True, with Mr. Bloomberg, master of the eponymous empire, there is always the slight suspicion that his campaign is an exercise in brand extension. But this is a guy who says if he can't be mayor his fantasy would be to run the World Bank or the United Nations. Phew. The man has the do-good disease bad.
Maybe they know something we don't. Being rich is not, in and of itself, evidence of great executive ability, or even emotional stability. (Ross Perot. Case closed.) But I'm prepared to believe that a competent mogul might actually know some things that could be usefully applied to overseeing a piece of government. Someone who has successfully run a company might, for example, know the value of economic diversification, fiscal discipline, quality control and customer service. A successful C.E.O. ought to know something about negotiating compromises and holding people accountable, which are essentials of politics. (And, yes, it is inescapably about politics. Mr. Bloomberg's slogan that he is "a leader, not a politician," would disqualify him for the job of mayor if he meant it literally.) Good bosses know how to master bureaucracy. If Jack Welch had spent the last year applying his tough-love management to the C.I.A. rather than compiling all his thank-you notes into a book, maybe we'd have seen Osama bin Laden coming.
One of the things rich people know something about, by the way, is other rich people. They are positioned to see the nonsense in nostrums proposed in the name of universal prosperity. When Republicans proposed earlier this year to repeal the inheritance tax, the most credible opposition came from a group of 800 rich Americans, including the likes of George Soros, Paul Newman and Warren E. Buffett, who argued that the estate tax actually nourishes the economy by rewarding merit rather than birthright.
Have a little faith in voters. It is tempting to believe that the American electorate is not very bright, or not very attentive. Maybe so, but there's little evidence that candidates with more money than talent do better than candidates with neither. The field is littered with failed plutocrats -- Michael Huffington, Steve Forbes, Ross Perot, our own Ronald S. Lauder and Abe Hirschfeld, and many others. Voters just aren't that stupid.
This is not, by the way, an argument against campaign reforms, including New York's much-admired public financing system (which allows candidates like Mr. Bloomberg to opt out), restrictions on soft-money propaganda and free TV time for candidates. Such laws, though, are designed to protect us not from rich candidates but from more pernicious dangers -- the poisonous influence of chit-calling donors and the chilling advantage of incumbency.
There may be plenty of good reasons not to vote for Michael Bloomberg as the next mayor of New York, but his money is not one of them. Let a hundred Bloombergs flower!

HEADLINE: Poll Finds Gap Narrowing For Bloomberg and Green 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY and MARJORIE CONNELLY 

 BODY:
New Yorkers now believe that both Michael R. Bloomberg and Mark Green are qualified to be the next mayor of New York, amid signs that Mr. Green's contention that Mr. Bloomberg does not have the skills or experience to run the city has not taken hold, according to the latest New York Times poll.
 By a slight margin, more New Yorkers saw Mr. Green as having "the right kind of experience" to be mayor of New York than felt that way about Mr. Bloomberg, who is making his first run for public office. Mr. Green is also more heavily favored among older voters, who tend to vote in disproportionately higher numbers. 
 But the poll found that by a significant margin, voters believe that it is Mr. Bloomberg who presents "strong qualities of leadership," a trait analysts believe could prove influential as voters choose who will lead New York through what are potentially perilous years. 
And Mr. Bloomberg -- who one year and at least $41 million ago was barely known by most New York voters -- is now viewed more favorably among New Yorkers than Mr. Green as he goes into the last days of the campaign.
The poll, taken Saturday through Thursday, found that among those most likely to vote, Mr. Green, a Democrat, is supported by 42 percent and Mr. Bloomberg, a Republican, by 37 percent. The difference is not statistically significant. About 20 percent are undecided -- an unusually high figure for this late in the contest, and a hint that New Yorkers might be in for a fairly ferocious final weekend of campaigning.
The poll was done in a week in which Mr. Bloomberg won the endorsement of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, apparently very much to his benefit. Of the self-identified Democrats who said they would have voted for Mr. Giuliani were he on the ballot, a majority said they intended to vote for Mr. Bloomberg. The poll also came out as Mr. Bloomberg is financing a final tidal wave of television advertisements, mailings and automated telephone calls, many of them harshly critical of Mr. Green, and directed at specific blocs, including Jewish and Hispanic voters. "He wants to tear apart Rudy Giuliani's City Hall," Mr. Bloomberg said of Mr. Green in one automated call that went out this week. 
At the same time, the combination of the war abroad, terrorist fears at home and a World Series has overshadowed the day-to-day news coverage of the race, coverage that in a typical year, would serve as at least a partial counterweight to the paid advertisements of both candidates.
Given Mr. Bloomberg's financial advantage, that would appear to be to the disadvantage of Mr. Green, particularly after a stretch in which even Mr. Bloomberg's supporters expressed concern about his first-time candidacy.
The poll found that Mr. Green's attempt to use Mr. Bloomberg's wealth against him -- "You don't understand the city just by spending a lot of private wealth," Mr. Green declared at a debate on Thursday -- may not carry much weight with this electorate. In an era when wealthy candidates have become something less than a novelty, most New Yorkers said they did not mind that Mr. Bloomberg was spending so much on his own contest; some said they even preferred it.
The poll of 791 registered voters, of whom 390 are considered likely to vote, has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points for all registered voters and plus or minus five percentage points for likely voters.
In every sense, this has been a thoroughly unusual political year, even before two planes flew into the World Trade Center on what was supposed to have been the day of the Democratic primary. Nonetheless, news that Mr. Bloomberg was appearing to close in on Mr. Green in a city with such an edge in registered Democrats, and after Mr. Green had been acting as if victory were at hand, caught supporters of both candidates by surprise.
And it distressed a number of Democrats, some of whom suggested that Mr. Green was making the same mistake in the general election as he had in his primary battle with Fernando Ferrer. Both then and now, they said, Mr. Green ran a safe campaign, avoiding attacks on his opponents or offering a compelling case for his own candidacy.
That began to change earlier this week, when Mr. Green ran his first negative advertisement directed at Mr. Bloomberg, though even some of Mr. Green's supporters said he should have moved earlier. 
"Didn't he learn his lesson in the runoff?" said one senior New York Democratic official. "This thing is slipping away from him, and he is still measuring the drapes in Gracie Mansion."
Mr. Green's campaign announced late yesterday afternoon that it would begin broadcasting what is by far its toughest advertisement directed at Mr. Bloomberg, raising -- among a host of other tough-worded charges against him -- allegations of sexual harassment that were directed at Mr. Bloomberg by employees of his company. "Do we really want to make Mike our mayor?" the announcer asks.
In a Marist College poll released yesterday, Mr. Green was ahead by 46 percent to 42 percent, also not statistically significant, based on interviews of 435 likely voters between Monday and Wednesday. 
Mr. Bloomberg expressed satisfaction with the changing poll numbers. "This is just an indication that we are getting the message out of why this time, given the problems this city faces, my background is what is needed," he said.
Mr. Green told reporters yesterday that he was not concerned about the shifting tides. "He's not gaining momentum, his ads are gaining momentum," Mr. Green said. "There's a clear contrast in this race." 
Mr. Green's supporters said they had expected the contest to tighten up, given Mr. Bloomberg's record-setting expenditures, and the ferocity and sheer ubiquity of his attacks. They noted that New York is a heavily Democratic city, that Mr. Green is a familiar figure with extensive experience in government, and that he has won the support of most of New York's major unions.
Still, there were some potentially worrisome trends for Mr. Green suggested in the Times poll.
For one thing, he is still having difficulty nailing down groups who tend to vote Democratic. Mr. Green is so far drawing the support of only about half of the city's likely black voters, and is trailing Mr. Bloomberg among Hispanic voters.
That is apparently a legacy from the fractious campaign Mr. Green ran against Mr. Ferrer to win the Democratic nomination, a fight that Mr. Bloomberg has sought to reprise, to his benefit, during this contest. And Democratic respondents in the poll who said they voted for Mr. Ferrer in the primary are evenly split between Mr. Bloomberg and Mr. Green. 
Mr. Green's support is also notably tepid among Democratic voters, presumably a reflection of the fact that Mr. Bloomberg is a former Democrat whose views are largely indistinguishable from Mr. Green. About one in two Democrats said they would vote for Mr. Green. (By comparison, four in five Republicans, or about 80 percent, said they were planning to vote for Mr. Bloomberg.) And turnout will play an important role in Tuesday's balloting. If the pool of likely voters is enlarged to include those only somewhat likely to vote, then Mr. Green's advantage shrinks to one point. 
Most of all, though, Mr. Bloomberg seems to be benefiting by his identification with Mr. Giuliani. The mayor has a huge favorable rating, around 80 percent, that crosses all demographic lines.
Three-quarters of black respondents, who have consistently given Mr. Giuliani low job-approval ratings, said they now approve of Mr. Giuliani's performance. And sixty percent of all voters said that, if it were possible, they would vote for Mr. Giuliani again -- with most saying they will vote for Mr. Bloomberg in the general election. "From what I see in his television ads, Bloomberg says he'll be very involved with getting people back to work and following through with the economic things Giuliani has started," Margaret Mariano, 81, a Democrat and retired seamstress from the Bronx, said in a follow-up interview. "Mark Green doesn't seem to be doing too much. I really favor Giuliani, but he's not running, and since he's endorsed Bloomberg, he knows a little more about him."
On what is arguably the key question of this election, the poll found voters evenly divided when asked whether they would prefer someone with governmental experience (Mr. Green) or business experience (Mr. Bloomberg). But when the choice was between government experience or a "fresh approach," they chose the latter, 53 percent to 47 percent.

How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Oct. 27 to Nov. 1 in all parts of New York City with 1,172 adults, of whom 791 said they were registered to vote. Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish. 
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of telephone exchanges in the city. The exchanges were chosen so as to assure that each area in the city was represented in proportion to its population. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household one adult was designated by a random procedure as the respondent. 
The results have been weighted to take into account household size and the number of telephone lines into the residence, and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to borough, race, sex, age, education, and Hispanic descent.
In addition, the questions about voting preferences in the 2001 election for mayor are based on the responses of "most likely voters," defined in terms of intention to vote, attention to the campaign, and past voting behavior.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results based on such samples will differ by no more than 3 percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all adult New Yorkers.
For smaller subgroups, the potential sampling error is larger. For example, it is plus or minus 5 percentage points for "most likely voters."
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Differences in the wording and order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat varying results.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
YOUNGKEN, HEBER W., JR.

 BODY:
 YOUNGKEN-Heber W., Jr., 88. An internationally known educator, researcher, and university administrator, died October 22 at his home in Peace Dale, RI. He was the son of noted pharmacognocist Heber Wilkinson Youngken and Clara Eastman Youngken. Youngken devoted his life's work to the field of pharmacognosy and natural products chemisty. He was the author and co-author of over 180 publications dealing with the sources, chemistry, and pharmacological characteristics of plants. He was the author of "Pharmacognosy," J.B. Lippincott, PA, 1951, second ed. 1965, a textbook, (with R. Pratt), and "Organic Chemistry in Pharmacy," J.B. Lippincott, PA, 1949 (with Wilson, et al), among other texts. His writings appeared in numerous national journals including the "Journal of Natural Products" and the "Herbalist." He also contributed to research findings in the field of drugs derived from marine organisms. Youngken was the recipient of numerous awards, including the American Pharmaceutical Association Newcomb Award in Pharmacognosy, and achievement awards from the American Society of Pharmacognosy. Youngken served on review councils of the National Institutes of Health and the National Science Foundation, and was a principal researcher of numerous grants for studies in the field of natural products. He was a member of the revision committees of the "United States Pharmacopeia" and the "National Formulary", and frequent consultant to members of the drug industry on botanical drugs. Youngken came to Rhode Island in 1956 as the dean to establish, organize and develop the University of Rhode Island College of Pharmacy after 15 years in the pharmacy faculty at the University of Washington in Seattle. 
Under Youngken's leadership the URI pharmacy college grew in teaching, research, and service from 9 faculty and 135 students to 33 full term and 18 part time faculty with more than 600 undergraduate and graduate students at his retirement in 1981. Its faculty and graduates have gained worldwide recognition for excellence in pharmacy research and the related health sciences. He was a visiting professor at the University of London, 1970 and the University of Cairo, Egypt, 1977, '79, '81, and '85. Nationally prominent in pharmaceutical education and research, Youngken chaired or served on various committees representing the American Pharmaceutical Association (APhA), the American Association of Colleges of Pharmacy (AACP), the Academy of Pharmaceutical Sciences, the American Society of Pharmacognosy (former president), the Society of Economic Botany, and many others. In 1953 he published one of the first papers in the United States to promote the concept of clinical pharmacy and the student externship programs. In 1958, he founded the Pharmacy Clinic at URI for continuing pharmacy education, now dedicated in his name. In 1994, the medicinal plant garden at the University of Rhode Island was dedicated to Youngken. A new faculty chair at URI, known as the OmarYoungken Distinguished Chair in Natural Product Chemistry, was created in his honor in 2001. Youngken served in the US Navy during World War II in North Atlantic convoy escort duty, later achieving the rank of Captain in the US Navy Reserve. He held degrees from Bucknell University (AB), the Massachusetts College of Pharmacy (BS), and the University of Minnesota (MS, PhD). In 1982 he received an Honorary DSc from the University of Rhode Island. Youngken is survived by his wife Daphne Goodwin Youngken, two sons, John Ronald Youngken of New York City and Richard Charles Youngken of Wakefield, RI, and two granddaughters, Kelly Goodwin Youngken of Arlington, VA, and Abigail Bouldin Youngken of Greensboro, NC. A memorial service will be held at St. Augustine's Church in Kingston, RI at 3:00 P.M., Monday, November 19th.

HEADLINE: The World; 
Allure Must Be Covered. Individuality Peeks Through.

BYLINE:  By RUTH FREMSON 

 BODY:
WHETHER they call it "observing purdah" or "hijab," the meaning is the same: a traditional Muslim woman's obligation to hide her physical beauty from men to whom she is not related. But there are many interpretations of what is required among the Afghan refugees now living in Pakistan. 
 When the Taliban took control of Afghanistan, they tried to impose a uniform standard: the head-to-toe covering called the burqa, a swirl of colored fabric that covers everything except a woman's eyes, erasing not just her allure but her individuality. 
 Aftab Ahmed Butt, who owns three women's clothing shops in Peshawar, Pakistan, summed up the argument for strictness: "Women should wear proper purdah with only their eyes showing. They should wear gloves and socks. Women not wearing purdah are wrong because males will be attracted to them. In your Western clothes your beauty, your dignity, would vanish. Women can wear makeup and Western clothes, but just for her husband."
But in the streets near his shops, Afghan women observe purdah or hijab (Urdu and Farsi words, respectively, that mean "covering")in many ways. 
Some keep the burqa while others use a large shawl that they call a chador, wearing it worn over loose clothing. (This is not the chador worn in Iran, which covers a woman completely.) The chadors vary in size, color and the way in which women wrap themselves, depending on the wearer's thoughts about hijab itself.
A few rebel still further. "Purdah was the oppression of the Taliban who forced us to wear these things and I left them behind in Kabul," said a recent arrival. Her blue eyes flashed defiantly from below a small, light, white scarf. But she dared not give her name.

GRAPHIC: Photos: "We are Pashtuns. We don't like the chador. The burqa is half of our faith. It is my religious duty to wear it. The wives of the prophet used to observe purdah. First, I was wearing a chador but when I got married my husband told me to wear the burqa. While you are in Rome do as Romans do." ZARGHONA, 19, in a full burqa in a shop that sells only burqas.; "I like the chador. When I was in Kabul I used to wear it. I was 6 or 7 when I started to wear it. It is quite comfortable and I don't cover my face. Next year, when I am in the seventh class, I will observe hijab. I will feel like a grown-up woman. I have seen Western movies and their clothes are their fashion, but this is an Islamic country, and Islam doesn't allow us to wear such clothes. I think they look very bad." HALEEMA, 13, a student.; "Every Pakistani woman wears a chador so I am supposed to wear it. I'm working, so I can't afford to wear a burqa. If I did, the mohajirs refugees would tease me because the burqa is for "good" women who stay inside the home. I face a lot of hurdles and problems. Men offer me money to go with them for the night." NOOREEN, vendor of bracelets in a Peshawar street market.; "This is the proper Islamic hijab. I've been wearing it for twenty 20 years. I made it myself. I like this color. It takes two or three hours to make and it costs 300 or 400 rupees about 5 or 6 dollars . It is economical to make it myself. It is a sin if you are not covering your face. We have to take care of our modesty. Hiya modesty is half of our faith." ULIYA, 45, in a homemade burqa.; "Because we are Muslims we should have a hijab. Some say only their hair should not be seen, some will wear a veil over their face and some will wear the burqa. It depends on each family how they do it. The disadvantage is the hot weather. I want to be in the house in the summer, where I don't have to wear it, but I think there are more advantages than disadvantages. Islam does not say you MUST wear it. Islam shows you the way and if you agree, you wear it." LIDA, 16, student of medicine at Afghan University in Peshawar.; "I won't hide my face. I don't agree with this rigid version of Islam that some people practice. I believe we should adopt the moderate, middle way. I'm not trying to be fashionable, I'm not wearing makeup. So why should people look at me? But if they do, I don't care. I will take my stand. My father-in-law gave me permission to work on the condition that I would hide my face. I told them I respect them but I don't like their way." RAHEELA, 45, girls' school principal. (Photographs by RUTH FREMSON/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Militancy; 
Living in a World Without Women

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
IN the war of militant Islam against the infidel West, there is a chilling paradox. Nowhere not on protesters' banners, pre-suicide videos or posters of the most wanted is there a woman's face. These martyrs and radicals call themselves the purifiers of society and the saviors of the poor, yet everything the world has learned in the last decade about why some countries develop and others stay mired in poverty shows that women can make all the difference.
 National standards of living improve family income, education, nutrition and life expectancy all rise, and birthrates fall -- as women move toward equality, said Jennifer Seymour Whitaker, a senior fellow at the Council on Foreign Relations studying how investing in women can help increase economic development and stability. She cites as an example a statistical model of Egypt that demonstrated if mothers with no education had completed at least primary school, the population below the poverty line would have been reduced by one-third. United Nations agencies produced similar findings in other countries. Amartya Sen, the Nobel prize-winning economist, has emphasized this repeatedly. 
 When women's influence increases, these experts explain, it strengthens the moderate center, bolstering economic stability and democratic order. Women might serve as powerful assets in the West's attempt to counter Islamic radicalism. 
The results of Iran's last two presidential elections reveal the moderating power of women -- their covered heads and bodies notwithstanding. President Mohammed Khatami, a moderate by current Iranian standards, was elected twice over the wishes of Islamic conservatives because of the pivotal support of women.
But for the last 30 years, Islamic extremism has flourished throughout the Middle East. As women have been pushed out of the political and economic spheres, their traditional moderating role has declined. "This is the warriors' time," said Fouad Ajami, director of Middle East Studies at the John Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies in Washington. "The warriors, the martyrs they're all men. In this moment of history, with the world of the Arabs and the larger world of Islam on the boil, the whole question of women and women's progress is shelved."
Indeed, in societies where women did gain footholds, that power may have prompted a backlash among lower middle class men in particular that helped militants. Women often look like competitors for jobs and a better life in countries where half or more of the population is under age 25. Angry young men, many of them unemployed, have seized the public arena from Algeria to South Asia and filled it with hate, intolerance and the abuse of women, Mr. Ajami said. He and other scholars of Muslim societies say these men are from the lower middle class, where expectations were rising fastest. "This is the class that is most hostile to women," Mr. Ajami said. "If this class dominates the Islamists, feminism and modernity are doomed."
Since 1979, radical Islamic movements have toppled or challenged governments from Iran to Egypt to Pakistan. Their growing popularity has many causes: poverty, the dissatisfaction with regimes viewed as corrupt and irreligious, the dislocation of modernity and unease with women's independence. Azar Nafisi, an Iranian scholar now at Johns Hopkins, said recruitment of militants is strong among low-paid workers or lower middle classes.
In recent decades, the media and the Internet have made images of Western life omnipresent. And what it looks like frightens this segment of the population. "If Western culture, if democratic culture, is spread to their countries, there will be no room for them," Ms. Nafisi said. "Women become the most obvious symbols of this change that seems threatening."
That backlash takes place even in less radical societies. In Kuwait, Mr. Ajami noted, the emir's efforts to bring women into politics has met a wall of resistance, and an Islamist backlash forced a vote in Parliament against coeducational universities.
Not all women oppose extremism. Some women aligned with extremists because they believed in the cause and were also disturbed by what seemed a Western-inspired cultural assault on traditional ways. Some thought they would improve their status by joining a revolutionary movement. Others choose to cover their heads or faces out of piety. Many initially rallied around militants for some of the same reasons as men -- distaste for corrupt secular rulers, frustration over poverty. In Iran in the 1970's, Mr. Ajami said, educated women donned the chador to protest the rule of Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlavi -- and walked into a trap. For a generation, he said, they have paid for the mistake with a loss of many freedoms and rights.
It could be that women are less inclined to support radicalism now. Ms. Nafisi, who was a professor of English literature in Teheran, explained, "They saw what happened in the Iranian revolution, the Algerian revolution, the Palestinian struggle and many other places."
WHILE these militants are fighting secularism or the West, "they need women, they use women," she said. But even women who have risked their lives, she said, found they were little more than advertisements. When the battle was won, she said, "they put the women aside."
What is happening now, said Mr. Ajami, is "the break of the compact with modernity" throughout the Arab and wider Islamic world. "The issue of gender is so crucial to progress and modernity," he said, "But if the cult of the martyr and the children of the stones on the West Bank, if that's the dominant cult, then what little place there was for women is shrinking."
The sense that the place of women is regressing under Islamic militancy is widely acknowledged. But in the history of Muslim movements, even violent uprisings, it was not always so. A woman, Cut Nyak Dhien, led the nationalists of Indonesia's deeply Islamic region of Aceh in rebellion against the Dutch in the 19th century. Egyptian and Turkish women were in the forefront of modernizing, secularist movements in the 1920's. In the 1970's, Leila Khaled of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine hijacked planes. Benazir Bhutto marched through the streets of Pakistan in the 1980's to demand a return to democracy.
By the 1990's, some Muslim women seemed to be on the verge of success in the professions, scholarship and public life. Educational levels and opportunities were rising in many Islamic countries. "Some of these networks we thought we were building don't seem to have survived," said Mahnaz Afkhami, who has worked with Islamic women around the world for decades. Ms. Afkhami founded the Women's Learning Partnership in Washington, which aids grass-roots women's groups in many Muslim countries. She calls them an invisible majority not noticed by the West.
In Malaysia, for example, an anthropologist, Norani Othman, formed a movement to reinterpret Islamic law and strip it of centuries of accretions that discriminate against women. In Bangladesh, Yasmeen Murshed founded one of several organizations that teach women how to run for political office. From North Africa to Pakistan and Indonesia, women have demanded the right to study theology along with men, breaking their monopoly of the Koran.
Rounaq Jahan, a political scientist from Bangladesh at Columbia University's School of Public and International Affairs, said it is often forgotten that "more than half of the billion Muslims in the world live in Indonesia, Pakistan, Bangladesh and India more than 500 million in just these four countries." Many are moderates if not secularists, she said, and how they have dealt with militancy could be instructive elsewhere.
Afghanistan has shown a world of Muslim women just how bad things can get. Ms. Nafisi said the West's promises that Afghan women would have choices in a post-Taliban era should be part of the anti-terrorism campaign. "When reconstruction in Afghanistan begins," she said, "the U.N. will find their most ardent supporters will be women."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 11, 2001

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about the influence of women in Islamic cultures misstated the affiliation of Rounaq Jahan, an expert on women in developing countries. It is Columbia University's School of International and Public Affairs, not Public and International Affairs.

HEADLINE: DataBank; 
A Stumble, Then a Rally Amid Bad News

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
By conventional logic, the stock market should have sagged throughout last week as investors were hit with a steady barrage of dismal economic reports. There was almost no encouraging news from corporate America. 
 Consumer confidence, construction spending, manufacturing activity and consumer spending all declined. The unemployment rate surged in October to 5.4 percent from 4.9 percent, with Americans losing more jobs in a one-month period than they had lost in any other month in more than 21 years. 
 But on Wall Street, some investors viewed the bad news as evidence that the worst might be over and that the economy would improve next year. After falling on Monday and Tuesday, the stock market stabilized on Wednesday and rallied on Thursday and Friday.
 Microsoft contributed to the rally on Thursday, reflecting anticipation of a settlement between it and the Justice Department on its long-running antitrust case.
 Stocks still finished lower for the week. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 221.63 points, or 2.3 percent, to 9,323.54. The Nasdaq composite index was off 23.23 points, or 1.3 percent, to 1,745.73. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 20.51 points, or 1.9 percent, to 1,084.10. SHERRI DAY
