HEADLINE: In a Suffering City, Charity Endures; 
The Times Neediest Cases Fund Helps a Man Who Has No Home

BYLINE:  By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
Robert Tucker hunched forward, his cheek resting on the side of a nearly deserted subway car. His body bumped up and down with the movements of a Manhattan-bound E train as it thundered through the tunnel under Queens Boulevard at 3 a.m.
 It was the night before Halloween, Devil's Night, and Mr. Tucker, 60, was spending it as he spends many nights, trying to catch as much sleep as he could before the train he was riding reached the end of the line. 
 During the day he spends time at a cafeteria for the elderly poor or earns pocket money by offering to carry bags for bus or train travelers. 
At night he sleeps in a Pennsylvania Station waiting area, in subway stations or on trains, at a crowded drop-in center that has comfortable chairs but no beds, with friends in Harlem or Brooklyn or on the street. At every hour, he knows where he is welcome and where he is not.
"Being homeless is hell," Mr. Tucker said. "A lot of people look down on you, they don't trust you, they look at you like you might do anything."
Mr. Tucker is one of the thousands of homeless in New York, and has been for two and a half years. It began, he said, when he told the police about the drug dealing going on at a flophouse on the Bowery where he was living, and was threatened by the other residents. 
He is also one of the tens of thousands of poor New Yorkers helped by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Today The Times begins its 90th annual appeal for donations to the fund, 24 days after ending a special monthlong campaign to help the victims of the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.
Officials who run the fund emphasized that the Neediest Cases Fund serves a different group of people from the 9/11 Neediest Fund. "We're maintaining a bright-line distinction between the two funds," said Jack Rosenthal, president of The Times Company Foundation, which administers the funds. "To meet need in one area does not diminish it in another."
The 9/11 fund has raised more than $43 million, more than five times as much as the record $8 million raised last year by the Neediest Cases Fund. "The public responded to the disaster with astonishing generosity," Mr. Rosenthal said. "But nonprofit organizations are already distressed to see a sharp drop-off in regular contributions. How painful it would be if such compassion fatigue depressed gifts for the neediest. That would turn the poor people of New York into the latest victims of the terrorists." 
"We set up the 9/11 fund within 24 hours as a way of trying to get assistance in sudden desperate need," Mr. Rosenthal said. "The regular Neediest Cases Fund seeks to help people whose poverty arises in the ordinary course of life."
The Starr Foundation, a private charitable group associated with the American International Group, the insurance company, gave $1 million to the Neediest Cases Fund last month. "We were anticipating a difficult winter for the needy in New York City even before Sept. 11," said Florence A. Davis, president of the Starr Foundation. "Now, after Sept. 11, that's even clearer."
In the nine decades that The Times has published stories as part of its Neediest Cases campaigns, much has changed. A government-run social welfare system now assists those at the bottom of the economic ladder, including Mr. Tucker, who receives $100.50 every two weeks in welfare and $130 in food stamps once a month, credited to an electronic benefits card. 
But men still live on the streets of New York, as the homeless did 90 years ago, when a shabby beggar approached Adolph S. Ochs, then the publisher of The Times, on Christmas Day 1911. The chance encounter with the beggar, whose name has not been recorded in any known source, inspired Mr. Ochs to use his newspaper to help the poor.
One of the many projects supported by the Neediest Cases Fund is a meal-in-a-bag program run by Project FIND (Friendless, Isolated, Needy and Disabled). Last December, Project FIND received a grant of $10,000 from the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies to give out lunches -- which cost Project FIND $1 each -- free to the elderly for a year. The federation is one of the seven local charities supported by the Neediest Cases Fund. 
From Sunday to Friday, workers give out about 20 bags of food a day to the elderly men and women who frequent the cafeteria on Ninth Avenue that sits snugly beneath an overpass to the Port Authority Bus Terminal. One of the aims of the project is to attract the homeless to the cafeteria, where Maury Sherman, a social worker, can help them get off the streets, said Cynthia Dial, executive director of Project FIND.
One of the men who began taking his meals there was Mr. Tucker. Last Tuesday, he gave a tour of the parts of the city he often calls home and told the story of his life, from his days as a child, when he dreamed of being a professional baseball player to his life on the windswept sidewalks of New York.
At 3:20 p.m., Mr. Tucker put down his foam cup of tea and emptied his pockets of their contents: a phone message from a social worker, some napkins, the chipped benefits card with his picture on it, $7 and a receipt from a Harlem optometrist for new eyeglasses.
His glasses had been stolen two weeks earlier, when he fell asleep on a subway station bench. But that is not the only reason his vision is impaired. When he was 6, he accidentally poked a wire into his eye. He bled profusely, he said, but doctors at the emergency room told him that he would be able to see again in a few weeks.
He never did. Now, there is a circle of light blue matter where the pupil and the iris once were, the damaged left eye jutting out from its socket a fraction more than the good one.
Mr. Tucker, born in Mobile, Ala., said his mother, Lorain Tucker, died when he was 12 and his father, Hickes Jessie, when he was 13. After his mother died, Mr. Tucker's uncle from Detroit raised him. He moved to New York in 1977. 
In addition to his vision problems, Mr. Tucker also has diabetes and a fungus on his feet that developed last summer, when he would go for days without taking off his sneakers. Despite his ailments, Mr. Tucker earns pocket money by carrying suitcases for bus travelers at the Port Authority terminal. He uses the money for food, clothes, cigarettes and periodic trips to off-track betting parlors. He said he never drinks, though, because drinking killed his mother and his sister Barbara.
At 4 p.m., Mr. Tucker picked up his meal-in-a-bag. Inside was a bottle of water, cans of orange juice, peaches, tuna fish, two slices of rye bread and some butter. It was food he could manage despite the fact that his seven remaining upper teeth had been pulled days before by a dentist. 
He drank the orange juice, holding the can high to get every last drop, put the rest of the food back into the bag and got ready to go. At 4:20 p.m., he walked across Ninth Avenue, and into the bus terminal's back door.
"Pardon me, darling, do you need help?" he asked a young woman who had just gotten off a bus and was looking around. "Oh, Richmond? That's Gate 74. Up the escalator, turn left, go down the hall, down the next escalator. Can I help you with that?"
She said she could manage her bag herself. No sale.
After a few minutes, he spotted a Port Authority police officer. Mr. Tucker turned and briskly walked out of the arrivals area, but the officer followed him. 
"I'm dead at this place," Mr. Tucker said shortly afterward. "My best bet is to go over to Penn Station. Maybe I can get $3 or $4 over there."
Mr. Tucker said he has been arrested about 50 times in the past few years for soliciting or trespassing. He often winds up spending a night in jail, and he is typically sentenced to time already served or to a few hours of community service, in which he picks up litter at subway stations. The arrests do not seem to deter him, though. "Sometimes I'll be so tired," he said, "I'll be glad to go to jail to get some rest."
Last winter, a friend told him about the Project FIND cafeteria, his first step toward ending his cycle of arrests. At the cafeteria, Mr. Tucker met Ms. Sherman. "Maury, she helped me out tremendously," Mr. Tucker said. 
When Ms. Sherman found out that he was a diabetic, she insisted he take his medication, which he told her he had not been taking. "He started talking to me about some of his past experiences and burst into tears," Ms. Sherman recalled.
She helped him find a part-time job as a foot messenger, and told him about Peter's Place, a drop-in center in a church basement on West 23rd Street that helps people find permanent housing. "He's taking care of himself, which he wasn't for so long," Ms. Sherman said.
After Mr. Tucker was reprimanded one morning for arriving at his job too early, he said, he became angry and quit. But Ms. Sherman hopes that if he finds a place in a single-room occupancy building, he can find a job more easily. "Once Robert is in an S.R.O., he would qualify for all kinds of vocational training programs," she said, adding that he would also have access to social workers there. 
At 4:45 p.m., Mr. Tucker left the bus terminal, bought a cigarette for 50 cents, and walked toward Penn Station, where he watched for potential customers. In an hour and 15 minutes he earned tips from a young woman with a suitcase who gave him $1, and from a middle-aged woman who gave him $3.
Now he had enough to do his laundry. Mr. Tucker wanted to look nice for an appointment he had with a psychologist, who was going to talk to him the next day about moving into Euclid Hall, an S.R.O. on the Upper West Side.
Mr. Tucker walked down to Peter's Place, where he stores his clothing, toothbrush and diabetes medications. At 6:50 p.m. he arrived at a nearby laundry with enough money for two single-serve boxes of Tide and his small load of wrinkled shirts, pants and socks.
After doing his laundry, he spotted a MetroCard on the sidewalk. "Oh, look at this," he said. "I always stop and pick up cards. Sometimes they be good."
At 8 p.m. he returned to Peter's Place, and put his bag in its spot. Then, it was time to go back to the bus terminal to see if he could earn money for the next day's meals.
But there was one matter of business to attend to first. He had to check that MetroCard. He descended into the subway station at 23rd Street and Seventh Avenue and swiped the card through a reader, which indicated that the card had $3 on it. "See that?" he said with a confident grin. "That's all I needed to know." 
At midnight, after eating a fast-food dinner and trying his luck at the Port Authority again, Mr. Tucker decided to go back to Penn Station and sleep in the waiting area for ticketed passengers. But he had to leave about an hour later when security guards started asking people to show their tickets.
"Well," he said, "our best bet now is to ride the trains." 
At 1:42 a.m., Mr. Tucker got on an E train -- which he favors because its doors never open above ground to face bitter cold air -- and found a seat near the window. When the train arrived at the end of the line in Queens, Mr. Tucker, eyes bloodshot, walked across the platform to a train waiting to go the other direction. He rode that train all the way to the chilly Canal Street station in Manhattan, where he arrived at 3:31 a.m. He dozed off on a wooden bench, waiting for the next train. Much later that morning, Mr. Tucker had meetings with workers from two S.R.O.'s. It was a step toward ending his pattern of nights spent on subway trains.
"Maury said if I went to Peter's Place, within a year I could be living somewhere," he said, "and she's almost right."

HEADLINE: Our Towns; 
A Nassau Republican Follows Marx (the One With the Cigar)

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINERIP 

DATELINE: MINEOLA, N.Y. 

 BODY:
LIKE Groucho Marx, Thomas Gulotta, the Nassau County executive, must be going. Mr. Gulotta, a Republican, is the top elected official in this Long Island suburb, home to the nation's oldest, most powerful Republican machine, but if he doesn't go soon, there may be few Republicans left here. Like Groucho, who could take dear old Huxley College and blissfully destroy it, Mr. Gulotta ran a wealthy county in a time of unprecedented prosperity and oversaw its near fiscal ruin, and now, his fellow Republicans say, he must be going.
 "He keeps showing up," says Fred Parola, the county comptroller and a fellow Republican, facing his toughest re-election bid in 25 years. "He'll be at a campaign opportunity and Republicans say, 'Oh my God, what's he doing here?' He's the poster boy for the fiscal crisis, but he doesn't get it. Last weekend I saw him at two Eagle Scout ceremonies and a Halloween parade." 
 Though Republicans outnumber Democrats 4 to 3 in Nassau, by last spring Mr. Gulotta's approval rating was 10 percent, and under pressure from Republican leaders, he agreed that after three terms, he would be going. By then, Democrats controlled the County Legislature. Even top Republicans expect Thomas Suozzi to be elected county executive on Tuesday, the first Democrat in 40 years. "For Republicans," says Mr. Parola, "Gulotta's a supernightmare."
While most Republicans push fiscal conservatism, Mr. Gulotta remained an avowed (Groucho) Marxist, refusing to raise taxes for eight years while the county spent freely. This was classic Groucho, one for me (voters love low taxes) and one for me (police unions and other Republican favorites donated big time to Mr. Gulotta). A Nassau cop with five years on the job makes $74,267, $20,000 more than a New York City cop doing far more dangerous work. Nassau Community College professors -- including Mr. Gulotta's wife -- had the nation's top community college salaries in the 1990's (salaries that now rank third in an American Association of University Professors survey).
Nassau faced a $178 million deficit in 2000 when the governor, a Republican, created an oversight board to monitor county finances. But Margaret Dumont could never get the Groucho out of Rufus T. Firefly, and Frank Zarb, the Republican businessman running the oversight board, could never quite eliminate Mr. Gulotta's brand of tutti-frutti fiscalism. One week after the Sept. 11 attacks, Mr. Gulotta produced his final budget, calling it balanced. No one believed it; not the Republican Mr. Zarb, not the Republican comptroller, not Republican legislators, certainly not Democrats. To balance it, Mr. Gulotta projected that sales tax revenue would be higher in 2001 than it was during the 2000 economic boom and even higher in 2002, making him the last American to predict a post-Sept. 11 boom economy.
FOR his part, Mr. Gulotta said he had no data to alter sales tax projections, so he left it for legislators to revise. He declined to say if he believed that police salaries were too high, but added that if they were, it was the legislators' fault for rejecting his union contract proposals, resulting in larger arbitration awards. And he said he didn't care how Republicans felt about his showing up. "I go at the request of groups seeking my support."
The men who ran Groucho's Freedonia loved rows of medals on their chests, and Mr. Gulotta is known for handing out record numbers of county certificates of appreciation. "He could do 100 ceremonies a week," Mr. Parola said. "He had staff people clipping the papers for every little event. I've been with him when he showed up at some private 100-year-old's birthday party. It was embarrassing."
And yet Nassau, a county of 1.3 million, has no central grants manager -- a position that Mr. Parola first pressed for in 1998. Nassau remains technologically primitive; many county workers have no e-mail or voice mail and Nassau is just now doing its first property tax reassessment in 70 years.
Republicans are worried. Mr. Parola was endorsed by Newsday in his first two comptroller races, but not this time. This year's editorial praised Mr. Parola for warning of the fiscal crisis back in 1996 and for often making his own party "spitting mad," but faulted him for being unable to change Mr. Gulotta. Truth is, nobody much influenced Mr. Gulotta; not his party leaders, not state overseers, not the press. And now that he must be going, Republicans worry about how many may join him come Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Political Briefing; 
Neighborly Repartee Takes On an Edge

BYLINE:  By B. Drummond Ayres Jr. 

 BODY:
Minnesota and South Dakota share a border, and their governors, like good neighbors, talk to each other a lot. The exchanges have been mostly good-natured, but lately they have taken on an edge -- which was probably inevitable, given that few governors are more outspoken than Jesse Ventura of Minnesota, an independent, and William J. Janklow of South Dakota, a Republican. 
 It all began two weeks ago when Mr. Ventura, at a trade show in Canada, speculated that Mr. Janklow was not at the show because he was home "cutting new ads" to induce Minnesotans and Minnesota businesses to move to South Dakota. 
 Then, warming to his topic, Mr. Ventura added: "I love his ads, and I love the points he makes. The bottom-line problem is you then have to live in Sioux Falls. If that element wasn't in there, you'd be home free."
Sioux Falls, just west of Minnesota's southwest corner, has received laudatory livability reviews in recent years in several polls and business publications. Mr. Janklow immediately countered the governor, a former pro wrestler, with this smackdown: "Whoever said that sounds like a jerk."
Then last week, after a few days of quiet, Mr. Janklow went back on the offensive.
A Minnesota company had decided to expand -- but in South Dakota, he announced. He said he wanted Mr. Ventura to know "how pleased we are that another company has seen that their future in Minnesota means an investment in the people of South Dakota."
Mr. Ventura responded that the company would not stay long in South Dakota after it discovered how much higher Janklow taxes were than Ventura taxes.
Stay tuned.

HEADLINE: Control of the State Senate Hinges on a Handful of Races 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Nov. 3 

 BODY:
The campaign between James E. McGreevey and Bret D. Schundler is no longer the most interesting governor's race in New Jersey.
 With Mr. McGreevey pulling ahead in the polls heading into Tuesday's election, and Mr. Schundler sounding increasingly defeatist, the more intriguing contest suddenly is the one -- really, the 120 separate races -- that will determine who will serve as acting governor for a single week in January. 
 Control of both houses of the State Legislature hangs in the balance, and the 80-seat General Assembly is widely expected to shift to a Democratic majority, while the 40-member Senate is too close to call. Because senators take office a week before the new governor does, the new Senate president -- or, in the event of an evenly split Senate, the Assembly speaker -- would serve as acting governor until the inauguration.
More important, the new governor and the Legislature will have to face projected budget deficits of more than $2 billion, falling revenues, a troubled economy and an already burdensome debt load. And some advisers to Mr. McGreevey, thinking ahead, are now talking as if the worst thing possible would be for Democrats to sweep to victory in the governor's race and both the Assembly and the Senate.
"Mario Cuomo and George Pataki have thrived under a divided Legislature," said one Democratic lobbyist here. "It's a model that, when it works, encourages bipartisanship. But dominating both houses in a difficult economic environment is hard. You want to share credit, and blame, with both parties."
A Republican strategist made the same point more sharply: "McGreevey would like one Republican house, to take the blame for a tax increase." 
Not coincidentally, Republicans have held the Assembly and the Senate since 1991, the election that immediately followed Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax increase.
Of course, should Mr. Schundler's campaign completely nose-dive by Tuesday, giving Mr. McGreevey a victory margin of better than 15 or 20 points, even Republican operatives think his coattails could be big enough to bring the Senate along with him. That is why many Republicans were dismayed when Mr. Schundler spoke openly this week of the possibility of losing.
"That may in fact dispirit Republican partisans a little bit, and depress their vote," said a campaign consultant working for Republican candidates in both houses of the Legislature. And every Republican vote will be vital on Tuesday.
Democrats hold 15 out of 40 seats in the Senate, meaning they need a net gain of 6 to win a majority. The redrawing of the map of legislative districts this year gave the Democrats a head start. Norman M. Robertson's seat in the 34th Legislative District, which was drawn to include heavily Democratic parts of Essex County, is likely to go to Nia H. Gill, a veteran Democratic assemblywoman there. And Barbara Buono, an assemblywoman from Middlesex County, is heavily favored in the 18th District, where the incumbent Republican, Jack G. Sinagra, is retiring.
To reach a majority, Democrats would have to win at least four of these competitive seats now held by Republicans:
District 1: In Cape May and Cumberland Counties, a veteran Republican, James S. Cafiero of North Wildwood, is being challenged by William J. Hughes Jr. of Ocean City, a former federal prosecutor and the son and namesake of a popular former congressman. The district is overwhelmingly Republican, but Mr. Hughes has spent more than $600,000 on his race, and Democrats have courted the growing Latino vote in Vineland, the largest city in Cumberland County.
District 3: Raymond J. Zane, a longtime senator who switched to the Republican party in February, is being challenged by Stephen M. Sweeney, an ironworkers' union leader who is also the freeholder director of Gloucester County. Each has been attacking the other with a barrage of TV advertisements in the Philadelphia market.
District 14: In the battle for Hamilton, a town neighboring Trenton where both Senate candidates live, the incumbent Republican, Peter A. Inverso, faces a stiff challenge from the Mercer County sheriff, Samuel J. Plumeri Jr.
District 22: This seat was held by Donald T. DiFrancesco, the acting governor, who is retiring. Joseph S. Suliga, a Democratic assemblyman from Linden, is considered the favorite against the Republican nominee, Milt Campbell, a former Olympic decathlon gold medalist from Plainfield who is black, like many others in parts of the district added to it this year. But Democrats say they expect Mr. McGreevey to win so big here that Mr. Campbell's ticket-splitters will do him little good. Senator Richard J. Codey, the Democrat who stands to lead the Senate and be acting governor if his party wins control, cited internal polling showing Mr. Suliga leading Mr. Campbell by 17 percentage points.
District 38: Louis F. Kosco, the incumbent Republican in this Bergen County district, faces Joseph Coniglio, a popular civic leader who is benefiting from the addition to the district of the heavily Democratic Fort Lee and Fair Lawn.
The one Democratic seat that is seen as vulnerable to a Republican pickup is that of Senator Garry J. Furnari of Nutley, in the 36th District. His Republican challenger, John V. Kelly, is a popular assemblyman, but the district was redrawn to protect Mr. Furnari by including more Democratic parts of Bergen County.

HEADLINE: The Candidates on Major Issues in the Mayoral Race: An Overview; 
Taxes and Budgeting

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton 

 BODY:
MR. BLOOMBERG -- He has ruled out any tax increases, even in the face of steeply declining city revenues. It is too easy for citizens and companies, faced with higher taxes, to leave New York, he says. 
 But he is also skeptical about the value of tax breaks as a means of keeping companies in the city. While the city must be able to offer tax incentives to compete in the "border wars," Mr. Bloomberg says that such breaks are less important to companies than the proximity to those they do business with and access to the kind of workers they need. 
 Acknowledging that the city is facing a tough time economically and fiscally, Mr. Bloomberg says that there is not very much that can be easily cut from the city's budget. He emphasizes the need to set priorities, and to work with the city's employees to find efficiencies if they are to make more money.

MR. GREEN -- Saying that New York City faces its worst fiscal crisis since it almost went bankrupt in the 1970's, Mr. Green has pledged to raise taxes only as a last resort. Instead, he hopes to find places to save large amounts through management efficiencies, through better contracting and through collective bargaining with the municipal unions (though he does foresee raises for city workers). He has put together an advisory commission on the budget, including the current city comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, and an advisory committee on business issues led by the former treasury secretary Robert E. Rubin.
In terms of economic development, Mr. Green has suggested focusing on industries and what they need to remain in the city, rather than handing out tax breaks and other incentives to individual companies. Leslie Eaton

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2; Column 1; Style and Entertaining Magazine; Pg. 28

LENGTH: 1814 words

HEADLINE: THE AMERICAN WAY; 
Mayo With A Slice Of Life

BYLINE:  By Liz Smith; Liz Smith is the author of "Natural Blonde," a memoir.

 BODY:
I was delivered out of Texas to Manhattan in the early 1950's, having escaped what I call American survival cooking -- barbecued or fried haunch of whatever, corn smoldering in its own husks, grain mashed into a flat fried cake, vitaminless vegetables cooked senseless and tables always decorated with red and yellow condiment bottles.
 Well, the next thing I knew, I was in Le Pavillon at 57th and Park, being cautioned by the owner and creator, Henri Soule, on how to eat caviar properly. With a different spoon for each tin he opened, Soule and I would nibble and taste. "Never, never, dear girl, never add anything to caviar," he'd say. In those days, Soule, the greatest restaurateur the country has ever known, would send me cases of a red wine he particularly favored. No one I knew had ever heard of Chateau Petrus. It was his enthusiasm. I unwittingly opened it like soda pop and served it with everything from chicken-fried steak to chili. (I might be rich today if only I'd put Soule's gifts away in a damp, cool place.) 
 I was a junior society reporter, and an apprenticeship with Soule was a gift from my boss, Igor Cassini, then Hearst's Cholly Knickerbocker. The first time we went to Pavillon, he cautioned: "Mr. Soule is very kindhearted, but he doesn't suffer fools gladly. He won't seat a lady at the table if she arrives alone. She must wait in the foyer no matter how much she needs a drink. He won't serve women in trousers -- not even Hepburn or Dietrich."
Back then, I occasionally yearned for what Tom Wolfe has called "the glories of boiling lard." In other words: Southern cooking, which I still love. But, no, I was in another universe of comfort food -- haute cuisine.
I ate the remarkable souffles at Voisin, where one day the actress Elaine Stritch and I celebrated our Feb. 2 birthdays. As she sat down, looking voguishly smart, Elaine said: "Oh, Lizzie, Noel Coward is coming. He's trying to entice me into 'Sail Away' in London, but I don't want to go." When the urbane master himself arrived, he was polite but cool. He gifted Elaine with a monogrammed passport case and to me said, "And you, young woman, will you please shut up!" (I did. And Elaine did go to London.)
I often went to Pearl's, a Chinese restaurant unlike any other. It had a Spartan decor by the great costumer Irene Sharaff, and it had Pearl herself, who treated Bill Paley, Woody Allen and Lauren Bacall the same way she treated us nobodies. Her yuk sung and lemon chicken were true Cantonese comfort foods, often imitated but never rivaled. And it was a far cry from eating out of cartons in "The Godfather."
I began to enjoy an ambience I'd never dreamed of -- perfect, stinging ice-cold martinis and wine that had to "breathe."
I learned to eat orecchiette, a pasta that looks like ears, at the now defunct Romeo Salta, and I discovered that while the "spaghetti red" my mother lashed together was tasty, spaghetti called pasta was better. I found that Le Veau d'Or served the best sole amandine in the world. At the Colony restaurant, I struck up a friendship with a waiter from Montecatini Terme, and thus I rode in on the wave that today is Le Cirque, as Sirio Maccioni later made his mark in 90's New York. 
I lived through the 60's, when theme eateries thrived. These experiences involved one place called the Forum of the 12 Caesars, where the waiters wore togas and served wild boar. I recall dining at the Tower Suite atop the Time-Life Building. The staff formally introduced themselves. The gent I was with, an Anglophile named Trumball Barton, sprang up after hearing "I'm John, your butler," and said, "And I'm Mr. Barton, your customer, so no more personal remarks, if you don't mind."
When we were given a mysterious first course, a small crab on toast, another guest, the comedian Kaye Ballard, looked at it and then hit it with her fist -- mashing it flat. "I'll never wash," Kaye said. I don't think we ever went back to the Tower Suite, where the between-course sherbet was the only thing as fascinating as the view. 
And when I went to Maxwell's Plum as a guest of Woody Allen's, I always ordered comfort food -- shepherd's pie in the Warner LeRoy manner.
These adventures kept me amused. I didn't learn how to prepare cuisine; I was too busy eating out. This was a new world, where baby veggies in strange combinations were described by Truman Capote as the vegetables of the rich. Taken to France on a tour by Mumm, I ate in a cafe near Paris, where the dessert included a hard-boiled egg covered in chocolate. I came to like delicate sauces and things blanched and buttered to perfection, eggs beaten and whipped to perfection. But frequently, haute cuisine was too haute for hicks.
Privately, I was still serving Southern comfort in my apartment. Batches of chili and fried chicken, I discovered, made me popular with the very people I was trying so hard to impress -- Helen Gurley Brown and her husband, David Brown, Gloria Steinem, Tom Wolfe, Gloria Vanderbilt, Donald Brooks, Geraldine Stutz, Mica and Ahmet Ertegun, Tommy Thompson, Nancy Friday, Gael Greene, Nan and Gay Talese.
Will Rogers once quoted a friend as saying, "I et for two hours and didn't recognize a thing I et, except an olive." My gang "et and et," as well. We ate high on the hog and low on the calf. We ate our way through the Eisenhower recession, the Cuban missile crisis, Vietnam, the assassinations of J.F.K., R.F.K. and Martin Luther King Jr., through Watergate, the Persian Gulf War and the Clinton crisis. Recently a journalist friend was on the street, covering the World Trade Center disaster. She ordered a sandwich, saying: "Don't bring me any fat-free mayonnaise. If the world is coming to an end, I want the real thing."
When I became a permanent guest of Lee Bailey in the early Hamptons, he was not yet the Clarkson Potter cookbook king writing about food. We made our social-climbing mark in Bridgehampton by feeding people. Lee constantly experimented. He would make something I adored, like chicken cooked with fresh peaches, and then never repeat it. His mantra was "homemade mayonnaise," which, frankly, I considered a waste of time. But "murder by mayonnaise" became our mantra. We talked more about food than drugs and sex.
I never attained the finesse of Lee's other devotees, who combined super careers and being perfect cooks and hostesses. I just stuck to my elemental favorites -- fried chicken in the classic mode. (All you need is a chicken, salt, pepper, flour and a paper bag to shake it in before depositing it in hot grease. "Do you cover chicken when you fry it, Mama?" I asked. "You can," she'd say, "but it won't make much difference.") This very chicken, plus my unusual standby -- chicken- or country-fried steak and cream gravy -- made me very unpopular with women who were dieting. But Lee opined, "Men love it!" Lee would sometimes hand over the main course to me while he enhanced the trimmings with taste and imagination. I recall once broiling 20 perfect T-bone steaks for 20 people, and Lee frothed up the rest. We were a big hit, proving the director Joel Schumacher's thesis that people just want to be fed. "Put some Cheese Whiz on a cracker on the windowsill, and you'll draw a crowd!" he'd laugh.
Lee Bailey was a father figure to my crowd, but he'd let someone else "do it" sometimes. The theater press agent Diane Judge constructed one of our favorite meals. Her New England Boiled Dinner became a perennial winner, as it could be held if the evening became too raucous.
I opened this dialectic on comfort food high and low with a memory of the late, great Henri Soule, who came here from France during the 1939 World's Fair and changed American food history. In his marvelous book "Dining at the Pavillon," Joseph Wechsberg tells the story of how he and Soule drove back from Long Island after Soule had established a restaurant, the Hedges, in East Hampton. Soule instructed the driver to stop at a roadside stand. "Let's get out and have a couple of hot dogs -- they're delicious here!"
I learned a lot about comfort from Henri Soule. One weekend the elegant DuPont-wed Francis -- yes, with an "i" -- Carpenter and her friend Shirley Maytag sailed into Sag Harbor. "We must go to the Hedges," Francis said, and so they set out for East Hampton. Arriving, Francis was stunned to see only a few cars. The dining room was all set up but empty. "Tell Mr. Soule that Mrs. Carpenter is here for lunch," Francis said to a passing busboy. Soon, Soule appeared in a bloody apron wiping his hands. Apologizing that he'd been butchering, he was charm itself, seating the ladies and asking what they'd like. "Whatever you'd like us to have," responded the gracious Francis. To Mrs. Maytag, she whispered: "Poor Henri. He has no customers."
Soule served them a fine lunch accompanied by an excellent white Bordeaux. When Francis asked for the check. "Oh, madam," Soule said, bowing. "There is no check. For you see, there is no lunch at the Hedges!"
So, who says there's no free lunch? If you're lucky, you eat high, and you eat low. 

Diane Judge's
new england Boiled Dinner

2 stalks celery, chopped
1 onion, quartered
1 bay leaf
1 handful mixed fresh herbs (sage, thyme and parsley) palm full of herbes de Provence
1 garlic clove, peeled and crushed
1 teaspoon peppercorns
3 boneless smoked shoulder butt hams (about 2 pounds each), rinsed
12 large carrots, peeled and cut into 2-inch pieces
2 large turnips, peeled and quartered
12 medium russet potatoes, peeled and halved
2 parsnips, peeled and cut into 2-inch pieces
24 pearl onions, blanched, rinsed and peeled
1/4 pound fresh green beans, trimmed
2 large cabbages, trimmed and quartered.
1. Combine 3 gallons water with the celery, onion, bay leaf, herbs, garlic and peppercorns in a 4- to 5-gallon pot and heat to boiling over medium heat. Simmer for 15 minutes. Add the hams, cover and simmer for 1 hour.
2. While the hams cook, prepare the vegetables: tie up the carrots and turnips in a piece of cheesecloth. Divide the potatoes and parsnips in half and tie up each bundle in a piece of cheesecloth. Tie up the pearl onions and beans in a piece of cheesecloth. Divide the cabbage wedges into 2 pieces of cheesecloth and tie up.
3. Remove the hams to a platter and keep warm. 
4. Add the carrot-and-turnip bundle to the simmering ham water; cover and simmer for 10 minutes. Add the potato and parsnip bundles; cover and simmer for 10 minutes. Add the onion and bean bundle; cover and simmer for 10 minutes. Add the cabbage bundle; cover and steam for 10 minutes. 
5. Using tongs, lift each bundle out and test for doneness. Cut the vegetable bundles and arrange the vegetables in bowls. Slice the ham thickly. Spoon cooking water over the vegetables and ham. Serve with mustard, horseradish, bread and applesauce.
Yield: 8 servings.
Liz Smith suggests you enjoy this with a bottle of Chateau Petrus. Or a Coca-Cola.

SECTION: Section 7; Column 1; Book Review Desk; Pg. 39

LENGTH: 1097 words

HEADLINE: The Close Reader; 
Barbarians Inside the Gates

BYLINE:  By Judith Shulevitz 

 BODY:
Now is not the moment to glorify violence. On the other hand, when Martin Scorsese puts off the release of a long-awaited new movie, you can't help dwelling for a moment on the forbidden spectacle implied by such self-censorship. A clue to "Gangs of New York," a film Scorsese has been working on intermittently since the mid-1970's, is the book it's based on -- Herbert Asbury's 1927 cult classic, "The Gangs of New York: An Informal History of the Underworld," which has just been reissued in paperback with a foreword adapted from a story by Jorge Luis Borges. 
 The book itself is hard to describe, and is better understood for what it isn't than for what it is. To begin with, "The Gangs of New York," a chronology of gangs who terrorized the city from its post-Revolutionary days through the early 20th century, is not a work of liberal reform in the spirit, say, of Jacob A. Riis, the social reformer who wrote "How the Other Half Lives." Asbury expresses neither shock nor dismay at the conditions that spawned the gangs, although he describes the city's squalor clearly and treats political corruption as part of the general criminality of the era. Nor does Asbury formulate scientific hypotheses about the causes of juvenile delinquency, a task that absorbed the fledgling discipline of sociology in his day. As he says in his introduction, "This book is not a sociological treatise, and makes no pretense of offering solutions for the social, economic and criminological problems presented by the gangs." 
 "The Gangs of New York" isn't respectable history, either. For years academic historians have quarreled with Asbury's representation of a 19th-century New York kept in a constant state of anarchy by thuggery, but their own methods aren't exactly confidence-inspiring -- they mostly rely on police reports, whereas Asbury paints a picture of a police force whose leaders were gangsters themselves. The latest historian to take on Asbury is Tyler Anbinder, author of "Five Points: The 19th-Century New York City Neighborhood That Invented Tap Dance, Stole Elections, and Became the World's Most Notorious Slum." A passionate defender of the hard-working poor, Anbinder accuses Asbury of seeing Five Points, a downtown neighborhood that was arguably the worst slum in New York history, through eyes prejudiced against its Irish newcomers. But the older book captured the feel of desperate poverty better than Anbinder's bland social historian's prose, even if Asbury got a few details wrong. And Asbury comes off as positively multicultural when you compare him with his peers and immediate predecessors, like Riis, who was openly revolted by what he perceived as greedy Jews, opium-peddling Chinese and other unwashed hordes who had floated up to America's shores.
What "The Gangs of New York" is, really, is literature, a string of unsentimentally observed, mildly ironic, only quasi-nonfictional stories about men who mythologized themselves as heroes, though the world rightly considered them scum. Critics have accused Asbury of failing to see through the criminals' braggadocio, but that misses the point. The book is the modern equivalent of an ancient epic, filled with tales of battles fought by club-wielding giants, as well as with many endless genealogies. 
Early on there were the Bowery and Five Points gangs -- the Bowery Boys and the Dead Rabbits, locked in undying enmity. The Dead Rabbits begat the Plug Uglies, named after the stiff woolen helmets they wore smashed down on their heads; the Shirt Tails, who always left their shirts untucked; and the Chichesters. The Bowery Boys (or B'hoys) begat the Mighty Mose, the Paul Bunyan of New York. This legendary figure was reputed to have been eight feet tall and to have lifted horse-drawn carriages with his bare hands and to have rescued a foundering ship by blowing smoke rings into its sails. 
Along the wharves, river pirates preyed on sailors, and they roamed the Hudson in rowboats, looting and pillaging as far up as Westchester and beyond. These became the Daybreak Boys, so called because they operated at dawn, and also yielded Albert E. Hicks, a gangster who after being shanghaied onto a sloop killed the captain and crew with an ax, scurried ashore and was caught with the captain's effects on his person. He confessed, became a celebrity and was hanged on Bedloe's Island in an execution carried out with great fanfare and watched by an estimated 10,000 people, including many politicians. Later came the statesmen of Tammany Hall who, Asbury says, ran New York for the benefit of themselves and other gangsters, with sops thrown to the poor. And on it went, against a shifting, squabbling ethnic background that evolved from Irish to anti-Irish Americans of English descent to Chinese to Jewish to Italian, with the criminal organizations becoming ever more professional and the violence more lethal.
Like all good literature, "The Gangs of New York" generated more literature. Luc Sante's "Low Life," a history of the New York underworld, owes a great debt to Asbury, as much in its bemused style as in content. Borges based his story "Monk Eastman, Purveyor of Iniquities" on a character he found in Asbury's book. Eastman, a misshapen Jewish thug and ward boss with a deep tenderness for birds and cats, at one time commanded more than 1,200 followers. "The story of the New York gangs," Borges wrote, "possesses all the confusion and cruelty of barbarian cosmologies, and much of their gigantism and ineptitude." 
After a lifetime of crime and imprisonment, Eastman redeemed himself on the battlefields of World War I. But Borges made Eastman his protagonist probably not because he reformed, but because he relapsed. Honored by the governor of New York for his wartime heroism, Eastman died shortly thereafter on the streets of New York, murdered, as it turned out, by his partner in bootlegging and drug dealing. The monsters who prowled historic New York weren't easy to tame -- that's why we like to read about them so much. Like the bank robbers and cattle rustlers of the West, they're part of American mythology. Historians may dispute that the gangs were ever as brutal or Tammany Hall as venal as people like Asbury made them out to be, but if our artists had limited themselves to straight history, Francis Ford Coppola might never have made his "Godfather" trilogy, or Sergio Leone "Once Upon a Time in America." As Scorsese said of the character in his movie last year: "These were warriors, and their gods were war gods. I'm dealing with making a film about barbarians."

SUBJECT: BOOK REVIEWS (90%); MOVIE REVIEWS (90%); HISTORY (89%); GANGS (89%); SLUM DWELLINGS (89%); HUMANITIES & SOCIAL SCIENCE (89%); SOCIOLOGY (87%); CENSORSHIP (78%); CHRONOLOGIES (77%); LITERATURE (76%); WRITERS (76%); CORRUPTION (75%); PAPERBACK PUBLISHING (73%); POLICE FORCES (73%); LIBERALISM (67%); POVERTY & HOMELESSNESS (64%); POLITICAL CORRUPTION (51%) SOCIAL CONDITIONS AND TRENDS; GANGS; BOOKS AND LITERATURE; MOTION PICTURES 

PERSON: ASBURY, HERBERT; SCORSESE, MARTIN; SHULEVITZ, JUDITH 

GEOGRAPHIC: NEW YORK, NY, USA (92%) NEW YORK, USA (92%) UNITED STATES (92%) NEW YORK CITY

HEADLINE: Ancien Regime 

BYLINE:  By Richard Vinen; Richard Vinen is the author of "A History in Fragments: Europe in the 20th Century."

 BODY:
 THE CULT OF THE NATION OF FRANCE
Inventing Nationalism,
1680-1800.
By David A. Bell
304 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
Harvard University Press. $49.95.
 "THIS people has become a worshiper of its fatherland, without ever having known, before the Revolution, what a fatherland was." So Giacomo Casanova wrote in 1797, expressing the common view that the explosion of French patriotic fervor that followed the Revolution of 1789 was something quite new. In "The Cult of the Nation of France," David A. Bell takes issue, arguing that the concepts of nation and fatherland had been important in France before then. 
At the center of Bell's subtle and intricate argument is religion. Religion, he suggests, was changing in the 18th century. And with men less likely to see God as an interventionist presence in their daily lives and more likely to stress God's distant, inscrutable quality, space was opened up for an autonomous realm of human action, described by a series of interconnected words: society, public opinion, civilization, fatherland and nation. One reflection of this sense of the autonomy was the rules change, in 1758, in the Academie Francaise's eloquence competitions: orators previously required to give speeches on subjects of religious devotion were now asked to deliver eulogies of "great men of the nation." 
Bell isn't arguing that patriotism remained static throughout the 18th century. Before 1789, it was a matter for the elite. (As Voltaire remarked, "The spirit of the nation always resides in the small number who put a large number to work.") The revolutionaries, Bell notes, tried to inculcate a sense of the nation into all men. Their missionary zeal, he suggests, was provoked both by a reaction against the influence of the Roman Catholic Church and by a propensity to imitate the church's techniques. Patriotism also became sterner with the Revolution, hinging on men's (and the emphasis on masculinity was important) ability to conquer their nature. The most chilling illustration of such patriotic feeling is David's 1789 painting of Brutus receiving the bodies of his sons, whom he himself has ordered to be executed for treason. Brutus sits apparently unmoved by the deed his patriotic feelings have provoked as his wife and daughters weep inconsolably. 
Bell winds up with a glance at contemporary France and a sideswipe at the training ground of the French intellectual elite, the Ecole Normale Superieure in the Rue d'Ulm, which he sees as a school for missionaries of the republic and believes to have been marginalized by the hegemony of American academia. This is odd. Anyone who examines the influence that Derrida, Foucault and Bourdieu have had on American universities might conclude that it is the Ecole Normale Superieure that has conquered America rather than vice versa. Indeed, Bell's own approach is characteristic of the Rue d'Ulm. (Nothing is more ulmien than his failure to mention the Ecole Normale at St. Cloud, which, as a trainer of primary schoolteachers, was less prestigious but probably more influential than its sister institution in Paris.) 
Like all good normaliens, as well as fashion-conscious American intellectuals, Bell is interested in ideas, culture and language, and he is rather dismissive of the idea that nationalism might be explained with reference to social, economic and technological change. But having deployed such sophisticated arguments to explain the construction of French nationalism, Bell seems to take it for granted that the decline of French national identity is a natural process. Will France, he asks, simply "dissolve into Europe, cyberspace and the global marketplace?" But cyberspace and the global marketplace are not just products of nature. The founders of what has become the European Union were aware that Europe had to be created by an act of political will; anyone interested in the links between Catholicism and nation-building would do well to examine the influence of Christian Democrats in forging postwar European integration.
It is axiomatic that the next mayor's central task will be rebuilding. But rebuilding what? If it is merely office space, then he may not even equal Giuliani, during whose tenure millions of square feet of commercial space have gone up in Times Square alone. And mayors, in any case, don't build office buildings; developers do. But mayors do guide the process of development through decisions about zoning, land use, subsidies, capital spending and so on. Planning, to use the collective term for this process, is a terribly important and generally tedious subject that experts usually care about much more than politicians do -- except when it comes time to cut the ribbon. But the next mayor will have to think about planning in the largest sense. He will have an opportunity to reshape the physical city as few mayors before him have.
The first issue will be ensuring that businesses and people return to Lower Manhattan. At a recent forum on rebuilding downtown, virtually all the panelists agreed that the single most important thing the city could do right now is to get money out of the federal government as fast as possible and into the hands of residents and small businesses. There are all sorts of mechanisms to accomplish this. The Giuliani administration is proposing to give businesses a $5,000 cash bonus for every employee they hire. Green had suggested a federal "residential tax credit" to induce jittery residents to return. Michael Bloomberg proposes providing tax incentives to landlords to lower rents for small businesses. There is also a consensus that funds must be used right away to begin rebuilding collapsed subway stations and to provide express bus service and perhaps ferry service to the area.
The short-term issues are, if not easy, at least straightforward; it is the long-term issues that are really thorny. Thousands of workers in the finance industry have been relocated from downtown Manhattan to New Jersey or Connecticut. Tax incentives and boosterism may not be enough to get them to return. And if some firms stay away, others may conclude that New York isn't so indispensable after all. And this raises a question that New York's mayors have not had to ask before: why should the financial industry be so heavily concentrated in New York, particularly in Lower Manhattan? The reason no one had to ask this question before is that New York City has been the financial capital of the country at least since the 1830's, when, as Mike Wallace, a co-author of "Gotham," an encyclopedic history of New York, points out, the demise of the Second Bank of the United States in Philadelphia left New York as the center of the national banking system and the source of capital for the expanding system of canals and railroads. New York's dominance is, as another urban scholar, Robert Fitch, puts it, "path dependent": it is the center because it has always been the center. 
The problem is not precisely that the finance industry will leave Lower Manhattan. The industry has been moving to Midtown for the last quarter-century, and few of the major investment banks still have their headquarters downtown. The issue is, first, whether the many brokerage and other firms that were quartered downtown will return there, and second, whether the big financial and other concerns that are located outside of downtown will remain in New York. 
Bloomberg, who ought to know about such things, says that the corporate headquarters are here to stay, no matter what threats their C.E.O.'s make in the hope of extorting tax breaks from the city. "You want to be where your customers are, where your suppliers are, where your competitors are, and the media that covers you," he says. The danger is rather that a new fear of keeping all employees in one building will encourage firms to move back-office and other functions to cheaper, and at least safer-feeling, regions beyond New York.
The solution may lie in the development of less-expensive commercial districts within the city. A body convened by Schumer and known as the Group of 35 has suggested the construction of 50 million square feet of office space in new "central business districts" in downtown Brooklyn, Long Island City and the far West Side of Manhattan. Green says that he was touting the virtues of downtown Brooklyn well before Schumer came along. Oddly enough, during the runoff Green savaged Ferrer for proposing to "disperse" the finance industry, and since scarcely anyone understood the issue, he was never called on it. 
But the conscious creation of new downtowns is not an expensive solution, since developers would need massive subsidies to build in marginal areas. Moreover, it is a real-estate solution to a problem perhaps best understood not solely in real-estate terms. Hugh O'Neill, the president of Appleseed, a New York-based economic development consulting firm, says: "What makes New York City a center of world finance is a concentration of talented people and an enormous base of shared knowledge, the socialized knowledge of global finance and the innovative financial culture. None of that is embodied in any particular building." 
It is more important, O'Neill argues, to think about the special character and the amenities that attract those people to New York than to replace the lost office space or to hand out subsidies to real-estate developers or corporate tenants. This is especially true in the case of Lower Manhattan. Though Wall Street is still dominated by finance and anchored by such institutions as the Stock Exchange, the Depository Trust Company and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, the whole area of Lower Manhattan has been revitalized by Internet firms, nonprofits, health care companies and other vibrant organizations whose employees typically live in the neighborhood, and this trend seems almost certain to continue despite the failure of so many of the dot-coms. In a recent study issued by the Center for an Urban Future, Joel Kotkin, an authority on technology and urban affairs, writes that small, high-tech firms are helping to reshape Lower Manhattan. And while the "old economy" demands "ready access to materials or convenience to the marketplace," the new one cares more about "quality of life and access to educated workers."
After initial patriotic vows to rebuild every square foot of damaged commercial real estate, it is now becoming clear that the key to revitalizing Lower Manhattan lies elsewhere. Development, as Green put it in a recent speech, "means not just rebuilding office buildings but building parks and open space, cultural institutions, restaurants, retail and housing." Carl Weisbrod, the president of the Alliance for Downtown New York, a business improvement district, says that the city and state must not only rebuild the subways and the PATH train from New Jersey but also connect the two to create a seamless commute and extend the PATH trains in Lower Manhattan to the Long Island Railroad to permit a relatively uninterrupted trip from New Jersey to Brooklyn and ultimately to J.F.K. Weisbrod argues that Lower Manhattan's two great advantages are the subway system and the waterfront. If the city focuses on those two resources, he says, "we have an opportunity to make downtown spectacular and absolutely breathtaking." All of these ambitious plans depend on federal money; if the Bush administration doesn't come through with more aid, Lower Manhattan will have to be rebuilt on the cheap.
Green and Bloomberg offer two very different models of downtown reconstruction. Green understands it as a grand civic project, on the order of the redevelopment of Times Square. "We will," he said recently, "marshal the talent and creativity of the New York City planning and design world -- through a competition -- to get the best and most creative ideas and to create a bold design for a better downtown, a downtown of the future that can be a model for the nation and the world." Green has proposed an Economic Reconstruction Authority, which would bring together representatives of state and local government, the public and private sectors and management and labor. 
Bloomberg is more focused on removing impediments from the private sector. "The money that's going to rebuild is all private money," he says. "So what's this agency going to do: tell private enterprise what they can do with their money?" Bloomberg also argues that the whole debate over keeping the finance industry in Lower Manhattan is beside the point. The big firms are already gone, he points out. "What you have to do is look for other industries -- biotech, media, fashion. And that's what a private developer will do." 
Crises either make mayors or destroy them. James J. Walker -- Beau James -- was a charming gadabout and dandy in the Roaring Twenties but then had the misfortune to be re-elected in 1929. Walker was forced to resign in disgrace in 1932: "a shallow, fun-loving politician in the most trying times in the city's modern history," in the epitaph of Thomas Kessner, the biographer of Fiorello LaGuardia. Abe Beame, an ancient veteran of the Democratic clubhouse, was elected in 1973 under the motto "he knows the buck" and was promptly overwhelmed by the city's fiscal crisis. David Dinkins took office in 1990 as a "healer" and was battered by racial psychodramas. 
LaGuardia was our first great crisis mayor. We think of LaGuardia today as the feisty character who read the Sunday funnies on the radio, but in fact, as Kessner makes plain in his biography, "Fiorello H. LaGuardia and the Making of Modern New York," LaGuardia was a remorseless, and frequently apoplectic, character who seized control of the city from a corrupt and worn-out Tammany Hall. LaGuardia was Giuliani's hero, and in fact there are striking parallels between the two men's administrations. What "the machine" was for LaGuardia, urban liberalism was for Giuliani: an entrenched foe to be uprooted through tireless combat. 
Both men used a fiscal crisis to assert control over city government. Gov. Herbert Lehman was so outraged over the emergency authority LaGuardia sought when he first took office that he accused the mayor, not unfairly, of demanding "dictatorial powers." In Giuliani's case, when the Health and Hospitals Corporation balked at his plan to reorganize the city's hospitals, the mayor said, "It was constituted by the city government; it could be reconstituted."
This is, traditionally, what it means to be a big mayor in New York. The reformers, as Vincent Cannato, the author of a recent biography of John Lindsay, says, "grab the city by the lapels and shake it." They confront their way to authority. But the next mayor will not be able to lash out at his foes as Giuliani and LaGuardia did, because he will have no Tammany, no entrenched liberalism to smite: the author of the city's woes is very far away, and only the United States military can smite him. He will not be able to seize the levers of power in the name of reform. And yet, as Cannato says, "the next mayor is either going to step up to the plate and be a big figure, or he'll be swallowed up by events" as Beame or Walker were. Cannato adds that he is "not terribly optimistic" about the next mayor's prospects. 
The most crucial aspect of the next mayor's job will be to preserve the tenuous solidarity the city now enjoys and turn it to practical use. This is in part a matter of policy. He will have to make public safety a paramount issue. He will have to remember that for many, if not most, voters, issues like housing or schools are far more pressing than cleaning up Lower Manhattan. He will have to found an ethic of shared sacrifice on real sacrifices by everyone.
At the same time, the mayoralty is a profoundly theatrical and intensely symbolic job -- and especially so at moments of crisis. When Fiorello fought fires and flattened recalcitrant city workers, it was just the kind of performance New Yorkers needed to restore their faith in government. The single greatest episode of John Lindsay's mayoralty was a coup de theatre -- his walk through Harlem in the midst of an incipient riot, his great shock of hair rising above the crowd like some WASPy banner. Giuliani has radiated hope and optimism in the midst of great suffering and thus has helped all those around him to control their fears, even if they can't dismiss them. The next mayor must, in effect, find a scaled-down, postwar version of the mayor's Churchillian style.
You can talk all you want about infrastructure and tax credits and so on, but the central fact of New York City right now is that people are living in fear. Their fears are rational and irrational; they involve airplanes and anthrax and smallpox and bombs in shopping bags -- whatever. And though in normal times New Yorkers might scoff at the idea of seeking reassurance from a mayor, no one is scoffing now. Perhaps nothing bad will happen from here on in, and the fears will subside. But if they don't, the mayor will still matter in a way he has rarely mattered before. And this is true not only in a broad, almost spiritual sense but also in regard to the decisions people make. As Eugene Keilin says: "The most effective retention policy is if people either feel secure or no less secure than they did before. And it will be done through force of personality rather than any specific issue." 
I was struck, as I spoke to academics and experts and voters around the city, that some people were making the existential choice of hope and others the equally personal and irreducible choice of fear, or at least profound gloom. And sometimes it was the people who had felt the most suffering who were most insistently optimistic. About a week or so after the disaster, I called Rosemary Scanlon, the former chief economist for the Port Authority. Scanlon had lost friends and colleagues in the collapse of the World Trade Center, and she was almost too upset to speak. But when I asked whether she thought Lower Manhattan would be permanently damaged, she pointed out that the Nazis had as a matter of conscious policy tried to obliterate the City, London's financial center, and that after the war the British had, with equal resolution, rebuilt it "block after block after block." And then she added that the fears of permanent dispersal that followed the 1993 bombing of the trade center proved to be groundless. And as if that weren't enough, she pointed out that air travel, after collapsing in the aftermath of the gulf war, returned to normal within a year, even in the midst of a recession.
A moment when people are hesitating between hope and fear, a moment when a moral account must be drawn down -- this is, quintessentially, the leadership moment. And New Yorkers can only hope that destiny has, in fact, chosen the right man for the moment or, better, that that man will become, through the same mysterious alchemy that produced the Mayor Giuliani we all see today, the one that the moment requires.

 CORRECTION:
The review on Page 24 of the Book Review today misstates a word in the book title. It is "The Cult of the Nation in France," not "of France." 
An article on Page 36 of The Times Magazine today about the prospects for New York City under its next mayor includes an outdated reference to pre-election polls. In a survey completed by The Times on Thursday, after the magazine had gone to press, Michael Bloomberg, who trailed Mark Green considerably in previous polls, closed the gap to five percentage points.

HEADLINE: Travel Advisory: Correspondent's Report; 
Washington Makes A Patriotic Pitch

BYLINE:  By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
FIRST there was the terrorist strike on the Pentagon. Then there was the anthrax attack on the Senate. Threats of new terrorism mean that tours of the White House and the F.B.I. have been shut down indefinitely. The city's close-in airport, Reagan National, has only limited operations.
 So what are the capital's beleaguered tourism officials to do? Confronting the worst tourism downturn in the city's modern history, their guess is that the best way to lure visitors back to Washington -- and perhaps the only way, for now -- is by appealing to their patriotism. 
 "In the spirit of national unity, we encourage our fellow Americans to join us in Washington, D.C., as we rally behind a timely message of patriotism," Mayor Anthony A. Williams says in a new statement that welcomes visitors to the city's tourism Web site, www.washington.org.
Tourism officials in neighboring Virginia, which draws many travelers who visit Washington first, have talked of temporarily dropping their "Virginia is for Lovers" advertising slogan in favor of "Virginia is for Patriots."
The events of Sept. 11 and everything that has followed are threatening to devastate the city's economy, with 24,000 jobs projected to disappear by next spring.
The hospitality industry is the city's second largest employer -- only the federal government is bigger -- and half of the job cuts are expected to take place in hotels and restaurants. Already, half of the members of the local hotel and restaurant employees union are out of work.
The hotel occupancy rate is normally 80 percent at this time of year; in mid-October, it was closer to 30 percent.
City leaders hope the situation will improve as federal aviation officials allow more flights to return to Reagan National, which was shut for three weeks after Sept. 11 because of fear that its proximity to the White House and every other major government building would make it a tempting target in a second wave of strikes.
In early October, the government allowed service to resume from Reagan to eight destinations, including New York, Chicago and Dallas. On Oct. 26, service was resumed to an additional 18 cities, including Philadelphia and Houston.
But the new security rules imposed by the Federal Aviation Administration on passengers flying into the airport remain strict, jarringly so. At O'Hare and Dallas-Fort Worth airports, security areas have been set aside for flights into Reagan airport, with passengers subjected to an extra search, including a frisking with an electronic wand.
Passengers on flights into Reagan are barred from standing up, even to use the lavatory, in the final 30 minutes of any flight, an effort to make it that much harder for someone to try to charge the cockpit. "If you violate this rule and stand up, I am required to turn this plane around," an American Airlines pilot warned passengers on a flight from Chicago two weeks ago. "Nobody is joking about this."
In the first weeks after Sept. 11, the city's leaders repeatedly tried to reassure tourists that the capital was safe, arguing that no city in the country was being more tightly guarded as a result of the terrorist attacks.
But their assurances became less reassuring after the anthrax attacks, and after Mayor Williams said in Congressional testimony on Oct. 12 that the city was "home to perhaps the greatest targets for terrorist activity in America" and therefore needed help to pay for new security measures.
For travelers willing to put aside their anxieties, there may never be a better time to visit Washington, especially for visitors who like to have tourist sites to themselves.
While tours of many public buildings have been suspended, the city's fabled museums are open, albeit with much tightened security and with many fewer visitors than normal. The Mall is uncrowded and quiet.
Many of the city's most luxurious hotels are offering deeply discounted rates. The Swissotel at the Watergate, which borders Georgetown, has splendid views of the Potomac, and normally sells rooms at more than $300 a night, has been offering weekend rates of $125. The new Hilton Garden Inn, only three blocks from the White House, has weekend rates of $79 a night, half its regular rate. As is true throughout the country, there are heavily discounted air fares to match.
"It's a great time to be a tourist in Washington," said Bill Hanbury, president of the Washington Convention and Tourism Corporation. "You can walk straight into the Smithsonian or the Holocaust Museum without any lines. You can get a seat to any play."
"We want people to come back to their nation's capital and to touch and feel the symbols that reflect on American democracy," he said, adding that a visit now is "absolutely patriotic."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Mall, like much of tourist Washington, is hardly crowded. (Marty Katz)

SECTION: Section 6; Column 3; Magazine Desk; Pg. 11

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 11-4-01; 
United Nations

BYLINE:  By Andrew Sullivan; Andrew Sullivan is a contributing writer for the magazine.

 BODY:
In crises, some things clarify. I grew up for 20 years in Britain, and I'm now closing in on 20 years of adulthood in the United States. It's funny how feelings of identity arc in such a life. I remember the first time I got a lump in my throat singing "The Star-Spangled Banner," on July 4 about 10 years ago. It took me completely by surprise. My attachment to my new country had taken shape and form without my even knowing it, until I found myself tearing up in a routine ritual of patriotism. It wasn't that I had left my love of homeland behind. But it was now refracted through the prism of my new love -- a love that is foolish to inspect because it belongs somewhere in the heart where reason doesn't follow. 
 And then, in the aftermath of Sept. 11, another surprise. As friends and family from the U.K. finally penetrated the tangled phone system, I found out that they, too, were almost as grief stricken as I was. "What can we do for you?" was one question I heard over and over again, as if ordinary Brits could do anything for me or anyone else in such a case. But the feeling was intensely serious. It was almost as if it had happened to them, as if a vicarious American patriotism had crossed the Atlantic. Days later, all of Britain stood still to mark a moment of silence for a tragedy thousands of miles away. 
 My own first moment of silence blurred nationalisms as well. It was at a memorial service for an acquaintance of mine from Provincetown, where I spend my summers. Graham Berkeley was a Brit, a violinist, a business professional, a big, tattooed bodybuilder, who'd been on the flight from Boston that crashed into the World Trade Center's south tower. Like me, he was a transplant for many years in America and loved the place with a passion. A bunch of us gathered around some candles and memorabilia on the farthest part of Herring Cove beach, the sun setting over Cape Cod Bay, told stories and wiped away tears. And by the side of us were two large flags impaled in the sand, Old Glory and the Union Jack. In the dusk, they intertwined until the reds, whites and blues seemed almost indistinguishable.
Sentimental? Surely. Irrelevant? Surely not. When the queen ordered the band to play "The Star-Spangled Banner" at the Changing of the Guard at Buckingham Palace for the first time in history, I doubt I was the only one watching through tears. When Tony Blair stood in Congress as President Bush gave his memorable tribute to America's truest friend, the hair stood up on the back of my neck. And as the news came through that British special forces were among the first soldiers to foray into Afghanistan, alongside Americans, it seemed simply fitting.
Tony Blair's role in all this has, of course, been central. Blair has not only been the key rhetorician of the war against terrorism; he has also become almost a second secretary of state of the United States. He has shuttled from Pakistan to Oman and Egypt, defending American policy, patching the leaky coalition ship. He was the figure who announced to the world the proof of bin Laden's complicity in the attack in the House of Commons. He has rallied the European Union and committed British troops as by far the biggest non-American contingent in the war in Afghanistan. And all this from a prime minister who is, primarily, a Europhile. A cynic would respond that Blair has, like many previous British leaders, merely seized an opportunity as America's diplomatic and military fig leaf to enhance British influence in the world. 
But there is surely more to it than that. What Blair was responding to was what I had felt from afar: the instinctual association of ordinary Brits with Americans under fire. Some of this was understandable. There were, after all, dozens of British victims in the World Trade Center attack. Their presence alone is a sign of how deeply interwoven the lives of Britons and Americans had become in the new global economic order, and a sign too of how Britain, an open country, deeply reliant on trade and international finance, would suffer if terrorism shut the global system down. 
But beneath this, there is also something primal. What struck me here among my American friends at the time was how instinctive their response was to British support. It wasn't so much gratitude, I sensed, as relief. At moments like these, the Brits somehow make America seem less alone in the world. They act as a sanity check when America feels beleaguered, a reassurance that not all foreigners harbor reflexive hostility to the United States. And at profoundly vulnerable moments, maternity matters. Somewhere in the American psyche, the support of the mother country buoys even those Americans who have no ethnic or cultural connection to Britain whatsoever. When faced with a real threat, we remember the fundamentals. Orwell foresaw this linkage in his vision of a new bloc of trans-Atlantic powers called Oceania in his novel "1984." Churchill, partly American himself, articulated it more cheerfully in his notion of a union of the English-speaking peoples. But now, perhaps because of deeper and deeper cultural penetration, because of growing financial and economic interdependence, the merger once dreamed of is finally coming to pass. What Orwell and Churchill foresaw, and the 1990's deepened, bin Laden catalyzed still further. And it's appropriate, perhaps, that this came about not because of some political effort from the top but simply because of an emotional groundswell from below. Those feelings soldered something new and deep between these two countries: if not a reunification, then something close to it. 

GRAPHIC: Photo (Toby Melville/Associated Press) Chart: "Joint Chiefs""At the present time we have in continual vigorous action the British and United States Combined Chiefs of Staff Committee. . . . This committee, with its elaborate organization of staff officers of every grade, disposes of all our resources and, in practice, uses British and American troops, ships, aircraft and ammunition just as if they were the resources of a single state or nation. . . . This is a wonderful system. There was nothing like it in the last war. There never has been anything like it between two allies. . . . If we are together nothing is impossible. If we are divided all will fail." Winston S. Churchill, speaking at Harvard in 1943

ORGANIZATION: UNITED NATIONS (84%)

PERSON: TONY BLAIR (58%); GEORGE W BUSH (52%) SULLIVAN, ANDREW
