HEADLINE: The Final Fronton Nears Its Final Days 

BYLINE:  By KENNETH BEST 

 BODY:
THE sanctuary of professional athletes, the locker room, is often a noisy place. Card games, practical jokes and loud banter characteristically can be heard from behind its closed doors. 
 But since the announcement on Oct. 15 that Milford Jai-Alai would close after 25 years, the players who call the fronton's locker room their home have been more subdued. 
 "It's very quiet in the locker room," said Josu Elesgarai, one of Milford's top jai alai players known on the court as Beitia, who first came to the United States from Spain in 1992 to play at Bridgeport Jai-Alai. 
Mr. Elesgarai is among 200 employees, including the 48 competitors, who will no longer have jobs after Dec. 12, when the last of the state's three frontons will close.
Leonard Meyer, the Milford Jai-Alai president, said the closing was forced by a combination of events including declining attendance, a continuing drop in revenue in the face of competition from Foxwoods and Mohegan Sun casinos, and the inability to gain legislative support for the simulcasting of horse races.
"Milford has been a wonderful city to be in business in," Mr. Meyer said. "The citizens and government have been more than supportive. We felt a part of the community. We have no argument with the casinos. They're doing what they have to do. We've had a working relationship with them."
In fact, one of the last major events that will take place at Milford Jai-Alai is the Mohegan Sun International Jai-Alai Championships, one of the sport's major tournaments, which ends today.
Milford had its best year of operation in 1988, when the fronton had revenues of about $100 million for six months of operation, said Bob Heussler, a spokesman for the fronton. Milford alternated seasons with the Bridgeport fronton at the time.
The fronton's best individual day was Memorial Day of 1983, when rainy weather helped inspire 7,000 people to bet $770,000.
The Foxwoods Casino opened in 1992 and within three years, Milford was the only jai alai fronton remaining. 
After Bridgeport Jai-Alai closed in 1995 and was converted to Shoreline Star Greyhound Park, Milford began operating year-round. At about the same time, the fronton in Hartford closed and is now the site of the Meadows Music Theater. However, revenues continued to drop steadily in Milford. Last year the total amount of money bet at Milford was just more than $70 million and this year it is at about $66 million.
Attendance was affected not only by the opening of the casinos, but by the acceptance of jai alai bets in the Connecticut Off-Track Betting system in 1994, a move the frontons made in an effort to keep revenue flowing. However, while it made betting more convenient, it kept fans out of the fronton, away from the restaurant and from experiencing the atmosphere of being inside the building watching first hand the sport that is billed as the world's fastest ballgame.
"It was a double-edged sword," Mr. Huessler said. "From a business perspective you had to be available in OTB, but at what price? I think it might have been, in the end, too steep a price to pay."
Milford Jai-Alai was not able to gain legislative support for the simulcasting of horse races, which is available at the dog track in Bridgeport.
The cavernous Milford fronton has a capacity of 4,500 seats, and average attendance when it opened was more than 3,800. Today, the average attendance is fewer than 500.
On the weekend just after the closing announcement was made, the smack of the pelota against the wall echoed periodically throughout the building as players moved about the jai alai court. The other constant sound was the loud buzz from one of the lighting ballasts. An occasional shout from a fan broke through from time to time. 
Those who have been regulars at the fronton for many years said that while they do enjoy the wagering, it is the game itself and its athletes that they will miss the most. 
"It's very exciting, I'm going to miss it because it's a fun night out and great entertainment," said Ken Samu, a social worker from Trumbull, lighting up a cigarette after checking his program. "I don't play the horses or the dogs. I like jai alai because I like watching the game."
The Dec. 12 closing was selected because it was a natural break in the Milford schedule, what was the annual two-week shut down for maintenance and repair work. 
Lester Trotto, 53, began working part-time at the fronton cashing in winning tickets for customers. Today as the mutuals manager he supervises nearly 50 people who take and cash bets. Mr. Trotto, who has spent 25 years in the jai alai industry and is a native of the Milford-New Haven area, is uncertain what he will do when his job ends, along with its salary of more than $40,000.
"I'd like to do something on the road, but not sales," he said. "I really don't have any other experience than this. I've met a lot of people working here, so I've got some people looking around for me."
After learning of the closing, some of Mr. Trotto's staff moved quickly to attend a job fair at Mohegan Sun, thinking that if enough of them were offered jobs, they could arrange car pools to work each day.
Mr. Meyers said he would work with his employees to assist them with unemployment and with state job programs. He also has already been contacted by those interested in acquiring the 25-acre property, located just off of Interstate 95 on Old Gate Lane.
The only other jai alai frontons in the United States are in Newport, R.I., and at locations in Florida. The players, who are primarily from the Basque region of Spain where the sport developed, hope to find jobs in those locations. However, not all players have the same ability to find new jobs.
Some players, like Mr. Elesgarai, have been living and working in Connecticut for many years and have a permanent work visa, known as a green card, that allows them to collect unemployment and work outside of jai alai. Others are in the United States with temporary work visas and will have to return to Europe if they cannot find a job. 
Jai alai players in Milford average about $50,000 per year, a figure that varies depending on their contracts and record of winning games. Even for those who can stay in Connecticut, it will be difficult to find a job with the same kind of income.
"It's happening too fast," said Mr. Elesgarai, 31, who owns a home in Milford where he lives with his family, including two young children. "We have two months. A lot of people are going to be unemployed. It's going to be tough working outside of jai alai."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Milford Jai-alai, the last fronton in Connecticut, has announced it will close on Dec. 12 after 25 years of operation. Lester Trotto, right, the mutuels manager, is one of 200 employees, including 48 jai alai players, who will be looking for new jobs. (Photographs by Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: HOLIDAY FILMS: THE LINEUP; 
Hogwarts, Middle Earth And Other Getaway Spots

BYLINE:  By ANITA GATES; Compiled with the assistance of Suzanne O'Connor.

 BODY:
 HOLLYWOOD would love to know what America wants to see at the movies this holiday season. (If only we knew ourselves.) Some big films have been moved to 2002, in hopes that times will be better or, as we say wistfully every day, "back to normal." A few serious, possibly Oscar-worthy pictures will open over the next two months, but the sure thing this season is fantasy. Thank God for Harry Potter and hobbits and time travel and terrifying stories set in a distant future that has nothing to do with us.

NOVEMBER

'OTOMO': Racism and violence in Germany. A West African man (Isaach de Bankole) has an ugly confrontation with policemen in the Stuttgart subway. Inspired by a real incident and directed by Frieder Schlaich. Opens Wednesday.
'EVERYTHING PUT TOGETHER': A low-budget drama about the death of a newborn baby. Radha Mitchell ("High Art") stars as the distraught mother, whose friends abandon her; Justin Louis plays her husband. Directed by Marc Forster, it was a hit at Sundance. Friday.
'HEIST': David Mamet's long-awaited contribution to the genre of the same name. Gene Hackman, Danny DeVito and Delroy Lindo star in this drama about a gang of thieves planning a jewelry-store job. Highly verbal thieves, we presume. Friday.
'I REMEMBER ME': A documentary about chronic fatigue syndrome. The filmmaker, Kim Snyder, is a sufferer, as are the director Blake Edwards and the former soccer star Michelle Akers. Friday.
'KEEPING IT REAL: THE ADVENTURES OF GREG WALLOCH': A documentary about a gay comic with cerebral palsy. His subjects include the sexual prowess of the disabled and a shocking campaign to promote bibliophilia in Chelsea. Directed by Eli Kabillio. Friday.
'KING OF THE JUNGLE': John Leguizamo stars in a street drama about a mentally disabled young man looking for his mother's killer. Meanwhile his mother's lover (Rosie Perez) is searching for him. Directed by Seth Zvi Rosenfeld, complete with a hooker with a heart of gold (Annabella Sciorra). Friday.
'MAZE': Rob Morrow wrote, directed and stars in a romantic drama about an artist with Tourette's syndrome who falls for his best friend's girlfriend (the easy-to-love Laura Linney). Complications: The boyfriend (Craig Sheffer) is out of the country. She's pregnant. Friday.
'SHALLOW HAL': The Farrelly brothers put Gwyneth Paltrow in a fat suit (for part of the movie). Ms. Paltrow plays Rosemary, an unattractive, overweight young woman adored by Hal (Jack Black), who has been hypnotized to see only women's inner beauty, not their surface appearance. And inside, Rosemary is a beautiful, thin blonde with great cheekbones. It's a comedy, with Jason Alexander as Hal's best friend. Friday.
'THE WASH': Hip-hop stars working just like regular guys. Dr. Dre and Snoop Dogg take jobs at a car wash to make ends meet. Then their boss (George Wallace) is kidnapped. An action comedy written and directed by D. J. Pooh ("Three Strikes"). Nov. 14.
'ABCD': The sister is promiscuous (defined by her sex life). The brother is a successful accountant (defined by his work). They're both Asian Indian immigrants in America, torn between two cultures. With Faran Tahir, Sheetal Sheth and Aasif Mandvi. Directed by Krutin Patel. Nov. 16.
'BOMBAY EUNUCH': An ancient royal tradition meets the 21st century. The film was named best documentary at this year's New York Lesbian and Gay Film Festival. Directed by Michelle Gucovsky, Sean MacDonald and Alexandra Shiva. Nov. 16.
'THE FLUFFER': A romantic triangle in the gay porn industry. It involves a straight actor who makes gay films (Scott Gurney); his stripper girlfriend (Roxanne Day) and the new boy on the set (Michael Cunio). Richard Glatzer and Wash West directed. Nov. 16.
'HARRY POTTER AND THE SORCERER'S STONE': Daniel Radcliffe plays the world's most famous orphan whose cruel adoptive parents don't know he's a powerful wizard. The first of J. K. Rowling's sinfully popular books about Harry comes to the screen, directed by Chris Columbus. If the books' young fans like its interpretation of Potter trademarks like the Hogwarts School, Quidditch games on broomsticks and the underground goblin sanctuary, this will be an instant classic. Also, box office will go through the roof. Supporting players include Richard Harris as Headmaster Dumbledore, Dame Maggie Smith as Professor McGonagall, Robbie Coltrane as Hagrid the gamekeeper and John Cleese as Nearly Headless Nick. Nov. 16.
'NOVOCAINE': Steve Martin in a serious (well, at least very darkly comic) sex-and-drugs crime thriller. He's an affluent dentist with a new patient (Helena Bonham Carter) who runs with a bad crowd. (But how will we forget the dentist Mr. Martin played in "Little Shop of Horrors"?) Nov. 16.
'THE SIMIAN LINE': Four couples in Weehawken, N.J. All have strong reactions when a fortuneteller (Tyne Daly) announces one relationship won't last until the new year. The couples are Harry Connick Jr. and Lynn Redgrave (May-December), Cindy Crawford and Jamey Sheridan (the ambitious ones), Monica Keena and Dylan Bruno (the young ones), and William Hurt and Samantha Mathis (the ghosts). Linda Yellen directed. Nov. 16.
'AMERICAN ADOBO': More culture-bridging. A comedy about five single Filipino- American friends in New York. With Paolo Montalban and Randy Becker. Directed by Laurice Guillen. Nov. 21.
'BLACK KNIGHT': Martin Lawrence in a time-travel comedy set in 1328. Medieval is big this year. Directed by Gil Junger ("10 Things I Hate About You"). Nov. 21.
'THE DEVIL'S BACKBONE': A ghost story set during the Spanish Civil War. A 10-year-old boy (Fernando Tielve) arrives at a school for orphans where the caretaker (Eduardo Noriega) seems dangerous and a young ghost ("the one that sighs") wanders the grounds. Written and directed by Guillermo del Toro ("Cronos.") Nov. 21. A related article is on Page 31.
'OUT COLD': A snowboarding comedy with Lee Majors and an ensemble of young unknowns (Flex Alexander, A. J. Cook, Caroline Dhavernas). Directed by Emmett and Brendan Malloy. Nov. 21.
'SIDEWALKS OF NEW YORK': Edward Burns's latest, already compared (for better or worse) to Woody Allen's urban-neurotic romantic comedies. Mr. Burns, Heather Graham and Stanley Tucci star in the story of half a dozen Manhattanites looking for love -- and connected in ways they don't know. Nov. 21.
'SPY GAME': Robert Redford and Brad Pitt in a C.I.A. suspense drama. How much blond handsomeness can we stand? Mr. Pitt is in a Chinese prison. Mr. Redford is his mentor, trying to free him on the brink of his own retirement (oh, that old plot device). This is the first time the two have worked together since Mr. Redford directed Mr. Pitt, then unknown, in "A River Runs Through It." Tony Scott ("Enemy of the State") directed. Nov. 21.
'THE WAY WE LAUGHED': A drama about two Sicilian brothers, one of them illiterate, living in Turin. Directed by Gianni Amelio ("Lamerica"). It won a cinematography award at the Venice Film Festival. Nov. 21.
'BANGKOK DANGEROUS': A sociopathic deaf mute killer finally meets the right woman. A Thai action thriller from the Pang brothers, Oxide and Danny. Starring Pawalit Mongkolpisit and Premsinee Ratanasopha. Nov. 23.
'IN THE BEDROOM': An intense family drama based on an Andre Dubus short story. Sissy Spacek and Tom Wilkinson play a Maine couple whose only child (Nick Stahl) is involved with an older woman (Marisa Tomei). The affair leads to tragedy. Directed by Todd Field, the film won a special acting prize at Sundance. Nov. 23.
'THE AFFAIR OF THE NECKLACE': Hilary Swank gets dressed up. She plays Jeanne de la Motte-Valois, an 18th-century noblewoman out for revenge against the French royal family. Based on a true story. Directed by Charles Shyer, whose past films have been homier ("Baby Boom," "Father of the Bride"). Nov. 30.
'BEHIND THE SUN': From Walter Salles, who did "Central Station," the story of a generations-long family feud in 1910 Brazil. Based on Ismail Kadare's novel "Broken April." With Jose Dumont and Rodrigo Santoro. Nov. 30.
'THE INDEPENDENT': You remember Morty Fineman (Jerry Stiller), the prolific filmmaker of classics like "Cheerleader Camp Massacre" and "Teenie Weenie Bikini Beach." A mock documentary clearly inspired by the career of Roger Corman. It won the top prize at Slamdunk, one of the Sundance alternatives. Directed by Stephen Kessler, with Janeane Garofalo as Morty's estranged daughter, Paloma. Nov. 30.
'IN JULY': A German romantic comedy about a young teacher who changes his mind about staying in Hamburg for the summer. Moritz Bleibtreu and Christiane Paul star. Written and directed by Fatih Akin, and filmed partly in Budapest and Istanbul. Nov. 30.
'PORNSTAR: THE LEGEND OF RON JEREMY': He's a short, fat, unattractive pornography-film legend. Now, after starring in more than 600 movies (many with titles like "Luau Orgy" and "For Your Thighs Only"), he wants to be taken seriously. A documentary directed by Scott Gill. Nov. 30. 
'SUPER TROOPERS': Overenthusiastic Vermont state troopers having a good time. Written by and starring the five-man comedy team Broken Lizard. Directed by Jay Chandrasekhar, one of the five. They loved it at Sundance. Nov. 30.
'TEXAS RANGERS': A genuine actual western that has been threatening to open since spring 2000. The mostly young stars include some TV heroes (James Van Der Beek, Dylan McDermott, Ashton Kutcher). Directed by Steve Miner, it's about the founding of the Rangers after the Civil War. Nov. 30.

DECEMBER

'B-52': Hartmut Bitomsky's documentary about the bombers of the same name. They have wingspans as wide as a football field, carry a crew of six and have a range of 8,388 miles without refueling. And who would have thought we'd care? Dec. 5.

'PINERO': Benjamin Bratt plays Miguel Pinero, Nuyorican poet, playwright, Tony Award nominee, actor, TV writer, heroin addict and ex-con. Unlike Reinaldo Arenas, the subject of last year's "Before Night Falls," this artist enjoyed his success before dying young of AIDS. With Mandy Patinkin as Joseph Papp. Written and directed by Leon Ichaso. Dec. 5.
'THE BUSINESS OF STRANGERS': Think of it as "In the Company of Women." At an airport hotel, an executive (Stockard Channing) and her young assistant (Julia Stiles) bridge the generation and income gap, then decide to play strange games with a corporate headhunter (Frederick Weller). A drama with black comedy, written and directed by Patrick Stettner. Dec. 7.
'EBAN AND CHARLEY': An ex-soccer coach returns to his hometown and bonds with a 15-year-old boy. Their families object. Brent Fellows and Giovanni Andrade star in this drama written and directed by James Bolton. Dec. 7.
'FINAL': Denis Leary as a man who is either insane or in a lot of trouble. Waking up in a small locked room, he believes it's 2399 and he's just been cryogenically unfrozen so he can be carved up into "donor organ packets." Hope Davis plays his doctor. A psychological thriller directed by Campbell Scott. Dec. 7.
'NO MAN'S LAND': Three soldiers in an abandoned trench: one Serb, two Bosnian -- and one is lying on top of a spring bomb. When a U.N. official and a journalist try to help, the situation becomes a media circus. A satiric drama written and directed by Tanis Danovic. Filmed in the former Yugoslav republic Slovenia. Dec. 7. A related article is on Page 31.
'OCEAN'S 11': George Clooney, Brad Pitt, Matt Damon, Julia Roberts and a few others star in a not-exactly-remake of Sinatra and the Rat Pack's not-exactly-good 1960 heist film. This time the gang is planning to hit Las Vegas casinos during a high-profile boxing match. Directed by Steven Soderbergh, which should count for something. Dec. 7.
'PRINCESA': A nice Brazilian boy working as a transvestite prostitute in Milan finds the man of his dreams, complete with more than enough money for a sex-change operation. But the dream disappoints. Directed by Henrique Goldman and based on the memoirs of Fernanda Farias de Albuquerque, who later committed suicide. Ingrid de Souza stars as Fernanda. Dec. 7.
'AS I WAS MOVING AHEAD OCCASIONALLY I SAW BRIEF GLIMPSES OF BEAUTY': A full 4 hours and 48 minutes of Jonas Mekas's 16-mm film diary. Mr. Mekas includes family scenes, European travel and lots of New York. Dec. 12.
'ESCAPE TO LIFE: THE ERIKA AND KLAUS MANN STORY': A documentary about the children of the author Thomas Mann. They were both gay, anti-Fascist and brave enough to satirize the Third Reich in their cabaret act. Directed by Andrea Weiss and Wieland Speck. With the voices of two other outspoken siblings, Vanessa and Corin Redgrave. Dec. 14.
'IRIS': A romantic, sure to be tear-jerking drama about the British novelist Iris Murdoch. She's played by Kate Winslet as a young woman at Oxford and by Dame Judi Dench as the older Murdoch, who loses all to Alzheimer's. Hugh Bonneville and Jim Broadbent play John Bayley, Murdoch's husband, whose memoirs the film is based on. Directed by Richard Eyre. Dec. 14.
'NOT ANOTHER TEEN MOVIE': A high school football star (Chris Evans) bets he can turn a bespectacled nerd (Chyler Leigh) into a prom queen. But this comedy, directed by Joel Gallen (whose claim to fame is having produced the MTV Movie Awards show for a decade), sets out to play with the usual cliches. Mr. T is listed in the cast, which could be a sign. Dec. 14.
'VANILLA SKY': This year's Meg-and-Russell award -- for the co-star romance that overshadows the film where it all began -- goes to this romantic comedy from Cameron Crowe. Tom Cruise is a handsome, womanizing publishing tycoon looking for his soul (just like Jerry Maguire). Penelope Cruz, as his best friend's girlfriend, has played this role before: in "Abre los Ojos," the 1997 Spanish film that inspired this one. Dec.14. A related article is on Page 3.
'LITTLE OTIK': It's based on an old Czech fairy tale. When a couple can't have children, the husband just carves a baby out of a stump. Unfortunately, it turns into a monster. A combination of live action and Claymation, written and directed by Jan Svankmajer. Dec. 19.
'LORD OF THE RINGS: THE FELLOWSHIP OF THE RING': Elves, hobbits, trolls, dwarves, orcs, ents, ringwraiths and a magic ring that must be destroyed. The first in a film trilogy based on J. R. R. Tolkien's cult fantasy novels. With Elijah Wood as Frodo, Sir Ian McKellen as the good wizard Gandalf and a supporting cast that includes Cate Blanchett, Liv Tyler, Sean Astin and Christopher Lee. Directed by Peter Jackson ("Heavenly Creatures") and filmed in New Zealand. So that's what Middle Earth looks like. Dec. 19.
'GOSFORD PARK': Robert Altman mixes "Upstairs, Downstairs" and murder. A comedy-of-manners mystery set in 1932 at an English country estate. Mr. Altman loves big ensemble casts, and here he has a mostly British one, including Alan Bates, Michael Gambon, Derek Jacobi, Helen Mirren, Jeremy Northam, Maggie Smith and Emily Watson. Dec. 21.
'HOW HIGH': Two stupid young men get into Harvard by smoking a particular kind of marijuana (which, inexplicably, makes them temporarily brilliant). Then they run out of the stuff. With the rap stars Redman and Method Man. Directed by Jesse Dylan, son of Bob, who once had something to say about getting stoned. Dec. 21.
'JIMMY NEUTRON: BOY GENIUS': Starring space aliens who look like green egg yolks. Thank goodness they're animated, as is the brilliant 10-year-old boy who has to save the people of Retroville from the invaders. With the voices of Martin Short and Patrick Stewart. Directed by John Davis. Dec. 21.
'JOE SOMEBODY': A divorced corporate nobody (Tim Allen) turns his life around. He has to. He's just been publicly humiliated at the office in front of his daughter. A comic drama from John Pasquin, who also directed Mr. Allen in "The Santa Clause." Dec. 21.
'KATE AND LEOPOLD': Time travel turns romantic. Meg Ryan is a 21st-century single American executive; Hugh Jackman is a 19th-century bachelor English duke, who has accidentally been transported (by Liev Schreiber) to present-day New York. As long as he's here, they might as well tour the city and fall in love. Directed by James Mangold, who did "Girl, Interrupted." Dec. 21.
'LANTANA': One woman's disappearance affects four marriages. Anthony LaPaglia is the detective on the case. With Geoffrey Rush and Barbara Hershey. A psychological thriller directed by Ray Lawrence. Dec. 21. A related article is on Page 13.
'THE MAJESTIC': Jim Carrey gets serious again and, by all reports, highly Capraesque. He plays a 1950's blacklisted writer who loses his memory and finds a new life in a small town. With Martin Landau as the local movie theater owner, Bob Balaban as the HUAC guy and Laurie Holden as the ponytailed love interest. Directed by Frank Darabont ("The Shawshank Redemption," "The Green Mile"). Dec. 21. Related articles are on Page 34.
'THE ROYAL TENENBAUMS': When bad things happen to early bloomers. Gwyneth Paltrow, Ben Stiller and Luke Wilson star as the amazingly brilliant, successful children of Gene Hackman and Anjelica Huston. But they've all gone seriously downhill, and now they're having a reunion. A comedy directed by Wes Anderson, who gave us "Rushmore." Dec. 21.
'ALI': If anybody can play the boxing legend Muhammad Ali with the right blend of wit, anger and, of course, greatness, it's probably Will Smith, who hasn't had a real acting challenge since "Six Degrees of Separation." He gets his chance in this drama directed by Michael Mann, whose last film was "The Insider." With Jamie Foxx, Jon Voight, Mario Van Peebles and Jeffrey Wright. Dec. 25.
'A BEAUTIFUL MIND': Russell Crowe as a math genius with schizophrenia and an active sex life. A drama based on a biography of John Forbes Nash Jr., the Nobel Prize-winning father of game-theory economics. With Ed Harris and Jennifer Connelly. Directed by Ron Howard, whose last was "How the Grinch Stole Christmas." Dec. 25. A related article is on Page 13.
'IMPOSTOR': Gary Sinise and Madeleine Stowe in a futuristic sci-fi romance. He's an engineer who invented a fabulous anti-alien weapon, but now people suspect he's an alien clone. Directed by Gary Fleder. Dec. 25.
'THE SHIPPING NEWS': Kevin Spacey in Lasse Hallstrom's film of E. Annie Proulx's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel. It's a drama about a writer who moves to Newfoundland after the death of his estranged wife (Cate Blanchett) and digs up a few secrets. Julianne Moore is his new love interest. Dame Judi Dench is his long-lost aunt. Dec. 25.
'MONSTER'S BALL': Billy Bob Thornton as a Southern death-row prison guard who falls in love with the widow (Halle Berry) of a man he just executed. With Heath Ledger and Peter Boyle. A drama directed by Marc Forster and filmed partly at Angola, the Louisiana penitentiary. Dec. 26.
'CHARLOTTE GRAY': Cate Blanchett as a young Scotswoman working underground in the French resistance. This is Gillian Armstrong's version of Sebastian Faulks's romantic World War II novel set mostly in rural France. Charlotte does it all in search of the R.A.F. pilot she loves but finds a handsome resistance leader (Billy Crudup) and his father (Michael Gambon) pretty fascinating too. They've changed the book's ending, which was, let's face it, a little too realistic. Dec. 28. A related article is on Page 3.
'DARK BLUE WORLD': From the people who gave us the Oscar-winning "Kolya" -- who must have seen "Pearl Harbor." A World War II drama about two Czech pilots, close friends who join the British R.A.F. and fall in love with the same woman. Ondrej Vetchy, Krystof Hadek and Tara Fitzgerald star. Directed by Jan Sverak and written by Zdenek Sverak, his father. Dec. 28.
'I AM SAM': Sean Penn in intense dramatic mode as a mentally retarded man trying to win custody of his daughter. With Michelle Pfeiffer, Laura Dern and Loretta Devine. Directed by Jessie Nelson, who dealt with father-daughter difficulties a few years ago in "Corrina, Corrina." Dec. 28.

'PAULINE AND PAULETTE': Two self-involved Belgian women refuse to care for their mentally retarded sister after the oldest sister dies. Then they read the will. A family drama with Dora van der Groen, Ann Peterson and Rosemarie Berghmans. Directed by Lieven Debrauwer. December. 

JANUARY

'EISENSTEIN': At 27 he was considered the greatest filmmaker in the world. Simon McBurney plays Sergei Eisenstein as he makes his reputation with "The Battleship Potemkin" (1925). Written and directed by Renny Bartlett. Jan. 2.
'42K': Four guys in a rock band end up with a necklace that wards off vampires. Ninjas, evangelical Christians and one gangsta rapper are also involved. Jan. 4.
'THE ACCIDENTAL SPY': Jackie Chan as an exercise equipment salesman? Yes, but he still becomes involved with jewel thieves, an international conspiracy and a virus. Directed by Teddy Chen. Jan. 11.
'ALL ABOUT THE BENJAMINS': Ice Cube and Mike Epps, who did "Next Friday" together, in an "action crime comedy," as a bounty hunter and a bail jumper who decide to team up. Directed by Kevin Bray. Jan. 11.
'BROTHERHOOD OF THE WOLF': Possibly a new genre blend: a French martial-arts horror costume-drama romance. Samuel Le Bihan plays an 18th-century scientist assigned to find a homicidal monster roaming the provinces. With Mark Dacascos as the scientist's American Indian blood brother, Vincent Cassel as a one-armed aristocrat and Monica Bellucci as a psychic prostitute. A hit in France. Directed by Christophe Gans. Jan. 11.
'ORANGE COUNTY': Next-generation Hollywood steps up to the plate. Colin Hanks (Tom Hanks's son) and Schuyler Fisk (Sissy Spacek's daughter) star in a comedy about a California high school senior who is desperate to get into Stanford. Directed by Jake Kasdan (Lawrence Kasdan's son). Jan. 11.
'THE FAREWELL': One day in the life of Bertolt Brecht. It's late summer, and he's leaving his lakeside house to go back to Berlin and surrounded by women. Josef Bierbichler stars. Jan Schutte directed. Jan. 16.
'THE ADVENTURES OF PLUTO NASH': Eddie Murphy as a nightclub owner on the moon. The year is 2087, and the local mob is making trouble. A sci-fi comedy directed by Ron Underwood ("City Slickers"). Jan. 18.
'BEHIND ENEMY LINES': A Navy pilot (Owen Wilson) is shot down over enemy territory and his commanding officer (Gene Hackman) decides to try to rescue him. A drama directed by John Moore. Jan. 18.
'BLACK HAWK DOWN': A war movie from Ridley Scott, who knows conflict and evil (from "Alien" and "Blade Runner" to "Gladiator" and "Hannibal"). The true story of American special forces in Somalia in 1993, on a mission that goes extremely wrong. The cast includes Josh Hartnett, Ewan McGregor, Ron Eldard and Sam Shepard. The screenplay's co-writer is Steven Zaillian, who did "Schindler's List." Jan. 18.
'ITALIAN FOR BEGINNERS': From Denmark, a romantic comic drama about students hoping to find love in Italian class. A Dogma production written and directed by Lone Scherfig. With Anders W. Berthelsen and Ann Eleonora Jorgensen. It won multiple awards at the Berlin International Film Festival. Jan. 18.
'KILLING ME SOFTLY': The Chinese director Chen Kaige makes his English-language debut with an erotic suspense thriller. Heather Graham is a London scientist who risks everything for her sexual relationship with a mountaineer (Joseph Fiennes) she meets while crossing the street. Jan. 18.
'SLACKERS': Not a sequel to Richard Linklater's "Slacker." A completely different film about a geek, a college-grades scam, blackmail and the pursuit of the most beautiful girl on campus. With Jason Schwartzman, Devon Sawa and James King. Directed by Dewey Nicks. Jan. 18.
'SNOW DOGS': Cuba Gooding Jr. in a drama about the Iditarod, the Alaskan dog-sled race. With James Coburn as his father. Based on Gary Paulsen's book and directed by Brian Levant ("The Flintstones"). Jan. 18.
'WHAT TIME IS IT THERE?': From the Taiwanese director Tsai Ming-liang, a tale of obsession, shot in Paris and Taipei. A young watch seller (Lee Kang-sheng) deals with his father's death, his mother's grief, international time zones and the young woman who got away. Jan. 18.

All dates are subject to change.

HEADLINE: HOLIDAY FILMS; 
Hollywood in Wartime: Lessons of Pearl Harbor

BYLINE:  By A. O. SCOTT 

 BODY:
ON Dec. 7, 1941, the Japanese attacked Pearl Harbor. On Dec. 8, a Warner Brothers employee filed a report on a property called "Everybody Comes to Rick's," which the studio released in late November of the following year, drastically altered to reflect the demands of the time, as "Casablanca." Everybody knows the story of how Rick, a cynical nightclub owner whose credo is "I stick my neck out for nobody," rediscovers his essential nobility and sacrifices self-interest to the greater good. The basic story line would become a staple of wartime American cinema -- the film historian Thomas Schatz said it "signaled the wartime conversion of Hollywood's classical narrative paradigm" -- and would help make Humphrey Bogart one of the top movie stars of the era. In retrospect, "Casablanca" can also be seen as a metaphor for Hollywood's own heroic contribution to the war effort.
 Not that the film industry's response seemed especially heroic at the time. A year after Pearl Harbor, performing the critic's traditional holiday duty of compiling a list of the 10 best movies of the year, Bosley Crowther, The New York Times's chief reviewer, while approving of a number of films that dealt with the war (including "Casablanca"), argued that "by and large, the general quality of motion pictures this past year has reflected the confusion and uncertainty in Hollywood." 
 "Producers have plunged willy-nilly on purely 'escapist' pictures or have made the war out to seem illusory by dodging it into old routines," Crowther went on. "Stories have been, in most cases, disappointingly unoriginal and methods have been generally jejune. American films have slipped -- or just marked time -- this year."
A year later, on Christmas Day 1943, James Agee, writing in The Nation, wearily complained that "last year, it seems to me, was the all-time low -- so far." 
But in the decades since the war ended, such demurrals have faded, and the era is recalled as one of the proudest in American movie history. "In many ways," Mr. Schatz writes in "Boom and Bust," his authoritative chronicle of American cinema in the 1940's, "World War II was the best of times for the movie industry not because of its unprecedented economic prosperity, but because of its social and cinematic achievements." He goes on to quote a foreign correspondent for Look magazine, who wrote in 1944 that "there was a time when it was considered smart to be cynical about Hollywood. That was before the war."
The holiday film season as we now know it is an artifact of recent history. In the 40's, the studios were not in the habit of crowding all their A-list pictures into the five final weeks of the year. The speeded-up, concentrated release schedule that has become the norm over the past decade has made the panic sown by Sept. 11 especially dramatic, as the studios have pulled some big movies from release and rescheduled others in a desperate attempt to divine the public mood. People will certainly go to the movies this December, as they did in December of 1941, and perhaps in greater numbers than last year. The movies we will see are, for the most part, the ones we would have seen anyway, but the circumstances have changed suddenly, and in ways we have yet to understand. 
Of course, historical analogies are always dangerous, and looking back on the war that began 60 years ago on Dec. 7 may not be much help in facing the one that began on Sept. 11 of this year. Putting aside the obvious military and geopolitical differences, it seems unlikely that industry will undergo wholesale conversion to wartime production, or that a formal collaboration between the military and the movie studios, like the one overseen by the Office of War Information in the 40's, is in the works. Nor, for that matter, do the movies enjoy the monopoly on visual information that they did then: images of the current war now reach us instantaneously wherever we are, around the clock, rather than in the communal darkness of the cinema.
But some things, it seems, have changed little in more than half a century. Critics are still wont to complain about the state of the movies. And cynicism about Hollywood, which may have been thought smart in 1941, is something of a no-brainer nowadays. But movies remain the flagship of the popular culture, and as such they are able both to formulate and to reflect public perceptions of crisis, and also to help the public cope with its own confusion and uncertainty.
In theory, anyway. The hard question that is being faced by nervous studio executives at the present time is, how. In a time of national worry, do audiences want to be distracted from grim and upsetting realities? Do we want to be reassured and comforted, or do we need to face down our fears? Do we want morale-boosting propaganda or honest criticism? The easy answer, confirmed by a look back at the 10-best lists and box-office records of the 40's, is yes, all of the above.
As the war dragged on (and the box office surged, setting a record in each year of the conflict, only to break it the next), it occupied an ever greater share of Hollywood's attention. In addition to the home-front melodramas and sagas of combat, though, the studios continued to turn out westerns, knockabout comedies with Abbott and Costello and Hope and Crosby, musicals, and crime dramas. For the latter genres, the mid-40's were the beginning of a golden age -- the age of Technicolor song-and-dance extravaganzas and film noir shadow plays.
In 1942, what would become the dominant modes of wartime storytelling were represented by "Casablanca," "Mrs. Miniver" and "Wake Island": thrillers with reluctant heroes, inspiring tales of ordinary indomitability and fictionalized bulletins from the front. The combat pictures especially satisfied a dual and sometimes contradictory craving: for the truth about what American soldiers, sailors and pilots were facing overseas and for stirring, morale-boosting tales of home-grown heroism. The best combat dramas -- like John Ford's "They Were Expendable" and William Wellman's "Story of G.I. Joe" -- managed to satisfy both demands, as did combat documentaries by leading Hollywood directors like Ford's "Battle of Midway," John Huston's "Battle of San Pietro" and William Wyler's "Memphis Belle."
Among the legacies of wartime film production was the reciprocal influence of the documentary and fictional approaches. According to Mr. Schatz, "as documentarians like Ford, Wyler and Huston dramatized and humanized their wartime subjects, fictionalized accounts of combat developed a more pronounced documentary realism."
IF one of Hollywood's responses to war was a new openness to realism -- understood both as a technical possibility and as an ethical imperative -- another was a renewed commitment to the difficult task of escaping reality. One film on Crowther's 1942 10-best list was Preston Sturges's "Sullivan's Travels." Released six weeks after Pearl Harbor (and therefore substantially completed well before the attack), this spirited satire of high-minded (or, in the Sturges idiom, "deep dish") Hollywood may have struck audiences in 1943 as suddenly out of date, a holdover from the prewar world. The real-world concerns that preoccupy its hero, a successful director of risque comedies like "So Long, Sarong," "Hey Hey in the Hayloft" and "Ants in Your Pants of 1939," are those of the Depression. The glitter and insouciance of Hollywood give way, in the course of his travels, to a grim landscape of hobo camps and chain gangs. What Sullivan learns in his journey through the lower depths is that the downtrodden want only to laugh -- an epiphany that comes when he watches a Mickey Mouse cartoon in the company of a rural black congregation and a group of brutalized convicts. 
At the same time, though, "Sullivan's Travels" can be taken as a pre-emptive parodic strike at the noble intentions that would overtake Hollywood over the next three years, and also as a harbinger of Sturges's own wartime comedies. In 1944, he released "The Miracle of Morgan's Creek" and "Hail the Conquering Hero," two home-front comedies that upend every convention of wartime Hollywood. In "Miracle," his heroine is a young woman (Betty Hutton) who, after a drunken one-night stand with a serviceman on his way overseas -- a tryst sanctified for the benefit of the censors by hasty vows of matrimony -- finds herself pregnant. "Hail the Conquering Hero" records the travails of a young man, played by Eddie Bracken, who is kept out of the service by chronic hay fever but who half-unwittingly deceives his hometown into treating him like a war hero.
Sturges, of course, was a kind of anti-Capra, perhaps the greatest cynic the American movie industry has yet produced. But his films of the 1940's show that in wartime, cynicism can, paradoxically, become a virtue, just as sentimentality can be a vice. "Hail the Conquering Hero" does not puncture the he-man mythology of the combat films so much as complement it, by reminding us that they also serve who only stand and sneeze. And "The Miracle of Morgan's Creek," in turning the iconography of the chaste, valiant hometown girl upside down, paints a picture of small-town Americans who are no less heroic for being completely ridiculous. 
The present appeal of movies made during World War II is obvious enough, and has been apparent in the "greatest generation" worship of the past few years. It is tempting to view the 1940's as a less ambiguous, simpler time, in which the moral choices were clearer and the cultural responses to them emphatically and intuitively appropriate. The reality at the time, of course, was more complicated, but the glory of wartime Hollywood nonetheless exerts a powerful nostalgic pull.
Nostalgia, though comforting, is not the best way to learn from history. Hollywood should look back on its finest hour not in the hope of repeating itself and turning out a new crop of stirring combat epics, film noirs or uplifting domestic dramas. It has done enough of that already. But perhaps this is a time for the film industry to stick its neck out a bit, to risk discovering new forms of realism and new modes of escape.

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL RECORDING; 
Stagnant Wages

 BODY:
To the Editor: 
 Anthony Tommasini writes that "recording costs, especially for symphonic and operatic fare, have skyrocketed." This is not true for the single largest component of recording costs in the United States and Canada: wage payments to orchestra musicians. Since 1977, the wages set by the relevant collective bargaining agreement between the American Federation of Musicians and the major record companies have remained virtually constant when adjusted for inflation.

ROBERT LEVINE
Glendale, Wis.

The writer is chairman of the International Conference of Symphony and Opera Musicians.

HEADLINE: Affairs of the Horse: 2 Centuries of Images 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER WEST DAVIS 

DATELINE: KATONAH 

 BODY:
WHAT does it mean to be an American? 
 Ask a horse. 
 So the new show, "Horse Tales: American Images and Icons 1800-2000," at the Katonah Museum of Art here argues.
Every culture has come up with its own take on the horse. Show what you've done with this common denominator, and you'll reveal who you are. 
"Everybody has a horse story," said the exhibition's co-curator, Ezra Shales. "Their first ride, the first time they were thrown, the reason they don't ride. They are all vivid memories and very powerful to listen to."
Mr. Shales and his co-curator, Dr. Susan H. Edwards, assembled two centuries of horse imagery (memorabilia, memento, art, craft, video, photograph, illustration, packaging), sorted them by theme rather than time line and compressed them into the 2,500 square feet of display space (a limitation that Mr. Shales says forces you "to be concise and specific"). 
For starters, horses evolved in North America, went "extinct" here, vanishing West over the land bridge to Asia, and, after a 7,600-year hiatus, reappeared courtesy of the Conquistadors.
They have missed out on little history since. They powered farms, pioneering, ranching, soldiering. Without Shoshone horses, Lewis and Clark would have gone home early (or not at all), cowboys would have looked for other careers, and picture Paul Revere running through the streets at midnight trying to rouse his neighbors to war on foot. 
The 1885 Sioux watercolor "General Custer Fighting Sitting Bull," the Frederic Remington bronze "The Bronco Buster" (1918) and George Catlin's "Wild Horses at Play" (1842) are all clear reminders of how the West was really won astride.
Changing into an industrial society did not chase the horse off. Today about 6.9 million horses are in the United States and 7.1 million people are involved in an equine industry that, according to the American Horse Council, has a $112.1 billion impact on the gross domestic product.
Still, several haunting images lament the beasts that have been discarded.
The exhibition's poster child, "The Wreck of the Ole 97" by Thomas Hart Benton, seems to stylize all the myths and misgivings of progress through technology with a rearing white horse spooked by the sight of a train, an innocent young girl who is thrown from the carriage as a result. 
There are no more forlorn-looking creatures than the four steaming nags pulling the No. 15 Harlem trolley through the snow and slush of Manhattan in Alfred Stieglitz's 1892 photo "The Terminal." For them, it is the end of the line.
Saddest of all is "Untitled (Turned Him Out to Die)," a 1939 crayon on cardboard work by Bill Traylor, a former slave who who took up art at the age of 80. 
Even after horses themselves had been hobbled, humbled and made redundant by machines, their symbol nevertheless remained. The horse, as Dr. Edwards put it, has been "co-opted to suggest power, speed, reliability, status, ruggedness, sexuality and wildness." 
Horses have also not avoided shouldering the baggage of modern psychology. Some themes are inescapable whenever anyone tries to explain the spell horses cast on everyone: male versus female, and the phenomenon of young girls and horses. "The psychic and symbolic functions of the horse might be very different for the two sexes," said one artist, Deborah Bright.
Might be? Judging from the evidence presented here, male artists think horses should be pulling plows, roping cattle, playing polo or leading a charge. In contrast, female artists tend to prefer their horses idyllic, unfettered and anthropomorphized to the point they seem ready to discuss the weather.
Reclaiming the form from the male context is one of Deborah Butterfield's missions. Her "Untitled (2040.1)" depicts a grazing horse made from pliable, frail intertwined branches, vines and twigs -- it is astonishingly all bronze. 
As far as the young-girls-and-horses issue goes, a 4-by-7-foot photograph by Janet Biggs, called "Celeste in Her Bedroom," gives a good idea of the subject's complexity. In a separate screening room in a corner of the gallery two looping videos explore how the jolting, repetitive motion of riding a horse can make a girl have trouble controlling her body. But as the essay in the catalog says, ours is "a society still invested in the romantic myth of childhood innocence."
The real myth and magic here comes when you just let the horses tell their own stories. The spooked, rearing stallion in John Steuart Curry's "Belgian Stallions," painted in 1938 -- why is he looking eastward with such apprehension and alarm? 
Look closely at Kazuhiko Sano's acrylic of Secretariat, the painting that was made into a 33-cent stamp, and look deep into those enormous dark eyes and kick yourself for never putting some money on that horse.
Horses have the largest eyes in nature, a trait that no doubt makes a lot of people self-conscious and nervous around them (remember "Equus"?). It also makes them excellent witnesses. If only they could talk. Spend an hour or two at the Katonah Museum and you'll start to think they can.
"Horse Tales: American Images and Icons 1800-2000," through Dec. 30, the Katonah Museum of Art, Route 22 at Jay Street. (914) 232-9555.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Kazuhiko Sano's acrylic of Secretariat, the painting that was made into a 33-cent stamp, left. "The Journey XVII," far left, by Linda Lomahaftewa. "Untitled (2040.1)," below, by Deborah Butterfield. All the works are part of the exhibition "Horse Tales: American Images and Icons 1800-2000," at the Katonah Museum of Art.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Rutherford; 
A Patriotic Town With an Easy Commute

BYLINE:  By JERRY CHESLOW 

 BODY:
A GRANITE pillar capped by a flame-shaped light and carved with the words "To Rutherford's Glorious Dead" looms over the intersection of Park and Passaic Avenues, in front of the Rutherford borough hall. The monument to World War I fallen is one of a half dozen war memorials near the two-story 1901 brick structure.
 At the point of wedge-shaped Lincoln Park, 30 yards south of the pillar, a cannon points down Park Avenue, the early 20th century business district. Freshly painted red, white and blue shields bolted to its sides honor those who fought in the Civil and Spanish American Wars. Also in the park are monuments to those who died in World War II, the Korean War, Vietnam and the 1898 sinking of the battleship Maine in Havana harbor. And throughout the town, a majority of houses display American flags. 
 "We've always been a patriotic town," said Mayor Bernadette McPherson. "Even before the events of Sept. 11, it was not uncommon to see flags flying. It may have seemed corny in other places, but not here. We live by the principles behind the flag. 
"There has never been a report of a bias crime in the town. On Sept. 11, I had many calls from residents who wanted to donate blood. More policemen volunteered to go to ground zero than we could possibly send. Although our fire department is volunteer, many of these people left their jobs to stand by in case they were needed."
As its war memorials imply, Rutherford is an old town, first settled in 1687 by Waling Jacob Van Winkle, a Dutchman from New Amsterdam. It calls itself the City of Trees and lives up to its name, with more than 6,000 two-foot-thick oaks, sycamores and maples arching over Rutherford's residential streets. 
At the intersection of New Jersey Routes 3 and 17, three miles from Exit 16W of the New Jersey Turnpike, four miles from the heart of the Meadowlands sports complex and seven miles from the Lincoln Tunnel, Rutherford has less than half-hour connections to Manhattan by bus or rail.
It is one of five New Jersey municipalities designated as "transit villages" by former Gov. Christie Whitman, qualifying it for priority status for state and federal aid for infrastructure improvements. Recently, New Jersey Transit and the New Jersey Department of Transportation financed two studies on possible downtown redevelopment, which the borough administrator, Robert A. Gorman, estimates cost well over $100,000. 
Most of Rutherford's single-family housing stock is at least 50 years old and is concentrated on 40 percent of the 2.6-square-mile borough. The remainder includes a capped landfill, slated for redevelopment as a golf course, and a commercial zone with several office buildings and two hotels -- the 127-room Extended Stay America and the 163-room Marriott Renaissance.
Peter S. Van Winkle, a descendant of the town's first settler and the owner of the 135-year-old A. W. Van Winkle & Company real estate office on Orient Way, estimates that nearly 20 percent of the houses are post-World War II Cape Cods near the Passaic River, which forms the western border. The other homes are primarily 50- to 100-year-old colonials, spread throughout the town, and 19th-century Victorians concentrated on Ridge Road and its surrounding streets near the commercial center. 
In mid-October, 19 houses were listed for sale on the Multiple Listing Service. The asking prices ranged from $169,900 for a pre-World War II two-bedroom colonial on Meadow Road near Route 17 to $550,000 for a seven-bedroom, four-bath center hall colonial of a similar age on West Pierrepont Avenue on the western side of town. 
Several garden apartment complexes have been converted to co-op or condominium ownership. The largest co-op complex is the 370-unit Hastings Village on Hastings Avenue. According to Glenn D. Elliot, a broker at the ERA Justin Realty Company, studio apartments in Hastings Village go for $30,000 to $35,000, one-bedrooms for $50,000 to $55,000 and two-bedroom units for $65,000 to $70,000.
The largest condominium complex is the 136-unit Rutherford Manor, where a one-bedroom unit recently sold for $96,000 and a two-bedroom went for $125,000. There are also town-house-style condominiums in complexes like the 20-unit River Oaks Villas on Donaldson Avenue near the Passaic River, where a three-bedroom, two-and-a-half bath unit recently went for $225,000.
Rutherford has more than 1,000 rental apartments, 890 of which come under a local rent control ordinance that applies to buildings or complexes of four or more units. The largest rental complexes are the 115-unit Union Bridge Apartments and the 109-unit Willow Gardens, both on Union Avenue, which stretches for one mile from Station Square to the Passaic River. According to Violet Rycroft, the borough rent control officer, rents throughout the town range from about $600 for smaller studio apartments to $1,700 for some larger three-bedroom apartments.
AMONG the town's newer residents are Charles E. Cornelis; his wife, Sharon Breslau; and their two children, ages 2 and 4. They moved from West Hartford, Conn., to a three-bedroom 1930's colonial on Wood Street five months ago to be closer to Mr. Cornelis's job as a graphic designer in Manhattan. "We are a seven-minute walk to the train station," he explained. "We liked the tree-lined streets, the old-style architecture and the fact that we can get into Manhattan easily for recreation."
Another attraction for the Cornelis family was the Williams Center for the Arts, named for the Pulitzer Prize-winning poet William Carlos Williams, who lived in Rutherford. Located in Williams Park near the train station, the center has three movie theaters and two theatrical performance halls. Upcoming performances are "Noah's Ark" at 1 P.M. on Nov. 17 and four performances of "Annie" on Nov. 17 and 18. 
Both Mr. Elliot and Mr. Van Winkle term the local real estate market as "very hot," with many properties selling within days of being listed. According to Mr. Van Winkle, prices have climbed about 12 percent in the past year. They expect the market to grow even hotter next fall, when New Jersey Transit's Secaucus Transfer Station is opened; the project will shave nearly 10 minutes off the trip to or from Manhattan by allowing train passengers to travel directly from Rutherford into Pennsylvania Station, rather than switching to the PATH train in Hoboken. 
"I would not be surprised if we saw a further 15 percent appreciation in housing prices because of the improved commute," Mr. Van Winkle said.
The borough's street pattern -- with Park Avenue slicing diagonally through a grid -- was laid out in 1866 by Daniel Van Winkle, Peter's great-great-grandfather, when he donated a tract of land to the Erie Railroad Company for the construction of the first train station.
A later station, built on the same plot of land in 1898 and restored by New Jersey Transit, stretches for three blocks across Station Square at the foot of Park Avenue, anchoring the downtown. With "Erie Railroad" chiseled into its stone lintel, the station, which is listed on the National Register of Historic Places, is the core of an ongoing downtown redevelopment effort. The borough is replacing cracked sidewalks with brick pavers, installing Victorian-style street lamps and giving financial incentives to business owners who upgrade their tired, sooty, turn-of-the-century storefronts. The mix of stores in the downtown includes numerous nail salons, a few clothing shops, a western wear store and Fun-Ghoul, a large supplier of theatrical costumes.
Rutherford's numerous restaurants, including Mignon (steakhouse), Paisano's (Italian), Cafe Mattise (French) and Trattoria Corrado (Italian) on Station Square, are "dry" because of a local ordinance that prohibits the serving of alcoholic beverages at commercial establishments. The closest major mall is the Garden State Plaza in Paramus, seven miles to the northwest.
The largest new development is the recently completed five-story Boiling Springs Savings Bank headquarters on Orient Way, a stone's throw from the station. The bank has also started foundation work for a 500-space parking garage, a 48-unit apartment building and a second office building.
Among Rutherford's attractions is its 2,350-pupil public school system, consisting of three K-5 schools, two K-8 schools and the 710-student Rutherford High School. Although all of the school buildings were built between 1913 and 1927, they are well maintained. Class sizes range from 18 and 22, compared with a statewide average of 21.4.
The superintendent of schools, Leslie A. Conlon, said all classrooms in the district have at least one computer, with computer instruction starting in kindergarten. Foreign language instruction is introduced in second grade and instrumental music in fourth grade.
On College Board tests, last year's graduating class scored a combined verbal and mathematics average of 1,032, compared with a state average of 1,012. Of the 153 graduates, 72 percent went on to four-year colleges and 16 percent to two-year institutions.
LAST year, Rutherford High School won the coveted United States Department of Education Blue Ribbon School of Excellence award. "We were recognized for our overall focus on technology," Ms. Conlon explained.
Every room in the high school is wired for Internet access, compared with a state average of 74 percent. There is one computer for every 2.9 students, compared with one for every 4.8 students statewide.
In addition, Rutherford High has its own television studio and offers special courses from Cisco Academy, a course of study intended to prepare students for jobs at the networking giant Cisco Systems. Rutherford High offers seven advanced placement courses in English, foreign languages, history, biology, computer science and art. It also offers college-level courses in cooperation with Fairleigh Dickinson University in nearby Teaneck.
Other schools in the borough include St. Mary's School, a K-12 coeducational Roman Catholic school, and one of the two campuses of Felician College, a coed four-year Roman Catholic institution with 1,600 students.
The largest park in Rutherford is the 30-acre Memorial Park off Union Avenue along the Passaic River. It has three baseball diamonds and four softball diamonds, a Little League field, a football stadium, five tennis courts, two basketball courts and three playgrounds, one of which, Katie's Corner, was recently refurbished through contributions in memory of a local girl who died in a fire. 
Another important recreational facility is the Nereid Boat Club off Riverside Avenue along the Passaic. Established in 1875 in Nutley, N.J., the club relocated to a town-owned building in Rutherford five years ago and restored the dilapidated structure. Rutherford residents can join the rowing club for $75 annually. Nonresidents pay $450 a year.

HEADLINE: Suffolk Is at Odds Over Tobacco Money 

BYLINE:  By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
A PROPOSAL by Robert J. Gaffney, the Suffolk County executive, to sell the rights to the county's share of the national tobacco settlement -- using the money to pay off debt, hold down property taxes and stave off a $37.7 million budget shortfall next year -- is facing opposition from county legislators who say it all sounds too much like a Nassau County-style scheme.
 Mr. Gaffney, a Republican who has curried a reputation as a fiscal conservative, and Kenneth Weiss, his budget director, contend that the plan is financially sound and merely duplicates what municipalities across the state and country have already done. And, they add, it would shift the risks and uncertainties about future tobacco payments from the county to private investors. 
 Detractors point to an analysis by the County Legislature's Budget Review Office, which says that benefits would be quick but temporary and long-term costs would be high. 
That analysis shows that under Mr. Gaffney's proposal the county would reduce debt by $354 million from 2002 to 2030, the plan's time span. But that amount would be $234 million less than the $588 million in tobacco revenues the county would otherwise receive.
The Gaffney plan is structured so that greatest benefits would come in the period from 2002 to 2009. But after that time, according to the analysis, the plan would become progressively more expensive.
Since 1999, New York City, Nassau County and more than half of all other counties in the state have sold the rights to their tobacco revenues, a process called securitization. Nationally, more than $6.5 billion in securitization bonds have already been marketed, principally to institutional investors, and most experts say conditions are ripe for more.
Under the Suffolk plan, a variation of those used elsewhere, Mr. Gaffney would establish a corporation to sell bonds to private investors. The bonds would be backed by the tobacco settlement revenues, which would go directly to the corporation.
The county would use the money to reduce long-term debt, indirectly freeing money for other purposes.
The tobacco revenues come from a settlement reached in November 1998 between 46 states and the major tobacco companies. The companies agreed to make long-term payments to the governments, and in return, the states agreed not to sue the companies for smoking-related injuries. In New York, settlement payments to counties are pegged to Medicaid costs; next year, Suffolk's share is projected at $23.7 million.
In Suffolk the more immediate problem is making up for the shortfall that is expected in sales-tax receipts, the backbone of county budgets. Mr. Weiss put the shortfall at $37.7 million in the county's proposed $1.2 billion budget for 2002 after the figures were revised following the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
He said the lower estimate on sales taxes and the fact that the proposed budget already called for an increase in property taxes of nearly 9 percent led county officials to turn to securitization. Securitization had been under consideration for future budgets, he said, but was moved to the forefront after Sept. 11.
But the proposal has not been well received by some legislators. Under the proposal, the County Legislature would be asked to approve a local law creating the corporation to sell the bonds. It will also get to approve the proposed budget.
The chairman of the Legislature's finance committee, Michael Caracciolo, a Republican from Wading River, said the short-term benefits of securitization were far outweighed by its high long-term costs.
"This is clearly the path we do not want to go down," said Mr. Caracciolo, who added that the Legislature should look for other ways to fill the budget gap. "We must avoid at all costs the type of financial gimmickry that was exercised in Nassau County and resulted in that county's having junk-bond status."
Mr. Weiss, the budget director, said that such a comparison was mistaken. He said the Gaffney administration had waited to see how securitization worked in other counties and states and was now convinced that it was a sound practice.
"Tobacco securitization is not some new invention," he said. "It's nothing that Suffolk County has decided to undertake on its own. It isn't experimental." 
Frederick Pollert, director of the County Legislature's Budget Review Office, said the approach still had major drawbacks for Suffolk.
"What really happens is that we borrow against the future revenue stream, and we accelerate the revenues for the time period from 2002 to 2009 so there is a net budget saving over that time," he said. "But then on the back end, it is costing us money in all those years that follow."
Mr. Pollert said the interest on the bonds, which would be about 5.5 percent, made tobacco securitization "an extraordinarily expensive source of capital." If the county simply issued short-term notes, the interest rate would be about 2 percent, he said.
Mr. Pollert has advised the legislators that another method for closing the projected $37.7 million shortfall would be to rescind the county's sales-tax exemption on clothing and footwear costing less than $110.
The exemption, which was approved by the Legislature and put into effect in March 2000, resulted in a revenue loss of $29 million that year and $24.7 million for the first half of this year. 
But the exemption has been popular with retailers and shoppers, and legislators may balk at rescinding it. "That I would totally reject," Mr. Caracciolo said. 
Mr. Weiss said securitization would help the county meet sharply rising social-service costs attributed to the weakening economy. Dennis J. Nowak, a spokesman for the county Department of Social Services, confirmed that costs and caseloads were up for Medicaid, foster care and the homeless. 
The number of families in emergency housing has risen from 249 in 1999 to 474 last week, Mr. Nowak said, topping a previous peak in 1994. Projected costs for 2002 are $29.2 million, nearly twice this year's total. He attributed rising homelessness to a shortage of affordable housing; rent for a two-bedroom apartment is currently about $1,200 a month.
Mr. Weiss said the county also faced increased police and emergency-service costs after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. 
Supporters of securitization say its greatest benefit may be that it protects governments against the risks of tobacco company bankruptcies or legal challenges to the settlement plan that could reduce revenues in the future.
In 1999, a number of New York cities and counties issued settlement-backed bonds: New York City, $709.3 million; Nassau, $294.5 million; and Westchester, $103.5 million. Several New York counties, operating a pool to cut administrative and underwriting costs, issued similar bonds for $117.1 million last December, and in March, the State of South Carolina issued bonds for $934.5 million. New York State has not yet taken the step.
In Nassau, proceeds from securitization were consumed in one budget year, in contrast to the Suffolk plan, which would stretch out the benefits.
Robert R. Gregory, executive director of the New York State Association of Counties, said he expected more counties to use securitization.
"The basic question is, do they want to continue with the inherent risks involved in the master settlement agreement or get out from under that liability?" he said. "Everyone on the market side will tell you the market has a certain appetite for these kinds of bonds."
Mr. Caracciolo said last week that he did not expect the Suffolk Legislature to approve the Gaffney plan. "I believe we pretty much put the nail in the coffin on that -- at least I hope so," he said. "Now we have to look for alternatives."
The county has until Nov. 20 to adopt a budget, with or without securitization.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Kenneth Weiss, Suffolk's budget director, left, backs using tobacco-settlement money to reduce county debt and close a budget gap. Michael Caracciolo, a county legislator, top left, opposes the proposal. (Photographs by Deirdre Brennan for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/Changes at the Top?; 
Unaccustomed Vulnerability in the Luxury Market

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
DURING the two weeks after the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center, the suburban real estate market around Manhattan ground to a halt. "We were numb" is a phrase heard repeatedly. Since then the lower and middle range markets have returned to some semblance of normalcy, but the top of the luxury market, traditionally impervious to economic conditions, has begun to show unaccustomed vulnerability. 
 Now, in the aftermath of a cataclysmic event landing on the back of a faltering economy, brokers in the elite communities where a preponderance of financial and corporate executives choose to live are concerned about the impact on that rich source of clients. 
 Of all such areas, Fairfield County appears to be most susceptible to a downturn because of the quantum leap in the numbers and prices of trophy homes built there in the 90's, compared with the older established suburbs of Long Island, Westchester and New Jersey. 
In Greenwich, the most resilient of wealthy communities because of a substantial number of very high priced homes, Linda Hodge, vice president of Preferred Properties, a Greenwich-based company that specializes in estates that can exceed $25 million, said demand seems to have decreased but has not totally dried up. 
"I've shown an $8.5 million house three times," she said in a telephone interview conducted while "I'm sitting in a $10.5 million house waiting for my customer to show up."
"Activity is there," she said, "but it's an unnatural world, and it remains to be seen how consumer confidence shapes up over the next selling season. Customers are looking for some relief in prices, but it's too soon to evaluate." 
For years she has watched as high-end sellers spurned requests for concessions. "The inherent value of the property is something they are not willing to forgo," she said. "They can just wait. So the high end is insulated to some extent, but the ripple effect is there."
Assessing where the current market stands and what lies ahead, Nicholas S. Perna, former chief economist at Fleet Financial Group, currently head of Perna Associates, an economic consulting firm in Ridgefield, and a member of the economics faculty at Yale, said: "Apart from Sept. 11 there were forces already at work that were going to take the wind out of the sails of high-end homes.
"Corporate profits have declined deeper than they have in 50 years, so a lot of those year-end bonuses that many of these people leverage to live on are not going to be there. To me it's inevitable that the economy and Sept. 11, which aggravated those economic forces, will act as a depressant on the sale of high-end real estate."
While activity is normally a bit slower this time of year, Joan Gallagher, manager of the Preferred Properties office in Darien, said: "In all honesty, Sept. 11 has affected everyone and everything. We still have sales, but there isn't much confidence. There's hesitation that's affecting the high end, and even though interest rates are low, people dealing with the big numbers are unsure." In the $2 million to $10 million market segment, " there have been reductions in prices, but no great bargains," she said. "Houses are staying on the market longer because people feel prices will go down further."
"We are turning from a seller's to a buyer's market," she said.
According to Marcia Charles, a broker in the company's New Canaan office, where upper end homes sell for $2.5 million to $5 million, "our job market is more diversified -- people work at UBS Warburg and GE Capital here in Fairfield County, so I think Darien and Greenwich may be seeing a bigger impact." The difference in population makeup is attributable in part to Wall Street commuters, who may prefer coastline communities like Greenwich and Darien, where they do not have to change trains at Stamford, as New Canaan commuters do. 
BUT, Ms. Charles said: "I have to say that new construction between $2 million and $5 million has been slow. We have had about 16 new homes on the market for several months, and we have seen reductions in houses that have been on for a while. I think builders who don't get their price for new construction will wait until the spring market."
One former New Yorker who owns a financial services company with offices in the Mercantile Exchange Building, a block from the World Trade Center site, is moving his family and his business to Greenwich. His offices were damaged, "but we were cushioned by the American Express building, and we went back to work the following Monday," said the executive, who talked on the condition that his company not be identified. Last May he made a down payment of more than $3 million on a 14,000-square-foot house now under construction on three acres in Greenwich, where he and his family have been renting. The house will be ready for occupancy in January. 
"It's a big purchase," he said. "I can't back out, and I'm frightened of where the market is going." Recalling a market downturn that followed the stock market plunge 14 years ago, he said: "Back in '87, real estate didn't start coming down until '89. I expect it to happen again. The bubble hasn't burst yet because everyone thinks their houses will go on being worth $ X million." 
Soon he will move his offices to Greenwich or a nearby town. "I've had enough of downtown and commuting," he said. "Some of my colleagues had meetings in the World Trade Center that day and didn't make it. Going down there every day reminds you of the death and destruction. It's kind of a sad place to work."
But there have not been enough corporate relocations yet to produce a flood of house shoppers. James Fieber, head of the Fieber Group, developers of upscale housing in Connecticut and Texas, said, "Traffic has slowed considerably, but we are getting more bona fide buyers at our New Canaan, Greenwich and Orange sites."
In other areas reactions are somewhat more positive. Homes for sale in Rye, N.Y., priced up to $6.4 million from before the terrorist attack, "don't fly off the market," said Martha Bentley, manager of the real estate firm Merritt Associates, "but an initial slack-off following Sept. 11 seems to have ended. Four homes priced over $1 million and one at $3 million sold almost immediately."
In Scarsdale, Lynne Clark, vice president of Julia B. Fee Real Estate, said: "Three houses are on the market at $5 million, and 11 houses, started on spec before Sept. 11, are still under construction, priced over $1 million. We haven't had a stampede, but I feel our market is quite stable."
ON Long Island, Joan Nahles, manager of Daniel Gale Real Estate in Manhasset, said: "This is a big Wall Street town, hit very hard with at least 40 deaths out of a population of 25,000. Certainly, one or two buyers wanted to wait, but sales of $900,000 and up are strong. We've seen some reduction in price, but we still have buyers anxious to get what they want and willing to pay for it.
"Property remains constant," she continued, "unlike the stock market. Sellers have doubled and tripled their money."
David Lurie, head of Lurie Real Estate in Great Neck Estates on Long Island, said: "A large number of wealthy Iranian families are in the area, where homes are priced from half a million to around $2.2 million. Prices are holding up, but we are not getting the calls we used to get for high-end houses, so I assume that in the near future prices will start to fall."
In Basking Ridge, a village within Bernards Township, N.J., Elsa Lisciandro, manager of the Weichert Real Estate office said: "The village lost 11 people. You could not call your clients. It didn't seem appropriate. Then, all of a sudden they started calling us. Some people are relocating out of New York and some are local upgrades. I've been in the business for 25 years, and I'd say we're going into a normal market."
But while Maggie Schimts, manager of Bergdorf ERA in Bernards Township, finds that interest in million dollar houses is coupled with a reluctance to buy. "It's more difficult to get them into a contract," she said. "There is the uncertainty about jobs and bonuses."
A Bernards Township developer, Bruce Bocina, lost three customers who worked for Cantor Fitzgerald at the World Trade Center and had binders on million dollar homes. "A lot of people in this area work in Lower Manhattan," he said. "There is a tremendous residual effect. Obviously, it has affected our business, although now there are other people looking from Manhattan, and local people who are upgrading."
He continues to complete sales of houses priced from $750,000 to $3 million. "Some have been sold; some will come on the market in December," he said. "We hope customers will be buying."
Mr. Perna, the economist, said, "The good news is that unlike 10 years ago, when the recession in the Northeast was far worse than in the rest of the country and prices fell precipitously, there is no reason for our recession to be appreciably worse than it is anywhere else."

An article last Sunday about the luxury home market described train service from New Canaan incompletely. Not all Metro-North commuters to New York have to change at Stamford; several trains a day in each direction are direct. A picture caption with the article misstated the price and ownership of a new house in Greenwich. It was built for its owner at a price of $8 million; it is not on the market for more than $7 million.
