HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Retail Leasing; 
At a Rockefeller Store, It's All Pokemon, All the Time

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
BUGS BUNNY is leaving town and Mickey Mouse has retreated from Times Square. But that's O.K.; Pikachu is moving into Rockefeller Center.
 The American branch of the Pokemon Company of Japan, which manages the rights to Pokemon cartoons, games and collectible figures, is expecting to open its first retail outlet later this month at 10 Rockefeller Plaza, on 48th Street between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas. The 17,000-square-foot store will have two retail levels and extensive interactive displays intended to appeal to children who watch the animated cartoons on television and play the games on specialized display toys. 
 Even though the Pokemon phenomenon has lost some momentum in the United States, company executives still see a viable market for the toys and games. The worldwide business had revenue of $4.3 billion in the most recent year, and the cartoons are broadcast in 65 countries in 30 different languages. The store is scheduled to open on Nov. 16. 
The move into New York by Pokemon comes at a time when stores operated by entertainment companies, like Warner Brothers and Disney, have faded in appeal. Warner Brothers, which sold souvenirs and clothing emblazoned with images of Bugs Bunny, Tweety Bird and other cartoon characters, closed its flagship store at 57th Street and Fifth Avenue last year and closed the smaller one in Times Square last month.
Disney's store in Times Square, which sold similar merchandise with depictions of Mickey Mouse, Minnie Mouse and cartoon characters from its library of films, was displaced by new construction last year, and real estate executives report that sales have softened at its Fifth Avenue store.
Nevertheless, some brokers who specialize in retail space say the Pokemon store could buck this trend because it is new to the city and is in a place that attracts both local traffic and international travelers. Indeed, some think it can provide a place where parents can take their children and escape for a little while from the aftermath of the attacks on the World Trade Center.
"Warner Brothers got tired and worn," said Alan Victor, an executive vice president of the Lansco Corporation, a brokerage company that represents retailers. "They didn't make the movies to back up the stores. There was no reason for people to go back to the stores." He added that Disney's stores appeared to be having a similar problem.
He said the Pokemon Center, as it is officially called, would be opening in a soft retail environment caused by the slowing national economy and the reduced numbers of tourists, as people have cut back on travel since Sept. 11.
Nevertheless, he said, Rockefeller Center is one of the best known landmarks in the world, with NBC's "Today" show broadcasting from there and with holiday season events set to open soon. "NBC brings a lot of traffic, and who knows how many people will go there to see the Christmas tree and the show at Radio City Music Hall," he said. "If they can keep their merchandise fresh, they could do well."
Pokemon's timing is just about right, said Faith H. Consolo, vice chairwoman of Garrick-Aug Associates, another broker specializing in retail space. "Warner Brothers and Disney were about things, T-shirts and teddy bears," she said. "Pokemon is more about entertainment. It is a fantasy store that is almost like going to the movies."
Sales of game-oriented electronic goods have increased since the attacks, Ms. Consolo said, indicating that people are seeking fantasy and an escape from reality. The Pokemon store, she said, "will be like visiting an old-time arcade."
Executives of Pokemon USA and their store designers are emphasizing entertainment and tie-ins with existing cartoons, games and figures. The store will be the only one in the United States devoted entirely to Pokemon products, and 40 percent of the merchandise will be available only at the store, the executives said. There are two similar stores in Japan.
Writers and cartoonists for Pokemon -- the word is a Japanese contraction of "pocket monster" -- are constantly inventing characters to use in the cartoons and games and to provide new objects for parents to buy. According to David Hillenbrand, general manager of Pokemon USA, there are 251 Pokemon characters, up from 151 a year ago. Pikachu, by the way, is the favorite creature of Ash Ketchum, the lead character in the series.
Because Rockefeller Center is a designated landmark, the store's design had to work within a tight set of rules imposed by the Landmarks Preservation Commission and the complex's manager, Tishman Speyer Properties. For instance, the store could not have any exterior signs.
"This is a 1937 Art Deco masterpiece, and we have gone back to the original drawings and articles about it to get the details right," said Alec Zaballero, an associate at the Phillips Group, the architects for the renovation of the store space, which was most recently a microbrewery.
Fortunately, the building, which is just south of where the "Today" show is broadcast, is encased on two sides with glass. Mr. Zaballero said the glass in the top-level panels appeared to be part of the original facade. Having the glass walls reduces the need for signs because the brightly lit interior is ample advertising for passers-by.
The new doors to the store are brass, in keeping with Rockefeller Center tradition, and the door pulls duplicate the pattern of the originals, Mr. Zaballero said. "We have had to blend a 21st-century store into a 1937 building," he said.
Pokemon is renting the ground floor, a mezzanine and a lower level, which will be used for storage. The two retail floors will be connected by a glass-enclosed elevator in addition to a staircase. Real estate executives said first-floor space in Rockefeller Center rented for about $250 a square foot, with mezzanine space costing about half that and the lower level about $50 a square foot.
The upper floor will be equipped with three domes, each illuminated by light-emitting diodes capable of generating millions of different shades of color. There will be a sound and light show every hour that will feature a large Poke ball -- in the cartoon, children are supposed to carry their creatures in hand-held Poke balls. The suspended ball will spin and then split open, emitting smoke and laser light.
I T is going to be a choreographic experience," Mr. Zaballero said. "The kids will see an animated cartoon come to life; it won't just be on television anymore."
Because children are the main audience, Mr. Zaballero said Phillips Group designers scaled the store for the short of stature. "We've spent a lot of time looking at things from the three- to four-foot level," he said. "The equipment is designed for kids' comfort."
That equipment includes an interactive device called the Ultra Pokedex, which contains the database of the Pokemon world. Included are statistics about the various characters and video clips of them in action that can be called up using a touch screen. Children can also test new games before deciding whether to buy them.
The space will also be furnished by replicas of Pokemon characters, sized as they are in the Pokemon world, from a foot-tall Pichu to a Charizard that is six feet tall. The characters will move and act as they do in the cartoons, games and videos. Over all, Pokemon executives said, only about 20 percent of the space in the store will be dedicated to retail sales.
The basic strategy is to make the store a continuing and often changing show, Mr. Hillenbrand said. "The lights are visible from Fifth Avenue, and they will tend to draw people inside," he said. "We want to create an event, not just a one-time shopping experience. We want people to have a reason to come back." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: The new Pokemon store is to open this month at 10 Rockefeller Plaza, on 48th Street between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: York, Me., Tackles Commercial Demand 

BYLINE:  By DAVID J. WALLACE

DATELINE: YORK, Me. 

 BODY:
Year-round residents of bucolic New England towns have a well-founded fear that vacation homes and weekend visitors will slowly change their local economy and culture. They worry that restaurants will force out supermarkets and antiques dealers will displace hardware stores or other shops that offer staple items.
 The citizens of this historic seaside town have voted three times since 1999 to limit residential construction, but the area's commercial growth has presented another challenge. Some activists have called for replacing stores with homes. Office and industrial space is limited, concentrated along Route 1 -- the two-lane primary north-south artery -- and has spawned traffic congestion that lasts even after summer tourists go home. 
 Demand for commercial space, some of it from residents who want to open businesses in their homes or nearby, poses an unusual urban planning problem in this town of 14,000 about 15 miles north of the New Hampshire border. Much of the town sits atop wetlands and some longtime residents worry about how development will coexist with rocky beaches, beautiful creeks and the 17th-century York Village. 
York's five-person planning department has been overmatched, leading to stacks of blueprints at Town Hall awaiting even the most rudimentary review. Delays have stretched as long as two years for developers to get approval from neighbors and regulatory agencies, arrange financing and start construction.
One of the town's largest new corporate offices, however, got public support instead of opposition. When a large chain hotel was proposed for a prominent piece of state-owned land several years ago, the town intervened to support Stonewall Kitchen, an upscale food purveyor that was scouting for a new headquarters in the area. In April 2000, the company, which had its start at nearby farmer's markets, opened a headquarters, outlet store and production complex that draws thousands of tourists each year.
Jonathan King and Jim Stott, Stonewall's owners, have based the company in York since 1995 and in neighboring Kittery, Me., before that. The headquarters store is expected to have sales of $3 million this year, Mr. King said, and the number of visitors has surpassed expectations.
Instead of a hotel tower, a farmhouse-style structure lavishly surrounded with flowers and birch trees now sits at York's gateway intersection of Route 1 and an off-ramp from Interstate 95. Visitors relax in Adirondack chairs under pergolas out of sight of passing cars, and plans have been approved for a 70-seat cafe.
"We wanted to build a brand, not just a new plant," Mr. Stott said. "It was important to us to make this a showplace." He pointed out such details as a pressed tin ceiling and sliding barn doors that separate the test kitchen from a conference room.
Stonewall invested nearly $8 million in the 55,000-square-foot faux farmhouse with rooflines of varying heights. Distinctive features inside and out increased the price by about $1 million over the original budget. The town offered a $3.5 million industrial revenue bond at a 3.5 percent interest rate to help the project as well as a $400,000 grant, with the balance coming from the company's founders and investors.
Other start-up companies have found a shortage of commercial space, said Steve Burns, the town planner. Demand for commercial space, he said, is slower and steadier than for residential and more fluid as merchants enter and leave the area. The town's commercial users are storage facilities and light industrial tenants, like woodworking shops. No study has addressed the town's maximum commercial capacity. 
On the residential side, more than 1,000 new housing units have been built since 1990 and requests for 130 new housing units per year have made this Maine's second-fastest growing town. "The sentiment here is antigrowth," Mr. Burns said, "but you can't stop it. It's a fundamental fairness issue for people who own property and we've never had an external control like the limits of a water, sewer or school system." 
Mr. Burns estimates that the town's population of 14,000 doubles when overnight guests are included in the summer peak season and may actually triple when daily visitors are counted. Only a 90-minute drive north from Boston, the town attracts home buyers who work in the suburban Route 128 technology corridor.
Empty-nest retirees are a large constituency in York, but they compete for home sites with a growing number of entrepreneurs who run businesses from home.
Andrew Siegel and his brother, Ron, own the When Pigs Fly Bakery, a bread maker that expanded this summer to 25,000 square feet of production space, with a retail store. The 50-employee company sells bread as far south as New Jersey, thanks to a location close to Interstate 95. The brothers, who grew up in nearby Wells, Me., started the company in 1993 and scouted the current site for years waiting for the chance to expand. "You couldn't find this kind of space in Boston," Andrew Siegel said. "And York is a family-oriented community. You can build a nice house here and be close to the ocean." 
York is a 55-square-mile territory -- nearly as big as Boston -- ranging from seaside cliffs to hilly interior land near creeks, ponds and reservoirs. In its 300-year history, several independent towns and villages have been combined, merging their various personalities: the beachfront motels, the Route 1 commercial corridor, the historically protected area and inland homes on heavily wooded property. Most homes have septic systems, and a recent survey estimated that 4,000 new homes could be built before usable sites were exhausted.
Mr. Burns said he feared the loss of York's traditional New England village pattern of land use, where Main Street stores have apartments above them and sit alongside libraries, churches or gas stations. He said he hoped the town could avoid modern zoning standards that concentrate residential, commercial and industrial land in discrete sections. Many residents operate small businesses from their homes and may have trucks, small craft shops or assembly operations in their garages.
The town has strict zoning requirements that make fast-food restaurants impossible. Meanwhile, culinary destinations like Stonewall Kitchen, along with other shops that sell pies and baked goods, have caused growing pains. Stonewall rents warehouse space in town and relies on local suppliers like as Carpe Diem Coffee Roasters.
"We employ 175 full-time people in slow season and 400 in our fourth quarter," Mr. King of Stonewall said. "But York County has no tax incentives and there's an unemployment rate here of 1.5 percent. We wanted to stay in Maine. To say 'Made in Maine' is a lure for our buyers." 
Last year, the Chamber of Commerce created the Government Affairs Steering Committee at the request of members concerned by antibusiness sentiment. One resident even proposed eliminating all businesses over time by requiring that property be converted to residential use when the current owner either retired or sold the site. Cathy Goodwin, the organization's executive director, said her group might develop an alternative.
Among the blueprints awaiting review at Town Hall is a proposal for 16 small workshops, complete with small offices and truck bays near Route 1. These could provide rented 30-foot-by-40-foot spaces for companies that are too big for home but too small for most industrial facilities.
Michael Conlon, a real estate broker at Century 21 Atlantic Realty, conceded that traffic has got progressively worse in his 15 years in the business but said that few developers have given up on their projects.
He said that the town just got its first large grocery store, while losing a smaller rival that had beaten back several attempts at competition, an indicator that both retail and commercial real estate follow quickly behind home construction. "It's been a case of supply and demand," Mr. Conlon said. "Commercial growth has come along with the increased population."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Stonewall Kitchen's production, retail and headquarters complex. (Herb Swanson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/25 to 41 Harrison Street; 
A Historic Renovation Improving With Age

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER GRAY 

 BODY:
BUILT almost two centuries ago, the simple brick houses at 25 to 41 Harrison Street were singled out for preservation in the 1960's in an urban renewal district in which hundreds of 19th-century industrial buildings were demolished. At first, this peculiar little enclave, in the shadow of the giant Independence Plaza housing project, had a synthetic character, but the passage of time has gradually added the patina of age.
 The area north of Chambers Street along Hudson, Greenwich and Washington Streets boomed with residential construction in the late 1700's and early 1800's, especially around the time City Hall was being built at Chambers and Centre Streets, in 1802 to 1812. Just south of Jay Street, Jonas Wood, a merchant, built a house at 314 Washington Street in 1804, across from the 1796 house at 317 Washington Street of John McComb Jr., who designed City Hall with Joseph Mangin. 
 A block north, at the southeast corner of Washington and Harrison Streets, row house construction peaked in the late 1820's, when different owners put up six chaste Federal-style houses at 29 to 33 Harrison Street and 327 to 331 Washington Street. These owners were also prosperous, like Wilson Hunt, a Pearl Street dry goods merchant, who built 327 Washington Street (now 41 Harrison Street, reflecting a renaming of that segment of Washington Street), and Ebenezer Miller, a Greenwich Street printer, who built 33 Harrison Street. 
Elite development continued to move north and toward the center of Manhattan, but by the 1850's two of the original six families were still in occupancy. But after the Civil War all the houses fell several rungs on the social ladder -- the 1870 census indicates that 31 and 33 Harrison Street had been combined into a single boarding house with 20 tenants, mostly foreign-born workers.
By the 1890's few people lived in the houses -- the lower west side had become the largest market area in New York, and the lofts and warehouses in what is now TriBeCa were also going up on the blocks west of Greenwich Street. But somehow the 314 and 317 Washington Street houses survived, as well as the six houses at the corner of Harrison and Washington Streets.
The 1893 King's Handbook of New York City described the market area as "a scene of wonderful animation and interest, crowded by myriads of purchasers, amid the flaring of oil torches, the shouts of the vendors, the strange commingled smells of the fruits and meats and countless other oddities."
By 1930, the fine plasterwork and mantels of Mr. Miller's house at 33 Harrison Street had been torn out and it was occupied by the Columbus Celery Company. And Mr. McComb's house had been similarly altered, occupied by the produce merchants Silverblank & Arbeiter. Although the houses had lost their ground floor facades, most of them retained their slim dormers and peaked roofs.
The 1939 W.P.A. Guide to New York City praised the "rude vitality" of the district, especially during its usual nighttime operations: "A weird spatter of lights provides illumination, and in the glow truck drivers, farmers, tally keepers and inspectors work at a swift pace. In winter, the streets are lined with bonfires around which the men warm themselves."
At the same time that the World Trade Center was being built, from 1969 to 1973, a wide swath of buildings north of Chambers Street along the Hudson River was being cleared for the Washington Market Urban Renewal Area. The young Landmarks Preservation Commission identified as worthy of preservation the six houses on Harrison and Washington Streets, plus the McComb and Wood houses, and also 315 Washington Street (also designed by Mr. McComb). The late 19th-century brick and stone industrial buildings west of Greenwich Street were considered of minor interest and were demolished, although in the 1990's the commission designated four TriBeCa Historic Districts, east of Greenwich Street, which had very similar buildings.
THE architects Oppenheimer, Brady & Vogelstein and John Pruyn designed the overpowering 40-story Independence Plaza North on Greenwich Street from Duane to North Moore Streets. The three Washington Street buildings were relocated to the east end of the Harrison Street row, making six houses facing Harrison Street in all. Herbert Oppenheimer says the ground floors of the houses had been heavily altered or destroyed during their period of commercial use, and so the doorways, windows and lower facades were almost all new. He says the contractors sandblasted the replacement brick to age it, but "we didn't want it to match perfectly."
But the rebuilt exteriors, completed in 1975, struck a tinny note. Paul Goldberger, writing in his 1979 book "The City Observed: New York," criticized the recreation of the long-vanished residential character of the buildings, compared with the vitality of the commercial area of TriBeCa. "There are facades at Disneyland that look more real, and all that these houses make you want to do is run back again across Greenwich Street where old buildings are still real and not kept alive by artificial respirator," he said.
But when the city put the houses on sale, many people were eager to buy. "My husband and I liked to walk down to this area; we used to dream about what it had been like," said Eugenia Wiener, who had been living on 20th Street with her husband, Norman. "But one day the whole place was leveled, except for these houses." The city offered the houses for sale, with unfinished interiors, for $35,000 to $75,000, and began transferring title in 1976.
Most of Washington Street in this section was destroyed, except for a Belgian block section just south of Harrison Street, and Mr. Oppenheimer's firm created an L-shaped court reaching around to the back of the houses.
Now, more than two decades later, the renovation of 1975 is beginning to show its age. At 27 Harrison Street, the old McComb house, the architect Gregory Talmont designed a new slate roof, finished earlier this year, to replace the old wooden one. At 25 Harrison Street, the old Wood house, Barrie Mandel says she has to replace her rotting clapboard side wall. Ms. Mandel, a real estate broker at the Corcoran Group, says that she would have preferred to have a real brick wall but that -- because of limited width -- "it would have to be those fake bricks, which I dislike" so she is retaining the clapboard.
Scott Frances, a photographer, moved into 31 Harrison Street with his mother and father when he was 21, and now owns it. He says that, by modern preservation standards, much of the exterior restoration was crude and unconvincing. But he likes the picturesque, relaxed character of the enclave.
"My kids have been born and raised here," he said. "You can let them play in the back and watch them from your kitchen window. It's not like the rest of New York City." 
Mr. Frances also says that his view of the buildings has changed over the decades, as the new material has weathered. "The houses have gained in age over 25 years," he said. "Now they look old again. It's a question of time, and patina."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Rebuilt brick row houses, above, along Harrison Street. At left, a 1940's nighttime view shows some of the Harrison Street buildings, to the left in the photograph, in their commercial days. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times; Milstein Division, New York Public Library)

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
A Costly Home Away From Home

BYLINE:  By ALINA TUGEND 

 BODY:
WHEN Anders and Yvonne Iversen transferred to Larchmont from London last year, they were told they could spend up to $3,700 a month on rent, and the company would pick up 75 percent of the cost.
 After scouring southern Westchester, the Iversens came to the conclusion that there was nothing at that price that would suit their family of four and asked for an increase to $5,000 a month. 
 With that, they were able to rent a four-bedroom house in Larchmont.
"When I first came over here, I was expecting a big house," Ms. Iversen said. "After seeing a few houses I was just happy to get one in good condition. We saw some awful ones." 
The Iversens got off fairly cheaply, according to relocation experts. Rent for a family of five in the Westchester area starts at $5,000 and goes up, said Sylvia Ehrlich, a partner in the Manhattan-based relocation firm Intrepid New York.
In Westchester, where there are usually few rentals available and many people looking, anecdotal evidence suggests that company subsidies to executives from abroad and other corporate transferees are skewing rents.
"There's no question the expat community drives up the rental market," said Ms. Ehrlich, whose company helps relocate about 350 to 450 people annually. Her company's services include finding housing, schools, child care and financial services.
She said that while Westchester is a sought-after location, it also is "one of the hardest places to find single-family homes in good shape; in a given day, we may only have three houses to show in Westchester." 
A list of available rentals in southern Westchester in October showed prices ranging from $2,200 for a 1,100-square-foot place in Mamaroneck to $9,000 for a 4,000-square-foot home in Rye.
It's not just people moving from overseas who are driving rents up -- people relocating within the United States can also arrive backed by generous relocation packages. 
"Nearly 50 percent of all foreign and domestic corporate relocations are renters instead of buyers," said Elizabeth Nunan, vice president of relocation for the real estate firm of Houlihan Lawrence. She relocates more than 1,000 families a year in the tristate area. 
Ms. Nunan attributed the high number of transferring workers seeking rentals to the decline in company-owned housing. Most companies have sold off such property, she said, because it was too costly to maintain.
Companies also are very wary of allowing their transferring employees to buy homes for the short term -- typically three to five years -- while they are in the country, Ms. Ehrlich said, because the costs associated with buying, like closing fees and mortgage costs can be "infinitely higher" than renting. The employee also usually remains unsettled and in temporary housing for an extensive period of time, she said, because the buying process usually takes much longer than finding a house to rent. 
While some companies offer employees the same resettlement package whether they buy or rent, others punish employees who choose to buy instead of renting by cutting their monthly housing stipend in half, Ms. Ehrlich said. Or companies may agree to the same monthly stipend but refuse to pay the associated costs of buying a house. Also, the pool of rental properties has decreased substantially over the last two decades, Ms. Ehrlich said, because new tax laws made owning rental property less attractive. 
She said that it was too early to tell whether the attacks of Sept. 11 and the subsequent terrorist threats would have an effect on the market. "There's a little softening in the market, but inventory levels are still limited," Ms. Erlich said. In addition to foreign transfers, "there are people in the city looking for rentals in the suburbs now."
A survey by Expat Exchange, a Web site that provides information to those who are relocating, found that 30 percent -- the highest percentage of those queried -- said the most important factor when choosing a town in the United States to live in is housing options. The second most important was a short commute to work.
Young and single people most often choose Manhattan as their home. Many international families also choose Manhattan, Ms. Ehrlich said, because they are often used to an urban lifestyle. 
Nonetheless, both foreign and domestic transferees with families frequently seek out the suburbs, and Westchester is one of the most popular.
"The usual preference is for Westchester or Connecticut -- they've heard the buzz about those places, rather than New Jersey," said Tory Masters, also a partner at Intrepid New York. Long Island is also not usually high on the list, Ms. Ehrlich added.
There are several reasons for Westchester's popularity. Historically, Westchester is home to many global headquarters, like I.B.M. in Armonk and MasterCard in Purchase, so employees often found housing close to their jobs.
In addition, international schools -- the French-American School in Larchmont, the German School in White Plains and the Keio School (Japanese) in Purchase and the Darul Arkam Islamic School in Mount Vernon -- lureg foreign transplants to Westchester. The number and variety of such institutions keep expanding. Recently, the Lyceum Kennedy in Ardsley opened Japanese and French schools.
One couple who rented a home in Larchmont for $8,000 a month is a case in point. The wife said many of the expatriates she met in Hong Kong -- where rents often are more than $10,000 a month -- chose to move to Greenwich when transferred to the New York area, because they see it as having a higher standard of living than Westchester. She and her husband selected Larchmont because she wanted her children to attend the French-American School.
They receive a generous company package that not only covers their rent, but also tuition and includes shipping of all household of furniture, as well as a $15,000 "curtain allowance" to decorate the home and first-class seats for a home visit to Scotland every year.
Ruth Chizzini, director of relocation for Julia B. Fee Real Estate in Rye, said that it's not only those relocating from overseas who receive large subsidies.
"Some people from the U.S. have big packages, especially if they're coming from a place like San Francisco or Washington, D.C.," she said.
Even with the slowing economy, no one expects to see any real downturn in relocations any time soon. 
"The global economy is rooted in the corporate culture," Ms. Masters said. "Being sent on assignment all over the world is becoming the norm."

They were able to rent a four-bedroom house at a cost of $5,000 a month for their family of four. Relocation experts say they got off fairly cheaply. (Chris Maynard for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Suddenly, Love in a Hurry 

BYLINE:  By FRANCINE PARNES 

 BODY:
DAIL METZGER, who runs a Connecticut and Westchester matchmaking service, says that in a post-Sept. 11 world, people are looking for love. Not only did calls from her clients double after the terrorist attacks, but also Ms. Metzger herself is re-examining a longtime platonic friendship for romantic possibilities.
 Deborah Schwartz, originally from Rye, became engaged to Dr. John Meer only four days after the hijackings. Suddenly just a five-month engagement will do. 
 Bob Barclay of Mamaroneck is back in touch with an old buddy from the post-college, ski-bum 1970's. After Mr. Barclay fled his office at the World Trade Center, the friend looked him up, at first fearing the worst. For two men who have reunited only twice in nearly a quarter-century, there is a lot of catching up to do. 
Throughout Westchester, as around the country, people are creating new ties and renewing old ones. Since the attacks, the clock seems to tick faster for rituals of romance. Other people are reconnecting with family or faraway friends. Still others are considering retiring early, adopting a child, acquiring a pet or putting off plans for divorce.
At the Singles Network, which has a branch in Hartsdale, Ms. Metzger said: "The week the world stopped, we stopped, too. Business froze. Then we were deluged for about three weeks, with five or six appointments each day; normally we have about three." Business remains better than usual. 
Sept. 11 is changing the way people approach their personal lives, Ms. Metzger said. "The good relationships are being cemented; the not-so-good ones are ending. People are saying, 'I have to make a change,' or 'I want someone to go home and watch TV with.' You see so many news stories in which people have been lucky to have loved so much. You look at your small life and think, 'I would like to be in a relationship.' " 
Ms. Metzger herself has begun to look at her friend, with whom she has a good time and laughs a lot, in a new light. "He's the same as he always was, but life around me is no longer the same," she said. "We're seeing if we want to take this relationship to another level."
For some, the answer is clearly "yes." Ms. Schwartz, the bride-to-be, who is returning to Westchester for her wedding, said, "Certainly after the attacks, there is no reason to wait." Her preferred venue, the Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, was available in either a few months or a year. She took the short route. In three weeks Ms. Schwartz, a private investigator in Manhattan, arranged for her gown, venue, rabbi, caterer, band, photographer, attendants and invitations. "Before, I would have said, 'A five-month engagement? Forget it.' I don't want to sound fatalistic, but look at how much can happen in one day." 
Dr. Meer, her fiance, is an internist and pediatrician who had been planning to propose after taking his medical boards at the end of August. "Despite the events, I wanted to forge ahead and give us both a sense that we were going to move on and have a happy life together," he said. His job now also involves treating survivors for post-traumatic stress disorder. 
Millie Martini Bratten, editor in chief of Bride's magazine, spoke with retailers during the New York showings of bridal collections in early October. "We've heard from bridal buyers in stores nationwide," she said. "Brides-to-be are referencing, 'I want someone to call me when they are in trouble or danger. And I want someone to care for me in that same way.' " 
Many unmarried couples have a new willingness to commitafter the collective mood of loss. "All the stories about people who had lost a fiance created this greater sense of 'Omigosh, I can't let this one get away, let's go ahead with it,' " said Carley Roney, a Manhattan-based co-founder of TheKnot.com, an online wedding resource. Traffic early this month on her site was up 17 percent for marriage license inquiries.
At a popular wedding venue, The Castle at Tarrytown, bookings for weddings are up about 25 percent over last year, said Michael Colquhoun, director of sales. "I don't know if I can attribute it totally to the attacks, but a small percentage of people are moving up their dates."
At Crabtree's Kittle House in Chappaqua, inquiries for weddings are up approximately 40 percent. "We seem to be almost inundated with phone calls and people coming in to look at the facilities for a wedding reception," said John Crabtree, the owner. "Rather than being concerned about the economy and counting their woes, they are counting their blessings." 
OTHER relationships are being forged outside the romantic realm. For Bob Barclay, a Verizon Communications sales manager, the crisis revived a long-dormant friendship. After college, in 1971, he and Lou Favata lived in a cabin in the woods for three years near Lake Placid. "I was a waiter, he was a bartender," Mr. Barclay said. "He taught me how to cook and drink brandy, I taught him tennis."
After the attacks, "We made a commitment to see each other in weeks or months, not years," Mr. Barclay said. 
He said his friend, now divorced, might have a shot at repairing his marriage, too -- the former couple connected by phone over mutual concern for Mr. Barclay. "Neither wanted to call my home in case the news was bad," he said.
"I would not be shocked if in a year they are living together," he continued. "They are both alone. The way the world is now, stranger things have happened." 
After the attacks, some telephone lines led to former lovers. 
"My very first call was to my ex-husband," said Michele Weissman, a lawyer from Nyack, who later called four former boyfriends. "I needed to hear his voice; we're still very close. My immediate reaction was to reach out. I was taking stock and letting people who had been in my life know they were important to me."
One old flame wanted to meet. "I wasn't calling to rekindle things," Ms. Weissman said. "I was thinking, we lost a fire captain, the husband of a close family friend, and this tragedy made me realize not to take anything for granted." 
Sharon Abrams, a personal trainer from Spring Valley, has revamped her approach to dating. 
"My new way of thinking is, if the guy is interested, he's the one who comes to me and asks me out, not the other way around," Ms. Abrams said. "I used to offer to split the check, and nine times out of 10, the guy is like, 'O.K.' But he should know better. What I've learned from the attacks is, life is short. I don't have to compromise anymore or push when something's not there." 
Gilda Carle, a Yonkers psychotherapist, has been hearing more about one-night stands lately. At a recent singles seminar on a Saturday night at the Jewish Community Center on the Hudson in Tarrytown, she said that some people were looking for love for all the wrong reasons.
In black leather stovepipe pants and a lavender leather jacket, Ms. Carle held the attention of a packed room of approximately 65 women and 15 men, many of whom had traveled across the Tappan Zee Bridge to hear about the finer points of dating today. 
"I have received more and more e-mails from people who hooked up immediately after the World Trade Center attack," Ms. Carle said in an earlier interview. "They are looking for instant comfort, instant love. People have been so distracted by worrying about terrorists, they have neglected to worry about the people they date and sleep with."
Ms. Carle said that more people are joining the online matchmaking service Getgaga.com to which she is a relationship consultant. "After the World Trade Center bombing, our numbers climbed," she said. "Then after the anthrax scares began, the numbers climbed again. Each time there's a crisis, singles are more aware of their life without a partner."
Elsewhere, singles are happy just to meet and greet. At Mighty Joe Young's in Hartsdale, a restaurant with an active bar, "everybody's been mingling more," said Timothy Kiyotoki, a manager, at the jungle-theme bar with palm-tree-and-safari-animal decor, exotic masks and zebra-print tables. "I am seeing more new faces. It used to be two girls or guys coming from work, now it's a group of four or five.
"It's depressing to stay home and flick on the same news reports," he added. "They come to meet someone at the bar, either to spark romance or brush up their dating skills."
For the Single Gourmet, an Eastchester-based dining club, a get-together in an old fieldstone mansion at the Renaissance Westchester Hotel in White Plains less than three weeks after the attacks attracted more than 100 participants. "When you have 135 single people coming to a social on a Sunday, it supports the fact that they prefer not to be alone," said Nancie Hart, the director. One of Ms. Hart's clients, Robert W. Villani, a White Plains lawyer, is weighing early retirement next year at 60. "I'm divorced, I'm not looking for a relationship for the sake of a relationship," he said, "but I would be much quicker to explore one now.
"Someone I knew who died at the World Trade Center had just started working there this year and was planning on early-retiring in Florida in a couple of years," he said. "You know that old adage, man plans but God disposes? The events of the 11th tell us we can't assume we will reach 65 or 70 -- or even 25. Somebody who is 18 and will die at 24 is already old."
Tina Ritsatos, 19, who is completing a two-year program at Westchester Community College, is likewise recalibrating her future. She planned to apply to New York University for her junior year. "Now I'm thinking of Marymount College in Tarrytown," said Ms. Ritsatos, who lives in Yonkers with her family. "It's only 15 minutes away from my house. This is a time to be around friends and family, people you trust. This tragedy has made me appreciate them 10 times more." 
Her family, she said, tended to do things individually, but now they talk more and go out to movies and restaurants. "It feels like something that needs to happen, that we all want to be together," she said. 
Even in class, Ms. Ritsatos has noticed: "I see people sitting closer to each other. They used to be scattered around the classroom, but now there are no big gaps." 
At the college, Sarah Rabinowitz, the personal crisis counselor, said the tragedy has been a wake-up call to young people who think nothing can harm them. "They get on motorcycles, bungee jump, take all kinds of risk," she said. "At that age, they normally want to assert their independence from their families, but today's events are pulling them back into the family system for a sense of safety and support." 
Other families are connecting through adoption. Mary L. Durel of Family Service of Westchester in White Plains said that about two weeks after the attack, the service heard from around 15 couples in 10 days seeking to adopt, up by approximately 15 percent.
As people consider their connections, Ms. Durel said, "the natural extension is to think about having a family, whether it's a family that is your biological family or extended family or close friends or even people in the neighborhood."
SOME are adopting pets. At the Elmsford Animal Shelter, "Since the attacks, adoptions have picked up considerably, at least 10 percent," said Mimi Stone, president of the Central Westchester Humane Society, which runs the no-kill shelter. One of the New York City firefighters who had been on his honeymoon when the attacks occurred returned early; several his friends and fellow firefighters had been killed. "He came here with his wife one day," Ms. Stone said, "and they adopted a Labrador-mix puppy. He was talking about his experience, how sad it was. We feel there is a tie-in. People are enjoying coming to the shelter. They come, they just fall in love."
Dale Schweizer, manager of Puppy Club Kennels in Mahopac, said people looking for companionship -- the elderly, single people -- are buying puppies. His sales are up around 15 percent. 
For some couples, a shaky relationship now seems preferable to divorce. Margaret Tyre, a matrimonial lawyer in Rye, said that some potential clients are reconsidering splitting up. "Clients feel they need time to evaluate their relationships," she said. "Divorce is an enormous stress to children of any age, and clients are fearful of adding any further insecurity to their children's lives." 
But while relationships are evaluated, not each one is deemed a keeper. 
Peter Nardone, a Scarsdale lawyer, said that for one of his clients, who worked at the World Trade Center and survived the attacks, it signaled the time to end her troubled marriage: "She decided that with the upheaval in her business life, she would try to regain some normalcy in her personal life," Mr. Nardone said. "She couldn't have upheaval in both places. After her workplace was destroyed, she needed to make her home a sanctuary for herself and children. So she decided to proceed with divorce."

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
Job Growth and Unemployment Tick Upward in Westchester

BYLINE:  By Corey Kilgannon 

 BODY:
As layoffs continue around the nation, job growth in Westchester was measured at a record high for the month of September, according to the New York State Department of Labor, although the numbers don't reflect changes in the economy since Sept. 11. The department reported 419,300 jobs in Westchester currently, 4,700 more than in September 2000. 
 "In terms of job growth, New York State is outpacing the nation and Westchester's outpacing both of them," said Frank M. Surdey, the department's principal economist. 
 Only two large job markets in the state, Albany and Long Island, now have a faster job rate growth than Westchester.
Although there are more people seeking jobs, Westchester's unemployment rate also grew last month, to 3.8 percent, compared with September 2000, when it was 3.2 percent.
The county has the 27th lowest unemployment rate of 62 counties in New York State. Of the state's seven largest job markets, Westchester had the third lowest unemployment rate for September.
Mr. Surdey cautioned that most of the data was collected before the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center, "and we can't gauge the effect of the collapse until next month's numbers." Corey Kilgannon

HEADLINE: Footlights; 
Foreign Policy Series

BYLINE:  By Roberta Hershenson 

 BODY:
Purchase College may be best known for the performing arts, but this time the spotlight is on the social sciences division. 
 Professors from the division, as well as groups like the Friends of the Social Sciences, the Westchester Center for Economic Education and the Purchase Student Action Coalition, have organized a series of free public programs focused on United States foreign policy and the turbulent world climate. 
 The series, "Globalization and the Current Crisis," began last month with topics like "Globalization, Why the Fuss?" and "Why Do They Hate Us?" The programs continue on Tuesday at 4:30 p.m. with "Patriotism and the American Left"' Future events include "A Clash of Civilizations" on Nov. 15 at 4:30 p.m. (with philosophy readings on ideas of good and evil); "United States Foreign Policy in Central Asia and the Middle East in a Post-Taliban Era," on Nov. 28 at 4:30 p.m.; and a wrap-up session on Dec. 4 at 4:30 on the topic "What Have We Learned, and What Do We Still Need to Understand?" 
All sessions will take place in the Fireside Lounge of the Social Sciences building. Dr. Peter F. Bell, a professor of economics and director of the Westchester Center for Economic Education who will lead the concluding discussion, said the series brought together a diverse group of faculty from social sciences and humanities to shed light on the events of Sept. 11 and their aftermath. HEADLINE: When Getting There Isn't Half the Fun 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SULLIVAN 

DATELINE: TRENTON 

 BODY:
LONG before the rush hour train leaves Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan, commuters are inching toward the favored track. The experienced ones have learned to place bets early, and they cluster at the top of the stairways.
 The more savvy New Jersey Transit commuters abandoned the station's main concourse long ago. Instead, they position themselves on the lower level, where amid the darkened halls -- with the low ceiling closing in from above and a sea of fellow passengers crowding in from all sides -- they almost lean like sprinters before the starting gun, anticipating. 
 The train is finally announced and the pack surges. No one speaks as commuters sway and jostle for position. The crowd thunders down the staircase and fans out onto the waiting trains. At last, the harried commuters can collapse into the empty seats, which will be gone in seconds. 
Stragglers fill the aisles and wedge tightly into the vestibules. No one bothers to read signs urging passengers not to ride between the cars. No one can see them anyway; riders are already crammed against the doors.
"It is like a herd of cattle rushing to be fed when they have not been fed for three weeks," said Margo Wheeler, a graphic designer who commutes between Manhattan and Metuchen. "You don't even have to walk, you are just pushed along."
That was true even before Sept. 11.
Today, New Jersey's mass transit system -- stretched thin for the last several years -- is being pushed well beyond its capacity. 
If the trains seem crowded, many bus lines are in worse shape. Even before the attack on the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, 14,000 riders could not find seats on New Jersey Transit commuter buses.
In addition, the PATH system, whose trains used to carry about 38,000 riders to Lower Manhattan each business day, is partly crippled. With the Exchange Place station in Jersey City shuttered and the PATH tunnel to Lower Manhattan closed for the foreseeable future, riders have had to find alternative ways to get to work. Many are taking ferries or the Midtown PATH lines, while others have shifted to New Jersey Transit for the whole trip.
PATH platforms in Midtown Manhattan are so crowded that riders often have to wait for several trains to pass before being able to enter. To try to cope with the crush, PATH officials have designated the Christopher Street station one-way -- for exiting passengers only -- during the morning rush hour.
"Some of the stations, like Christopher Street and Ninth Street, are seeing 150 percent of capacity," said Michael P. DePallo, director and general manager of services for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. "They were really not built to accommodate this number of passengers."
New Jersey Transit is facing an equally difficult situation. Since the attacks, some trains have seen as much as a 44 percent increase in ridership in and out of Manhattan. That was the kind of increase planners expected over the next 10 years; instead, it came in a week.
Jeff Warsh, the director of New Jersey Transit, put it most succinctly: "We are in a crisis situation."
In the anxious weeks since the twin towers were obliterated, New Jersey Transit has scrambled to ease the difficulties, but officials say that in the short term, there is little that can be done.
For now, Mr. Warsh says his agency has added cars to existing trains and plans to buy more equipment in the next several months. But transit officials also hope that people will try to vary their commuting times.
"The best way we can provide short-term capacity is for employers to encourage staggered hours," Mr. Warsh said. "We are in the middle of a very serious crisis, and it is not going to get any better quickly."
The crunch has come at a particularly difficult time for the transit agency. New Jersey Transit, already overcrowded, had planned a major expansion next year, the opening of the Secaucus Transfer Station -- which would have crammed even more riders onto the trains. Now, however, those plans are in doubt. At the same time, the agency has run out of money just when it would like to buy a new fleet of double-decker rail cars at a cost of about $500 million per train, but for now it cannot afford to. Planners project a shortfall of more than $1.5 billion over the next four years.
THE short-term cause of the overcrowding on the trains is painfully obvious: PATH riders can no longer reach downtown Manhattan, and single-occupant cars cannot use the Lincoln or Holland Tunnels during the morning rush hour. But many people who follow mass transit closely in New Jersey say the effects will linger long after train service is restored to Lower Manhattan. For one thing, many offices forced to move their headquarters from the financial district have relocated to Midtown Manhattan or to New Jersey, resulting in a sharp change in commuting patterns.
"The dislocation and the relocation of offices from Lower Manhattan and the loss the PATH has resulted in a huge shift of people going to Midtown, either by transit, Amtrak or by the PATH uptown route," said James Weinstein, the commissioner of New Jersey's Transportation Department. "We have had more people riding our public transit system in all its modes than we have ever had."
Government agencies and private transit companies have struggled to provide alternatives. New York Waterways, the main ferry service between New Jersey and Manhattan, has increased its fleet to 35 vessels from 24.
But Arthur E. Imperatore Jr., president of New York Waterways, admitted recently that the response so far was not nearly enough.
"We need to create as much additional capacity as we can and add new routes where possible," Mr. Imperatore said. "We have been able to cope so far, but we have to look for ways to expand."
Bus companies are also trying to increase capacity. Coach USA, which owns a large proportion of suburban commuter buses that pour into the Port Authority bus terminal on Eight Avenue in Midtown Manhattan every morning, has shifted some of its charter buses into commuter service. As a result, said Tom Vitale, a regional vice president with Coach USA, which operates under such names as Suburban, Red and Tan, Shortline, Olympia Trails and Community Coach, the lines still have available seats.
On the other hand, many New Jersey Transit bus lines have reached their limit.
Cedrick T. Fulton, general manager of the Port Authority bus terminal, said the facility's 230 gates had been at operating at capacity for several years.
"When carriers ask for my space, we tell them we just don't have it," Mr. Fulton said.
He said there had not been a large increase in the number of buses entering the station since the attack -- about 70 percent of the 200,000 riders who pass through the terminal each day ride New Jersey Transit buses -- although ridership had increased. In addition, he said drivers had been experiencing delays because of added security at the Lincoln Tunnel, particularly during the evening rush. 
Mr. Warsh said New Jersey Transit had only seen a 3 percent increase in bus ridership since the attacks. But, he said, the small increase could be attributed to the fact that there was no room on the buses to begin with. Nearly two-thirds of the agency's 400,000 daily passengers of all types already take the bus.
"Capacity is the problem," he said. "You can't fit any more people."
For now, New Jersey Transit has added 15 new buses to its busy Route 9 corridor from Old Bridge. But local officials say the increase, while welcome, has still not kept pace with demand.
"Bus ridership is at 100 percent," said Assemblyman John S. Wisniewski, of Bordentown. "It was crowded before and now it is bursting at the seams."
Mr. Wisniewski, a member of the Transportation Committee in the Assembly, said the Legislature would have to consider increasing money for mass transit.
"There is clearly a need to increase capacity under the Hudson River," he said.
In fact, New Jersey Transit has already ordered 1,400 new buses, which it expects to roll out over the next two years. Many of those were intended to replace the aging Cruiser-style buses -- most of which are nearly 20 years old -- but transit officials said that they might keep some of the older buses rolling to meet the increased demand.
YET even when the new buses are on the road, the agency will still have a problem finding places to unload passengers.
"We have no more capacity at the Port Authority bus terminal and we have used up all capacity at the Lincoln Tunnel," Mr. Warsh said.
Jeanine Bauer, executive director of the Tri-State Transportation Campaign, a private research organization that studies transportation issues, said the bus terminal had always been been a choke point for New Jersey commuters.
"We have heard that a lot from Bergen and Rockland commuters -- the crowding is a longstanding problem and it has gotten worse," Ms. Bauer said. "There are not enough buses, not enough frequency and not enough platform space."
The Port Authority has plans to renovate its north terminal, which could accommodate as many as 25,000 additional commuters each day.
If the Port Authority decided to go forward with the plan, officials said the job could be completed within 15 months. That, however, is small comfort to riders swaying with the bus as it crawls around the helix toward the Lincoln Tunnel.
"In a perfect world, we would start construction sometime mid-year next year," Mr. Fulton said. However, he said the developer and the Port Authority were still discussing financing for the project.
"In the short term, there is going to be additional congestion and additional crowding," Mr. Weinstein said. "We are trying to respond quickly to the worst of the problems. But it is going to take time."
JAMES R. CANTWELL, who has been a conductor for New Jersey Transit for 37 years, has traveled between Trenton and New York more times than he can remember. But one trip that is burned into his memory is the 10:37 a.m. train out of Manhattan on Sept. 11.
It was the last train leaving Pennsylvania Station after the attacks on the World Trade Center, and people had poured down the stairs and crammed onto the platform. But Mr. Cantwell had to shut the train doors. Emergency officials deemed the train tunnels too dangerous, so the train left empty as people stared in dismay.
"I wanted to get these people out of there, but I had a notice to evacuate the train," Mr. Cantwell said. "I had all these people coming down. They had looks of horror on their faces."
For tens of thousands of people, New Jersey Transit has always been a lifeline. If there was any question of that, it was dispelled in the weeks after the attacks. Mr. Cantwell said the crowds of commuters have returned to his 12-car train. Most of the same faces are back, and many new ones have joined.
"If you get lucky enough to get a seat, you get a seat," Mr. Cantwell said. "If not, you are going to have to stand. They accept that."
There is not much choice. Before Sept. 11, New Jersey Transit trains carried 34,000 people into Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan from 6 a.m. to 10 a.m. every workday. Since then, the trains have been carrying about 50,000 passengers each day.
Yet it is difficult to say how each particular train is affected. For riders from Trenton or the North Jersey coastline, the increase is not really felt until the train arrives in Newark -- where people who used to take the PATH trains to Lower Manhattan pour on.
The problem is, the new riders have been added to train lines that were already seeing people standing each day because of the lack of adequate seating.
"There are probably 12,000 to 15,000 more people on those trains during the morning commute," said Steven M. Weber, a senior transportation planner with the Regional Plan Association. "Cars that were carrying 120 people before are now carrying 200."
The situation is even worse on New Jersey Transit's most popular line, the Midtown Direct. Crowding on that train, which travels from Morristown through the suburbs west of Newark is severe because riders who used to ride the train to Hoboken and take the PATH to the trade center or the ferry are now taking Midtown Direct.
Ms. Bauer of the Tristate Transportation Campaign said the Midtown Direct was so crowded these days that conductors could not even move through the cars to open doors.
"The conductor had to get off the train and walk along the outside, opening each door so that passengers could disembark," Ms. Bauer said.
PROBLEMS with capacity are nothing new for the agency, which had 8,000 train passengers and 14,000 bus riders standing each day before the attacks. Even before Sept. 11, Mr. Warsh said, New Jersey Transit had ordered 1,400 new buses as well as 200 new train cars and more powerful locomotives to handle additional passengers.
He said that the new train equipment, scheduled to enter service during the next two years, would create about 16,000 new seats. But rail cars -- unlike automobiles -- take a long time to finish.
"It takes two years for a rail car to be built," Mr. Warsh said, "and it needs to be safety tested."
The problem is, those 16,000 new seats are already spoken for. Next fall the Secaucus Transfer, a new train station under construction, is expected to open, allowing riders from Bergen County to transfer to trains that go directly to Manhattan. The long-promised station is expected to be immensely popular, and New Jersey Transit has estimated that 16,200 passengers will use it to transfer into the city.
While New Jersey Transit has spent more than $400 million on the project, planners already question whether the agency will be able to open the station because of the overcrowding. The problem is this: the Secaucus Transfer sits between Newark and New York, and planners counted on many riders leaving the trains at Newark and taking PATH into the city. Those seats were expected to be open for the new passengers from Bergen County. But because PATH is closed, riders are not leaving the trains, and there may be no room for the new passengers.
"I think Secaucus is a pretty big problem," said Martin M. Robins, director of the Transportation Policy Institute at the Alan M. Voorhees Transportation Center at Rutgers University. "They may be able to hold off on the opening of the Secaucus project until the reopening of PATH."
New Jersey Transit opened its Newark Airport train station on Oct. 21, allowing passengers to connect with the airport monorail system. Despite the sharp decline in air travel caused in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 attack, transit officials said ridership to the station had been high. They said the new stop had been averaging over 1,100 riders a day, more than the 600 to 800 passengers they had been expecting.
The problem with waiting for the reopening of the PATH stations at Exchange Place and at the site of the World Trade Center is that Port Authority officials cannot even predict when that service will resume. According to the latest projections, it is likely to be about two years before service is restored to the World Trade Center stop.
For now, said Mr. DePallo, the PATH director, engineers had not even been able to evaluate the damage under the trade center, and it will be six months before they could say how long the stations would remain closed.
Even without the displacement caused by the attack, Ms. Bauer of the transportation campaign said that New Jersey Transit would have had severe problems opening the Secaucus Transfer without creating a logjam.
"The Northeast Corridor and the Midtown Direct trains were at capacity anyway," she said. "They could not fit another body onto those trains."
There are differing views about the project -- particularly within New Jersey Transit and the state's Transportation Department.
For his part, Mr. Warsh said his agency still planned to open the new station as scheduled, and insisted that New Jersey Transit could cope with the new riders. Mr. Weinstein, the transportation commissioner, said the project was crucial to northern New Jersey, particularly because it could ease some of the road congestion in Bergen County.
But he said he recognized that the additional crowding had placed new strains on the system. 
"That is something we are clearly going to have to re-evaluate," he said."I don't think the whole thing has settled out, and because of that you can't make plans."
ANYONE who has heard of Senator Jon S. Corzine knows he spent years working on Wall Street, rising up through the ranks at Goldman Sachs to become its co-chairman. But how many people know that Mr. Corzine spent a good portion of his lifetime driving through the predawn darkness and watching the sun come up over the Manhattan skyline? "I got up every morning at 5 a.m. to car-pool into New York to avoid the traffic and the congestion on the trains," he said. 
The commute, whether fighting tunnel traffic or cramming onto a bus or a train, has always been the down side to living and working in the New York region. Even before the current crisis, the difficulty of moving employees into and out of the city was driving businesses out of New York's financial district.
But in the end -- as Senator Corzine and most transportation planners agree -- there is not much that New Jersey can do to expand the capacity of mass transit into New York without building a new tunnel under the Hudson River.
Senator Corzine, who campaigned on the promise of improving mass transit in northern New Jersey, said that short-term "patchwork" solutions might add some space, but a real solution would require a huge expansion.
"It is more essential than I can put into words," Senator Corzine said.
Although talked about for decades, a serious proposal to add a second tunnel under the Hudson River for passenger trains has been discussed endlessly since the mid-1990's. Mr. Robins of Rutgers shepherded the plan as part of a joint project between New York, New Jersey and the Port Authority called Access to the Region's Core.
Mr. Robins estimated the project would cost from $3 billion to $6 billion. The least expensive plan called for running a second rail tunnel from Pennsylvania Station in Newark to Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan, and building a second passenger concourse beneath the existing station in New York. The project, which was estimated to take about 10 years, would almost double the number of people who could cross the river on trains.
The more ambitious -- and more expensive -- project would involve a tunnel running from New Jersey to Grand Central Terminal in Manhattan. That project would allow for interconnection between all of the commuter rail lines in New York -- New Jersey Transit, Metro-North and the Long Island Rail Road.
For now, however, Mr. Robins said, the project was stalled for one big reason: money.
There are many competing projects with proponents clamoring for funds, and the tunnel advocates have not presented a united front to the federal government. In fact, Mr. Robins said, while New Jersey officials had generally supported the tunnel, most New York leaders had either distanced themselves from it or opposed it altogether.
"It is soft opposition, but it is opposition," Mr. Robins said. "The City of New York under Mayor Giuliani does not want to hear about it. Their attitude is that it is going to drag people from jobs in New York to New Jersey."
Without federal support -- which means New York as well as New Jersey pushing the project -- the tunnel will move ahead with all the speed of the 5:45 leaving Pennsylvania Station in a snowstorm. Not only is New Jersey ill-positioned to build the tunnel by itself, but the fact is that New Jersey Transit is already facing a serious financial crunch. 
It is the paradox faced by all of the country's government-subsidized railroads: the more customers they attract, the more money they lose. Nor is the problem as simple as the inability of conductors to collect fares because they cannot walk through the trains -- although that happens frequently these days. Ticket sales meet only part of the cost of running the railroad; the rest comes from government subsidies.
More customers mean more wear and tear, more equipment, more salaries. And unless government subsidies rise along with ridership, the railroad begins to lose more money. But in fact in the 1990's, as ridership soared, subsidies for New Jersey Transit operations actually fell, though they increased a bit in the last two years.
"There is no question that mass transit is critical to our economy," said Curtis Fisher, program director for the New Jersey Public Interest Research Group. "We have to make more of an investment in transit. We can't continue to absorb these 30 percent increases in use without stress on the system."
Indeed, New Jersey Transit's five-year financial plan shows the signs of impending financial problems. The document predicts a deficit of more than $1.5 billion for the period. Perhaps more troubling, it shows that the only way the transit agency can continue to pay for its operations is by diverting money from its capital budget, a sure sign of long-term problems.
"The operating budget has been grossly short-changed for a number of years," Mr. Robins said. "They have had no fare increase in 10 years, and for a number of years money was decreasing from the state."
The way Mr. Warsh sees it, money difficulties are already being felt on the train lines. He said one crucial way to ease congestion between Newark and New York was to add bilevel train cars, which Long Island Rail Road is already using. While there is practically no more room for additional trains during rush hour -- only so many can enter or leave New York at any time -- adding another passenger level would provide about 16,000 more seats.
Mr. Warsh said his agency wanted to buy 200 double-decker cars, and had asked builders to provide proposals for the new designs.
But to Mr. Robins, the issue is not the technical design but the financing.
"In 1998, they decided they were going to buy the bilevel cars," Mr. Robins said. "I would assume they have had the specs for some time. They don't have the money."

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES; 
Who Best Protects Shareholders? The Shareholders

BYLINE:  By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a newsletter based in Annandale, Va. His column on investment strategies appears every other week. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
GIVING shareholders more rights is good for a company to do.
 That is not a political judgment. It appears to be an investment truth, though discovered only recently -- in a study that found that the stock prices of companies that place the most restrictions on their shareholders' rights have lagged behind those that had the fewest such limits. 
 The restrictions take many forms. Particularly well known is the poison-pill defense, which aims to immunize management from hostile takeovers. Others include the staggered election of company directors -- which keeps shareholders from throwing out an entire board in any given year -- and requirements for supermajorities in voting. These changes make it difficult for shareholders to exercise real influence or control. 
But as many and varied as the restrictions can be, their net impact on long-term performance has been negative, according to a new study by three researchers -- Paul Gompers, a professor of business administration at Harvard Business School; Joy Ishii, a graduate student in economics at Harvard; and Andrew Metrick, a finance professor at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. The team studied 24 ways in which a company may restrict shareholder rights and combined them into an overall index. A low reading meant that a company imposed few restrictions. 
Working with a database of companies representing 90 percent of the market, the team constructed 10 portfolios, according to those companies' index values. The portfolios were reconstructed periodically. From Sept. 1, 1990, to Dec. 31, 1999, the researchers found, the portfolio with the lowest index values gained 9.3 percentage points a year more, on average, than the one with the highest values. While the other eight did not always adhere to the pattern, the performance difference between the extremes has withstood attempts to explain it away.
To put the researchers' findings in perspective, consider that the performance difference is almost double the five-point margin of victory that growth stocks had over value stocks during the same period -- a heyday for growth investing -- according to the Standard & Poor's 500/Barra indexes. 
But how could a difference of such magnitude have escaped notice? For one thing, researchers couldn't have detected it until recently. Widespread shareholder restrictions are relatively new; most companies did not impose them until the mid-to late 1980's.
Furthermore, to the extent that shareholder restrictions could have been studied, previous researchers tended to focus on the immediate market impact. But over the short term, that impact is ambiguous. For example, even though a poison-pill defense turns out to be a long-term negative, the market may react to it positively over the short term because it may signal that a hostile takeover attempt is imminent.
Why would companies that restrict shareholder rights be such poor performers? The authors of the new study are careful to stress that the jury is still out. Maybe the restrictions lead to a deterioration in a company's culture -- away from shareholder responsiveness and toward immunity from competitive pressures -- and eventually to poorer fundamentals and inferior stock performance. Or maybe the restrictions on shareholder rights are just symptoms of a deterioration caused by something else.
I find it safe to say, however, that investors should begin to pay more attention to a company's culture. Assuming that restrictions on shareholder rights are either a cause or a symptom of cultural deterioration, an investor should be less inclined to buy, and more inclined to sell, a company that chooses to impose them.
That also means that investors should consider a company more favorably if it relaxes previously imposed restrictions. Companies that imposed heavy restrictions were so beaten down by the market over the last decade that changes in their corporate cultures could unleash enormous potential.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Free to Profit"For the most part, stocks of companies that grant shareholders the most rights have outperformed those that are most restrictive. Graph shows the average annual performance of companies, based on shareholder restrictions, versus all stocks with similar characteristics, Sept. 1, 1990 to Dec. 31, 1999 (Sources: Paul Gompers and Joy Ishii, Harvard University; Andrew Metrick, the Wharton School)
