HEADLINE: OUT THERE: Colombia; 
Who's the Fairest of Them All?

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO 

DATELINE: BOGOTA, Colombia 

 BODY:
ANDREA PAOLA GARZON, tall and impossibly thin, takes her beauty seriously.
 Every day at 5:30 a.m. she hits the gym for a strenuous workout, followed by a massage, a thermal bath and a stint on the tanning bed. What the six-hour morning regimen has not altered, plastic surgery has: she has undergone a breast lift. 
 It may sound extreme. But Ms. Garzon is vying to win Colombia's National Beauty Pageant, a 17-day extravaganza that began on Oct. 27, turning everyone's attention -- if only briefly -- from the country's most intractable problem: a civil conflict that has lasted for decades and claims thousands of lives every year. 
"This is a tremendous sacrifice, to have surgery and do all this work," said Ms. Garzon, 21, who holds a fashion design degree. "People think being a beauty queen is to put on a dress and go, but they do not take into account all the sacrifice and hard work."
Beauty is a national obsession in Colombia, readily apparent on the nightly newscasts, which often end with shots of bikini-clad young women. The economy as a whole may be faltering, but cosmetics companies and spas thrive, as do matchmaking services that find Colombian women for American lonely hearts.
The pageant, in Cartagena, has 400 journalists accredited to cover it, and takes the mania to a new level. Would-be beauty queens spend tens of thousands of dollars on wardrobes, travel, security and other expenses. They hire "preparers" to teach them how to walk regally, answer questions from the media and discuss the government's troubled peace talks with leftist rebels. One well-known consultant, Javier Murillo, even invites legislators, scholars and Colombia's former national police director, Rosso Jose Serrano, to brief contestants on Colombia's turmoil.
"A queen gets asked questions," explained Diana Quimbay, 23, a contestant and recent university graduate, "so you have to be prepared."
As for the high cost, in some cases contestants' wealthy families foot the bill. And though the country's per capita income is $2,000, provincial governments -- ever proud of their local queens -- have used public funds for the queens' preparation without arousing complaints. But usually, contestants have corporate sponsors.
Critics see the obsession as a step backward in a country where women have made impressive headway in recent decades. They note that more than half the university students here are female, and that women are well represented in the professional class. More than 30 of the 263-member Congress are women, as is one of the leading presidential candidates, Noemi Sanin.
"The advances of a country should be measured by the advances of its women," said Florence Thomas, a leading feminist at National University in Bogota. "But this is humiliating. For me, it is like a horse fair, where their faces and nose and hair and bust are assessed."
Ms. Thomas and others also question how a pageant and the accompanying media blitz can be justified when Colombia is struggling with civil strife now in its 37th year.
But there are scholars who see a relationship between the conflict and the pageant mania. Michael Stanfield, a Latin America specialist at the University of San Francisco, is writing a book about it. His thesis is that Colombians, bedeviled by violence and a floundering government, use pageants to try to project what is good about their country. Their soccer teams may often fail on the world stage, but with the pageants, they can show off.
"Colombians need the hope of beauty, they need the presentation of beauty, to feel connected, to feel proud," Mr. Stanfield said. "You occasionally have a Colombian win a stage of the Tour de France or someone winning a car race, but nothing rallies that sense of national identification like the beauty queen."
Pageants have a long history here; upper-class women in the colonial period held some of the first, using slaves as contestants. It was a way, Mr. Stanfield said, for the elite to display power, since the contestants wore dresses and jewels belonging to their masters.
Modern-day Colombia has hundreds of pageants each year, honoring natural resources like coal and coffee, or cultural icons, like Vallenato music. None, though, compare in size, scope and cost to the National Beauty Pageant, which has been crowning queens since 1934. This year, 9 out of 21 contestants sought the advice of Alfredo Barraza, a fashion designer, who keeps a portrait collection of his pageant winners -- 14 so far. He has counseled this year's clients on everything from fixing crooked teeth to plastic surgery. And he designed their dresses -- 144 in all, 16 for each contestant.
That many are essential, for the various pageant events: cocktail parties, solemn wreath-layings, tours of poor neighborhoods, prayer services. The outfits must match perfectly with the event -- not too showy for those serious functions, not too plain for those meant to dazzle. So there are light dresses for Cartagena's steamy nights, business suits for news conferences and then the folk get-ups for the Night of Fantasy event, which highlights Colombia's regional styles. The most important, though, is the elegant gown they wear for the coronation, Nov. 11 -- when there is an even chance that one of Mr. Barraza's clients will take the crown.
"I like to win," Mr. Barraza said. "This is my job, and I go to win."
For the contestants, his advice is gospel. "I'm like a sponge," said Johanna Cure, 23. "They tell me everything I need to do, and I just soak it up."
And if Mr. Barraza thinks a contestant's nose is crooked or her legs have cellulite, who is to argue?
"I fixed my bridge," said Consuelo Guzman, 19, touching her nose. "I am fine with it. If you are going to feel good about yourself, what is the problem with that?"
Mr. Barraza said his role was to help his charges find the talent they might not have known they had. "Look," he said, "many of the girls are beautiful physically on the outside, but inside they have not found that inner beauty."
To help the contestants reach that inner beauty, Mr. Barraza and other preparers say, they are urged to read newspapers and books. "I read a lot," Mr. Barraza explained. "So I know what they should read. Charisma, there is a good book on that, so I tell them: 'Read this book so you know what charisma is. A queen has to be charismatic.' "
On a recent day, Mr. Barraza's home buzzed with energy. His 10 seamstresses, many of them relatives, were on hand. A local television crew waited to interview contestants. One of them, Ms. Quimbay, sat in an adjoining room while Mr. Barraza applied her makeup. Another, Johana Acosta, 20, waited for a fitting. Still others waited for a moment with Mr. Barraza, as always in a flurry of activity.
Some have won their places in the competition through victories in local pageants; others have been appointed by government officials. For many, the pageant is the culmination of a lifelong dream -- the highest honor a woman could hope for.
"A queen is the bright face of the country," Ms. Garzon said. "In Colombia, a queen is always seen as someone who is very important, an example to follow."
Yet it is clear when talking to contestants that while winning is paramount, losing is not bad either. At least they have created professional possibilities for themselves. After all, newscasts are stocked with former contestants, as are the soap operas and Colombia's red-hot modeling industry.
"They are on television, doing radio; they are professionals," Raimundo Angulo, the pageant president, said of former contestants. "So this has opened doors for them. Beauty has allowed them to reaffirm the talent that they have."

HEADLINE: PULSE; 
Marked Bills for Patriotic Purchases

BYLINE:  By SOREN LARSON 

 BODY:
A New York-based artist is putting the tools of capitalism to double use -- combating fear as well as recession -- by putting his mouth where his money is. The artist, David Greg Harth, has been stamping United States paper currency with one of two phrases, "I am not afraid" or "I am not terrorized." 
The bills are then put back into circulation in the time-honored way with the goal of providing subliminal comfort to skittish consumers.
 "The point is that I will continue doing what I do," Mr. Harth, 26, said. "I will create art, go out for dinner, go to a concert. The terrorists want to kill us by destroying our economy and productive spirit. It's not going to happen. We will continue to be free to play, work, earn -- and spend." 
 Don't be surprised if one of the declarative dollars ends up in your wallet, because Mr. Harth is hoping to mark at least 100,000 of them with his red or black slogans. He has friends stamping away across the country and even has a connection working in Berlin. So far, more than 25,000 bills have been stamped in the United States, Mr. Harth said. 
This is not unfamiliar territory for him. In 1998 Mr. Harth tagged bills with the legend "I am America." But this time around there's a greater workload -- and a sense of urgency.
Those interested in joining Mr. Harth's stamp act may visit www.davidgregharth.com/dollars. He will send a stamp (free, but it must be returned) or exchange a check or money order for marked bills. SOREN LARSON

HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT; 
Drugs Aside, Drugstores Feel the Pain Of Prudence

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
ON the face of it, the nation's big drugstore chains, which generate $180 billion in revenue, would seem to be immune to turns in the economy. 
 Recession or no recession, people need drugs. And as the nation grays, more people need more drugs. 
 That is the logic. The reality is something else. Drugstore sales are slumping. Chains are closing stores and laying off workers. Investors have been dumping the stocks. 
Mark Husson, food and drug retailing analyst at Merrill Lynch, spoke about the business last week. Following are excerpts from the conversation.

Q. Why are drug chains slumping?

A. First, there has been a slowdown in comparable-store sales and a heating up of the competitive environment.
The industry gets about 60 percent of its sales from drugs, which are nondiscretionary, and about 40 percent from convenience items. Profit margins are higher on convenience items. 
In normal times, people go into the drugstore thinking they need 1.5 items, and to their surprise they come out with 2.3 items. 
In tight times, you go in for 1.5 items, and that is what you come out with. And the stuff they are not selling, the candy, the Big Mouth Billy Bass, the weight loss pills, is the stuff with the highest profit margins. 

Q. What is the other factor?

A. The second problem is what is called shrinkage, which is another word for staff and customer theft.
Rite Aid and CVS have talked about this, and Duane Reade is starting to talk about it. 
And the reason it is more of a problem now is that retailers sell a lot of expensive stuff, from home diagnostic kits for diabetes to smoke-cessation products. 
During the last recession, in the early 1990's, technology wasn't good enough to quantify the shrinkage amount. Now they know precisely what is happening. 
Shrinkage is up about 30 basis points. Typically, it runs at 1.5 percent of sales. Now, it is about 1.8 percent of sales. 

Q. Who competes with the big drug chains?

A. Outside of New York City, all the discretionary stuff you buy in the front of a drugstore you can get at a convenience store, a mass merchant or a supermarket.
It's interesting that in the United States, 70 percent of all drugstore customers are women, and 70 percent of all 7-Eleven customers are men. America has evolved where men buy stuff at convenience stores and women go to drugstores. 
Outfits like Wal-Mart are not viable competitors on the drug side. But on the convenience side, the Wal-Marts, the Kmarts and Targets have always been extremely competitive.

Q. Are drugstore stocks defensive investments?

A. Drugstores have not proved themselves to be as defensive as food retailing stocks. And next year, when you are looking for something aggressive, they won't have as much upside potential as electrical or home improvement retailers, like Home Depot.
If you want defensive growth, I would much rather own food distributors like Sysco or Performance Group, which supplies restaurants. 
That said, as long as gross margins go back to normal after this decelerating phase is over, then drugstores are great investments. That should happen, but we can't say definitely when it will. 
We are worried enough about the gross margin problem right now not to have any direct buy recommendations on the drugstore chain stocks right now. We would not mind accumulating Rite Aid and Walgreen on the dips, but we would not out-and-out buy them right now.

Q. When will Rite Aid be profitable again?

A. On an earnings-per-share basis, I would expect Rite Aid to become profitable in about three years.

Q. Walgreen, CVS and Rite Aid represent 30 percent of the market. Are smaller chains worth a look?

A. Duane Reade and Longs Drug Store are not national, but they are fine little companies. Duane Reade's sales per square foot are among the highest in the country, no matter what the good is being sold. At $900 per square foot, per year, it is twice the industry average. And they have made it extremely hard for others to get into the New York market.

Q. Does the aging of America make these companies viable long-term investments?

A. Once you get to age 55, your body starts malfunctioning. It is not going to be long before we see large numbers of malfunctioning bodies.
As a result, we see drug sales growing at a compound forward rate of 9 to 10 percent a year, year after year after year. By 2010, drugs will likely represent about 80 percent of drugstore sales.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS: VOWS; 
Rebecca Odes and Craig Kanarick

BYLINE:  By EMILY EAKIN 

 BODY:
"SHE swirled into class late, like a tornado, with a whirlwind of hair flying, and my impression was 'Wow, this woman is completely interesting,' " said Craig Kanarick, recalling his first encounter with Rebecca Odes, then a student in his New York University course on interaction design in 1996. 
 Ms. Odes, 32, was equally interested but had a complaint. During a break in the three-hour class, she asked Mr. Kanarick, who was a founder of Razorfish, a digital services firm in New York, why his lecture did not correspond with the course description. "Are you going to stick to the syllabus?" demanded Ms. Odes, a founder of gURL.com, a Web site for teenage girls, which she created with two N.Y.U. classmates that year. 
 That was the start of a freewheeling conversation about art, color theory and Web design, which took place each week after class and, after semester's end, continued over a series of increasingly romantic dates. 
One involved a five-day low-tech stay on a Caribbean island. "No phones, no cars, no television" Mr. Kanarick remembered. In another they made a trip to the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam. 
"I had always felt intimidated by art," said Mr. Kanarick, 34, whose life before Ms. Odes had been primarily about computers. "She gave me a whole new set of eyes. I'm a real geek. Not a new geek. I'm old school." 
He had his first e-mail address in his freshman year at the University of Pennsylvania, 1985, when virtually the only people online were other computer science majors. At 26, he teamed up with a friend from nursery school to start Razorfish, which became a hot property of the new economy. 
Ms. Odes, on the other hand, studied art at Vassar and taught herself to play bass guitar. By the end of her freshman year, an indie-rock band she formed with two other students, Love Child, was playing in Boston clubs. They toured the United States and Europe before breaking up. Ms. Odes managed to squeeze in a year studying painting at the Art Institute of Chicago before joining Silicon Alley. "My life had been enshrined in the music scene," Ms. Odes said. "Craig was different: a real professional person." 
Their relationship was tumultuous. Once, they separated for a year and a half. But after the dot.com failures, Mr. Kanarick and Ms. Odes remained intact. The businesses they had started were too, although Mr. Kanarick left Razorfish in May. (He is now an apprentice cook at Babbo, the hip downtown restaurant, and a publisher of Bust, a feminist women's magazine.)
"They're a brilliant, uncompromising couple," observed Michael Stipe, the rock musician, with whom Mr. Kanarick has worked.
Ms. Odes and Mr. Kanarick were married on Oct. 27 at the Angel Orensanz Foundation, a crumbling former synagogue on the Lower East Side. Evidence of their first major creative collaboration was everywhere. Before the ceremony, amid flickering candelabra, guests sipped a cocktail of pear, litchi, pomegranate, sour cherry and prosecco. 
The bride wore a filmy white corset dress with a blood-red sash by Peter Soronen, a New York designer, from a sketch she drew. 
After the ceremony, the guests feasted on delicacies like flying fish roe, a collection of Moroccan salads and Peruvian blue potatoes, and they danced to an 11-piece jug band. At one point, they crowded around a three-tier stand covered with lavishly iced cupcakes. On the top stood remarkably lifelike figurines, painted by the bride, of the couple embracing. 
"Rebecca has always been a very creative, passionate, vibrant person," said Esther Drill, the bride's oldest friend, one of the gURL.com founders. "Other people she went out with just couldn't match her intensity. But Craig does. He has an obvious appreciation for who she is. He rounds her out."

HEADLINE: ON THE CONTRARY; 
It's Time for Teamwork on New Drugs

BYLINE:  By DANIEL AKST; Daniel Akst's column tilts at conventional business wisdom and appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: culmoney@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
NOTHING weakens our faith in the sanctity of intellectual property like a little bioterror. After anthrax started killing Americans, the Bush administration put the arm on Bayer to provide Cipro, the best-known treatment, on the cheap, lest the company's patent be abrogated.
 Until recently, at least, bioterror didn't strike every day, so the case of Cipro seems a special one. But, in fact, it is only the latest episode in a long-running melodrama of dysfunctional family life -- the family ties in this case being the uneasy marriage of government and the pharmaceutical industry. 
 The government, remember, pays for much of the basic scientific research in this country. And the United States issues the patents that protect the drug companies' lifeblood -- the fruits of their research and development spending. As the issue of AIDS in the third world has already demonstrated, the eternal problem is how to balance the needs of the desperately ill, who often cannot pay, with the needs of investors, who insist on a solid shot at profits if they are to go out on a drug-development limb. 
Several solutions have been proposed in recent years. Michael Kremer, a Harvard economist, suggested that the government buy drug patents at prices set by auctions. These auctions would serve as mechanisms for setting the price the government would pay; private bidders would participate because, in a certain percentage of cases, the government would step aside and the highest private bid would win. But what if bidders collude? Or, conversely, what if private parties lose interest because they aren't winning enough patents?
Jenny Lanjouw, a Yale economist, proposes that companies could patent a new drug in the industrialized world or in the developing countries, but not both. Companies could thus choose their most profitable market, typically the industrialized countries, and leave the third world to low-cost producers. That would make AIDS medications, for instance, available in Africa at much lower prices.
Unfortunately, a recent study in the Journal of the American Medical Association found that even in countries of sub-Saharan Africa where there are no relevant patents, AIDS drugs are unaffordable.
What to do? First, the government needs to become the monopsony, or sole, buyer of drugs, a technique used by some European countries to help offset the monopoly pricing power of patent holders. Second, a government panel of scientists should designate the highest-priority ailments based on prevalence, years of life lost and cost to the economy. Drugs for these conditions would receive full 17-year patents. But medicines aimed at hair loss and other lesser maladies would receive much shorter patents.
Third, and perhaps most important, the government would make mandatory dollar-for-dollar matching grants to pharmaceutical companies for research and development in return for a 50 percent stake in any resulting patents. It's hard to imagine a better public investment: drug companies are immensely profitable, and by doubling what is spent on research, we would save lives and ease suffering by accelerating drug discovery. And by blindly matching private spending, the government can ride along with the best decisions of the marketplace without big investment-allocation headaches. The drug industry should welcome this new money, especially since it is tied to the sanctity of its patents.
Over time, the government's 50 percent patent portfolio will throw off a lot of cash. That could be used to finance new drugs to fight lethal ailments that are too rare for drug companies to otherwise address economically. In an emergency, the government could cut a drug's price by forgoing its profit share. It could even sell its stake, say, in a dermatitis drug patent to buy one for a malaria drug, whose distribution it could afford to subsidize. If the fund grew very large, it could become self-perpetuating.
Best of all, the cost would be relatively small. The pharmaceutical industry says it will spend roughly $30 billion this year on research and development, counting foreign spending in this country. That may sound like a lot, but the United States government will spend almost as much this year on farm subsidies alone. And that expenditure buys us only more expensive food -- not a bad idea if it kept us thin, but no such luck.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; 
. . . and Students Go on Assignment, Dollars in Hand

BYLINE:  By JESAMYN M. GO 

 BODY:
Gay Snodgrass, a professor at New York University, wanted to help the local economy recover after the Sept. 11 attacks, but she thought that spending the money herself would be overindulgent. So when her husband suggested that she turn her psychology students into designated shoppers, she fell in love with the idea, and so did her N.Y.U. colleague Ted Coons. 
 The two professors then gave $6,500 of their own money to 305 students, about $20 each. 
 "We thought it was a joke," said Michelle Perna, a sophomore. "Nobody expects to receive a $20 bill at the end of a psych lecture."
So what did the students buy?
Betsy Williams, who previously thought it was uncool to do touristy things, spent her money on a carriage ride around Central Park. She also shopped for tourist souvenirs -- postcards, pins and small flags -- near her dormitory on Water Street, which was evacuated for a few weeks after Sept. 11.
Some spent the money on mundane items. Lin Wang, a freshman, bought sandpaper. "I finally sanded the hinges of my roommate's squeaky drawer," she said.
A romantically inclined student approached a girl he had been admiring in class and asked her to join him for dinner in Little Italy. Another went out to get a fake ID card south of Washington Square. Why? "So I can further stimulate the economy," the student said.
Many students spent their cash on frivolous items, from expensive nail extensions to a good haircut to a second ear piercing. Others added to the money and escaped from their meal plans at downtown restaurants, or defrayed the cost of Broadway shows, from "Les Miserables" to "Reefer Madness."
"They were floored when I told them I was giving them money," Professor Snodgrass said. "They couldn't have been happier than if I announced they were all getting A's." JESAMYN M. GO

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ted Coons and Gay Snodgrass gave students $6,500 of their own money. (Ozier Muhammad/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Voices From a Place on the Verge 

BYLINE:  By ANNE HEMMETT STERN 

 BODY:
ONLY yesterday, or so it seems, the meatpacking district on the far West Side of Manhattan was the hottest place in the city. Restaurants, nightspots and expensive retailers were sprouting with a vengeance among the wholesale meat houses. By late summer, even as the economy sagged, the cluster of blocks south of 14th Street and west of Ninth Avenue seemed destined to become a second SoHo.
 Then, as a bright September morning shockingly turned black, the district suddenly found itself on the frontier of Manhattan's shutdown. Its shiny future seemed uncertain. 
 News on the home front and abroad remains bleak, and a scrim of dread continues to shroud the city. At the same time, sporadically but unmistakably, the meatpacking district is eyeing the future. The 24-hour activity has resumed. High-heeled shoppers in designer clothes pick their way over the Belgian cobblestones, past meatpackers wearing blood-smeared white jackets. In front of stylish new galleries, the streets are often clogged with trucks and workers. Clubs and signature restaurants, like Pastis on Ninth Avenue, are packed once more on the weekends. 
There's construction, too. A new restaurant called Meet is being built in a vacant meatpacking plant at Gansevoort and Washington Streets, and an another, operated by the four-star chef Jean-Georges Vongerichten, will open in a warehouse at Ninth Avenue and 13th Street. Developers are seeking permission to erect a slender, 32-story residential tower designed by the illustrious French architect Jean Nouvel and flanked by two smaller buildings, in the heart of the district, although preservation groups see the project as a threat to the district's character. The fierce debate over a proposal to designate the Gansevoort Market as a historic district has resumed. Both the tower and the landmarking issue are bubbling up in meetings of Community Board 2. The district's eventfulness has returned. 
The story of the meatpacking district, however, is not simply about real estate. More centrally, it is about the diverse inhabitants -- old-timers reluctantly moving on, newcomers staking a claim -- of this fast-changing neighborhood. It is their stories that give a human face to the transformation taking place.
Before Sept. 11, they were already being swept along in the powerful wake of urban change. Afterward, life seemed to slow to a near stop. But like the rest of the city, those in the district are struggling to find ways to move on. Here are their voices.

Metal Sculptor
Jeffery Mase
Jeffery Mase moved to the district in 1980, at 22. He had just finished art school at New York University, and his 1,400-square-foot ground-floor space on Ninth Avenue, previously a meatpacking plant, rented for $450 a month. 
"I like a grittier New York, personally," he said of the changes in the district. A compact man with a serious demeanor, he recalls the meatpackers of the early, lawless days "in white, bloody jackets with pistols in their pockets and cigars in their mouths." By contrast, many shoppers at the new stores strike him as "well-dressed women with baby-doll faces." 
Mr. Mase can usually be found welding at a vast workbench in his studio while jazz pours from a stereo. His commissions include the marquee entryway of City Hall, the fancy Duane Street restaurant, but he also creates his own pieces, some of which he describes as "vignettes of a vanishing New York." The host of an informal salon, he often throws back his welder's mask to greet other artists who regularly pop by to borrow books or chat. They sit on stools by his old forge stove, reading, or settle into the sofa, often staying on for dinner parties. 
Having spent more than half his life working and living in the district, Mr. Mase calls his studio "my anchor." But like many other local artists, he will soon be leaving. He has struck a deal with his landlord -- he wouldn't say for how much -- and will be out of the district by February.

AFTER SEPT. 11
"I know a lot of people are talking about leaving New York right now. It might be the sensible thing to do, but I don't feel it." He plans to stay in the city he loves. "I saw a space the other day," he said. "A block from the World Trade Center." Has the attack affected his work? "I think work is overrated," he replied.

Co-owner, Heller Gallery
Michael Heller
With his close-cropped gray hair and impeccable attire, Mr. Heller often acts as the public face of Heller Gallery, which he owns with his brother, Douglas. But Michael Heller exhibits a reserve similar to that of his ever-present basenji, a breed of dog known for not barking. 
"Having been pushed off Madison Avenue, I sympathize with the meatpackers," said Mr. Heller, 51, who was born and raised in Far Rockaway, Queens. "But I limit my sympathy, because they're out of step with the times."
The first Heller Gallery opened on Madison Avenue 27 years ago, quickly moving to the more affordable but relatively desolate SoHo. Two years ago the brothers made a similar landing, on West 14th Street near Washington Street. With expansive wood floors and pristine white walls, the gallery has a churchlike quality. It is hard to believe that meat hooks once rattled along overhead rails. Light glances off glasswork, the gallery's specialty, casting color into the air. In this space, the Hellers sell lustrous decorative art objects that can fetch tens of thousands of dollars apiece.

AFTER SEPT. 11
"I still get emotional talking about it," Mr. Heller said of the attack. "And I don't generally show much emotion." Though he and his brother are, in his words, "reassessing everything; advertising, everything," Mr. Heller has no worries about the gallery's long-term future. "We're still selling things," he said. "And we do believe the opposite of war is creation, including art." Even at this moment, a new installation of massive pieces cast in the Czech Republic is taking shape.

Owner, Master Purveyors
Sam Solasz
Sam Solasz, a Polish-born survivor of the Nazi concentration camp Treblinka, came to America in 1951. "I went to the meatpacking district the day I got off the boat," he said. "That afternoon, I got a job." Now 73, Mr. Solasz and his two sons own Master Purveyors, whose customers he describes as "the finest hotels and restaurants in New York," including Peter Luger and the Hilton Hotel chain. "By me, you can eat off the floor in the coolers," he said. 
For 44 years Master Purveyors was on 13th Street near Washington Street. But last spring the landlord refused to renew the lease, and the company relocated to Hunts Point Terminal Market, a 60-acre site in the Bronx surrounded by chain-link fence topped with razor wire. "Reminds you like you're in the war," Mr. Solasz said, his blue eyes clouding. "In a camp." 
His bright yellow trucks must travel much farther to reach their customers, and Mr. Solasz misses his old digs. "It was so alive," he said of the district during its heyday, which extended from the 50's through the 70's. "You couldn't move on the streets. There were five policemen on horses taking care of the traffic. You took an hour to get out of the market." He shook his head. "Today, you're flying through."

AFTER SEPT. 11
"Somebody above is watching over us," Mr. Solasz said of his good fortune at being far from the site of the attack. The company's accounts included Windows on the World and the Millennium Hilton, which together, he said, brought in $100,000 a month. "I feel bad, sick to my stomach," he said, saying he has lost many friends with whom he had done business for years. "Now the plan is to pick up more business to cover the losses. We'll get it."

Owner, Restaurant Florent
Florent Morellet
Born in France, educated as a city planner in London, Florent Morellet came to New York in 1978. Learning that he was H.I.V. positive seven years later, he nonetheless radiates energy and occasionally presides over his restaurant in drag. "People always call me a pioneer," said Mr. Morellet, 48. "I don't see myself as that. I came to the market because I liked it, not to change it." 
Change it he did, opening Florent in 1985, drawing a trendy crowd to a gritty outpost. But Mr. Morellet worries that the neighborhood's distinctive character may soon be erased, and as a result he is a co-chairman of the Save Gansevoort Market Task Force, which is seeking landmark designation for the market. On Bastille Day last July, the restaurant held its annual party, featuring can-can girls and drag-queen chanteuses. Mr. Morellet held court as "Meat Market Marie" (Antoinette), wearing a tiara made of plastic steak garnished with faux hot dogs, perched atop a cloud of white wig. The headpiece's trim, along with the busboys' aprons, smeared with fake blood, read, "Save Gansevoort Market."

AFTER SEPT. 11
"The show must go on," Mr. Morellet said of his business, adding that the activity has helped keep his mind off the "depression and horror and depth" of the attacks. "I want to keep doing whatever I've been doing." This includes going "full steam ahead" with the task force's campaign and, on Halloween, holding a party at Florent with a Catholic school theme at which he dressed as a mother superior. "I'm a recession-free type of restaurant," he said. "People always want to go somewhere fun."

Transgender Prostitute
Kelly Michaels
"This year has been all-out war on transgender prostitutes," said Kelly Michaels, absently hiking up the straps of her purple tank top and cream-colored bra. Hormone therapy and surgery have made her look feminine, although she hasn't been able to afford a full sex change. Ms. Michaels, now 30, said she has worked the streets since her parents abandoned her in a Los Angeles bus station when she was 8. Five years later she found her way to New York and soon discovered the meatpacking district. 
"This used to be a street of opportunity where a girl in her right mind could survive," said Ms. Michaels, who lives in an S.R.O. building in Harlem. As she remembers the 80's, "If you came down here, you were either a trucker, a hooker or a john." Now it's harder to find business, but work gets done. 
"I got to go," she said. "I got a trick coming." The trick was a clean-cut young man in a silver Mercedes with New Jersey plates and a baby seat in the back. No deal, though. "He asked me if I like dolls," said Ms. Michaels, turning away from the car in her high-heeled black boots. "And they call us the freaks."

AFTER SEPT. 11
How has she been since the attack? "Fine," Ms. Michaels said somberly. "I didn't know anybody that died or anything like that." She said she earned about $100 a night before Sept. 11, but that has dropped to less than $200 a week. "People are angry right now," she said. "They're looking for someone to take it out on. I don't think they're picking us up now for sex. They're picking us up to get that grudge out." Since the attack, she has also noticed more bottle-throwing and harassment, usually from people with flags on their cars. "It's rough enough that it's forcing girls to look for other options," she said. She herself hopes to be off the streets before winter, leaving her S.R.O. and working as a dominatrix out of an apartment.

Concession Stand Operator
Jason Adame
"Every time I got the chance, I snuck out of school and went down there," said Jason Adame, 20, who started spending time in the district when he was 11. He would help his father, then the superintendent of 430 West 14th Street. Later, the son started working in the concession stand outside the building, which his father still runs.
The stand leans like a discarded appliance box against the Washington Street side of No. 430. Through a sliding plexiglass window, Mr. Adame and his father sell snacks, from Power Bars to beef jerky. They could soon see competition from Starbucks, but their top-selling item, a cup of coffee, still goes for 65 cents. 
When Mr. Adame walks through the neighborhood, meatpackers honk their horns and wave from their trucks. Having known them since he was a child, he automatically waves back. "They look out for me," Mr. Adame said. Like so many salty uncles, they taught him about contraception, kept him out of fights and urged him to stay off drugs. They also gave him driving lessons in their trucks. 
When Club Mother was open on the building's ground floor during the 1990's, the stand's late-night clientele was a mix of meatpackers, clubgoers and transvestites. "I remember one time when I was about 14," Mr. Adame said, "and a man in a black mask and leash and leather underwear was being led into the club. The meat guys just laughed." The stand is open from 1 a.m. to 1 p.m. to accommodate the meatpackers. But as they continue to leave the district, business is steadily dwindling.

AFTER SEPT. 11
"We used to be all confident," Mr. Adame said, referring to Americans in general, "and now a piece of that is gone." Before the attack, the stand brought in $600 or $700 a day. Now the take is $200 to $400, he said. With business still fading, the Adames have decided to leave the stand later this year. The father has already gone back to Chilpancingo, the small city in Guerrero, Mexico, where he was born, and the son plans to join him once the stand closes for good. "I'll take a nice little vacation," he said. Then he will either study architecture or open a clothing store in Mexico. "We'll see how it goes," he said. "First I've got to sharpen up my Spanish."

HEADLINE: The Glorious, the Gaudy: 5 Decades of T-Birds 

BYLINE:  By JIM MOTAVALLI 

 BODY:
THE lights dim, the curtain rises and glamorous fashion models pull the wraps off the retro-styled, nostalgia-inducing 2002 Ford Beaver.
Doesn't sound right, does it?
 Yet the name of nature's dam builder was once considered for the car now known as the Thunderbird, whose rich history reaches back to the 1955 model year. Or the T-Bird might have been called the Detroiter, a name whose luster faded as the fortunes of the Motor City declined. And another label once considered, the Hep Cat, would seem as hip today as "23 skidoo." 
 It was a young Ford stylist, Alden Giberson, who gave the Thunderbird its evocative name. Having lived in the Southwest, he had heard the Native American legend about a creature whose flapping wings created thunder and winds. The name stuck -- Mr. Giberson was rewarded with a $95 suit -- and Ford rolled out its two-seat convertible as an answer to Chevrolet's sporty Corvette. To most buyers, it didn't matter that the pretty skin covered off-the-rack Ford parts, or that vague steering and a low-revving V-8 made the T-Bird more suitable for turnpike cruising than for weekend racing.
In 47 years, the Thunderbird has come full circle: from jaunty two-seater to flashy personal coupe to bloated luxury barge -- and now, back to its roots. And even as the new car evokes Ford's glory days of the 50's, the company is returning to day-to-day control by a member of the founding family, for the first time in more than two decades. Last week, William Clay Ford Jr. became chief executive as well as chairman.
Few cars are as evocative of the 50's as the 1955-57 T-Birds. While the models that followed sold better, only the two-seaters qualify as American icons. Still, some other generations are of interest to collectors, and the arrival of the '02 Thunderbird, after an absence of four years, may stimulate a broader interest in previous models.
"I think the new car will complement the old ones," said Al Walentis of Mount Penn, Pa., who runs a Web site, TBirdFans.com. "This will help build interest."
The T-Bird supports several national collector clubs. Rick Carey, an automotive historian in Mystic, Conn., said he did not expect the new car's arrival to affect prices of early models very much. "The supply of classic T-Birds is pretty substantial, so a blip in demand can be met without forcing prices up," he said.
Here is a look at each generation of T-Birds, and how they have fared in the used-car market:

CLASSIC BIRDS The T-Bird roadster may have been hastily conceived to compete with the Corvette, but it was an instant success. The entire production run was sold out, and there were waiting lists of eager customers.
The early T-Bird underwent small changes during its three-year run. In '56, the car got a 12-volt electrical system, the famous porthole hardtop and a "continental kit" -- a covered spare tire perched on the rear bumper. Larger but graceful tailfins arrived for '57.
It is easy to understand the enduring popularity of these cars, which look good from any angle and represent a rare instance of restraint from a period of over-the-top styling. And the car succeeded in its principal task: slaying the Corvette in the market. In just three years, Ford sold 53,000 T-Birds, more than three times the Corvette's total for five years.
Early Thunderbirds have always been popular with collectors, so there are many restored examples at premium prices. A rare supercharged "F" Bird once owned by the animator Mel Blanc brought $145,500 at a Christie's auction in 1997. A fairly plain '56 sold for $178,500 in 1999 -- but its first owner was Frank Sinatra.
Sales: 14,190 in model-year '55; 16,763 in '56; 15,173 in '57
1955 base price: $2,695
Recent prices: $30,000 ('55, full frame-off restoration); $65,000 ('56, perfect and unrestored, driven just 89 miles); $100,000 (rare, supercharged '57)

SQUARE BIRDS For 1958, Ford sought to broaden the T-Bird's appeal by adding a back seat. The square, four-passenger model was no sports car: it weighed more than a big Ford sedan. Still, it won on racetracks.
Motor Trend magazine made the '58 its Car of the Year. Annual sales quadrupled those of the two-seater, proving that the change made good business sense. The styling has a certain blunt appeal today, and prices are gradually rising. A concours-winning '60 convertible brought $54,000 at the Barrett-Jackson auction in Scottsdale, Ariz., in January.
Sales: 48,482 in 1958; 72,859 in '59; 81,555 in '60
1958 base prices: $3,630 hardtop; $3,914 convertible
Recent prices: $22,500 ('60 convertible, good driver); $8,500 ('58 hardtop, needs work)

BULLET BIRDS These cars' clean lines fit neatly with the era's fascination with space exploration and supersonic flight. The oversize round taillights looked like jet turbines and the interior resembled an airplane cockpit (complete with "Swing-Away" steering wheel). As for performance, a '61 hardtop with a 390-cubic-inch V-8 could reach 60 m.p.h. in 8.5 seconds, despite a weight of two tons-plus.
The most sought-after model today is the Sports Roadster, which mimicked a two-seater with a rather odd fiberglass cover over the rear seats. A very original '63 Sports Roadster with a 340-horsepower tri-power engine and desirable Kelsey-Hayes wire wheels brought $84,800 at last year's Barrett-Jackson auction.
Sales: 85,142 in 1961; 74,306 in '62; 67,871 in '63
1961 base prices: $4,170 hardtop; $4,637 convertible
Recent prices: $14,500 ('61 hardtop, all original); $23,900 ('62 Sports Roadster, restored)

FLIGHT BIRDS If 1961-63 T-Birds hinted at the Space Age, those of 1964-66 looked as though they were ready to take off, complete with "Flight Deck" instrument panel. Power disc brakes (an option on the '65) meant that the T-Bird could stop as well as go. On the '65 and '66, the rear turn signals lighted in sequence, like a neon sign on the Las Vegas Strip.
These are considered the last of the classic Thunderbirds, and because of 60's nostalgia, they retain a strong following. Landau models, which came with vinyl roofs and fake carriage trim, were the most expensive hardtops.
Sales: 85,661 in 1964; 72,132 in 1965; 68,816 in 1966
1964 prices: $4,486 hardtop; $4,589 Landau; $4,853 convertible
Recent prices: $6,950 ('64 Landau, good driver); $14,500 ('66 convertible, unrestored)

FLIGHTLESS BIRDS "The 1967 Thunderbird represents one of the most dramatic styling changes in industry history," Ford says. But many collectors say the shift from sporty to luxurious was a change for the worse. All T-Birds had put on weight and society airs, and a new four-door model made purists cringe. The public's response was lukewarm, and it remains so today.
Sales: 57,313 in 1967; 67,373 in '68; 49,381 in '69
1967 prices: $4,603, two-door hardtop; $4,704, two-door Landau; $4,825, four-door Landau
Recent price: $3,895 ('69 two-door Landau)

BEAKED BIRDS The '70 T-Bird thrust an aggressive, Pontiac-style nose at an indifferent public. Insurers hated the accident-prone prow, and owners griped about pumping premium fuel for the thirsty 429-cubic-inch V-8. Prices went up and sales went down despite a "Special Brougham package" and lots of gadgets.
Sales: 40,868 in 1970; 41,801 in '71
1970 prices: $4,961, two-door hardtop; $5,104, two-door Landau; $5,182, four-door Landau
Recent price: $3,000 ('70 Landau)

FLABBY BIRDS Given the chance to redesign the Thunderbird completely, Lee A. Iacocca, Ford's president, ignored the fading cries of purists and made the '72 even bigger and more ostentatious. Now based on the Lincoln Continental Mark IV, the T-Bird weighed in at more than 4,500 pounds before options. The lapse in taste was rewarded with higher sales, though interest flagged quickly after the '73 model. Collectors are perfectly happy to let these cars rust away, though there's a spark of interest in the one-millionth T-Bird, an Anniversary Gold '72 with a commemorative plaque.
Sales: 58,731 in 1972; 79,759 in '73; 47,646 in '74; 36,803 in '75; 91,104 in '76
1972 price: $5,293, two-door
Recent price: $2,500 (1972, new paint, 105,000 miles)

SHRUNKEN BIRDS After the nation's first fuel crisis, the Thunderbird -- 10 inches shorter and 900 pounds lighter -- was a shadow of its former self. Though the new car was based on the Ford LTD, it was still rococo, with "opera windows" in the roof pillars and concealed headlights beside a square, convex grille.
The public liked the smaller size, and they loved the upscale Town Landau, with an aluminum applique that wrapped over the roof. After purchase, owners were mailed a personalized "gold finished" nameplate. Even more sought-after is the Diamond Jubilee Edition, commemorating Ford's 75th anniversary. Color choices included Pastel Beige with Ember vinyl roof. The Jubilee even had owners' initials hand-painted on the doors. Proving that there's no accounting for taste, these were the best-selling Birds ever.
Sales: 322,517 in 1977; 304,430 in '78; 215,698 in '79
Original prices: $5,063, '77 hardtop; $10,106, '78 Diamond Jubilee
Recent price: $2,500 ('78 Diamond Jubilee, needs work)

LOW-RENT BIRDS Downsizing continued with the 1980 models, based on the pedestrian Ford Fairmont. Still, T-Bird styling cues abounded, including opera windows, neoclassic grille and covered headlights.
In '80, Ford used yet another anniversary gimmick: the T-Bird's 25th birthday. Owners of the high-priced Silver Anniversary car could sink into "velvetlike knit velour" seats. One advantage of the downsizing was better fuel economy: 29 m.p.g. on the highway. In 1981, Ford shocked purists by introducing a six-cylinder engine. Sales plunged.
Sales: 127,248 in 1980; 69,775 in '81; 49,585 in '82
1980 prices: $6,432, hardtop; $10,036, Town Landau; $11,679, Silver Anniversary
Recent price: $3,000 (46,000-mile '80 in original condition)

AERO BIRDS The T-Bird finally flew again in 1983, with aerodynamic styling that presaged the future Taurus and was considered radical in its day. To the chagrin of buyers over 40, the traditional look was out as Ford pursued youth. A new model, the performance-oriented Turbo Coupe, could be ordered with a five-speed manual transmission and special handling packages. Enthusiasts, and the automotive press, went wild.
Sales: 134,710 in 1983; 154,865 in '84; 157,209 in '85; 140,713 in '86; 132,623 in '87; 117,866 in '88
1983 prices: $9,485, V-8 hardtop; $12,516, Heritage; $11,790, Turbo Coupe
Recent price: $2,000 (Turbo Coupe, loaded, 95,000 miles)

SUPER BIRDS Ford spent more than $1 billion to develop the '89, and for its money, it got a handsome wedge shape. Young men lusted for the year's favorite car-magazine cover model, the Super Coupe, which used a supercharger to extract 215 horsepower from the 3.8-liter V-6. Nascar wins helped to bring customers into showrooms, too.
Traditionalists wanted the V-8 back, and Ford obliged in 1991 with the motor from the 5.0 Mustang. But the market for coupes was shrinking; when sales sank below 70,000 in 1997, Ford clipped the T-Bird's wings and a five-year hiatus began.
Sales: 120,645 in 1989; 106,124 in '90; 74,189 in '91; 84,186 in '92; 122,415 in '93; 130,713 in '94; 104,254 in '95; 68,577 in '97
1989 prices: $14,612, coupe; $16,817, LX; $19,823, Super Coupe
Recent prices: $2,000 ('89 Super Coupe, loaded)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: TIMES SQUARE; 
On Once-Bawdy 42nd Street, The Last Dirty Picture Show

BYLINE:  By KELLY CROW 

 BODY:
Perhaps Peep-O-Rama, at 121 West 42nd Street near Avenue of the Americas, never meant to make history. Awkwardly sandwiched between a Tad's Broiled Steaks and a Touch of New York souvenir shop, its neon red-and-black marquee is kept unlighted,day and night. Inside, the workers behind the counter are polite but reticent. 
 Recently, though, Peep-O-Rama, a sex video store, became the last of its kind along the entire stretch of 42nd Street, a lone survivor of Times Square's seamy past. Three similar stores on the same block have closed in the past year; the latest shut down in late summer. Ten other sex-oriented shops still dot the area, down from 96 in 1977 and 35 in 1987. But only Peep-O-Rama remains on what was once the most X-rated of streetwalking strips, 42nd Street. 
 By the turn of the last century, the street from Madison to Eighth Avenues was lined with "silk hat" brothels and burlesques; discreet men in carriages gave way to giddy soldiers on leave in wartime. During the Depression, male prostitutes filled its sidewalks as barkers lured customers into theaters to see nude dancers.
By efforts of reform and economy, those establishments gave way to the "Midnight Cowboy" era of peep shows, massage parlors, pornographic bookstores and strip clubs in the 1960's and 1970's. Through it all, there were campaigns to clean up the Square, most famously in 1995, when the city passed strict zoning laws governing sex-related businesses. High real estate prices also did their part; the street now glows with multiplexes, a corporate sheen. 
Two weeks ago, a City Council committee approved amendments to the 1995 laws, including tighter definitions aimed at what officials call "sham compliance" by video stores and bookstores. But could a case ever be made for preserving Peep-O-Rama or its facade for Times Square posterity? 
Discussion is scarce. The Landmarks Preservation Commission and the New-York Historical Society would not comment; neither would the Mayor's Office of Midtown Management.
Gary Brandt, a landlord of the shop, said Peep-O-Rama had been on 42nd Street since 1950, first as an adult movie theater. Mr. Brandt said he was not sure how long the business would stay open, although, he added: "The character of this street is so well documented in movies and books and tourists' snapshots that the store is already in a time capsule of sorts. Any historical designation rings hollow to me."
But for William R. Taylor, editor of "Inventing Times Square" (Johns Hopkins, 1991), the lasting presence of a sex-oriented shop on 42nd Street is as significant as the Tenement Museum of the Lower East Side.
"A big city should, in some way, be able to write its autobiography in places," he said. "New Yorkers love our underworld in film and fiction, so it makes sense to somehow preserve it in reality." KELLY CROW

GRAPHIC: Photo: Peep-O-Rama, a vestige of a seamy past. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The Sex-Worker Literati 

BYLINE:  By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
TRACY QUAN, the 30-something author of "Diary of a Manhattan Call Girl," sat in the generic chill of an Upper East Side Starbucks and talked about how one goes about having sex with strangers for money. 
 "See that building?" she asked, narrowing her almond-shape eyes at an anonymous tile brick apartment across First Avenue. "It's a perfect working-girl apartment. It's anonymous, there's no nosy doorman, but it's still an appropriate building in a relatively safe place." She laughed and added: "And I ought to know." 
 American readers ought to know, too, if the onslaught of new books by strippers, prostitutes, hustlers and pornographic film actors is any indication. Suddenly, it appears that sex for hire is to pop literature what cocaine and models were to fiction in the 1980's and Prozac was to the memoirs of the 90's -- obligatory references in works aspiring to urban realism. 
Whether a novel about prostitution like Ms. Quan's or a memoir of a male street hustler in Hollywood, the books are selling and, to the annoyance of some critics, trying to be part of a no-shock zone in American culture. At least one Barnes & Noble, on East 86th Street, displayed Ms. Quan's "Diary of a Manhattan Call Girl" alongside Harry Potter books and "Jack: Straight From the Gut," the best seller by John F. Welch Jr., retired chairman of General Electric.
Though some critics see the genre as only the latest attempt to market titillation, their authors insist their aspirations are mainly literary. In the last 18 months, at least a dozen books have explored the inner lives of prostitutes or strippers. Rick Whitaker's memoir of male prostitution, "Assuming the Position" (published by Four Walls Eight Windows), was followed by J. T. LeRoy's "Sarah" (Bloomsbury), an autobiographical novel about a 12-year-old boy who so idolizes his addict-prostitute mother that he dresses like a girl and performs sex acts at a truck stop. Mr. LeRoy's work has achieved cult status since Courtney Love and Angelina Jolie conducted a public fight over which actress would play the role of the addict-prostitute in the film.
In recent months, along with Ms. Quan's autobiographical novel, Lily Burana's "Strip City" (Talk Miramax) and Alexa Albert's "Brothel: Mustang Ranch and Its Women" (Random House) have also been selling well. And Tristan Taormino, an author of sexual how-to manuals -- her most recent is "Pucker Up: A Hands-On Guide to Ecstatic Sex" (HarperCollins) -- said she was now working on a personal book. 
Early next year, HarperCollins will publish David Henry Starry's memoir, "Chicken: Self Portrait of a Young Man for Rent," and in the spring will reissue "The Happy Hooker," Xaviera Hollander's 1970's best seller. And Ms. Hollander has been signed to write a memoir about discovering her sexuality as a child. 
Reviews for Mr. LeRoy's and Ms. Burana's books have generally been favorable. Ann Powers, writing in The New York Times Book Review, described "Sarah" as "a wonderfully dirty, picaresque roman a clef." Also in the Book Review, Kate Sekules praised Ms. Burana's "candid, juicy, streetwise prose." 
On the other hand, Michiko Kakutani, commenting on Ms. Albert's book in The Times, said it "provides an often intriguing look at the economics and emotional dynamics of the brothel but is seriously undermined by the author's lack of reportorial skills."
Sex memoirs are nearly as old as the world's oldest profession. The 11th-century "Tale of Genji" is a biographical account of the sexual exploits of a Japanese prince in the demimonde. Some critics argue that the current rush of titles originates not in an increasingly sex-obsessed America but in changing feminist attitudes. Susan Griffin, the author of "The Book of the Courtesans" (Broadway), a history of courtesanship from ancient Greece to the belle epoque, published this year, says that in the last decade many academic feminists have shifted their position on prostitution. 
"Feminists are now starting to look at sex work as an undeniable part of women's lives, and not with such a baleful, shameful eye," she said. "This is something that women have had to resort to when options were narrow, and let's not join in the chorus of moralizers -- who often, by the way, are the patrons -- but let's study sex work as we would any other phenomenon in our society."
Ms. Burana, who stripped her way across the United States for her book after she became engaged, said she was secretive when she started as a stripper because she feared the disapproval of friends. 
"It was the late 80's, and feminist politics were strict," she said. "Then the stick got bent in the other direction. Suddenly it was 'Stripper power! Thumbs up!' " 
Think of these books, Ms. Burana instructed, as the literary equivalent of thong panties. Ten years ago, only professional strippers wore thongs, she said. Now average women buy them at Kmart and Victoria's Secret. An elevated sexuality in popular culture -- Britney Spears's hot pants, the charged images in music videos -- saturated the country when Ms. Burana wrote her book, she said. In 1997, when she started the strip tour, she was able to find appropriate outfits only in boutiques that catered to the sex industry. 
"By 2000, I was buying my outfits at Contempo," she said, referring to a shopping-mall clothing chain. "The clothes for teenagers have become so strippified. I was a little alarmed. These aren't clothes for a 30-year-old. These are for 16-year-old girls who are going to a party with their peers. All of a sudden I had this mad flash of protective conservatism. But it was a cultural marker." 
Christine Stolba, a senior fellow at the Independent Women's Forum, a conservative research institute in Arlington, Va., said she thought of the sex books as "a self-centered literary seraglio." 
"We're not so blase, even in the post-Clinton years," Ms. Stolba added. "We know that this is different than being on Temptation Island. The big problem I have with these books is that the authors think their personal experience has anything to teach society at large. I don't think a fun book about being a prostitute is going to teach women, especially young women, anything of value." 
Furthermore, Ms. Stolba said, the memoirs are a bald attempt to cash in on titillating subject matter. 
That's a line of attack that Ms. Burana said she had heard before. 
"There is that accusation that you are Gordon Gekko in spandex, and that this is all about greed and opportunism," she said. "To suggest that these books are about opportunism is the critical equivalent of saying, 'Your mama wears army boots.' " 
Ms. Quan said she was unaffected by criticism of her motives.
Besides, she said, she has hit her own cultural milestone. She is to appear with Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist at the Meet the Authors Night and Book Fair in Washington on Nov. 28. 
"If that's not being part of the Establishment, I don't know what is," she said. "I can't wait."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Rumbles Of Warning As Housing Weakens

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
THE already sinking American economy is developing a new leak. 
 The leak is in housing, not only home construction but also home sales, home prices, home remodeling, rents, brokerage fees -- the whole industry. All have weakened since June, by enough to pull down the growth rate of the entire economy. Instead of contracting at an annual rate of four-tenths of a percent in the third quarter, as the government said last week, the economy would have declined only half that much, just two-tenths of a percent, if housing had been as strong in the third quarter as it was in the second. 
 "People were asking me only a couple of months ago if a bubble was developing in home prices, like the bubble that developed in high-tech stocks," said Nicholas Retsinas, director of Harvard's Joint Center on Housing Studies, referring to the persistent strength in housing that defied a sinking stock market and economy. "They are not asking me that question anymore, absolutely not."
The leak is still small. No one is claiming that home prices are actually falling, at least not most home prices. But they are rising more slowly. The statistical and anecdotal evidence is now clear on that point, and on a couple of others. Without anyone having really noticed, sales of new and existing homes have inched downward since June, despite steadily falling mortgage rates. And home construction is off its peak, having begun to fall before Sept. 11, and certainly afterward. 
Anecdotal evidence of a weakening housing sector is also proliferating. Mr. Retsinas, for example, says landlords in Boston, his hometown, are beginning to offer rental incentives. Without lowering the actual rent, they are waiving payment for the first month or two. "That way, the amount on the lease remains unchanged, and thus the value of the rental dwelling," he said. 
In Cincinnati, Sibcy Cline, that city's biggest real estate broker, reports that inventories of unsold homes are rising, and while actual sales have not dropped, home prices are going up much more slowly -- at a 2.5 percent annual pace, half the rate early this year. "People selling their homes are becoming more realistic about the prices they are asking," said Robert Sibcy, the chief executive. 
Mr. Sibcy shares many forecasters' view that the economy will rebound by early next year, before layoffs and rising unemployment begin to really affect housing. "Housing may just miss the recession," he said. 
Or housing may swing from a source of support for the economy to a drag, as the third-quarter data suggests. Falling mortgage rates may have kept housing robust through many months of sluggish economic growth, but other factors are now weighing in. The surge in layoffs and the terrorist attacks appear to be making people cautious, particularly about buying a home. Then, too, falling stock prices may finally be taking their toll on housing; while stocks were rising, wealthier households used the gains to remodel or to buy new homes. The housing market, in effect, may be following the stock market down. 
Whatever the explanation, housing has a multiplier effect potentially greater than that of the stock market. Housing, not stocks, is the principal asset for the middle 60 percent of all households, those with annual incomes of $30,000 to $75,000, according to Edward N. Wolff, a New York University economist who studies household wealth and income.
WHEN home prices rise, these households feel wealthier and are quicker to spend their weekly pay. And when mortgage rates drop at the same time, there is a great willingness to refinance and turn, say, a $100,000 mortgage into $105,000, for the same monthly payment. 
Refinancing has indeed surged, and half the households that refinanced in the last year increased their mortgages, Mr. Retsinas said. They cashed out the extra equity from rising home prices. That extra cash, available for consumption, helped to prevent a sluggishly growing economy from tipping into contraction, until last July. The wealth effect from rising home values turned out to be enough to offset the damage from the plunge in stock prices. 
Now new studies are turning up "strong evidence," as Robert J. Shiller, a Yale economist, put it, that variations in housing market wealth have much more effect on consumption than any wealth effect from stocks. The stock market grabbed the headlines as the great source of stimulus in the booming 1990's, while housing did the heavy lifting. And now that housing is shifting toward reverse, mortgage refinancing is likely to become more of a means of lowering installment payments than sustaining consumer spending. The damage to the economy could be considerable.

HEADLINE: Word for Word/Sept. 11 Seminars; 
Academe on War: Man (and Woman) The Psychobabble Detectors!

BYLINE:  By TOM KUNTZ 

 BODY:
AMERICA is at war, and following suit, the nation's professoriate is rapidly deploying courses. Notably, the University of California at Los Angeles has just launched 49 undergraduate seminars across a range of disciplines to address "the innumerable issues arising out of the events of Sept. 11." The courses include "Navigating Between Blithesome Optimism and Cultural Despair" and "Implications of World Crises for Student Stress and Academic Achievement: Coping Strategies."
 Eyebrows are already being raised. Citing the U.C.L.A. courses and other such developments in the United States, Bryan Appleyard, in a commentary for The Sunday Times of London, wrote that "an unprecedented assault on mainland America is being turned into sentimental psychobabble, an occasion for nationwide counseling or politically correct pseudo-courses." 
 But judge for yourself. Here are excerpts from some of the course descriptions (a couple with grammatical errors), posted on U.C.L.A.'s Web site at www.college.ucla.edu/hnrs98. TOM KUNTZ
Course: "Navigating Between Blithesome Optimism and Cultural Despair"
Instructor's description: I intend to share the sense of crisis about my teaching mission that I experienced on Sept. 11, and examine the context of Enlightenment values that have given meaning to my life's work. My faith in the unlimited creativity of human beings in solving the problems of their environment, in the capacity of the imagination to invent new solutions to economic, physical and psychological dilemmas, in the liberation of mental energy and fresh ideas from the fetters of dogma and fear, was sorely tested on that fateful Tuesday. I will attempt to dissect and comprehend the events through their representations, for only through understanding can we prevent future recurrences of such events.
Course: "Women's Participation in Political Violence"
Description: The course poses the question: What is women's relationship to political violence? Using a feminist lens, the course examines the participation of women in radical political movements in the late 20th-century United States. Women are often not the director actors in violent acts; more often they are victims, participants or accomplices. The course tries to understand the motivations, complex behaviors and world views of radical women.
Course: "Echoes of Terror in Brain, Mind and Literature"
Description: Traumatic historical events, such as those of Sept. 11, evoke both shared and highly individual responses. In this seminar, we will discuss ways in which people cope with public terror in their lives. We will examine the neurobiological and psychological effects of terror and the transformation of these responses into creative expression.
Course: "What the U.S. Should Do to Be Popular in the Third World"
Description: The reasons for the unpopularity of the U.S. government in the third world are examined. The persistently negative reaction of the Latin American left wing against U.S. trade policies; the 20th-century condemnations of the U.S. by essentially all communist countries; the Ugly American in Southeast Asia; the demonstrations against our W.T.O. meetings; and the growing Arab hatred of the U.S.: Are these hatreds coincidental? What do they have in common? Although our policy makers clearly desire to help these countries, have we subconsciously evolved policies that are highly economically inefficient and essentially exploitative of the third world?
Course: "Implications of World Crises for Student Stress and Academic Achievement: Coping Strategies"
Description: sic Exploration of the relationship among world crises, students stress as they relate to student achievement. Students will maintain a journal during the quarter, including interviews of other students. Enrollment limited.
Course: Understanding the Unthinkable and Incomprehensible
Description: In this course we will try to understand two fundamental questions that are raised by events of Sept. 11. First, how can people unleash acts of terror on innocent citizens? Second, what are the consequences of mutual cultural ignorance? . . .
Course: "Terrorism and the Politics of Knowledge"
Description: While the world rightfully stands united in its condemnation of the bombings of Sept. 11, the American mainstream media has remained impervious to those critical voices which have also drawn attention to America's own record of imperialistic adventurism and the relation of the W.T.C. bombings to American excesses in Iraq, Sudan and the Middle East. This seminar asks fundamental questions about how we constitute terrorism and its agents. What are the categories of knowledge deployed to understand terror? Should the continuing sanctions against Iraq also be considered a form of terrorism? What is the relationship of the bin Ladens of this world to Western state terrorism? Who defines and names terrorism, with what authority, and with what consequences?
Course: "Culture and the Deferral of Violence"
Description: Exploration of the hypothesis that human language and culture sic is essentially a means of deferring violence, and its application to the current situation.
Course: "Terror & Society in Bergman's Films"
Description: Drawing on two films by Ingmar Bergman about terror, questions will be asked about the origins of terror in Society and, in particular, within male/female relationships. Possible reduction in the threat of terror will be explored.
Course: "War, Terror and Violence: Reflecting on Machiavelli"
Description: Is war a legitimate instrument of politics? Can war be a just act of the state? How do wars waged by states differ from acts of violence by individuals? Why is the word 'terror' used for some acts of violence? This seminar will explore these questions from the point of view expressed by Niccolo Machiavelli in parts of "The Prince," a book written almost five centuries ago but often cited today when such questions are discussed.
Course: "Literature as Mourning: China and Greece"
Description: Examines texts from world literature, especially the Chinese and Greek traditions, as responses to the loss of loved ones and as ways of managing, cultivating and redirecting the force of grief.
Course: "Beyond Tears: Evidence, Fact and Crisis"
Description: An exploration of the evidentiary concepts that may help students and citizens avoid being misled by those who manipulate crisis for their own ends.

HEADLINE: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS; 
Comfort Shopping, Premium Pricing

BYLINE:  By LYNNLEY BROWNING 

DATELINE: GREENWICH, Conn. 

 BODY:
FASHION-CONSCIOUS shoppers, distracted more by economic and political concerns than by the latest Prada tote, are shunning luxury goods. Purveyors of opulent wares are bracing for a lean Christmas. In Susie Hilfiger's opinion, that means it's a perfect time to sell $540 cashmere bunting bags for babies.
 Ms. Hilfiger, who is separated from the fashion designer Tommy Hilfiger, is the founder and owner of Best & Company, a retailer of costly clothing and furnishings for children. The private company, with a store in this leafy New York suburb of multimillionaires, is betting that in a world worried about the economy, anthrax and Afghanistan, wealthy Americans want what Ms. Hilfiger calls "comfort shopping." 
 In August, Best opened a boutique offering $510 hand-smocked silk toddler dresses and $4,700 rocking horses in Bergdorf Goodman in Manhattan. It is preparing to photograph for a spring catalog in the West Indies, where some customers own estates. It is redesigning its Web site so that clients can buy a $5,000 Margarete Steiff toy giraffe or a $1,200 Silver Cross baby carriage online. And Ms. Hilfiger is thinking of opening shops across the country. 
In the uneasy world that has emerged since Sept. 11, Best strives to be Old World.
There is nothing Old World about prices at the store here, where leather club chairs nestle among Oriental rugs and sterling silver curl boxes line mahogany cabinets. There are $6,000 English pedal cars (an antique one costs $20,000) and $380 silk christening gowns. There are 19th-century embroidered cloths, first editions of children's books and hand-painted furniture from Dragons of Walton Street, which outfitted Prince William's nursery.
Best also sells children's basics like cotton baby shirts and Levi's, as well as other, more midrange items like $78 lamb's wool sweaters. The company seeks to be what Ms. Hilfiger calls a "lifestyle brand," with one-stop shopping and old-fashioned service -- sewing name labels into a boarding-school wardrobe, for example, or packing a camper's trunk with a Best riding habit.
"This is not a luxury experience," said Ms. Hilfiger, who has been a fashion designer for more than 20 years and has four children ages 6 through 16. "It's a timeless, sensible background. The way you feel when you shop here is like holding a warm cup of cocoa."
BEST resurrects the name and ambience of the fabled Fifth Avenue emporium that was a favorite among wealthy New Yorkers until it went bankrupt in 1971, after 122 years in business. Ms. Hilfiger acquired the trademark rights to the abandoned name without cost and opened the Greenwich shop in 1997.
Since the attacks, spending has been regarded as an almost patriotic duty. But the more frugal-minded may question the appropriateness of spending $350 on a cashmere baby throw in increasingly lean times.
Although people may be feeling a renewed commitment to family since Sept. 11, said Juliet Schor, a professor of consumer psychology at Boston College, "excess and exclusivity do not feel comfortable or important to people right now."
That was not necessarily the mood on a recent October afternoon at the 4,500-square-foot Best store here. Over the course of an hour, perhaps a dozen well-dressed customers came in to buy cashmere baby sweaters, bow ties and leather shoes. Six of the $4,700 rocking horses have been sold so far this year, more than in all of 2000. And sales of cashmere crib blankets have picked up this year, to about a dozen a month. 
"Right now, purchases for the self seem indulgent, but purchases for children reinforce a sense of family," said Ellen H. Keogh, 44, who as president of Best oversees its business. Ms. Hilfiger, 43, designs many of its clothes and decorates clients' nurseries and playrooms.
Sales at the Greenwich store dipped slightly after the attacks, and the drop notched down sales projections for the third and fourth quarters by 10 percent, said Ms. Keogh, who was previously a staffing manager at PepsiCo. About half the store's customers are from Greenwich -- many of them Wall Street executives -- and the remainder are from elsewhere in Connecticut as well as Long Island and New Jersey.
But the Bergdorf boutique, which opened in August, has not had a slowdown in recent weeks, said Ronald L. Frasch, chairman and chief executive of Bergdorf Goodman. 
"The person who's looking for a quality product for their children is still going to be looking for a quality product for their children," Mr. Frasch said. Sales had exceeded his expectations, he said, although he declined to provide figures. Anne Randell, a spokeswoman for Best, said sales of luxury products at the Bergdorf boutique were outpacing those at the Greenwich store.
ALTHOUGH Best's sales have quadrupled over the last four years, the company expects revenue this year of $7 million, the same as last year. Unlike many other retailers, Best said it had not canceled or reduced any orders from suppliers in recent months.
That does not surprise Gregory J. Furman, chairman of the Luxury Marketing Council, a trade group in New York. Amid economic and political uncertainty, he said, many wealthy shoppers want "things that bring emphasis to the home and family and bring joy and warmth."
Best may also be tapping into the guilt felt by extremely wealthy parents about the time they spent working during the recent economic boom. Parents who spend more hours at the office and fewer at home "may feel they have neglected their children and are trying to make up for it" with high-ticket purchases, said Lars E. Perner, a visiting professor of marketing at the University of California at Riverside.
Best, which has 19 employees, closed its Nantucket store last January after its lease was not renewed. (Its building was put up for sale.) Business there was too seasonal to warrant looking for new space, Ms. Randell said.
But the company aims to grow, though not into a mass luxury brand like Gucci. Over the next three years, Best plans to open at least five freestanding stores and boutiques in luxury department stores like Neiman Marcus, which, like Bergdorf Goodman, is owned by the Neiman Marcus Group. While no stores are scheduled to open anytime soon, possible locations include Los Angeles, Palm Beach, Fla., and Chicago. Ms. Keogh said the company had not scaled back any expansion plans but declined to provide details.
Best said its Web site, under construction, will be a cyberspace version of its white-glove service. Best's catalogs, issued sporadically in previous years, will appear regularly starting next spring. Best declined to provide details on how Ms. Hilfiger will finance its growth.
The expansion strategy may work, said Kristine Koerber, a luxury-retail analyst at W. R. Hambrecht in San Francisco. "If you can afford to expand now, it makes sense to gain market share," she said, adding that several mass-market retailers like Pottery Barn entered the market for higher-priced children's goods. 
Sandra Chollet, a merchandising manager for luxury baby clothes and furnishings at Barneys New York, the department store, echoed that view. "The baby business has not suffered -- if anything, people are being even more generous with their buying since Sept. 11," Ms. Chollet said.
BEST'S competitors, at least in luxury clothing, include private boutiques on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, the French chain Tartine et Chocolat, and the children's lines of designers like Burberry, Dolce & Gabbana and Paul Smith, which are sold mainly in specialty stores like Barneys.
But Ms. Keogh said that no competitors carried both deluxe children's furniture and high-end clothing, and that brands like Dolce & Gabbana were not in line with what she called the new conservative taste. 
That taste, some marketing consultants say, reflects not only a new form of conspicuous consumption but also a longing for a bygone era. 
Best's image "captures the spirit of wanting to go back to a more innocent time," said Wendy Liebmann, president of WSL Strategic Retail, a consulting company, referring to the time before Sept. 11. "People are looking to refocus their spending, and they've recognized that our children are important because we may not come home tomorrow."
