HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH/Clifford Greenberg; 
Baron Small Cap Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
MANY investors in small-capitalization stocks look for rapidly growing technology and biotechnology companies. But not Clifford Greenberg, who runs the $600 million Baron Small Cap fund.
 "There's no rocket science in this fund," Mr. Greenberg said from his office in Midtown Manhattan. "I buy industries and businesses that I can understand." 
 As a result, his fund owns no technology or biotech stocks, even though the average small-cap growth fund has a technology stake of 25.4 percent, according to Morningstar Inc. (Morningstar does not break out biotech from technology and health care.)
The fund returned 14.4 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday, compared with 11.4 percent for its small-cap growth group and 0.8 percent for the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, Morningstar said. It lost 17.1 percent in the 12 months through Thursday, versus a 25.1 percent loss for its group and a 22.7 percent decline for the S.& P. 500.
Mr. Greenberg, 42, sifts through United States companies with market capitalizations of $100 million to $1.5 billion. The fund wants to buy, he said, "when we can make a 100 percent return over the next 18 months because, in our opinion, the stock is priced incorrectly."
To pick the 50 or so stocks in the portfolio, he uses no computer screens. Instead, he works with 14 industry analysts at the Baron Capital Group to find what he calls classic growth companies, fallen angels and special situations.
Classic growth companies, he said, can enjoy annual earnings growth rates as high as 50 percent or 100 percent. Fallen angels are distinguished by steeply declining stock prices. "These are companies where we believe the long-term prospects are great," he said, "and the short-term problems that knocked down the price are insignificant."
Special situations include companies that are emerging from bankruptcy or those with new management or new products. 
He spends much of his time talking with companies' executives. "We're significant shareholders in most of the companies we own, and we have close relationships with management," he said. "We want to understand their business plan and keep a close watch on how the business is developing."
He seeks companies with price-to-earnings multiples that are no higher than the companies' projected earnings growth rates. And he wants businesses with strong growth prospects for at least five years; one-quarter of the companies have been held since the fund's inception in 1997. He sells when a company's shares have met his price targets or when its business fails to develop as anticipated.
The fund's biggest position is in the Career Education Corporation, a company in Hoffman Estates, Ill., that provides a variety of post-secondary education at 38 campuses in the United States, Canada, Britain and the United Arab Emirates. He anticipates that earnings will grow 30 to 50 percent a year for the next three years.
"They buy a small local college with a good reputation that teaches one curriculum," he said. "They take over management, recruiting students from local high schools and outside the area, and add additional curricula." The company's schools offer programs in business administration, interior and graphic design, computer programming and other disciplines. Its campuses include Briarcliffe College on Long Island and Katharine Gibbs Schools around the country.
He bought the stock at $4 in 1998 and added shares at $21.90 in September. They closed on Friday at $28.74; his 12-month price target is $45.
MR. GREENBERG bought shares of California Pizza Kitchen, a restaurant chain based in Los Angeles, at $23.70 in the initial offering in August and added shares at $17.36 in October. The company operates about 100 restaurants nationwide, concentrating in California. The stock price has fallen, he said, because investors have worried about the California economy. "They charge $10 for a meal, so even if unemployment rose, it wouldn't affect their customer base in California," he said. Management is expanding the chain rapidly, he said; he expects per-share earnings growth of 25 percent a year.
The shares closed at $17.92 on Friday; his price target is $30.
Mr. Greenberg said catalysts for his investment in AMC Entertainment, the movie theater company based in Kansas City, Mo., were a company recapitalization and an industry consolidation that has closed down other companies' theaters, to the benefit of chains like AMC.
He bought shares at $6.97 in April and more at $9.39 in October. The stock now trades at $12.01; his price target is $18.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
Hands Out,Even in a Time Of Crisis

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
WHERE'S Frank Capra when you need him? 
 Surely, he would know how to make entertainment out of the greed and rank opportunism that has characterized behind-the-scenes Washington since Sept. 11. The moment it became clear that lawmakers would be bailing out troubled industries, passing a stimulus package to restart the economy and putting some teeth into money-laundering laws, the lobbyists moved in. 
 Alas, with Mr. Capra gone and his kind of movie a thing of the past, Americans may never enjoy the spectacle of wealthy corporate lobbyists swarming the Capitol steps, lunging for handouts at the whiff of crisis. Instead, they'll suffer through it. 
Whatever happened to the idea of everybody pulling together, setting aside self-interest for the sake of a wounded country? Is grabbing for all you can now so imbued in corporate culture that executives don't remember what it is to act with honor? 
Richard Sylla, professor of business history at New York University's Stern School of Business, said corporate lobbying for tax breaks during a crisis is a relatively new behavior. "Taxes went up in World War II and nobody seemed to object," he said. "There was more of a spirit of cooperation. It was more 'What's in the national interest?' than 'Can you do something for us?' "
One egregious me-first move now gaining traction is repeal of the corporate alternative minimum tax, created in 1986 to keep profitable companies from using loopholes to eliminate taxes. Even worse, the House plan would return all the A.M.T. ever paid by these corporations. That would send billions in rebates to I.B.M. and Ford Motor and hundreds of millions to General Motors, General Electric, Texas Utilities and DaimlerChrysler.
If corporate America were groaning under the weight of onerous tax rates, repealing the alternative minimum tax might be acceptable. But while the presumed corporate tax rate is 35 percent, loopholes bring the effective average tax rate for big companies way down. Robert McIntyre, director of Citizens for Tax Justice, a liberal advocacy group in Washington, calculated the effective corporate tax rate at 20.1 percent in 1998, on average, down from 26.5 percent in 1988.
While I.B.M. reported $5.7 billion in pretax profits last year, Mr. McIntyre said its federal income tax bill amounted to just 10.8 percent of that figure. Without the alternative minimum tax, I.B.M. would have paid 7.6 percent. G.M. earned $2.9 billion, pretax, in 2000, he said. Even with the A.M.T., its federal tax bill totaled only 1.5 percent of that.
"Take the repeal of A.M.T. and park it next to the big goose in depreciation write-offs in the bill and we're back to the early 1980's, when half the biggest companies in the country were regularly not paying any taxes at all," Mr. McIntyre said. 
Big banks and financial industry groups mounted perhaps the most sinister post-Sept. 11 lobbying effort, trying to thwart some money-laundering provisions of the antiterrorism bill. Publicly, the corporations claimed support for the bill, which became law on Oct. 26. But several people who witnessed the furious lobbying efforts said some banks and industry groups tried to water down the bill into October. 
"The bill gives important weapons to the administration to fight money laundering," said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan district attorney, who has pursued money launderers aggressively. "The only reason this bill was passed was because of the leadership of Carl Levin, Paul Sarbanes and Joseph Biden. They dug in their heels," he said of the three senators.
Even hardened Hill staff members were surprised at the opposition to two relatively basic provisions in the bill. The first required financial institutions to conduct due diligence about who their customers are and where their money comes from. The second, which the staff members say Citigroup worked especially hard to defang, prohibited American banks from opening accounts for foreign shell banks, those with no physical presence and no affiliation with another bank. Shell banks are post office box operations tailor-made for money laundering and are found in places like Egypt and Ukraine. 
IMAGINE requiring banks and brokerage firms to know who their customers are. Don't lawmakers realize how much due diligence can eat into profits? So what if asking such questions might have stopped a handful of terrorists from killing thousands of innocents in the World Trade Center? 
Richard Howe, a Citigroup spokesman said, "We strongly supported the anti-money-laundering legislation." The modifications were designed not to soften it, he said, but to make it more effective.
Still, Citibank has had dealings with shell banks. The Senate's Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations last February named it as holding accounts for two shell banks, one associated with criminal behavior. Billions of dollars moved through the accounts, it said, until they were closed.
Perhaps self-interested corporate machinations are de rigueur now, war or peace. Maybe putting profits before patriotism is the way that the world works today. If so, I want to get off.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Learning to Love Fannie and Freddie

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
MAE WEST undoubtedly had something other than the stock market in mind when she declared that "too much of a good thing can be wonderful." But it is a sentiment that pretty much describes the way Wall Street's security analysts now appraise Fannie Mae, the giant mortgage company.
 Of 23 analysts who follow it closely, 22 recommend buying its stock; the other recommends holding on to what you already have. 
 The earnings increases at Fannie Mae -- running at a 20 percent pace this year -- have repeatedly beaten expectations and have been so robust that it has been buying back its debt, holding down current profit for future benefit. Interest-rate margins have actually expanded, even though the company's chief financial officer predicted in January that they would shrink as they did in the refinancing boom of 1998. 
The Treasury's decision last week to discontinue sales of its 30-year bond should also help. Analysts said that this would lead to lower mortgage rates, implying more business for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac and further widening of their profit margins as their securities become benchmarks.
But people who buy stocks are less enthusiastic than those who peddle them. The shares of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, its younger and smaller brother in the $5.9 trillion residential mortgage finance business, are relative laggards. They are selling at about 14 times projected earnings for next year, half the level of the Standard & Poor's 500. Three years ago, their multiples were in the low 20's.
"The markets work in mysterious ways sometimes," said Kenneth A. Posner, mortgage finance analyst at Morgan Stanley, who recommends Fannie Mae. 
Jayne J. Shontell, Fannie Mae's senior vice president for corporate development and investor relations, agreed. "It's an enigma," she said.
It did not help when Warren E. Buffett, the billionaire investor, sold a big chunk of Freddie Mac stock last year. Some investors apparently took his decision as a signal that heady returns were likely to slow. Investors may also be wary of political backlash against special government benefits that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, created to promote home ownership, still enjoy.
Fannie Mae predicts that a 20 percent profit leap this year will be followed by "mid teens" growth in 2002, its typical pace for the last several years. The only other companies in the S.& P. 500 to produce double-digit earnings growth every year since 1987 are Microsoft, Automatic Data Processing, Home Depot and Schering-Plough.
OUTSPOKEN bears are nowhere to be found, but analysts say investor reticence about the companies mainly reflects fears of recession and the possibility of less new mortgage business. More important, they say, are possible defaults by people with existing mortgages. Some investors, not aware of the companies' sophisticated hedging practices, may have thought that they would suffer as declining interest rates induced borrowers to refinance, paying off mortgages early. 
"There are people who are cautious, because they think it's as good as it's going to get," said Bruce W. Harting, who follows the stocks for Lehman Brothers. But those who study Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac professionally, like Mr. Harting, contend that so much of a good thing can indeed endure and prove wonderful for investors.
Jonathan E. Gray, an analyst who covers mortgage finance at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, said that the stocks have the potential of increasing 20 percent or more. He believes Fannie Mae could be selling at $105 to $110, compared with the current $82.56, and Freddie Mac could be at $85, compared with $69.52. 
The federal government chartered Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac but later privatized them -- Fannie Mae in 1968 and Freddie Mac in 1989. Essentially, their business is buying residential mortgages from banks and others who originate them, paying for them with the proceeds from sales of their bonds in the market. Then they either package the mortgages for sale to investors or retain them in their own portfolios. They also guarantee third-party mortgages.
"The worry seems to be that the events of Sept. 11 will tip the economy into recession and this will lead to rising mortgage defaults and credit losses," said J. Timothy Howard, Fannie Mae's executive vice president and chief financial officer, in a conference call with analysts on Oct. 15. He said the parallel cited most often was the 1990-91 recession linked to the Persian Gulf war.
Wall Street generally agrees with Mr. Howard that such fear is misleadingly superficial. For one thing, Fannie Mae suffered little in the early-1990's recession, its total credit losses in portfolio and mortgage-backed securities rising by less than two-hundredths of 1 percent by 1994. If that experience were repeated now, growth in earnings per share would be trimmed by less than one and a half percentage points annually over the next three years. "That's not a very big hit," Mr. Howard said.
Moreover, the economy has fewer imbalances than it did a decade ago, housing is stronger and, most tellingly, Fannie Mae's book of business is considerably more solid. 
Homeowners' equity now averages 42 percent of market value, versus 30 percent in 1990, reducing the risk to lenders of a default. The percentage of guarantees carrying insurance or some other form of credit enhancement has risen to 36 percent from 24 percent. In addition, riskier adjustable-rate mortgages have dwindled to 7 percent of business from 17 percent.
"Concerns about impending Fannie Mae credit problems seem greatly overblown," Mr. Howard said.
Even the political winds have shifted to Fannie Mae's and Freddie Mac's backs. With federal charters and modest lines of credit to the Treasury, the companies benefit mightily from market presumptions that the government would come to their rescue if they had financial trouble.
That makes their borrowing costs less than those of competitors, several of whom have organized to prevent them from using their advantages to expand into other businesses. These advantages include exemption from registering with the Securities and Exchange Commission and from state and local income taxes. "They're too big to fail and too big to control," complained Mike House, a Washington lawyer who serves as executive director of FM Watch, whose members include banks, mortgage brokers and others who see a threat to their role in housing finance. A few members of Congress have joined in the criticism.
Fannie Mae, one of Washington's most ferocious lobbyists, and Freddie Mac have largely blunted the attack. "They did a really good job of handling the political risk," said Anna Dopkin, who holds both companies' stocks as portfolio manager of the T. Rowe Price Financial Services fund. And with terrorism and recession now such dominant concerns, she said Congress was likely to find little time for "messing around with one of the few parts of the economy that's held up."
ANALYSTS and others regard the critics' complaints as a testament to the companies' prospects. While barred by charter from originating mortgages -- in a whimsical moment, Franklin D. Raines, the chairman of Fannie Mae, offered to tattoo on his forehead that it would abide by this restriction -- Fannie Mae has been moving onto new turf like subprime loans while making increasingly effective use of powerful, proprietary technology. Its program of automated underwriting, for example, may threaten others in the business, notably mortgage bankers.
"We've got intermediaries who are losing their power," said Gary Gordon, mortgage finance analyst at UBS Warburg, who also rates Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac as strong buys. 
While the mortgage market itself may be growing at only 6 percent or so a year, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac are viewed as likely to expand their share of a broader business. "This is really the key to our call," said Mr. Posner of Morgan Stanley, who figures on double-digit profit growth continuing for 5 or 10 years. Despite the huge size of Fannie Mae, he said, there is "lots of room" before it bumps any ceiling.

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
Patriotic Partisanship On Capitol Hill

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
EVER since the terror strikes of Sept. 11, President Bush, like some latter-day George Washington, has tried to position himself as a man above party, the commander in chief, for whom politics itself is slightly declasse.
 Mr. Bush has forsworn fund-raisers and campaigning as he pursues his mission to "rid the world of evil." His once omnipresent political guru, Karl Rove, is nowhere to be seen, strategizing far offstage. And the new standard photo op of this presidency is the stern faces of a war cabinet. 
 But politics goes on. There are programs to be fought over, and another election is always on the horizon. Partisanship may be a dirty word with an anxious electorate, but life without it is unnatural, even impossible, in Washington.
The ideological differences between the two parties remain profound. And so, despite the overwhelming support for the war effort on Capitol Hill, political combat returned with a vengeance last week in the House over whether airport security screeners should be federal employees.
Everyone reverted to familiar roles. Conservatives raged against government bureaucracy and accused Democrats of wanting to swell the ranks of organized labor. "It's all about union membership in a union that imposes compulsory dues that fund their campaigns," said Representative Dick Armey, the majority leader from Texas, in the days leading up to the House vote.
Senator John McCain, the Republican from Arizona, played the scourge of his party's right wing, noting that "some of the brave firemen and police enforcement people that have died in the World Trade Center were members of a union."
And Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House minority leader, called House Republican leaders extremists who had taken campaign money from the airport security companies, "the special interests who did not want to lose their contracts."
Only Mr. Bush was out of character, a new convert to former President Clinton's faith in political triangulation. While the president worked hard, and successfully, behind the scenes to pass the Republican version of the bill, his administration signaled publicly that he would sign any reasonable measure to make it to his desk -- allowing him to look statesmanlike and to claim victory either way.
"He's trying to stay above politics," said Representative Thomas M. Davis III, the Virginia Republican who is head of his party's re-election effort in the House. Noting Mr. Bush's sky-high approval ratings, Mr. Davis added: "In a way that's good. A president with strong numbers helps the incumbent party."
But it is also a high-wire act. Mr. Bush's conservative base is complaining that the president they helped put into office is no longer reliably on their side. And Democrats are predicting that the vote to keep airport security private will prove a costly victory, reinforcing the view that on domestic matters, the Republicans are led by Mr. Armey and Representative Tom DeLay, two Gingrich-era hard-line Texas conservatives.
"I think Tom DeLay and Dick Armey will make the case for a Democratic House," Representative Nita M. Lowey, the New York Democrat in charge of her party's House campaigns, said succinctly.
Other crisis-era presidents may offer some perspective on Mr. Bush's task. Abraham Lincoln also sought to stand above party, campaigning for re-election not as a Republican but as the candidate of the union party. Franklin D. Roosevelt dropped the rhetoric of class warfare he had used during the Great Depression and used prominent Republicans in the war effort after the bombing of Pearl Harbor. "This is what presidents do in wartime," said Richard Shenkman, a presidential historian.
Maybe, but senators and representatives can't simply call themselves sub-commanders in chief. Especially in a recession, they have to show that they are better able to help their constituents than their opponents.
Both parties are already trying to figure out how to win the 2002 elections under these changed circumstances. The Republicans in Congress contend that they will be bolstered by Mr. Bush's approval ratings and the public's desire for stability (and hence incumbency) in a crisis. 
Republicans also say that issues of war and national security, which they said favor them, have displaced the Democrats' issues of education, health care and environmental protection.
Democrats counter that history is on their side -- that even popular wartime presidents see their party suffer in off-years. Roosevelt's Democrats took a beating at the polls in the off-year election of 1942, less than a year after Pearl Harbor.
"There was enormous support for Roosevelt," said Doris Kearns Goodwin, a presidential scholar. "But a long war was dragging on without many victories, and the price of the war was being felt throughout the nation. The sacrifices were being felt without the concomitant victories."
Similarly, the nation may be mired in an inconclusive war on terror next year, and the economy could still be in trouble. So Democrats plan to stay firmly at Mr. Bush's side in support of the war effort, while putting forth their own economic plans, with calls for increased unemployment compensation and more health care.
"There are clear differences on the domestic front, and we are going to have to articulate them," Ms. Lowey said. "People are so nervous. They are hurting. They are afraid. The candidates who show them they are on their side will be the ones who succeed."
INDEED, polls show that despite Mr. Bush's popularity, Democrats stand poised to win races for governor in New Jersey and Virginia and the mayor's race in New York City on Tuesday. 
It could well be that the political landscape is changing even now in ways that neither party has recognized. David Winston, a Republican pollster, has found that voters are fundamentally rethinking their values. And in what he calls a "bizarre bifurcation never seen before," voters feel optimistic about the direction of the country even as they say that the economy is worsening and that they fear for their personal security. He attributes the optimism to pride in the nation's response to terror, the sacrifices of New York's firefighters and police officers.
Bill Frist, Republican of Tennessee, is not just the Senate's lone doctor but also the head of the National Republican Senatorial Committee, and recently he asked 17 Republican media advisers about the shape of the political future. 
"I asked each one to address the impact of Sept. 11 and the president's response on the next elections," Mr. Frist said, referring to 2002 and the control of Congress. "Every one of them said there was no precedent and we don't know. It was interesting. People don't even try to pretend there's a construct out there."

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
The Boom Is Over. What's Next?

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
DON'T count on going back to the days when the Nasdaq was a one-way bet, Alan Greenspan was omniscient and all-powerful, Bill Gates could be portrayed as the worst predator on the horizon and the biggest challenge for the unemployed was sorting out the job offers. 
 If there was any remaining doubt that the boom of the 1990's had expired, burying the assumption that the good times could continue forever, last week took care of it. 
 First the government reported that the economy contracted in the third quarter, signaling that the nation has almost certainly entered a recession, the first in 11 years. Then came a statistic that brought home the meaning of an economic downturn: the unemployment rate surged by half a percentage point last month, to 5.4 percent, the biggest one-month jump in 21 years. 
It is not clear when the economy will recover, or how robustly it will perform once the downturn ends. Economists are forecasting a relatively healthy bounce-back by the middle of next year, but their projections are little more than guesswork, especially given the raft of uncertainties about the course of the war and the possibility of further terrorist attacks.
Whenever the rebound happens, though, the character of the economy that eventually emerges from the recession is sure to be very different from the economy the United States enjoyed and grew accustomed to over the last decade. Humpty Dumpty cannot be put back together again.
Every business cycle has its own flavor, and it is impossible to know exactly what characteristics will define the next expansion. But it is a good bet that after a long period in which the virtues of unfettered capitalism have been almost unquestioned, the next new economy will reflect a wartime drift back to a recognition of the importance of government and a post-boom hangover induced by excessive faith in market forces to get it right all the time.
"The normalized economy will be wearing a different set of clothes on the other side of the recession," said Paul A. McCulley, an economist at Pimco, an investment firm in Newport Beach, Calif. "When we come out of it, the pendulum will again be trying to find the right place between unadulterated capitalism and enlightened government."
The prosperity of the late 90's -- what now seems to have been the final stage of a long expansion that began in the early 80's -- was shaped by and reflected a variety of influences, many of which were fading or changing even before Sept. 11.
Being the lone military and economic superpower, the embodiment of the triumph of democratic capitalism, turned out to mean being vulnerable, as well as being the envy of the world (and there is almost certainly a link between the two). 
The federal budget deficit turned almost overnight into a huge surplus -- which in turn disappeared just as fast. The democratization of the stock market meant that everyone could share in the riches created by the nation's entrepreneurial genius, and suffer along with the plutocracy when the bubble burst.
The pervasive sense of optimism, the national swagger that both reflected and helped fuel the high-performance economy of the 1990's has, temporarily at least, given way to a period in which Americans are looking over their shoulders to see what they did wrong, while peering anxiously ahead in the hope that they will see a glimmer of hopeful light.
BUT for all that it looks in retrospect to have been unsustainable all along, the 90's boom had plenty of characteristics that are well worth trying to preserve. Two in particular are likely to get considerable attention in coming months and years.
One is the benefit the upturn brought to people at the low end of the economic spectrum.
At a time when there was a political consensus to scale back welfare programs and encourage and reward work, the last expansion generated millions of entry-level jobs, allowing people who might previously have been unemployable to get a toehold in the work force. And while some of those jobs did not pay a living wage, incomes grew at a healthy pace across the economic spectrum and in black and Hispanic as well as in white households, helping to drive down poverty rates.
The other positive characteristic of the long boom was the edge it gave the United States in business efficiency. 
Beyond all the hype about dot-coms, technology really was transforming the economy in concrete ways -- in particular by helping to drive a resurgence in productivity, or the ability to produce more for less. After languishing for two decades, the growth rate of productivity -- the single best indicator of an economy's ability to expand in a sustainable way -- began accelerating around 1995.
WHEN productivity growth is strong, companies can make more money without raising the price of their products, and can afford to pay their employees more. Computers, more precise machine tools, faster communications -- companies invested heavily in all of them and more, seeking an advantage in a brutally competitive global marketplace.
Those issues and others will be considered in an atmosphere in which some of the assumptions about economic policy and the role of government in general are being re-examined. 
Under the pressures of war, the Bush administration, which until Sept. 11 held a fairly doctrinaire view of the benefits of small government and market forces, has already taken such interventionist steps as threatening Bayer with the loss of its patent if it did not drop the price of the anthrax-fighting drug Cipro. 
This week the House and the Senate will clash over whether airport security workers should be made part of the federal work force, with some Republicans joining most Democrats in arguing that the nation cannot rely on private industry to protect travelers.
"No one wants to have stupid government," Mr. McCulley said. "But no one wants stupid capitalism either."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The United States Capitol on Oct. 17, after concerns over anthrax caused the shutdown of the House of Representatives. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Nicaragua to Decide Fate of Ortega's New-Age Candidacy 

BYLINE:  By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Nov. 3 

 BODY:
Throughout Daniel Ortega's third campaign to return to the Nicaraguan presidency, the slogan "love is stronger than hate" has been his New Age mantra. The question for Nicaraguans going to the polls on Sunday, however, is whether it is stronger than their memories.
 Mr. Ortega, the Sandinista leader, lost the presidency in elections in 1990 after more than a decade in power. Now, tied in opinion polls with the Liberal Party candidate, Enrique Bolanos, he concedes that his movement's concept of socialism was a utopian goal and says he accepts free markets and democracy. 
 He is popular among thousands of young people who never knew the hardships of life under his administration but who complain that corrupt officials are enriching themselves while opportunities for jobs and education are shrinking. 
Mr. Ortega has built a coalition that includes former political foes. Some of them, including his running mate, Agustin Jarquin, were once jailed by his government.
His opposition has been reminding voters, though, of the country's economic and social collapse during the 1980's, when inflation veered out of control and thousands of young people were drafted into the military.
The opposition has been supported in spirit by the United States government, which also played a role in Nicaragua during that era by financing the contra resistance army that ensnared the country in a violent and divisive war.
American diplomats have repeatedly expressed serious reservations about a Sandinista return to power and have criticized Mr. Ortega over his government's record of confiscated properties, human rights abuses and relations with foreign leaders who had financed, trained or sheltered terrorists.
Tonight, former president Jimmy Carter, who is heading an international delegation of electoral observers, criticized the strong statements that had come from Washington in recent months. "I personally disapprove of statements or actions by any country that might tend to influence the vote of people in another sovereign nation," he said.
Both leading candidates have offered ambitious programs that they contend will create jobs and help the poor while stimulating investment. While the appeals from both sides will do little to sway their own partisans, they could make the difference with the thousands of undecided voters, who may well determine the outcome of a race that seems too close to call.
"They are people who move between fear and desperation," said Carlos Fernando Chamorro, a political analyst and publisher of a political newsletter. "There is fear from the association of Ortega and the past conflict with the United States and an economy that was out of control. And there is the desperation over unemployment, poverty and corruption. Bolanos has the fear vote in his favor." 
Mr. Bolanos has clearly enjoyed the favor of American officials, including the United States ambassador to Nicaragua, Oliver Garza, who invited Mr. Bolanos to accompany him on a delivery of emergency food aid to hungry peasants. 
Governor Jeb Bush of Florida wrote an opinion article for The Miami Herald in which he said "Ortega's past and present clearly indicate that he neither understands nor embraces the basic concepts of freedom, democracy and free enterprise."
The opinion piece was reprinted as an advertisement in a local paper under a headline that said, "The brother of the president of the United States George W. Bush Supports Enrique Bolanos." 
Also, John Keane, the acting deputy assistant secretary of state for Western Hemisphere affairs, said last month that the Sandinistas still had in their fold hard-liners who were responsible for "abominations" of human and civil rights.
"Given their history," he said during a speech he delivered in Pittsburgh, "why should we believe assurances that they have changed, since there have been few concrete actions to demonstrate it?" 
Statements like his have taken on a new urgency since the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, with the United States stating that nations must show whose side they are on. Mr. Bolanos has seized on these statements in advertisements and campaign speeches, including his closing speech in his hometown of Masaya on Wednesday.
"If Ortega comes to power, that would provoke a closing of aid and investment, difficulties with exports, visas and family remittances," he said. "I'm not just saying this. The United States says this, too. We cannot close our eyes and risk our well-being and work. Say yes to Nicaragua, say no to terrorism." 
Mr. Ortega has avoided responding to those criticisms for most of his campaign, although some close supporters have repeatedly said they were willing to work with the United States to combat drugs and terrorism. But they have also criticized the American warnings.
"How is it possible for the United States to talk so much about democracy and then try to intimidate the people of Nicaragua to go to the polls with a pistol at their heads?" asked the Rev. Miguel D'Escoto, a former Sandinista foreign minister. "Is that a free election? No." 
On Thursday night, during a reception at the Hard Rock Cafe here, Mr. Ortega finally addressed some of the barbs, making reference to the country's past armed conflict.
"This country has been the victim of military operations and terrorism," he said. "We have the moral authority to condemn terrorism and to show our willingness to contribute to the United States' struggle against terrorism." He also said he thought the American criticisms would not have the intended effect.
"The will of the people has been defined," he said. "This will not be modified, regardless of their declarations."
In his closing campaign speech in Nindiri on Wednesday, Mr. Ortega told the crowd that he wanted the country to reject the politics of hate and confrontation that his opponents had espoused. As he spoke, several people waved American flags, including a huge one that fluttered over a billboard.
"That shows we want peace and good relations with the United States," said Adilia Gonzalez, a college student. "We show with that flag that we do not want war. We want unity and we want this country to move forward. What better than the support of the greatest power, the United States?"
While many Sandinista supporters said they believed that Mr. Ortega had changed, Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo, a longtime Sandinista critic, delivered a homily the next day that questioned whether Mr. Ortega's transformation was sincere. 
Mr. Ortega, who faces unresolved accusations of sexually abusing a stepdaughter, was in the front row at the outdoor Mass with Rosario Murillo, the woman with whom he has lived for decades. Though he has insisted the abuse charges are without merit, Mr. Ortega did not go to trial since the Legislature refused to lift his immunity from prosecution as a member.
"Parents should look at their children as children of God and respect them as human beings," the cardinal said. "In electing our candidates we should see if they preach with the testimony of their lives, if they have been exemplary in their families."
The crowd cheered loudest when he said: "Do their acts support their words? Has the candidate always had that attitude or position or is it simply a change of direction with electoral goals?"
Beyond the accusations, whoever is elected will inherit a government crippled by debt and burdened by unemployment. And given the economic contractions being felt around the world, the winner will have little room to maneuver as he tries to deliver on campaign promises. Investment had already slowed to a trickle as businessmen wait for the outcome of the elections.
"Given the state of the U.S. and the hemisphere's economies, a quick rebound is unlikely," said Robert Pastor, a professor of political science at Emory University. "The days of utopia have passed. Latin America is into either incremental progress or none." 
Some experts see Mr. Ortega as having the advantage of not having been associated with the charges of rampant corruption that have afflicted the government of President Arnoldo Aleman. And unlike Mr. Bolanos, a successful businessman who was president of the private enterprise council, Mr. Ortega has support among some of the poorest neighborhoods in the country.
But Mr. Bolanos does have the confidence of investors. He is also perceived as undoubtedly honest, though as Mr. Aleman's former vice president, Mr. Bolanos waited until late in the campaign to distance himself from Mr. Aleman. In several recent speeches, Mr. Bolanos took pains to mention that he, Mr. Ortega and Mr. Aleman should not be above the law.
At the Liberals' closing rally, people streamed through the streets of Masaya insisting they would defeat Mr. Ortega.

GRAPHIC: Photos: As Nicaraguans vote for president today, Daniel Ortega, the Sandinista leader, above, and Enrique Bolanos, below, are about even in the polls. (Photographs by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL; 
Jordan Lifts Wizards Out of Their Mediocrity

BYLINE:  By MIKE WISE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 

 BODY:
Matt Harpring was holding Michael Jordan down in the third quarter, using his forearms and his quick feet to stay with him. The crossover dribble did not freeze Harpring. Jordan's bobbing head did not rattle him. Nothing from the past was working.
 So, on a night when pro basketball ostensibly returned to the nation's capital, Jordan merely transported his game to the future. 
 A spin to the left. An exaggerated head fake. The high-arching rainbow, softly rolling around the rim and in. And the foul. The 3-point play that put the Washington Wizards ahead for good tonight at the MCI Center gave the clearest glimpse yet of what is in store for this reinvigorated franchise.
Sometimes passing off, sometimes plodding, but always snarling, a very old-school Jordan shelved athleticism and relied on his savvy. Before a sellout crowd of 20,674 and a first-ever, prime-time network television audience in November, Jordan and his team simply competed, beating the injury-depleted Philadelphia 76ers, 90-76, in the home debut of the game's most accomplished player.
Jordan's 20 points on 7-of-21 shooting and his 9 assists helped put the Wizards above .500 for the first time since 1999, when the team opened the season with a victory. Washington, now 2-1, rebounded from a 13-point deficit in the second half to blow out the Sixers, who were missing Allen Iverson, Eric Snow and Aaron McKie.
Whether this little run lasts does not seem to matter. Tonight, in a city that has known more infamy than excellence on the basketball court, a legend represented new hope.
"Once I realized I wasn't in an offensive rhythm, I just started moving the ball," Jordan said. "When you're not shooting the ball well, there are other things you can do on the basketball court to help the team. I was just trying to help my team any way I could."
The whole evening was mostly an homage to Jordan's playing career. Washington Mayor Tony Williams welcomed Jordan before the game, saying, "We happen to have our own economic stimulus package in the nation's capital."
By the time the "From North Carolina" refrain pulsated through the arena's sound system during player introductions, the crowd let out a thunderous ovation. At halftime, the singer R. Kelly sang "I Believe I Can Fly," a leftover from Jordan's animated movie.
Tony Metzger, a season-ticket holder since 1992, said the game was the most emotionally charged he could remember. "Can't imagine why," he said, smiling.
Simmy Martin, whose brother bought her tickets for her 14th birthday, said: "I came two years ago to a Wizards game. It was depressing. Nobody was here and it was a sad game. I wasn't inspired to come back, until Michael came back."
For Jordan, surely it beat watching from an executive-level suite with fewer than 10,000 people in the stands.
He had help. Richard (Rip) Hamilton was on the receiving end of several of Jordan's kick-out passes from the post. Hamilton scored 29 points, hitting 11 of 18 shots and keying a third-quarter run that effectively ended the Sixers' quest to win their first game of the season.
Philadelphia (0-3), the defending Eastern Conference champion, was led by Craig (Speedy) Claxton, who had 22 points. Claxton, a Hofstra graduate, wowed the crowed, knifing his diminutive frame through mounds of muscle and carrying the 76ers the way only an undersized point guard could.
Jordan struggled early, making only 4 of his first 13 shots. He looked out of sync, his reflexes seemed slow and his vertical leap was nothing to write Nike headquarters about. But as the game wore on, Coach Doug Collins put Jordan at the top of the key, a point guard's game in a small forward's frame.
"I really could not find my rhythm," Jordan said. "I'm struggling with my jump shot, but there was so much focus on me, I was able to get teammates involved. And Rip got hot and that really helped us a lot."
Jordan passed out of the double teams, penetrated and distributed at the last possible second. And as the lead grew to 20 points in the final minutes, the crowd rose and roared. Fast breaks and 15-0 binges, once a foreign concept to the Wizards, were suddenly part of the landscape.
As the game ended, Jordan congratulated each of his teammates. He did not have the look of a high school principal handing out diplomas, but it was close.
"The hunger to win is very strong here in Washington," Jordan said. "And that's something you can sense as a player."
Perhaps Billy King, the 76ers' general manager, best summed up the night: "Wizards-Sixers on NBC? In November? You believe this?"

HEADLINE: Deep-Running Similarities Link New York's Mayoral Rivals 

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

 BODY:
Mark Green and Michael R. Bloomberg say they would be very different mayors at an enormously important time for New York City, when an economic downturn, the aftermath of the terror attacks and considerable shortcomings with the schools seem to demand exceptional qualities in the city's next leader.
 Mr. Bloomberg, a billionaire businessman, characterizes Mr. Green as someone who complains about problems and himself as someone who solves them. Mr. Green, the city's public advocate, depicts Mr. Bloomberg as an elitist dabbling in elective politics for the novelty of it and himself as a public servant with a long record of doing the right thing. 
 Each insists that the next four years are too important for voters to take a chance on the other in Tuesday's mayoral election. Yet for all the attention to their different backgrounds, Mr. Green, the Democratic nominee, and Mr. Bloomberg, the Republican, are not unlike each other in other significant ways, including some of their underlying prescriptions for running the city. 
Few doubt that a Mayor Green and a Mayor Bloomberg would convey decidedly different public images. For starters, Mr. Bloomberg, who is divorced, has said that he would not make the mansion, which is the mayor's official residence, his regular home. He prefers the familiarity of his apartment on East 79th Street, he said.
Mr. Green has identified some of the people whom he would look to for advice, a list that is heavy on well-known Democrats in the city, from Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi to Stanley Brezenoff, a deputy mayor in the Koch administration. Mr. Bloomberg has been more circumspect about the makings of his inner circle, suggesting in a recent interview that he would draw from academia, business and government and that perhaps the best clue would be the guest lists for his dinner parties.
Almost predictably, their criticism of each other has been directed primarily at who they are and who they are not.
"Hopefully, more people as time goes on will find that my background makes the most sense," Mr. Bloomberg said on Friday about his improved standing in recent public opinion polls.
At their televised debate on Thursday, Mr. Green was asked to identify Mr. Bloomberg's main shortcoming as a would-be mayor.
"Of the two of us, I'm the only one who's spent time in the public sector," he said. "My rival hasn't spent one minute in public life."
In the final week of the campaign, the two have expanded upon those themes and intensified their attacks on each other's ability to govern. Mr. Bloomberg describes himself as able to unite the city, arguing that Mr. Green has encouraged racial divisiveness by running a tough primary campaign against Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president. Mr. Green says his record demonstrates his commitment to the city's diverse communities and criticizes Mr. Bloomberg for having little familiarity with the city's residents and for trying to buy support by spending a record $41 million on his campaign.
But in essence, both men have identified the same basic priorities in the next four years. Style and backgrounds aside, the choice between them is not dominated by significantly divergent views of where the city is or where it should be going. 
From rebuilding Lower Manhattan to keeping police officers on the streets, the two candidates differ on details and on some bigger issues in the campaign. Mr. Bloomberg wants to give police officers BlackBerry hand-held computers; Mr. Green has proposed using Palm hand-helds. More substantially, Mr. Green has a goal of keeping classes to no more than 20 children in the early elementary school grades; Mr. Bloomberg wants to decentralize decision-making and give principals the authority to decide what is best for their schools. 
"Having a healthy difference of opinion and working things out together, that is what politics really is about," Mr. Bloomberg said last week. "Politics is pulling together people and coming up with a common agenda that helps most people."
Above all, both Mr. Green and Mr. Bloomberg say they will demand improvements in the city's schools -- reflected in better test scores -- and they expect to be measured on their success as mayor on that promise. They also both pledge to hold down crime while increasing sensitivities in the Police Department to concerns among black and Hispanic residents about racial profiling. And they have promised to guide the city through its financial and economic problems by attracting new businesses, convincing those here to stay and shepherding the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan in a way that will benefit other parts of the city as well.
Mr. Green and Mr. Bloomberg even share a significant and seemingly irreconcilable budgetary quandary: each has identified the city's payroll as a major focus of his municipal cost-cutting efforts, yet each has said teachers, police officers and firefighters, who together make up the bulk of the municipal work force, should get pay raises.
There are other similarities. Even parts of their resumes could come from the same page.
Mr. Green and Mr. Bloomberg are both self-described liberals born at the time of World War II. Both are Jews with advanced degrees from Harvard. Both live on the Upper East Side (Mr. Green and his wife, Deni Frand, live on East 90th Street). And until last year, both were lifelong Democrats who were active in the party or contributed generously to it. Mr. Bloomberg even gave $1,000 to Mr. Green's re-election campaign in 1997. 
They have some personality traits in common as well.
Both have reputations for being strong-willed, ambitious and accustomed to getting their way. When it comes to self-description on the campaign trail, both have been prone to using superlatives. Mr. Bloomberg recently described himself as "the most experienced person in the world" in dealing with foreign governments; Mr. Green, who has never been a legislator, said in an interview in September that "if I had never been born" several of the city's more progressive laws would not have been enacted.
And each has been willing to adopt positions that in some significant way could influence how much support they win: Mr. Bloomberg by switching to the Republican Party and giving up longtime memberships in several exclusive social clubs, and Mr. Green by moderating his views and toning down his criticism of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
Perhaps most significantly, the two men espouse approaches to running New York City that sound very much the same. They both talk about being a mayor-manager, assembling a diverse array of expert aides and advisers who would help guide them through difficult decisions. Both have promised administrations that would be more open and forthcoming than that of Mr. Giuliani.
"There's no perfect training to be a mayor," Mr. Green said in an interview last week. "We've had a couple of borough presidents, we've had a couple of Congress people, we've had a couple of citywide officials, we've had a prosecutor in the last half-century. And all of them had to be amazed and impressed at how much they grew in the last few months of the campaign and the first few months of the mayoralty. So I may be self-confident but I'm modest enough to know what I don't know."
On some of the most pressing issues that the next mayor is likely to confront, Mr. Green and Mr. Bloomberg have often drawn attention to their differences on the campaign trail.
Mr. Green, for example, likes to criticize Mr. Bloomberg for suggesting that new high schools should be built on Governors Island rather than in neighborhoods around the city and for minimizing the importance of teaching computer skills in schools.
Mr. Bloomberg faults Mr. Green for saying that the rebuilding of Lower Manhattan should be centered on the financial services industry when some of that industry lost interest in downtown years ago. He also questions how friendly Mr. Green would be to businesses in the city because as consumer affairs commissioner he led a crackdown on small businesses as a revenue-raising tool.
At their core, the proclivities of the two men even in the areas where they disagree are often more alike than not.
On schools, both want to build more of them. The question is where. Mr. Bloomberg has said he is not wedded to the Governors Island idea but offered it to encourage more creative thinking. On the downtown rebuilding, Mr. Green has stressed the symbolic importance of the financial services industry, but he also talked about luring other businesses as anchors, including those specializing in information technology.
Mr. Green had also proposed the creation of a new city-state agency that would oversee an aggressive effort to bring renewed economic life to the area around the World Trade Center site. Mr. Bloomberg rejected the idea and even ridiculed Mr. Green for suggesting it.
But Mr. Bloomberg has acknowledged all along that the rebuilding would have to be done through some kind of a cooperative city-state endeavor, and when Gov. George E. Pataki announced on Friday that he would create a new redevelopment authority, Mr. Bloomberg said he would not oppose it.
"You work with people rather than work against them," he said.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: INSIDE BASEBALL; 
The Owner Who Overpaid for Rodriguez Irks His Peers Once More

BYLINE:  By MURRAY CHASS 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Nov. 3 

 BODY:
Borrowing from "The Ugly American" of several decades past, Tom Hicks is becoming the Ugly Texan to other baseball people.
 Hicks, owner of the Texas Rangers, went a long way toward acquiring that reputation last winter when he coveted Alex Rodriguez so heatedly that he signed him for $100 million more than anyone else was prepared to pay. The Rodriguez contract instantly raised the ante for Manny Ramirez and Derek Jeter and will have an impact on the money teams will pay Barry Bonds and Jason Giambi this winter. 
 Just the other day Hicks enhanced his position as the Ugly Texan when he announced a double-barreled hiring: John Hart as general manager and Grady Fuson as his assistant. The only problem was that Hicks did not have the O.K. from their previous employers to name them to those positions. 
The matter, technically a tampering case, has been delivered to Commissioner Bud Selig. While it is too early to predict Selig's action, he will very likely assess a steep fine against Hicks for both hirings, though he will probably let them stand.
High-ranking baseball officials said Hicks violated the agreements he had with the Cleveland Indians to interview Hart and with the Oakland Athletics to interview Fuson. The officials said both clubs were furious over the way Hicks ignored their understandings, with the Athletics being more irate than the Indians.
"They are just beside themselves," one official said of the Athletics, who immediately filed a grievance against the Rangers with the commissioner's office.
Oakland officials gave the Rangers permission to talk with Fuson about the general manager's job, other officials said, but only the general manager's job. They said the Rangers did not have the Athletics' permission to offer the 44-year-old Fuson, the Athletics' scouting director, a lower-level job.
In Hart's case, officials said, Hicks had an agreement with Larry Dolan, the Indians' owner, that gave the Rangers permission to interview Hart and negotiate a contract if they so chose, but before hiring him, the Rangers had to negotiate compensation for Hart with the Indians. One official said the Rangers notified the Indians on Thursday that they had hired Hart but did not call to discuss compensation.
In announcing the hiring of Hart, Hicks also insulted members of minorities, whose road to high-level, decision-making positions is already strewn with roadblocks of disregard and land mines of insincerity. Hicks insulted them by not interviewing the only black or Latin on his list of candidates.
Omar Minaya, senior assistant general manager of the Mets, had an interview with a headhunter, as the other four candidates for the Rangers' job did, but that was his only contact about the position. Minaya congratulated Hart on his appointment but said: "I must express my disappointment. I was looking forward to the opportunity of interviewing with Mr. Hicks for the general manager position. I will continue to pursue my goal of being a general manager someday."
Telephone efforts to reach Hicks for comment were unsuccessful.
It became evident early in his search for a general manager to replace Doug Melvin, whom Hicks fired on the last day of the season, that Hicks wanted to hire a well-known general manager, either Hart or Dave Dombrowski of the Florida Marlins.
Hart, the Indians' general manager, had announced earlier in the year that he was retiring, though no one believed for long that he would really retire, and Dombrowski had made it known that he would consider leaving his position as president and general manager of the Marlins because of their uncertain financial future.
One story circulating about the Rangers' search for a general manager was that Hicks initially wanted to hire Dombrowski but that Dombrowski declined because the job was contingent on his taking Fuson as his assistant.
Other candidates for the job were Fuson and Dan O'Brien, the Rangers' assistant general manager. Fuson was highly recommended to Hicks by Scott Boras, the high-profile agent who negotiated the $252 million deal for Rodriguez.
Boras is another part of the Rangers' ugly story. Some baseball officials believe that Boras, having developed a close relationship with Rodriguez's benefactor, undermined Melvin's position as general manager. Then, one official said, Boras became involved with Fuson, pushing him for the job and spending time prepping him for his interviews.
Another official said word had circulated among general managers and others that the Rangers had already begun pursuing players who will be free agents, even though players cannot file for free agency until next week. The players the official mentioned included Chan Ho Park, a Boras client.

The A's and Free Agency
Twenty-five years ago, Charles O. Finley, outcast owner of the Oakland Athletics, suggested that the owners deal with impending free agency by declaring every player free every year. Commissioner Bowie Kuhn and the other owners greeted Finley's idea the same way they viewed the orange baseball he proposed using.
Marvin Miller, the players' labor leader, understood the implication of Finley's plan and held his breath until the owners rejected it. If every player were available each off-season, the demand would not exceed the supply. Ergo, players could be signed more cheaply than when only a handful of free agents are available at any one position.
The first class of free agents included the nucleus of Finley's powerhouse team, and that was the end of Finley's powerhouse teams.
A quarter-century later, the Athletics are faced with losing not their nucleus but their heart and soul. Jason Giambi was prepared to sign a multiyear contract last spring and forgo free agency, but the Athletics refused to include a no-trade clause. Giambi wanted protection against a trade to a wealthier team after giving the economically weaker Athletics a "hometown discount."
Now the Athletics are prepared to give their first baseman the no-trade clause, but they do not know if they will be able to sign him.
"We're going to file," Giambi's agent, Arn Tellem, said Friday. "What we said last April has no bearing now. That was then; this is now. He played all year with the pressure and the risk of injury with no security. He's now two days away from free agency and he intends to see what's out there, what his options are."
Eligible players can file for free agency during a 15-day period beginning the day after the World Series ends. Free agents can begin signing with clubs as soon as the filing period ends.
In past Novembers, eligible players have filed throughout the filing period. This year, however, most, if not all, eligible players are expected to submit their names immediately. They do not want to take a chance that with the collective bargaining agreement expiring next Wednesday the owners will take some action affecting the players' ability to be free agents and sign with any team.
"We'll be there when the bell rings," Tellem said.
Giambi will be one of the elite free agents. He will be joined by Barry Bonds, Juan Gonzalez, Moises Alou, Bret Boone, Johnny Damon and half of the Yankees' infield, Tino Martinez and Scott Brosius. John Smoltz will be the most intriguing pitcher available because he could attract interest as a starter, which he used to be and could be again, or as a closer, which he became this season.

By the Numbers
Everyone knows that Barry Bonds hit 73 home runs and that Sammy Sosa became the first player in history to reach the 60 plateau for the third time. But what about some other statistical leaders?
Vladimir Guerrero of Montreal grounded into the most double plays, 24, and tied for second in times caught stealing with 16, one behind Juan Pierre's 17. Colorado's Pierre, on the other hand, was the toughest to strike out, averaging one strikeout for every 23.6 plate appearances. Jose Hernandez of Milwaukee and Jim Thome of Cleveland struck out the most times, 185 each.
Ichiro Suzuki of Seattle was the toughest to double up, grounding into one double play every 230.7 times at bat, and he had the best batting average with runners in scoring position, .445.
Livan Hernandez of San Francisco allowed the most hits, 266, and the most earned runs, 132. In the American League, Rick Helling of Texas was No. 1 in a host of categories -- most hits allowed, 256; most home runs, 38; most earned runs, 124; most runs, 134.
If Helling thought he had a tough summer, wait until the winter. He is the A.L. player representative, meaning he will be knee deep in labor negotiations.

Same Old Same Old
President Bush watched four innings of Game 3 of the World Series at Yankee Stadium last Tuesday night. He sat with George Steinbrenner in the owner's box on the press level, arriving and departing through Steinbrenner's office, which is right behind the box.
During those early innings, according to another person in the box, Steinbrenner was grumbling about the ball and strike calls of the home plate umpire. As Bush was leaving, the person said, he remarked to Commissioner Bud Selig, "I see not much has changed."

HEADLINE: The Candidates on Major Issues in the Mayoral Race: An Overview; 
Education

BYLINE:  By Abby Goodnough 

 BODY:
Teachers' Salaries

MARK GREEN -- Mr. Green has consistently said that teachers need higher salaries, but unlike some of his opponents in the Democratic primary, he has never promised to close the sizable salary gap between city teachers and their suburban counterparts. In the wake of the terrorist attacks, he has continued to call for an increase in teachers' pay but has warned that it will take longer. Mr. Green has been careful not to publicly predict just how much of a delay will be necessary. But in recent weeks, he has said that the second call he would make after moving into City Hall would be to Randi Weingarten, the president of the teachers' union, to jump-start the contract negotiations that collapsed last spring. (Mr. Green has said his first call would be to President Bush.)

MICHAEL R. BLOOMBERG -- Mr. Bloomberg has clung to the goal of raising teachers' pay despite the economic downturn and the shift in priorities caused by the terrorist attacks. But last week, Mr. Bloomberg said that he would impose a citywide hiring freeze that would apply to teachers along with all other city workers. This alarmed some education officials, because the Board of Education has predicted needing as many as 10,000 additional recruits by next September, mostly because of retirements.
But Mr. Bloomberg's spokesman, Edward Skyler, said on Thursday that Mr. Bloomberg would still allow hiring to fill classroom vacancies. He would not, however, allow the total number of teachers to grow, Mr. Skyler said.
Along with across-the-board raises, Mr. Bloomberg has proposed bonuses for every teacher in those schools whose test scores rise, a plan the teachers' union is likely to embrace as a preferable alternative to bonuses for individual teachers whose students outperform others.

Other Educational Issues

MR. GREEN -- Even more than increasing teachers' pay, Mr. Green has advocated reducing class size to 20 in kindergarten through third grade. But he has warned that he will not be able to do so as quickly as he had planned before Sept. 11.
His emphasis on class size reduction angered the teachers' union, which contended that the salary issue was more important; the union punished Mr. Green by endorsing other candidates in the primary and runoff elections.
Mr. Green has also pledged to continue hiring new teachers despite the worsening economy -- a difference that helped him finally win endorsement by the teachers' union last week. Increasing the number of classroom teachers would be a crucial component of Mr. Green's class size reduction plan, since the plan would require creating new classes.
Mr. Green also wants to give principals more power to assign teachers to grades and classes where they are needed. He advocates mayoral control of the school system, and wants to replace the seven-member Board of Education with a panel of educators who would advise the mayor but not have voting power. Like most city Democrats, Mr. Green is very strongly opposed to providing taxpayer-financed tuition vouchers to allow public school children to transfer to private schools.

MR. BLOOMBERG -- He said last week that reducing class size was an unrealistic goal given the city's precarious financial situation. Instead, he said, he would invest what limited resources exist after Sept. 11 into increasing the salaries of the city's 80,000 teachers. The starting salary is currently $31,910.
Mr. Bloomberg has said that he is not opposed to the concept of tuition vouchers, but it is "a politically charged issue the school system doesn't need." Mr. Skyler, his spokesman, said that Mr. Bloomberg would "not be leading the charge" for vouchers in New York City.
Mr. Bloomberg has, however, voiced support for allowing private companies to take over the management of failing public schools.
 Mr. Bloomberg would like to abolish the Board of Education and let the mayor appoint the chancellor, with the consent of the City Council. Unlike Mr. Green, he does not advocate creating an advisory panel to help the mayor shape education policy. Abby Goodnough

HEADLINE: The Will to Rise 

BYLINE:  By Roy Reed; Roy Reed's most recent book is "Faubus: The Life and Times of an American Prodigal."

 BODY:
 VERNON CAN READ!
A Memoir.
By Vernon E. Jordan Jr.
with Annette Gordon-Reed.
Illustrated. 344 pp. New York:
PublicAffairs. $26.
 IF the racist who shot him in the back in 1980 had killed him, Vernon E. Jordan Jr. would be remembered as a genteel and effective civil rights leader and little more. But thanks to good surgeons and to Jordan's will to live, and not just live but go on climbing, "Vernon Can Read!" is the story of a black Southerner one generation removed from rural poverty thrusting himself up not only to help lead a great social movement but then to claw his way into the establishment. Unfortunately, the book stops just as his old friend Bill Clinton is elected president. Perhaps there will be another volume someday when Jordan feels ready to tell how a couple of good old boys made it to the top and what they did there.
The present memoir, written with Annette Gordon-Reed, a professor at New York University Law School, by necessity is more than a success story. It is also a recollection of the pain suffered and the bravery asserted by so many black Americans -- and more than a handful of white Americans -- in the struggle for political and economic equality. Jordan did not become a truly national figure until he was made executive director of the National Urban League in 1971. But before that he had earned the right to leadership. As a young lawyer, he walked through the mob with Charlayne Hunter to integrate the University of Georgia. He drove the lonely Southern roads at night to sign up members for the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and to register black voters in precincts where either activity could get a black man lynched, and often did.
Through it all, there was a powerful personal ambition. An intriguing part of his story is its similarity to that of countless white boys of the lower middle class who came of age in the same scorned South, boys with proud, driven mothers who had pushed themselves and their children out of an utterly unromantic farm life and into the cities. Jordan's parents had fled the farmsteads for a better life in Atlanta. His father found satisfaction in a steady job at the post office. His mother, anything but satisfied cooking every day for white families, built a catering business that made her a figure of prominence in Atlanta's burgeoning black business community. She passed on her ambition. Before young Vernon left high school, he was a go-getter: chauffeuring, waiting tables, even a little nickel-and-dime bootlegging while working at a country club in a dry county.
Back in Atlanta after DePauw and Howard Universities, he sped through a succession of jobs in the civil rights movement and the federal government, before long finding himself appointed to influential government and then business boards. He was a natural choice to lead the one civil rights organization that had always been more reserved than flamboyant, more interested in economic advancement than in street demonstrations for basic rights.
When his luck almost ran out, it was not on a lonely back road in the South but at the door of a hotel in Fort Wayne, Ind., on May 29, 1980. He had just got out of the car of a white woman -- one of his board members -- when a bullet from a hunting rifle just missed severing his spinal cord. Jordan learned later that his assailant had intended to kill Jesse Jackson in Chicago but had settled on Jordan because Jackson was out of town. The man was acquitted on a dicey federal charge after the state decided not to try him. He was later convicted and sentenced to death for murdering two other black men.
Even before then, Jordan had decided to move out and up. He became a partner in the law firm of Akin, Gump, Strauss, Hauer & Feld in 1981, expanded his high-level corporate contacts and, one supposes, became very rich. He doesn't say. In fact, he has little to say about the private Vernon Jordan. He writes movingly about the death of his first wife from multiple sclerosis and a few other family events. But this is largely a public history. It is mildly refreshing to have a memoirist tell us that he is "congenitally private" and that some things are none of our business. 

CORRECTION-DATE: November 25, 2001

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, a review on Nov. 4 about "Vernon Can Read! A Memoir," by Vernon E. Jordan Jr. with Annette Gordon-Reed, misstated Gordon-Reed's affiliation. She is a professor at New York Law School, not New York University Law School.
