HEADLINE: HOLIDAY FILMS: ADAPTATIONS; 
'Remade in America': A Label to Avoid

BYLINE:  By DAVID EDELSTEIN; David Edelstein is the film critic for Slate.com.

 BODY:
WHEN we last encountered Cesar (Eduardo Noriega) -- the handsome, then nightmarishly disfigured, then surgically restored protagonist of the sexy 1997 Spanish psychological puzzler "Open Your Eyes" ("Abre los Ojos") -- he was either dead, dreaming or about to awaken from a virtual-reality coma in which his true love, played by that sultry toothpick Penelope Cruz, might or might not have been a figment of his imagination. "Abre los ojos," commands a woman's voice. What will Cesar look like when he next opens his eyes?
 Tom Cruise, actually. Well, his name will be David Ames, he'll speak English instead of Spanish and he'll be living in Los Angeles. But he'll still be chasing Penelope Cruz, he'll still be disfigured in a car accident and he'll still come to wonder if his life is a dream. Cesar will have undergone a transplant more perilous than any organ replacement: he'll have been wrenched from an artistically and commercially successful European film and plunked down into the strange new world of megabudget Hollywood-studio remakes. This way lie the battered husks of la femme Nikita, Martin Guerre and the heroes of "The Vanishing,""Nightwatch" and "Wings of Desire," among many others. Few complex characters have come through this journey with their souls intact. 
 "Vanilla Sky" is the name of this latest remake, and with Mr. Cruise on board, along with Ms. Cruz, Cameron Diaz and Kurt Russell, it's one of the holiday season's most enticing prospects. (It opens on Dec. 14.) The part is certainly a plum one for Mr. Cruise, who first gets to bask in his movie-star glamour and sexual potency and then to sport a pathetic-freak makeup job -- sure-fire Oscar bait. What remains to be seen is if the writer and director, the cheerfully down-to-earth Cameron Crowe ("Jerry Maguire," "Almost Famous"), will be able to straddle the eerie border between fantasy and reality that his Spanish predecessor, Alejandro Amenabar, occupies as if by birthright. 
Mr. Amenabar didn't come aboard for "Vanilla Sky." Perhaps that was because Mr. Cruise had hired him to direct his wife at the time, Nicole Kidman, in the summer's arty spook-show hit, "The Others." But I'd like to think that even if he hadn't been otherwise engaged, Mr. Amenabar would have been savvy enough to sell the rights to his story for a heap of money and then run like crazy in the other direction. He didn't need to revisit material he had thoroughly explored -- especially in the company of image-obsessed movie stars, obtuse studio executives and platoons of marketing people eager to try out sundry endings on fickle test audiences.
It would be terrific to report that Hollywood does not, contrary to popular belief, have a coarsening effect on the foreign properties it remakes. Terrific, but wrong. In this area as in few others, studios live up to their reputation as titanic forces of philistinism. Remakes don't, from the outset, attract artistic adventurers. Victor Drai, the producer who in the 80's turned the dim French comedy "Pardon Mon Affaire" into the even dimmer "The Woman in Red," and "The Tall Blond Man With One Black Shoe" into the frightful "The Man With One Red Shoe," explained at the time why selling a foreign film to Hollywood executives makes for an easy day's work: "With a book," he said, "you have to tell them what kind of picture it will make. With a movie, you just show them." 
A successful American screenwriter -- currently adapting a Hong Kong action picture -- was even more explicit. "I don't have much wisdom to offer beyond this one deep insight," he said. "It's a whole lot easier to borrow a story than to think up your own."
The problem with translations goes deeper than lack of originality, though, to what one might term the DNA of cinema. In Richard Linklater's recent animated feature, "Waking Life," a professor (Caveh Zahedi) paraphrases the essential doctrine of the French theorist Andre Bazin: that film can capture "that guy in that moment in that space." Bazin called it "the holy moment" and argued that when you succeed in getting "ontological reality" on film, you have a permanent record of the "everlasting face of God."
God is palpably absent from, say, the American version of "The Vanishing," probably the most maladroit of all Hollywood adaptations. A filmmaker laboring to duplicate something he or someone else has already done doesn't have a prayer of discovering "the holy moment." He's too busy asking: "Uh, how did it go this last time? Where was the light? Was the guy standing here or there?" The spark, the fever of creation inevitably dies: the action feels predetermined, as if it had already happened a long time ago in a galaxy far, far away.
But that's theory. Here's practice: Over the last month, I've watched close to 100 hours of foreign films and their contemporaneous American counterparts without finding one -- not one -- remake that measured up to the original. Some, like Steven Soderbergh's "Traffic," are gripping in their own right, and a majority aren't out-and-out travesties. After all, "Pardon Mon Affaire" (remade into "The Woman in Red," 1984); "Profumo di Donna," 1974 (remade into "Scent of a Woman," 1992) and Coline Serreau farces like the 1985 "Three Men and a Cradle" ("Three Men and a Baby," 1987) weren't classics to begin with. Some work splendidly as Hollywood entertainments: "The Magnificent Seven" lacks the charge, the passion, the poetry of Akira Kurosawa's "Seven Samurai," but it's a rousing ensemble western on its own terms. And yet, next to Sergio Leone's lyrically distended "Fistful of Dollars," the Italian treatment of Kurosawa's "Yojimbo," "The Magnificent Seven" seems smoothed out, filtered through a committee, processed.
The Hollywood instinct to seize something small, foreign and idiosyncratic and make it bigger, squarer and slicker is hardly new. In 1939, in his quest to make an American star of Ingrid Bergman, the producer David O. Selznick imported from Sweden both the actress and her most sentimental vehicle, "Intermezzo." The Selznick version, directed by Gregory Ratoff, was a canny blend of continental elegance and Hollywood corn. The year before, the producer Walter Wanger had a huge hit with John Cromwell's "Algiers," a gussied-up but almost shot-for-shot remake of Julien Duvivier's "Pepe le Moko." There were small changes, however. Americans have no romantic tradition of suicide, so Pepe didn't stab himself in despair but took a slug in the back from a policeman. And other things got lost in translation. In "Pepe," Jean Gabin gazes at Mireille Balin and purrs that she reminds him of the part of Paris he loved best: "le Metro." Charles Boyer's ode to Hedy Lamarr in "Algiers" -- "You're lovely, you're marvelous, do you know what you remind me of? The subway" -- seems more likely to provoke a slap than a swoon.
Over the last several decades, Hollywood has devised its own informal set of import rules.

'FIX' THE PACING: Test audiences are monitored for yawns and backside-shifting, so a fragile thing like mood is the first to be jettisoned. When Miramax acquired the rights to Ole Bornedal's 1994 necrophile thriller "Nightwatch" ("Nattevagten"), the studio was so confident that it had a blockbuster property that it shelved the Danish original and put a 1998 American version into production with the same director and a cast that included Ewan McGregor, Nick Nolte and Patricia Arquette. What resulted was a slicker piece of work, but it doesn't weave the same kind of spell. Much of the original's horror comes from its draggy pace, from the long silences and endless tracking shots through clammy morgue corridors. Cracking the whip makes "Nightwatch" play like psycho-killer-business-as-usual. The faster it gets, the duller it gets.

STREAMLINE THE LIFE OUT OF THE NARRATIVE: The emotional core of "Nightwatch" isn't the rampaging necrophile. It's the story of two graduating law students terrified of growing up, losing their freedom, dying: the morgue and the killer are nightmare extensions of their morbid anxiety. The American version puts all the weight on the bogeyman. In a hilarious irony, the Danish buddies worry that their lives will become as false as "a Hollywood movie." So what do they cite in the Hollywood remake? A "USA Network movie." I guess there's always farther to fall.

NIX TEMPORAL TRICKS FOR THE STICKS: Forget disorienting leaps back and forth in time. You're not in Oz anymore, Toto -- you're in Kansas, a Kansas multiplex, where folks will be irritated by a lack of linearity. So the American "Vanishing" begins at the beginning, with the killer -- instead of with the man and woman who should be the focus of everything.

DOPILY OVER-ROMANTICIZE: "City of Angels," the American adaptation of "Wings of Desire," is cheekily honest enough to arrange its platoon of heavenly messengers on top of the Hollywood sign -- as if to signal that this won't be Wim Wenders's dreamy, Berlin-based meditation on anomie and spiritual rebirth but a piece of wet kitsch in which Nicolas Cage (especially hangdog-soulful in his long black trenchcoat) abandons his angelic perch to inhale the fragrance of Meg Ryan's bleached coiffure. His "fall" to earth makes her so deliriously happy that she hops on her bicycle, leans back and closes her eyes in ecstasy, and pedals straight into a logging truck. Mr. Wenders's original had its sentimental streak, but it left you yearning for something more profound than tighter bicycle-helmet laws.

RESPECT FAMILY VALUES: Other countries, especially France, have a more fatalistic attitude toward adultery. (They found the American sanctimoniousness over President Clinton's dalliances peculiar.) So adapting the 1975 French film "Cousin, Cousine" must have posed quite a challenge. An Oscar-nominated counterculture comedy that celebrates abandoning one's marriage (provided that one has been cheated on first, and that one engages in extramarital sex openly, proudly and without bourgeois guilt), the movie took a decade to remake -- by which time its thrust had been painfully dulled. In place of the original's blithely irresponsible climax, "Cousins" offers earnest discussion, hand-wringing and self-denial; instead of reveling in the abandonment of family, it says that conscientious infidelity leads to a new, improved family. You could argue that this is a wiser, more moral scenario. But I'll bet you had more fun at "Cousin, Cousine."
The American Civil War-era adaptation of "The Return of Martin Guerre" treats sex outside marriage even more gingerly. The French Martin is cold and sexually dysfunctional, so when a warm and hunky impostor (Gerard Depardieu) arrives, it's enough that he works hard and shows his predecessor's love-starved wife (Nathalie Baye) a good time in the sack. In "Sommersby" (1993) the real husband isn't just a creep but a racist, wife-beating murderer -- and he's dead to boot, so there's really no moral downside when the wife (Jodie Foster) jumps into bed with the pretender (Richard Gere). Together they create a racial, economic and sexual utopia: a scene in which whites and "coloreds" plant tobacco seed gives way to the hero's planting a different kind of seed in the heroine. "Sommersby" weaves a rich tapestry, but the simple and mysterious erotic heartbeat of "The Return of Martin Guerre" (1982) is here not even a murmur.

KEEP THE STARS STRONG, SYMPATHETIC AND ATTRACTIVE . . .: even when that irons out dramatic complexity. The American "Traffic" doesn't pay the same kind of attention to economics as its British television counterpart, "Traffik." But what really undermines its realism is Michael Douglas's making like John Wayne in "The Searchers." Then Mr. Douglas gets one of those scenes in which the politician spontaneously chucks his prepared text and extemporizes from the heart -- a cliche that he had already wrung dry in 1995 in "The American President." Have you ever seen an honest politician in a Hollywood movie successfully deliver a prepared text?

MISCAST A STAR, DON'T CAST AN UNKNOWN: Luc Besson's "Femme Nikita" (1990) makes little sense, but it's one of the most irrationally sexy thrillers ever made. The title character (Anne Parillaud) is a feral junkie who coldly kills a cop and is forced by the government to become a chic, supermodel-like assassin. She's taught how to dress and make herself up and act like a real lady -- all at the expense of her soul. Somewhere underneath the splattery action is a parable about how women are forced to surrender their autonomy and individuality to a patriarchal state -- a parable made less than feminist by the way in which Mr. Besson madly fetishizes his leading lady (whom he was dating).
The real focus is how Ms. Parillaud's little black dress rides up her muscular thighs as she clutches her big gun, and the ripeness of her flesh in her bra and panties as she points a long, long rifle. She's a squirmy but hard sexual object -- exactly what her American equivalent, Bridget Fonda, is not. In "Point of No Return" (what a flaccid title!), the set-pieces are virtually identical but have almost zero impact. It's possible that Ms. Fonda is a better actress than Ms. Parillaud, but she has a soft, needy, tremulous presence. She isn't an autonomous object, so there's no unknowability, no mystery -- and no erotic tension.

LEAVE NOTHING UNRESOLVED: Unlike the bracing ending of "La Femme Nikita," "Point of No Return" (1993) offers a tidy coda, appended after test audiences complained that they didn't understand what had happened to the heroine. It's the most embarrassing sequence in the movie -- and it brings us to the American "Vanishing," which manages to embody all ruinous principles above and more. The film is so deeply awful that a video store manager told me that not only didn't he stock it but that he would never work in a store that did.
The 1988 Dutch original, "Spoorloos," directed by George Sluizer, has a Bazinian "holy moment" in its first sequence -- largely thanks to Johanna ter Steege, a transcendent actress who makes her abandonment by her boyfriend (Gene Bervoets) in a tunnel so momentous that you can understand why he'd spend the rest of his life trying to dispel it. The comparable scene in the American remake, also directed by Mr. Sluizer, passes quickly and meaninglessly, as Sandra Bullock gives a coquettish little smile to show that she forgives her guy (Kiefer Sutherland) and would now like nothing more than a can of Diet Coke. This version is impatient to move on, past the woman who will vanish with no trace to a new, hash-slinging heroine (Nancy Travis), who will coax the protagonist back to life -- and ultimately rescue him from the tomb of his obsession.
The most indelible aspect of the Dutch "Vanishing" -- the turn that haunts everyone who sees it for days, weeks, years -- is its ghastly finale, in which the protagonist finally learns what happened to his girlfriend and joins her, first with horror and then with a kind of hysterical glee, in their prescribed destiny. At that point in the American "Vanishing" the movie still has half an hour to go, enough time for girlfriend No. 2 to make her way to the scene and engage in standard cat-and-mouse thriller games with the cretinous villain (played by Jeff Bridges like a nerd out of a "Saturday Night Live" parody).
What is it about this new ending that makes the film so overarchingly dreadful, so much worse than the sum of its parts -- and so representative? I think it has to do with its naked Americanness. The revised "Vanishing" stands for Hollywood-fed fantasy in the face of fear. It's how we wish that the original had turned out -- with true love and Yankee gumption trumping destiny, trumping an unfathomable foreign enemy, trumping foreign movies and their ambiguous sympathies and open endings. We can buy you and remake you, the American "Vanishing" proclaims: a fatal bit of hubris, with global implications.

SECTION: Section 9; Column 1; Style Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1921 words

HEADLINE: Looking for a Way Home for the Holidays 

BYLINE:  By NANCY HASS and LESLIE KAUFMAN; Additional reporting by Ariel Hart and Mindy Sink.

 BODY:
AS a convert to Hinduism, Douglas Brooks normally regards the holiday season skeptically, as a curious and overly commercial artifact of American life. This year, however, he feels the need to mark the end of the year meaningfully. So Mr. Brooks, a professor of religion at the University of Rochester, has created his own ritual.
 He has printed the names of thousands of the victims of Sept. 11 he found on the Web, and on Christmas Day plans to "sit in front of my gods" and intone the names aloud. "It may be only for me and not for them, but I wish these souls their peace," he said. 
 Christine Drumright, a handbag designer in Denver, will remain at home with her husband and two cats for Thanksgiving and Christmas, but she plans to visit relatives in Connecticut in early December. "It feels like a pilgrimage," she said. "It is my gift to my family. We are not exchanging presents this year." 
To counter a black mood under the pall of war and terrorism, Tom Fontana, who lives in Greenwich Village and produces the television drama "Oz" for HBO, has bought out the house for the Off Broadway musical "The Fantasticks" on Christmas Eve. He is inviting a legion of friends to spread a little corny cheer. "It's sort of sweet and Christmasy," he said of the play, which is closing in January after 41 years. "I guess what I'm trying to say to people is, you either believe or you're afraid." 
As the Thanksgiving kickoff to the season of making merry approaches, Americans are saying they want to mark this year of fragility and insecurity differently. Everyone from religious leaders to party planners, marketing gurus to toy sellers, who make it their business to parse and measure the collective psyche, are registering powerful tremors on their seismographs.
The trend could be described as the cyclical resurrection of home, hearth and spirituality, after an era of no-holds-barred indulgence, but it is not quite that simple. Americans are too familiar with the dysfunctional family, in pop culture and around their own dinner tables, to pine for a simple return to a Norman Rockwell America that never really was. 
Like Dorothy and Toto, Americans want to go home, but they have to invent their own path. This holiday season is about compromises and half-steps back to tradition, showing up in the unexpected popularity of board games to be played by a crackling fire, or the preference for Brahms rather than Britney Spears at office parties. The way home is not obvious, and it is being mapped by individuals rather than by political leaders or marketers with products to sell. 
Americans were undergoing "a shift in priorities" even before the calamity of Sept. 11, driven by months of economic deterioration, said J. Walker Smith, the president of Yankelovich Partners, a leading market research company. "We are now seeing that spike," he added. "People are expressing a claustrophobia with abundance." He predicted that a new set of traditions would emerge. 
Anxieties about the safety of air travel are causing many to forgo long-distance travel, instead driving to nearby relatives or adding extra leaves to their holiday tables to include "orphans" who won't make it back to their own family gatherings. Most airlines have reduced their flight capacity by 15 to 20 percent through the end of the year, and hotel occupancy rates are still about 20 percent below normal, according to the Travel Business Roundtable, a trade group for the travel and tourism industry. 
Cathy Pelaez, an executive vice president of Liberty Travel, the nation's largest privately owned leisure travel company, reports that despite bargain basement prices, overseas travel is down 30 percent and bookings to the Caribbean and Mexico are off 15 percent. "It is a different mentality," Ms. Pelaez sighed, "people are wanting to nest more than in the past."
Family is the universal sentiment, but it is being celebrated with modern flexibility this year. Julee and Kenny Shapiro, who live on Fulton Street, just blocks from the site of the World Trade Center, will celebrate Thanksgiving in a weekend house in the Berkshires that they have rented for years with a group of friends. But this season there will also be room at the table for more than the usual complement of housemates.
"A lot of our other friends are single and don't live near their families, so we're going to have to make room," said Ms. Shapiro, who still doesn't have phone service back at her apartment. "We don't want anyone to be alone this year." 
As West Coast transplants to New York, Gina and Tim Ryan usually celebrate Thanksgiving in their Upper East Side apartment with friends, but after Sept. 11, Ms. Ryan said, the couple "definitely felt like it was time to hunker down with family." They hadn't visited Mr. Ryan's brother's family in Pennsylvania in four years, but a week after the terrorist attacks, they booked a rental car and a hotel for Thanksgiving so they could go.
The reasons were not so much sentimental as starkly practical. "I felt it was important to be with family this year because, let's face it, we might not get another chance," Ms. Ryan said. 
If the urge to hunker down and hang together is jarring industries like travel, companies that specialize in products that encourage cocooning are in the green.
"Anything that will engage the whole family is more popular than we anticipated back in the summer," said Jeanne Meyer, a spokeswoman for Toys "R" Us. Board games like Clue, Monopoly, Life and three-dimensional puzzles are all selling unexpectedly well, she said. "The K'Nex Screamin' Serpent Roller Coaster, a very elaborate construction kit, is an excellent example of the zeitgeist toy," she said, "because it engages the whole family for hours in the same place."
Beyond family, the search for spirituality, another holiday perennial, has come back with new vigor and with a new twist.
At Mariner's Community Church in Half Moon Bay, Calif., attendance has been soaring, as it has at many houses of worship across the country since Sept. 11. But people are not just returning to pray, said Glenn Park, the minister, they are asking questions. "People want to know if God is real," Mr. Park said. "They are struggling."
Reflexive acts of piety, like filling pews and contributing money to good causes, don't seem to satisfy either. Melody Neal, the director of resources at Chris Homes, a network of homes for needy youths in Atlanta, said that cash donations were down, echoing a lament of charities across the nation, as people diverted money to 9-11 relief funds, or tightened their belts for a recession. Volunteerism, however, is another matter.
"We have a program where volunteers can make homemade cookies for children," Ms. Neal said. "Three times as many people are wanting to do this project than last year, and it's all since Sept. 11. There's a lot more interest in people wanting to get their hands into something as opposed to just writing a check."
Terri Davis, an executive recruiter in Parker, Colo., certainly fits that description. For many years, Mrs. Davis has given money to the Denver Rescue Mission, a homeless shelter. This year, she will reduce her cash contribution and instead try to recruit the 22 families who live on her cul-de-sac to adopt a needy family each.
"This year, we really want to rally to the support of other neighbors," she said. "The emphasis needs to be placed on the intrinsic values of the holidays, rather than on toys and presents." She said her 7-year-old son will still get gifts, though.
Many parents of young children emphasized that Santa's bag would still bulge this year, if only to defy attempts by the country's enemies to undermine normal life. Still, retailers are deeply fretful that this year consumers will finally shut off the geyser of holiday spending, but the economy is the main culprit, not the threat of terrorism coming to malls or even mail-ordered packages. Overall holiday retail sales are expected to be flat, according to Merrill Lynch, which would make it the worst season in 33 years.
As a significant number of adults are seeking to separate this holiday season from the materialistic splurge of the last decade, it affects everything from gift buying to religious services to entertaining.
The actress Sarah Jessica Parker said that neither she nor her husband, the actor Matthew Broderick, feel much like celebrating. The couple live in Greenwich Village and, like many residents of downtown, still feel unsteady. "I just want to sit around and knit," Ms. Parker said. "I told Matthew that unless there was something he really wanted, I just didn't feel like buying anything."
"Home for the Holidays," will be the Christmas theme at Willow Creek Community Church, an enormous congregation in suburban Chicago that expects some 40,000 people to attend 10 Christmas services this year. Reflecting a more somber mood among congregants, the church is toning things down. "We are not going to have as large a service from a complexity standpoint," said David Stahl, a church spokesman. The church has canceled the full orchestra and is going with a six-piece band. "Services will have more of a singing around the piano feel," Mr. Stahl said.
At the Bronfman Center at New York University, Rabbi Andy Bachman predicted that the typical festive atmosphere surrounding Hanukkah will be "tinged with more serious spirituality this year."
"There seems to be a different feeling in the air," Rabbi Bachman said. "The whole old saw of Jews sort of pooh-poohing the whole holiday season, the jokes about them going out to Chinese restaurants on Christmas -- well, that's probably going to be less the case this year. I suspect that this is going to be a holiday season when values are brought to the surface." 
The holiday office party, which grew ever more elaborate as corporate profits rocketed in the 90's, will forgo the dancing girls and Champagne fountains this season. David Adler, the chief executive of bizbash .com, a New York-based online directory of caterers and other services for event planners, said the industry has lost an estimated $1 billion in bookings since Sept. 11, and the mood for parties going forward is restrained. "Instead of things like having Britney Spears sing at your corporate Christmas party," he said, "there will be lots of quartets playing beautiful music." 
Maria Thompson, the director of rentals and events at the Callanwolde Fine Arts Center, an Atlanta mansion used for corporate entertaining, said most companies are going ahead with holiday parties, but with a humbler tone than in recent years. "A company that has in the past had a mystery theater, tremendous entertainment and maybe flew singers in from the East Coast, or an orchestra," she said, "now they're looking at not even a sit-down dinner, but a buffet, with maybe ham, beef tenderloin, warm foods like a mashed potato bar." 
From comfort food to the comforts of home, Americans who had felt that only the bright and shiny future mattered, not the past, are rediscovering the tried and true.
"This was the year I was not going to go home for Thanksgiving, the first year in my life," said Marilee English, an advertising account executive who lives with two Siamese cats in Brooklyn Heights. "I was going to stay right here and make dinner for three friends." But that was before Sept. 11. 
When Ms. English's widowed father called from Michigan, she said, "I melted down. He said he wanted his girl at home. What could I say?" She booked a flight to Kalamazoo.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Not Relying on Aid From Bush in '02 Elections 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 3 

 BODY:
Despite President Bush's colossal job approval ratings, many Republicans who are running in the midterm elections next year say they do not expect him, even if he remains enormously popular, to help their own campaigns.
 If anything, some Republican lawmakers and strategists fear that the war and Mr. Bush's desire to appear bipartisan could prevent him from doing much to benefit them next year. And they are worried that the sagging economy -- underscored by the surge in unemployment announced this week -- could eclipse the war as a political issue and that voters could blame the Republicans. 
 The 2002 elections are a long way away, and no one can safely predict what the political climate will be next week, let alone next year. Even so, many Republicans are nervous that Mr. Bush is not thinking ahead to next year, when control of the House and Senate will be at stake, as well as a third of the governorships.
"There is a danger that the president is going to be worried about how to maintain his popularity and not sacrifice it," said Representative Mark Souder, Republican of Indiana. "When presidents are involved in tough international conflicts, very seldom do they want to use their inventory of good will helping House and Senate members. Even when they do help, it's like pulling teeth."
Gov. John Engler of Michigan, a close ally of Mr. Bush who because of term limits cannot run in 2002, said that if the president's popularity remains "at nosebleed levels, that's not a guarantee that we win" in elections next year. Already, Mr. Engler said, "the economy is bigger than the war in local elections."
Some Republicans also said that although they expect the public to continue to rally behind Mr. Bush on the war, that support will not carry over to other looming issues, notably the economy. To underscore that point, these Republicans note that in the two governors' contests this Tuesday -- in New Jersey and Virginia -- the Republicans are trailing in the polls.
Strategists on both sides say the outcome will turn on local economic matters and not the drive against terrorism. Advisers for the two Republicans have complained privately that they have not been able to capitalize on Mr. Bush's popularity because he has not campaigned on their behalf.
"What I worry about is that people will divorce the president from the party," said Tom Cole, a former chief of staff of the Republican National Committee. "You'll probably see that in New Jersey and Virginia. You'll see the American people drawing a very clear separation -- 'I support the president overseas, but on domestic issues I'm not letting that get in the way of my judgment.' "
The president, Mr. Cole said, was "doing the right thing as president to keep us united, but it's going to cost the president's party in terms of not having as much active participation from the White House."
One of the Republicans' top fund-raisers said that if Mr. Bush cannot raise money for candidates next year, "that's an enormous loss."
The most recent example of what some Republicans say is Mr. Bush tending to his own interests was his role in winning support on Thursday for a House bill that would place the federal government in charge of airport security. He opposed a version that would have made the baggage and personnel screeners federal workers. By backing the Republican alternative, Mr. Bush placated his conservative base, which he will need to be re-elected in 2004. But that could come at a cost for Republicans in swing districts next year, who could be accused of delaying a resolution and sacrificing safety.
"With Bill Clinton, it was all about Bill Clinton," said Representative Peter A. DeFazio, Democrat of Oregon. "It wasn't about having a Democratic majority. If it becomes all about George Bush, the same thing could happen to them."
Many Republicans insist they are well poised for the midterm elections. Even if the president lacks coattails, they say, his popularity is building the morale of active Republicans and has been a boon to the party's efforts to recruit candidates. 
Ed Goeas, a Republican pollster, said the only way Republicans would suffer in 2002 would be if Mr. Bush were viewed by voters as not moving sufficiently to rescue a faltering economy -- which was what happened to his father when he ran for re-election in 1992.
"The only danger that I see right now is that if attention to what's happening in the war abated quickly and Republicans were not paying attention to the economy," Mr. Goeas said. "But Bush is not the only one who has learned from his father's past. Republicans have learned as well."
Charles Cook, who edits a respected nonpartisan political newsletter, said: "I'm becoming more and more convinced that the spotlight is going to be moving back to the economy, back to domestic issues. If the spotlight is the economy, I don't know how the Republicans hold the House. If the spotlight is where it is today, it would be hard to see how Republicans could lose the House."
Republicans seem the least worried about the Senate because the war has undermined Democratic efforts to recruit potent Senate candidates in some crucial races.
Yet Republicans are concerned about losing their slim majority in the House, as well as governorships. There are 29 Republican governors, but 23 of those seats are being contested next year.
The president's party almost always loses House seats in midterm elections, even when the nation is at war. In 1942, when President Franklin D. Roosevelt was wildly popular, the Democrats lost 55 seats in the House and 9 seats in the Senate.
While they may not be able to count on Mr. Bush, incumbent Republicans can take solace in the fact that, at least for now, the political climate favors incumbents. Just as Mr. Bush's popularity is at record highs, so is that of members of Congress. Voters seem to want to turn to seasoned leaders in times of crisis. That, of course, is also good news for Democratic incumbents.
Still, it is impossible to know now how the war or the hunt for the terrorists -- or the economy -- will play out.
"There's no way to foretell this election," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, who was reluctant to engage in his election-year pitch about how the Democrats will take back the House. "It's really, really cloudy. I could argue both sides of it. But I don't know a thing, and I don't think anybody else does either."

HEADLINE: Flash in the Pan 

BYLINE:  By Rob Walker; Rob Walker is a contributing writer for Slate. He lives in New Orleans.

 BODY:
 THE GODFATHER
OF SILICON VALLEY
Ron Conway and the
Fall of the Dot-coms.
By Gary Rivlin.
103 pp. New York:
AtRandom.com. Paper, $15.

A VERY PUBLIC OFFERING
A Rebel's Story of Business Excess, Success, and Reckoning.
By Stephan Paternot with Andrew Essex.
Illustrated. 236 pp. New York:
John Wiley & Sons. $27.95.

DOT.BOMB
My Days and Nights
at an Internet Goliath.
By J. David Kuo.
311 pp. Boston:
Little, Brown & Company. $25.95.
 When the dot-com boom was in its heyday -- a period that lately seems more distant than ever -- the "first-mover advantage" was a popular idea. In the new economy, apparently, capitalism had become a raw sprint, to be won by those who were first to recognize and claim a new business "space." More recently, the dot-com unraveling has set in motion another competition: the race for first-mover advantage in recounting where the new economy went wrong. 
It seems likely that "The Godfather of Silicon Valley," by the journalist Gary Rivlin, was not conceived this way at all. The subject is a man named Ron Conway, a wealthy investor with a gift for networking. After amassing a fortune in the computer business, by 1997 he had started making angel investments in tech companies like Marimba. Usually angel investing refers to financial backing for a tiny start-up that can't get help from more mainstream sources. That's why it's angelic.
Conway, though, seems to have been trying to get a piece of deals that already looked hot, or that's the spirit that animated the two investment funds he soon formed. He raised tens of millions of dollars from the well-off folks in his apparently infinite Rolodex -- from those famous in the tech world, like Bill Joy and Esther Dyson, to those who are simply famous, like Shaquille O'Neal, Arnold Schwarzenegger and Henry Kissinger. Conway returned to the Rolodex and spread much of this money over a range of Internet start-up deals.
As you've already guessed, things have gone rather poorly. By early 2001, 43 of the companies Conway backed were out of business, and he had written off dozens more. Instead of scoring a return of 10 times their original investment, Rivlin concludes, it now seems possible that Conway's high-rolling investors may actually lose money.
This raises two questions. First, why should we care about the travails of Ron Conway? Rivlin does a nice job of telling his story in this brief book, and it's not his fault that by now such stories sound so familiar. Probably Conway seemed more interesting when he was the Most Powerful Investor You've Never Heard Of, but as it turns out he's just another dot-com also-ran. And few readers are likely to be outraged that Shaq isn't getting the return on investment he'd hoped for.
The bigger question is, what exactly made Conway and all his investors -- many of whom are smart people, or at least employ smart people to manage their money -- believe that they could earn such massive returns? A key moment Rivlin points to is the initial public offering of Theglobe.com, an online community business, in November 1998. "To some in the Valley," Rivlin writes, Theglobe's one-day leap from $9 to $97 a share "represented a critical inflection point," as "an overly forgiving stock market seemed to drop all pretensions of rationality."
Theglobe, famously, was the brainchild of two Cornell students, one of whom is Stephan Paternot. His book, "A Very Public Offering," written with Andrew Essex, begins on the morning of that memorable I.P.O. He and his partner, "dressed casually," settled in at the offices of Bear Stearns, their firm's underwriter. Briefly that day, Paternot, who is in his mid-20's and calls himself a "rebel," was worth $97 million.
Maybe because of his limited experience of life generally and business in particular, Paternot seems to have no real insight into the weird hothouse environment that made Theglobe's I.P.O. a landmark event. Instead he tells us the documents for the preoffering road show "were certainly sleek. We insisted that our S1 be matte black with hip green graphics, which was very much considered taboo." (There's a rebel for you.) And he goes on at some length about his briefly euphoric high life: Manhattan nightclubs were "mind-blowing." Flying in a private jet was "phenomenal." Making it to the top was "slammin'." O.K., that last example is actually from "Ice by Ice: The Vanilla Ice Story in his Own Words." But Paternot's offering is less like a business book than like a pop star's self-serving reminiscences of a fleeting moment at the top: every success is the fair result of hard work, every skeptic is a small-minded player-hater.
More seriously, Paternot still seems confused about the relationship between a business and its share price. While he claims he was frustrated that others focused on Theglobe's stock as it gradually sank into the single digits, his own anecdotes make it seem that there was more internal focus on ways to "goose the stock" than on building a profitable business. He grouses about those who doubted him and his partner "even though we'd just made them a 1,000 percent return in one day." In fact, those who made such a killing by flipping the stock the first day it was traded profited precisely from their skepticism. It was the suckers they sold to, who believed in Theglobe, who got crushed.
By the book's end Paternot has left the company, and he announces that he plans to "channel my creative drive into film." Theglobe's stock has been delisted, and, since the book went to press, its flagship site has shut down. Whatever "inflection point" caused people to bid the shares of such unlikely companies into the stratosphere has passed. But who were those people? Did anybody really believe this or that dot-com would eventually justify the nutty valuations they briefly achieved?
J. David Kuo believed. "Dot.Bomb," his memoir of life at the ill-fated e-commerce firm Value America, begins with him punching away at his laptop, trying to corral shares in that company on the day of market debut. "I had heard about the quick riches that e-commerce I.P.O.'s offered," he explains. The offering price was $21; Kuo got in at $72, "assuming it was still going to go to $100." This did not happen, of course, but it turns out that Kuo did land a job at the company, as a public relations executive. He got in at the top -- and was on hand for the whole ride down.
This means Kuo wasn't there for the company's creation or early growth; he seems to have dealt with this by interviewing those who were there, but he's often vague on his sourcing. A bigger problem is that a great deal of the book recounts office politics and insider bickering at a company that seemed marginal even during the peak of interest in dot-coms. Value America's main moment in the spotlight came as a result of its first-mover advantage among dot-flops.
As at Theglobe, executives there spent an inordinate amount of time worried about the sinking stock. (Maybe all happy dot-coms are different, but it seems unhappy ones are all alike.) On several occasions the company badgered stock analysts to issue positive reports -- especially the analyst for the investment bank that took Value America public. From the company's point of view, Kuo writes, this analyst "needed to be . . . telling the world that we were better than AOL or Microsoft had ever been. . . . That was the way this world was supposed to work." He should have been "pimping our stock."
Since ripping analysts has become such a popular pastime, it's worth noting that the Value America team never did get the support they wanted. (Theglobe.com had a similar problem with its analyst at Bear Stearns, who actually downgraded that stock.)
But here as elsewhere in the book, it's hard to figure what Kuo really makes of all this. Sometimes he seems to believe the company could have made it, sometimes he seems to be saying the whole thing was a house of cards all along. Craig Winn, the company's founder, comes across alternately as a visionary or a near-delusional tyrant. All these things could be partly true, I suppose, but they never really get reconciled; like Paternot, Kuo seems content simply to offer anecdotes, not judgments.
These first rough drafts of dot-com history mostly tell us things we know: how some of these companies soared and then crashed with dizzying speed. One suspects there is more to say about why this happened, and how our world really has changed (or not) as a result. Maybe the lesson -- a familiar one in the "new economy" -- is that that the first movers may not get the last word.

LENGTH: 4971 words

HEADLINE: No-Fun City 

BYLINE:  By By James Traub; James Traub, a contributing writer for the magazine, writes regularly about New York politics.

 BODY:
In August, a poll appeared in this newspaper indicating that New Yorkers, a perennially discontented lot, had reached a possibly unprecedented level of contentment under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani. Barely a third of the respondents said that they would move out of the city if they could, down from 60 percent 10 years earlier. Only a quarter expected life in the city to worsen over the next 10 to 15 years, which was the lowest such figure the pollsters ever recorded. Though few respondents knew much about the six major candidates then vying to succeed Giuliani, who is barred by law from seeking a third term, the outcome scarcely seemed to matter; nearly two-thirds said they felt that New York would be as good a place to live, or better, under any of them. The city appeared to be running on rails. 
 It seemed, in that remote era, that the next mayor, whoever he was, would inherit a job shrunken back to normal size after the grandiosity and melodrama of the Giuliani years. Listening to the candidates' rather desultory speeches and debates, it was a fair guess the new mayor would retain the core Giuliani program while making symbolic and tonal changes -- no more concrete barriers at City Hall, no more savage mockery of critics -- that would allow him to pronounce an end to the Giuliani Era. New York no longer needed a Big Mayor. 
 And now, quite suddenly, it does. The next mayor will have to deal with the largest budget deficits in the city's history; he will have to guide a rebuilding effort of unprecedented proportions, and do so according to a coherent vision of the city's future he must forge; he will have to be the city's advocate in Washington; and he will have to play the Good Father to anxious New Yorkers. As John Mollenkopf, the director of the Center for Urban Research at the CUNY Graduate Center, put it recently, "There's a strong sense that we need a Colin Powell figure -- in command, confidence-generating, warm, good at soothing our cares and worries." 
Well, Colin Powell is busy, and the two candidates who made it through the primaries and are on the ballot in this Tuesday's election -- the Democrat Mark Green and the Republican Michael Bloomberg -- don't remind anybody of the secretary of state. 
It is strange to think what Rudy Giuliani's reputation might be today had the World Trade Center disaster never occurred. He would still have ranked as one of the big mayors, of course -- up there with LaGuardia, his hero, and a cut above figures like Ed Koch, Robert Wagner and John Purroy Mitchel, a reformer from the early part of the century. Giuliani achieved two extraordinary things. He made New York a significantly safer place at a time when a high crime rate was considered virtually part of the order of nature. And he established, if less permanently, a new ethic of limited government in place of the sprawlingly generous social-welfare state that LaGuardia himself did so much to create. 
But he did both of these things by the end of his first term. All of the big mayors before him ran out of gas eventually; Giuliani began to appear aimless -- shadowboxing against errant cabbies and jaywalkers -- not long after his re-election. Had it not been for Sept. 11, New Yorkers would have remembered the end of his second term for the epic bathos of his "good friend" Judith Nathan, his prostate cancer and his aborted Senate run. Indeed, the August poll found that Giuliani would have had a tough race against any of the four major Democratic candidates, none of whom the public seemed to know all that well.
The truth is that Giuliani was either not so engaged by or not so effective with problems that could not be solved through confrontation. It would be left to his successor to grapple with those issues, and so the next mayoralty was going to be about things like education, housing and public health. The pendulum appeared to be swinging at least slightly back to the left, which is to say back toward a more activist, ambitious government. Earlier this year, the Century Foundation and the CUNY Graduate Center published a volume of essays titled "Rethinking the Urban Agenda: Reinvigorating the Liberal Tradition in New York City and Urban America." The book serves as a blueprint for a post-Giuliani, and often an overtly anti-Giuliani, world, laying out progressive solutions to problems of welfare, homelessness, health care, taxation and criminal justice.
Attention to these issues found their echo -- albeit, a rather pale one -- in the Democratic primary, in which several of the candidates talked about increasing taxes to pay for teacher salaries and smaller class size and about resuming the ambitious public housing program begun under Koch. One candidate, Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, played directly on a sense of estrangement in the minority community -- Giuliani was a different sort of big mayor to many of the city's blacks and Hispanics -- with his message about "the other New York." Ferrer was quoted as saying: "The good news is Rudy Giuliani is out of here in three months. And the better news is, if you help me become mayor, his policies are out of here in three months, too." 
Here, then, was the status quo ante on Labor Day, which traditionally is when people start paying attention to the mayoral campaign: a general expectation of prosperity and calm, a crisis mayoralty that had played itself out, perhaps a widening gulf between satisfied middle-class voters and dissatisfied poor and working-class ones. Then two aircraft were steered into the twin towers, and the status quo became irrelevant. The critique of Giuliani came to an immediate end, and so did hopes for a new era of government activism. Alan Brinkley, a historian at Columbia University and the author of an essay in "Rethinking the Urban Agenda," says: "All these ideas about the city stepping in and doing progressive things that the federal government didn't do -- I don't think it's likely to get anywhere. The new mayor is going to have to identify himself with reconstruction and with the anguish the city will still be recovering from."
Sept. 11 transformed both the mayor and the mayoralty. It may be that there has never been a moment when the mayoralty was so crucial and so charged with symbolic power. 
During one of the Yankees' recent playoff games, the big screen in right-center field flashed an image first of the American flag, then of the face of Rudolph Giuliani and then of the flag once again -- as if the mayor's face had itself become a banner of freedom and flinty resistance. His moral authority seemed boundless. On Oct. 1, he became the first mayor to deliver a substantive address to the United Nations, where he lectured the delegates like the head of a proud but beleaguered nation. 
But you have to look at the remainder of the mayor's day to fathom the extraordinary dimensions of this new job. From the U.N., he went directly to ground zero to give one of the almost-daily tours of the wreckage he was providing to global and national leaders, in this case a delegation of more than 100 members of Congress. And then he attended a funeral for an assistant fire chief and a memorial service for the hundreds of employees of the Cantor Fitzgerald bond-trading firm who died in the attacks. He was, all at once, an international, national and metropolitan figure.
I joined the press pool at ground zero when Giuliani gave his Congressional tour. The group stationed itself at the southwestern corner of the site, from which they could see the two great cathedral-like skeletons of the twin towers and the smoke curling from fires still smoldering underground. The mayor had changed into his monogrammed Police Department jacket and N.Y.P.D. hat, and as he offered his narrative of destruction and rebirth, the representatives huddled around him like awestruck pilgrims gazing at a holy sepulcher. It was very moving, and it was also brilliant theater.
"The businesses that have been dislocated are the core American businesses," Giuliani said gravely. "Their dislocation has something to do with the performance of the economy." Ike Skelton, a Missouri Democrat who towered over the mayor, said softly, "It's the saddest scene in the world -- every American ought to be here." Afterward, on the immense, drafty pier that the mayor was using as his makeshift command center, Dennis Hastert, the speaker of the House, vowed, "We will come back to New York again to see this town . . . rise from the ashes that we saw today."
Giuliani risked sacrificing some of his moral prestige when he tried to inveigle his way into a third term, or at least into a 90-day extension of his current term, but whatever ill feelings he may have created instantly vanished with the anthrax scare, which restored him to his role as New York's father figure. His combination of stoicism and empathy made him what he had never been before, and perhaps never even wanted to be before: beloved. And it is very likely that he will remain the city's beloved authority figure for the last two months of his term, though with his gift for going too far -- and then a little farther -- you can never tell. 
Who wants to succeed a beloved authority figure? It is a formula for failure. Anyone would seem diminished by comparison. On Primary Day, Sept. 25 -- actually the rerun of Primary Day, which was held but suspended on the fateful Sept. 11 -- I spoke to about 30 voters in Greenwich Village, Riverdale and Harlem, all highly liberal neighborhoods. About half of them said that the only candidate they really wanted to vote for was Giuliani, on a write-in ballot, and some of them were furious when election workers told them they could not do so.
Randee Mia Berman, who works for the state government, said that though she had volunteered for Mark Green, she had voted for Peter Vallone, the City Council speaker, simply because he was closest to Giuliani. "Giuliani made all the others look so small," she said. "Maybe it's an optical illusion because he looms so large. It's like 'Alice in Wonderland': the Democrats are the croquet players, and the mayor is the Cheshire Cat."
Greatness of soul had not, of course, been a prerequisite for the job when the candidates first presented themselves to the public earlier this year. Placed now in the impossible position of trying to seem bigger than they appeared to be, they only diminished themselves further, as when Mark Green rather defensively insisted that he would have done "as well or better than" Giuliani had. (Bloomberg actually topped Green in the braggadocio department when he said, "I have more experience in dealing with governments than probably anybody in the whole world.") Bloomberg, Green and Vallone all told me that they admired Harry Truman -- a small man who succeeded a very big man and turned out to be much bigger than anyone expected. Of course, F.D.R. was dead when Truman took office.
Mark Green likes to say that destiny nominates the right man for the moment -- pace Truman -- but it is not obvious what destiny has in mind in this election. Truman, like LaGuardia, Koch and Giuliani, enjoyed the unimpeachable authenticity of a humbly born son of the soil. Neither Bloomberg nor Green has this advantage. Both are polished men who not only live on the Upper East Side of Manhattan but also obviously belong there. Neither one talks New York: Bloomberg still sounds like Medford, Mass., where he was reared, while Green speaks with the deracinated accent of Great Neck, the well-to-do Long Island suburb from which he hails. And both men are products of the 60's, though very different aspects of the decade: in Bloomberg's case, the go-go financial years that made him a young millionaire at Salomon Brothers, and in Green's, the pamphleteering, ideologically charged era that made him a comrade in arms of Ralph Nader and a kind of gadfly without portfolio. 
Bloomberg is certainly the more unlikely of the two. He is an entrepreneur and political neophyte who argues that his experience founding and directing an extraordinarily successful company, the eponymous Bloomberg LP, gives him the managerial experience to run New York City; the tag line of his ads is "A leader, not a politician." He is, he says, a "pragmatist," not an ideologue; a businessman who looks for good solutions, not perfect ones. He says that he can instill in the city's work force the same kind of "esprit de corps" that has made Bloomberg LP so successful, thus increasing productivity and permitting the city to afford raises even in the tough times ahead. But New Yorkers do not share either the national contempt for politicians or the national reverence for entrepreneurs: Bloomberg has had trouble tapping into a vein of discontent or generating a wave of enthusiasm, and he has remained far behind Green in the polls despite shattering local records for campaign finance by spending close to $30 million of his own money. 
Until he began campaigning, Bloomberg had the same relationship to the city that most rich people do: he consumed its rarefied treats and enjoyed its hubbub from a safe distance. He lived, in the derisive phrase of Fred Siegel, a historian at Cooper Union, "inside a double bubble" -- the bubble of the Upper East Side and the bubble of the corporate boardroom. When I encountered Bloomberg outside a campaign event a few weeks ago, he exhorted me, with the most perfect earnestness and with something like wonder in his voice, to "go around the city," to see neighborhoods as he had -- something he has been telling journalists since the early days of the campaign. I had the impression that he had been overwhelmingly relieved to find that people in strange and exotic neighborhoods on the other sides of those bridges were receptive and friendly. Here was a man encountering the city for the first time (though his philanthropic activities had occasionally taken him out of his bubble before). It is not easy to imagine a figure whom New Yorkers would be less likely to identify with in times of trouble.
There is, in fact, something almost touching, but also disconcerting, about watching Bloomberg try to make common cause with people a world away from himself. This July, I heard him tell a Baptist congregation in Harlem how proud his father would be to know that his grandchildren had attended the finest universities in the Ivy League and that he himself sat on the board of the most exclusive charities. Working variations on an uplifting theme about the civil rights struggle, he said, "My daughter is a champion equestrienne, and her biggest competitor is a kid who is black."
Mark Green is, at least in politics, as thoroughgoing a professional as Bloomberg is an amateur. He has been in and around politics for 30 years and running for office for the last 20. Nobody works a subway more single-mindedly. Green is sometimes too nimble for his own good; he has a way of barely skirting disingenuousness that puts you in mind of Bill Clinton. When I reminded him, in a recent conversation, about his inopportune claim that he could have bested Giuliani's performance during the crisis, he turned to me with an innocent smile and asked what could possibly be wrong with the sentiment that "anyone who runs for mayor should aspire to do as well as or better than his predecessor." Green has many of Clinton's virtues as well: he is a serious thinker about issues, with an instinct for the available middle; a shrewd commentator who provides his own footnotes; and a centaur with the head of an activist and the hoofs of a pol. 
There is a kind of long-wave theory of the mayoralty popular among some conservatives and ex-liberals that dictates that reformers are predictably followed by restorers of status quo liberalism. Green appears, superficially, to be just such a figure. He comes out of "the movement" and is an old friend of the city's liberal lions; the mayor he puts you most in mind of is John Lindsay, the figure in whom big-city liberalism came to grief. But he is a much tougher and more ambitious character than the aristocratic Lindsay ever was. It is no coincidence that Green has virtually attached himself to the hip of William Bratton, Giuliani's first police chief, thus neutralizing fears that he would be soft on crime. He is, moreover, a supple figure who recognized immediately that the World Trade Center disaster had changed everything. In fact, one reason Green defeated Ferrer is that he seemed to have integrated this new understanding far more deeply than Ferrer had.
Green has a mastery of policy that he can match against anyone in city government. But one effect of the terrorist attack is that a fine-grained sense of where the debate is on policy solutions now seems to matter less than it usually does -- and character to matter more. New Yorkers want a mayor with whom they can personally identify and then follow. And Green is, like Bloomberg, rather cool to the touch. Even his appearance -- the white hair, the dark tan -- leaves an impression of glossiness, of high artifice. Green has the reputation of being too confident by half, and a bit smirky; Ed Koch, never one to mince words, called him "obnoxious." 
Green is obviously pained by this line of attack, which he describes as "an unserious and all-too-personal criticism from people who apparently couldn't criticize my record or vision." Whether or not he is obnoxious, Green does seem to lack the empathy, the intuitive connection, that makes Bill Clinton such a great politician. It is, of course, worth recalling that scarcely anyone attributed those gifts to Rudy Giuliani before Sept. 11. Leaders are not just born; they are also made.
In the immediate aftermath of the attack on the World Trade Center, the distinctions among New Yorkers that once seemed so salient disappeared. Green himself said: "Some emotional, unthinking people have said to me after Sept. 11, 'Oh, God, who would want to run New York City now?' In one obvious way, it will be easier to run New York City, not despite but because of the World Trade Center incident. There is an extraordinary solidarity that is supplanting the ethnic, racial and borough divisions that previously governed the city." 
But solidarity is an unnatural condition for New York, and it began to fray almost as soon as the political campaign resumed. In the runoff between Green and Ferrer, both men struggled to capture moderate-to-liberal white voters. Ferrer shelved his "other New York" message and briefly gained the upper hand. Green, suddenly faced with the shocking prospect of losing, took Ferrer on directly, running an ad in the final days that cited newspaper articles criticizing Ferrer's budgetary plans and asked, "Can we afford to take a chance?" Phone calls were made and fliers distributed -- not, apparently, by the Green campaign -- insisting that Ferrer would be the Rev. Al Sharpton's cat's-paw. In the end, Green carried almost all of the white vote and Ferrer almost all the Hispanic vote, as well as nearly 70 percent of the black vote. Green won by a bare 20,000 votes. 
It was a result almost guaranteed to provoke racial rancor, and it did. Ferrer and his supporters were outraged by Green's ad and by his insufficient condemnation of the calls and literature, though they scarcely violated local standards of decency. For a few days, all hell broke loose. Ferrer's principal backers, including Representative Charles Rangel, paid ostentatious visits to Michael Bloomberg. The Republican candidate, in turn, abandoned his high-mindedness in order to fish in troubled waters, solemnly noting that "we don't need people to pay lip service to pulling people together and then, in fact, in their personal lives, in their political lives, in their business lives, do the opposite." 
After a week of this mummery, Green promised to take the accusations more seriously, and Ferrer finally agreed to a mega-unity event at which practically every prominent Democrat in the state lined up together on a raised platform, like a summer-camp photo. Ferrer stood as stiff as a wooden soldier while Green intoned, with transparent insincerity, "I can hardly put myself in the place of someone who lost so narrowly and had to witness racial stereotyping at the end of a substantive and heroic campaign."
As soon as the ritual ended and before the questions began, Sharpton and Roberto Ramirez, Ferrer's chief adviser, walked off the stage. A few days later, I called Ramirez, the Bronx Democratic county chairman and leading figure in Hispanic political circles, to see how serious the split was. Ramirez was still exercised. He insisted that the primary campaign had proved that "it's O.K. to use the race card to vilify a candidate" and, more specifically, that "if you happen to be a Hispanic, there's going to be a double standard." He said that while Ferrer had promised to support the Democratic nominee, he was under no such obligation. Ramirez seems quite prepared to make mischief in the Hispanic community, as Sharpton has long done among blacks. And the occasions will arise, as these are precisely the communities that are bound to suffer most in the austerity measures to come. 
A few weeks after taking office, the next mayor will appear in the Blue Room of City Hall to deliver a very solemn message about the budget for the coming year. "New York City," he will say, "is facing the largest deficit in its history." Thanks to the recession that began gathering force well before Sept. 11, the city's Independent Budget Office was already predicting a deficit of $3 billion for the 2002-2003 fiscal year, which begins July 1. These projections often prove unduly dire, at least in normal times, but the collapse of the World Trade Center has changed everything. The city's controller, Alan Hevesi, predicts that in the current fiscal year the city will lose $738 million in tax revenue and 115,000 jobs. And then the losses will mount. 
Eugene Keilin, the chairman of the Citizens Budget Commission, compares the city's economic state today with that of the mid-70's, another time when a crisis dragged down an economy that was already soft. Keilin says: "I think the falloff in revenue will be sharper than anybody has been expecting. Wall Street is way off; theaters, restaurants, hotels, the tourist industry are way off; a lot of businesses aren't operating." Fiscal experts are now projecting a deficit of $4 billion to $6 billion for next year, with the larger number perhaps the likelier one.
How do you cut $6 billion from a $40 billion budget? You could raise taxes, of course; but even Mark Green, a big-government liberal, if a chastened one, says, "The last thing I want to do is raise taxes, because that makes it harder for residents or businesses to stay here when they may be looking across the river or across the country." Green says that a commuter tax, which would in any case only raise about $450 million, is "politically unlikely, but economically desirable." (Bloomberg opposes any tax increase.) Some proceeds can come from fines, license fees and other small revenue items, but everything else will come from cuts, and the main cost of city government is people. Giuliani financed a severance package for 15,000 employees when he took over, but the city may have trouble finding the money to do that. 
The next mayor will institute a hiring freeze that will produce attrition; but since attrition won't create anything like $6 billion in savings, he will almost certainly have to consider the dreaded final option of layoffs, which in turn means service cuts. Even layoffs pose a problem, however. Michael Jacobson, a former deputy budget officer in the Dinkins administration and now a fiscal adviser to Green, points out that several major city unions have now won no-layoff clauses and that about 90 percent of the employees who have been added to the work force as the city's economy has grown in recent years are policemen, teachers or caseworkers for the foster-care agency, the Administration for Children's Services -- all of whom are close to sacrosanct. Where will the cuts come from? Diana Fortuna, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, ticks off the list of "traditional suspects": parks, street cleaning, libraries, capital projects, housing, the City University. 
That first year will be a terrible time for the mayor, and the city. The city will be facing what Bloomberg calls "a triple whammy" with the police, who will have to do without expected large raises, who will likely be retiring in large numbers owing to a quirk in their pension plan and who will be hearing attractive offers as the market for private security grows. Bloomberg has no convincing solution to this problem; nor does anyone else. But Giuliani has made crime control a nonnegotiable issue in New York; any sign that the long-term drop in crime is reversing will send alarm bells ringing all over the city. Even if crime stays down, the informal quality-of-life tally that New Yorkers carry in their heads is bound to decline: streets will be dirtier; park repairs will take longer; libraries will be closed Saturdays; after-school and summer jobs programs will be curtailed.
The single greatest asset the next mayor will have is the universal expectation of sacrifice and the willingness, maybe not quite so universal, to accept sacrifice in the name of some larger good. David Dinkins could not persuade the teachers' union to accept a raise the city could afford at a time of shrinking revenues in 1990, and the city suffered the consequences of an unaffordable agreement for years. This time around, Fernando Ferrer had promised teachers a staggering 30 percent raise back in the pre-Sept. 11 era; now teachers understand that they cannot have the raise they believe they deserve. That is the good part. The bad part is that the same mayor who lays off city employees and asks all New Yorkers to live with austerity will be handing out tax abatements and subsidizing the construction of office buildings in Lower Manhattan. Green, in fact, says that the swift revitalization of Lower Manhattan "may require sacrifice from others." How is a mayor going to explain that to the "others"? In the new ethic of shared sacrifice, what sacrifice will he ask of the business community? Neither Bloomberg nor Green could give me a satisfactory answer. 
Cuts in the city budget do not fall equally on all New Yorkers. Blacks are disproportionately represented among municipal employees; the poor are the principal consumers of the kinds of social services, including public assistance and health care, that are almost certain to be sharply reduced. These were the voters who went to the polls believing that education, housing and other services remain the most salient issues. Both Green and Bloomberg talk about the importance of not losing sight of the pre-September concerns -- what Green calls "the homeland issues." Green promises to make inroads on these longstanding problems "by the time I'm done as mayor." Since Green expects to be mayor for eight years, this may not be very reassuring to voters who care about their children's test scores or who cannot afford a decent apartment. 
Alan Hevesi has estimated that the World Trade Center may cost New York an almost inconceivable $105 billion over the next two fiscal years in the form of lost wages and rent, cleanup costs, reconstruction and so on. As much as $40 billion may return to the city in the form of insurance. New York has appealed to Washington to make up as much of the difference as possible. President Bush agreed to give the city $20 billion worth of help the moment Senators Chuck Schumer and Hillary Rodham Clinton asked, and an administration official insists that despite a growing clamor for scarce dollars, that promise is ironclad. Giuliani's guided tours of the unspeakable are designed to keep the spigot open. Indeed, Fred Siegel has argued that the city should have found a way of giving the mayor the extra 90 days he wanted because no one else, and least of all a Democrat, could have equaled the exalted standing Giuliani enjoyed in Washington. 
There is a long tradition of presidents rewarding like-minded mayors and ignoring those who aren't. LaGuardia exploited his strong ties to F.D.R. to make New York the principal urban laboratory of the New Deal, while Lindsay was able to do much the same during L.B.J.'s War on Poverty. Abe Beame, on the other hand, never had a prayer with the Ford administration. No one in the Bush administration is going to tell either Mark Green or Michael Bloomberg to "drop dead," as The Daily News famously described the Ford administration's attitude toward Beame's New York, but neither the Nader's Raider nor the Silk Stocking Republican is likely to be a good fit with the national Republicans. One Republican strategist with close ties to the Bush administration describes the mayor's impending departure as "a big loss" for New York's status in Washington, though he adds that the city has already begun to lose altitude. "There was a moment when everybody had 'I Love New York' in their heart," he says. But when the state and city submitted a request for an additional $34 billion, including upstate rail projects that had obviously been dragged off some wish list in Albany, "it looked a little opportunistic."
The Giuliani administration, along with Senators Schumer and Clinton, is planning to submit a more modest wish list. But since Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., the director of the federal Office of Management and Budget, has said that no additional funds could be made available until next year, it will fall to the next mayor, along with Gov. George Pataki and the rest of the New York Congressional delegation, to actually make the case. $

HEADLINE: Compressed Data; 
May the Force/Boss Be With You, in 3-D

BYLINE:  By CAREN CHESLER 

 BODY:
In an early scene in "Star Wars," the robot R2-D2 projects into the room a holographic image of Princess Leia, who implores Obi-Wan Kenobi to help defeat the Empire. Her image was lifelike and three-dimensional, but it was a cinematic gimmick reserved for the movies.
 No more. A Dallas company, Teleportec, has introduced technology to transmit holographic images of people over high-speed digital circuits. A chief executive can stand at a lectern in New York, for instance, while a three-dimensional, life-size image of him is projected onto a stage in San Francisco. The executive can remotely see the audience, and the participants on both sides of the transmission can communicate in real time. 
 "The optical portion of your brain insists the person is in the room because he meets all the criteria," said Philip Barnett, a vice president at Teleportec and one of its founders. "He's life-size, he's making eye contact, and there's no latency between when his mouth moves and you hear the words."
A special camera captures the subject's image, digitizes it and then transmits it to a remote location over any high-speed line capable of carrying audio and video signals. The image is then funneled through a beam splitter and projected onto a pane of glass, giving it a three-dimensional effect. Users can install the equipment in their offices and pay a subscriber fee of about $5,000 a month for each location, or they can rent conference rooms equipped with the technology for about $500 an hour.
Teleportec is pitching its product to executives of Fortune 500 companies, government agencies and educational institutions as a way to beam themselves to a remote location without actually having to be there. Executives from BP and Nortel Networks have already used the technology in giving speeches. And CB Richard Ellis, a commercial real estate firm with headquarters in Los Angeles, plans to use the technology to show clients properties in remote cities.
The system has reached the market at an opportune time for Teleportec. Many companies have cut travel budgets and are increasingly relying on various forms of teleconferencing in response to the economic downturn and concern about terrorism. 
HQ Global Workplaces, a Dallas company that rents videoconferencing rooms and plans to offer Teleportec's technology, says its more conventional videoconferencing business has doubled since Sept. 11.
"The National Business Travel Association says a one-day business trip costs $1,500," said Todd Foster, an HQ vice president. "We can do a videoconference for six or seven hours before you would reach that cost." CAREN CHESLER

GRAPHIC: Photo: Todd Foster, a vice president of HQ Global Workplaces, reaching out to touch the teleported image of the company's chief executive, David Rupert. HQ plans to offer Teleportec's technology for teleconferences. (Mark Graham for The New York Times)
