HEADLINE: Now, Hitting 'Save' Is Not Enough 

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
IN the aftermath of Sept. 11, job No. 1 for most information technology managers outside the World Trade Center neighborhood was to make sure their operations were functioning normally. But it did not take long before they began to assess the business lessons of that horrific day. In most cases, their analyses included a re-examination of which data should be stored, how it should be kept and whether plans for retrieving it were adequate.
 "We estimate that 25 to 30 percent of our customers are going to end up changing what they do in some way," said Gary Francis, the general manager of automated tape products for StorageTek, which makes disk and tape storage systems and is in Louisville, Colo. 
 The first wave of changes has involved simply backing up critical data more frequently, said Kevin Coyne, the director of business operations for Sun Microsystems. But many of Sun's customers are also rushing to thoroughly inventory the many types of data they create and reconsider what is critical, he added.
Data management experts say that big companies are not likely to make sweeping changes before next year because comprehensive data policy reviews take weeks to finish. If reviews point to a significant shift -- buying new equipment to duplicate data at distant recovery sites, for example -- efforts to fix these problems can drag on for months.
Therefore, those companies that are already revising their practices tend to be small. The first to do so also include a few larger businesses that had been weighing changes to systems they had installed in the late 1990's to head off disruptions associated with computers mishandling year 2000 dates, according to vendors and consultants.
"Almost everybody has a backup strategy, but they aren't always well implemented," said Adam Couture, an analyst who is based in Lowell, Mass., and works for the Gartner Group, an information technology consulting firm.
Computer consultants say that although the economic slowdown has reduced investments in new data-storage equipment, data-management reviews have risen this year. Despite the scrutiny that data received during the year 2000 overhaul, many practices have become obsolete. This is because databases have grown in size and diversity through the expansion of e-mail, digital forms of entertainment and e-business. Likewise, computer users have more data storage and recovery options. 
A growing number of computer users are handing over their data storage and management needs to companies like I.B.M., Electronic Data Services and Storage Networks. These vendors manage networks of storage equipment at big data centers. Many companies also "mirror" critical data, a process that simultaneously stores new data, as it is generated, on computers in two different locations. That way, business can continue if one computer is knocked out.
At the lower end of the market, companies that back up their computers on tape have a growing number of businesses they can turn to for off-site storage and duplication of their records. Another alternative, sometimes combined with tape storage, is to send crucial files automatically over secure Internet lines to storage service providers.
Automation is a common theme in many new services. Most data storage currently involves transferring data from disks to tapes and manually collecting and storing the tapes. Such jobs often fall to administrative employees rather than information technology specialists, and it is not uncommon for glitches to occur, thus preventing companies from making reliable backups as frequently as their policies require.
The Sept. 11 attacks appear to have stimulated interest in some of the newer services.
"Business is up 50 or 60 percent since Sept. 11," said Bud Stoddard, the founder and chief executive of Amerivault, a Waltham, Mass., start-up that allows computer users to back up files over the Internet. "People are calling us, we're not calling them."
The calls to Amerivault, which focuses on data kept on work stations and servers that deal with small networks of desktop computers, reflect the nature of most of the data that was lost on Sept. 11.
The attacks had little effect on mainframe computer operations for banks and other large businesses. Commercial real estate in the World Trade Center neighborhood is so expensive that most large companies there moved their main computer operations elsewhere long ago.
Companies in the area were also early users of mirroring technology. As a result, the speed with which companies were back in business after the attacks depended largely on how fast workers were relocated, not on the availability of their mainframe computer data.

HEADLINE: To-Do List for Christmas: This Year, the Little Things 

BYLINE:  By BOB TEDESCHI 

 BODY:
IN the 1999 holiday e-tailing season, marketing was in, as merchants like eToys and Amazon engaged in what amounted to an arms race fought with advertising dollars. Last year, the watchword was fulfillment, the industry term for shipping and handling, which so many e-tailers ignored the year before in their quest to simply attract holiday customers.
 This holiday season's common element among e-tailers is -- nothing. 
 The few remaining Internet-only merchants and their traditional retail counterparts say the business of selling on the Web has reached a milestone in that the work cannot be reduced to a few boldfaced bullet points, like "keep the site running," "launch ad campaign with B-list star" and "build several monolithic warehouses."
Rather, Web retailers preparing for the holidays spend their days wrangling with much more subtle and unglamorous details, like optimizing their e-mail marketing campaigns, tweaking their site navigation and adjusting prices to attract the right mix of customers. But the good news for consumers and executives alike is that, as Internet retailers shed their baby teeth, they are getting better at these tasks, and more. 
"This will be the first year where nothing really interesting happens in Internet retail," said Ken Cassar, an analyst with Jupiter Media Metrix, an online consulting company. "The growth of the online channel was really a double-edged sword. On the one hand it was great to have sales jump like they did, but things were so volatile, it required companies to make huge changes all the time to keep up."
Indeed, the projected holiday Internet retail sales for 2001 look unspectacular. Jupiter predicts that holiday sales will be roughly 11 percent higher this year than last, coming in around $11.9 billion. By contrast, 2000 holiday sales were 54 percent higher than those in 1999, which were 120 percent higher than 1998 levels.
With more stable businesses, Internet retail executives say they can focus better on efficiency and service for customers. Consider Amazon. According to David Risher, the senior vice president for marketing and merchandising, Amazon is expected to begin a service this month that will allow customers to track the shipping on 85 percent of the company's merchandise, compared with about 50 percent before.
"It's a subtle thing, but if you increase the trackability of packages, you'll increase the customer's confidence it will arrive on time," Mr. Risher said. "A couple of years ago, it was way too early to worry about this kind of stuff. But now, customer expectations are rising, so we do."
Amazon is also focusing on lower prices in certain categories, Mr. Risher said, aiming to solidify the company's place as the dominant mass-market retailer. In mid-2000, Amazon raised its prices on books and other items. At the time, some analysts attributed the increase to the company's urgent need to attain profitability.
Now, Mr. Risher said, the company is simply experimenting. "If you look back 30 years from now, this will all be lost in the preadolescent noise of figuring out what kind of company we wanted to be," he said. "We came out of it firmly on the side that we should be able to, and can, lower prices in many categories."
For instance, Mr. Risher said, Amazon has "structural economic advantages" over other book retailers, because, among other things, its distributors can ship books directly to consumers and the company does business in such great volume it can shave costs. "So, for items over $20, we can give some margin back to customers and still make money on the sale," he said.
Another early online retailer, Bertelsmann's CDNow, is also at the stage where it can fine-tune its shipping techniques, both for the customer's sake and the company's. Mike Haney, CDNow's senior director for merchandising, says the focus is not tracking items more closely, like Amazon, but coordinating the shipments so they get to the customer more quickly.
In the past, Mr. Haney said, the company kept CD's, videos and merchandise like T-shirts in different warehouses across the country, so when customers ordered an item from each category, they would have to wait until the company had all the merchandise in one place. Then it could be shipped in one package.
Starting the first week of this month, CDNow shifted to a new system, in which its distribution centers hold a more diverse mix of items. In addition, Mr. Haney said the company had contracted with more distributors east of the Mississippi, where a majority of the population is concentrated. One result is that customers who order a mix of merchandise are more likely to get it more quickly.
Against the backdrop of Internet retailers tangling with the intricacies of shipping and pricing, there are many who wonder whether the economic downturn that preceded the terrorist attacks and accelerated after Sept. 11 will dim their holiday hopes.
Among the more optimistic is Neiman Marcus. Karen Katz, the chief executive of Neiman Marcus Direct, which oversees online and catalog sales for the Neiman Marcus Group, says she suspects her Web site will generally not suffer from the downturn in the economy.
Nonetheless, she said that the site, NeimanMarcus.com, would feature relatively less-expensive gifts this season to round out the usual collection of exorbitant gifts, like helicopters and custom-made gingerbread houses.
"Consumers come to the site because they want to be able to give a gift from Neiman Marcus," Ms. Katz said. "So we tailor the site to a broader base during the holidays."
WHILE the lower-priced merchandise, which includes items like $35 liqueur cake samplers and $28 potpourri gift sets, helps attract those with fewer shopping dollars, they serve another important function: those items could attract new shoppers during the holidays who might return during the rest of the year, Ms. Katz said.
The Neiman Marcus site is also taking advantage of some lessons it learned during last year's holiday season regarding the type of customers who do or do not shop on the site, Ms. Katz said. "Last year, we thought, 'Well, there are a lot of men who are interested in the Internet, who are into the technology,' " so the site featured a wide array of men's shirts and fashions.
Unfortunately, many more women than men showed up on the site. "So, we'll be offering a bigger selection of things a woman would buy for a man," Ms. Katz said, including gifts like cashmere dress socks and a set of 1933 replica baseball cards.
Unlike NeimanMarcus.com, which was introduced two years ago, the outdoor goods retailer REI has been selling on the Web since 1996. Given that comparative longevity, said Joan Broughton, REI's vice president for direct sales, REI.com requires only "very subtle changes" for this holiday season.
For example, REI has been changing the site to discourage people from bailing out of a purchase. "We're doing things as simple as making the buttons bigger and breaking the number of questions into bite-size pieces," Ms. Broughton said. "If you ask for a lot of information on one long page, they'll sometimes just turn away."
With only the smaller changes needed, "I guess that means we're in a mature phase now," Ms. Broughton said. "Everything's in place. Now, we're pretty much just battening down the hatches."

HEADLINE: A Safety Net For New York 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "Hungry and Jobless" (column, Nov. 1): Bob Herbert correctly underscores that those hardest hit by the economic downturn that New York faces after the World Trade Center tragedy are those who have been falling through the cracks all along: the city's uninsured and low-wage earners, a population likely only to grow larger post-Sept. 11. 
 Vital social services, including low-cost health care, are likely to be slashed as money from the already depleted city and state budgets is reallocated to public safety and rebuilding efforts. 
Coupled with job loss, social service cuts are a virtual double whammy for poor and low-income New York women and their families. We can meet the basic health care needs of all New Yorkers only by preserving direct access to services, including a safety net for the uninsured.
This tragedy has brought out the best in New Yorkers -- our resiliency, pride and compassion. Let us work these characteristics into the fabric of our daily lives and our financial priorities and make them the blueprint for a new New York.

JOAN MALIN
Chief Executive, Planned
Parenthood of New York City
New York, Nov. 1, 2001

HEADLINE: COLLABORATION; 
Making Better Toys and Jumbo Jets by Sharing the Rough Draft

BYLINE:  By SCOTT KIRSNER 

 BODY:
FOR Mike Barbato, making changes to three-dimensional objects and beaming them to colleagues around the world has become as easy as altering a sentence in a shared word-processing document.
 Mr. Barbato is the director of engineering at Equity Marketing in Los Angeles, which designs many of the promotional toys that are given away by Burger King. Like most companies that make toys, cars, cellphones and other consumer products, Equity used to start a project with a lump of clay, from which designers sculptured a series of models and shipped them to customers, licensers and safety consultants for approvals. Finally, a model would be sent to the company's manufacturing office in Hong Kong, which determined whether the toy could be produced as designed. 
 Now, with the help of two novel tools that allow designers to operate in three dimensions, Equity's employees can work simultaneously on a single design, print out copies for review and "fax" them to the Hong Kong office for immediate advice.
"We've found these tools to be extremely powerful," Mr. Barbato said. "They've reduced our cycle time, from the initial product brief to tooling, by at least two weeks."
The technologies that Equity uses -- FreeForm, a device made by SensAble Technologies, and the ThermoJet printer, made by 3D Systems -- are part of a raft of innovations changing how companies design products, thereby opening the door for greater collaboration, shorter cycle times, higher quality and wider customizing. These innovations are often grouped under the rubric "rapid prototyping."
FreeForm lets designers use their hands to shape and refine objects that exist only on a computer screen but have the same tactile qualities as the clay or plastic foam they are accustomed to working with. The ThermoJet, a solid-object printer about the size of a large copy machine, produces shapes by spraying layers of plastic from a set of nozzles. A similar printer from the Z Corporation can render objects in 64 million colors and produce a model the size of a football in about two hours. Color scanners from companies like Arius 3D can import existing objects into the computer to serve as templates for changes or new designs, and a monitor being developed by Actuality Systems displays three-dimensional objects in a dome of glass.
"The marginal cost of doing different iterations of a product design used to be extremely high, and it took a long time to do each iteration," said Michael Schrage, a researcher at the M.I.T. Media Lab and the author of "Serious Play: How the World's Best Companies Simulate to Innovate."
He said that these tools "completely transform the economics and the social dynamics of model-making."
"It becomes as easy to change a slope on a car's hood as it is to change a typeface in the company newsletter," Mr. Schrage said. He thinks that the ability to make such changes easily can yield significant competitive advantage.
Equity Marketing has already benefited from the innovations, Mr. Barbato said. In the industry, there has been an increase in the number of recalls of promotional toys because of safety concerns, so designers at Equity can now deliver the company's prototypes to safety consultants earlier in the process.
Now, the initial rough sculpture takes five days to make, not three weeks, Mr. Barbato said. Designers who have worked on a character before -- Bart Simpson, for example -- can use last year's toy as a template instead of starting with a lump of clay. And Equity's engineers in Asia can spot problems sooner.
One chief advantage of the new technology is that it allows various departments to work simultaneously, instead of sequentially, on a product. At Gillette, Jill Shurtleff, a senior industrial designer, said that working with digital designs allowed for "concurrent engineering."
"I can be working on the same model as a mechanical engineer," she said. "The purchasing department can be getting quotes on the material costs, and if vendors are within our confidential sphere, they can see it, too." 
At the Ford Motor Company, some departments are sending three-dimensional models of parts to suppliers, as well as traditional requests for price quotations. Ford executives have found that suppliers tend to respond with lower prices when they have a better idea of what they are expected to produce.
Marina Hatsopoulos, the chief executive of the Z Corporation, which makes three-dimensional printers, agreed. Companies "find they get much lower quotes when they send a three-D model along with the request."
In designing Gillette's Venus razor for women, Ms. Shurtleff found she could not get the "very organic, undulating form" she wanted by creating models on a computer screen. So, she made a prototype by hand, scanned the three-dimensional model into the computer and refined it. 
Arius 3D, the maker of a new three-dimensional scanning technology, predicts that its tool, a color scanner, will also help at the end of the design process, when the first samples roll off the assembly line.
"You'll be able to scan the object, e-mail it around the company and get people's feedback as to whether it's acceptable," said Walter Noot, the chief operating officer of Arius. Because the new tools reduce the time and cost of designing products, some companies find they can afford to produce variations on existing designs. "Each of the retailers we supply products to wants their own unique item," said Mike Zerbe, a senior model maker at Graco Children's Products, which makes strollers, cribs and other baby items. 
Some analysts expect the three-dimensional technology to encourage more customizing as it becomes less expensive. A color three-dimensional printer from the Z Corporation sells for $64,000; the FreeForm system from SensAble costs $25,000.
For example, one thing that Nokia, the cellphone maker, is known for is letting customers choose different faceplates for their phones, said B. Joseph Pine, a consultant at Strategic Horizons and a co-author of "Mass Customization." He said that one of his recent recommendations to Nokia was that "they ought to have mass-customized skeletons that, for example, fit the hand of the person who buys them."
One catch, however, is that buyers must be willing to pay a premium for the customized products to justify the investment in the technology, Mr. Pine said. But a big advantage of mass customizing, he said, is that "you have no finished goods inventory sitting around." 
Others think that the technology will be cheap enough to allow consumers to design and customize objects at home, like bookends or picture frames, perhaps by downloading templates from the Internet. They might print the items out on their own three-dimensional printers or at a copy center.
Whether or not that will be possible, people using these technologies at their jobs right now like them. 
"When I started doing product design at Gillette 18 years ago," Ms. Shurtleff said, "I was sitting at a drawing board with a big piece of paper and lots of pencils and erasers. Now, that seems like the dark ages."

HEADLINE: COLLABORATION; 
Machine-Made Links Change the Way Minds Can Work Together

BYLINE:  By KATIE HAFNER 

 BODY:
MODERN science is accustomed to bigness. In five years, the world's most powerful particle accelerator will be in operation at the CERN physics laboratory outside Geneva. The $4 billion accelerator will give physicists the tools they need to search for scientific prizes like the elusive Higgs boson, a particle believed to be the origin of mass and weight in the universe.
 But when the accelerator starts up, scientists will not necessarily need to travel to Switzerland to conduct their experiments. Instead, they will be able to work together remotely, using a federally financed project called the Grid Physics Network, or GriPhyN (pronounced GRIFF-in), a system that can be used in real time by researchers working on experiments that require vast amounts of computational power. 
 At the other end of the spectrum is Freeverse Software, a small company in New York whose dozen or so programmers work from places as geographically dispersed as Romania and Arizona, using e-mail messages as their primary means of collaboration. 
And somewhere in the middle lies an intensive engineering collaboration -- the recent design and manufacture of a wireless headset for a new Chrysler minivan. Instead of placing conference calls and taking business trips, the half-dozen contractors working on the product used the Web as their principal meeting place.
All three are examples of the way in which the intelligence of the Internet can be greater than the sum of its parts. For years, the Internet has served as a tool for communication; when the Web came along in the early 1990's, it added a multimedia component to the Internet, with images, music and text.
Now the world is seeing a new level of connection emerge in the form of an unprecedented amount of computer-based collaboration that not only helps companies do business more efficiently and more economically, but also augments human intelligence. 
This became more apparent in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, when, in the face of reduced travel or even physical displacement, many companies were forced to rely on the Web and e-mail as a primary means of doing business.
The new collaboration is not necessarily the result of expensive, flashy technology. The real consequence is social; when computers interact differently, the humans who use them do, too.
"Most technical innovations are extensions of technology," said Michael Schrage, a research associate at the Media Laboratory at M.I.T. "This is an extension of human behavior, of how people actually interact. It's one thing to share a design. It's another to have a technology that lets you create a design together."
The idea is not new. Forty years ago, J. C. R. Licklider, a research director of the Pentagon's Advanced Research Projects Agency, predicted that complicated tasks could be shared by computers and humans, with the computers performing much of the rote work, leaving the higher-level problems of analysis and judgment to humans. And Dr. Licklider predicted a global network that would link its users to a universe of information. Through the years, others have echoed his words.
There have been plenty of false turns along the way. Dr. David Gelernter, a computer scientist at Yale, described efforts in the 1980's to create highly advanced software that would allow researchers to work together. "It turned out that the tools didn't correspond to what people wanted to do," he said. "None of it was simple enough. It was like killing a gnat with a nuclear missile."
Two things have changed since then. One is the ubiquity of simple tools like e-mail, attachments and shared Web pages that allow millions of computer users inside corporations and outside to take on projects together. "Far more gets done that way than with specialized tools," Dr. Gelernter said. "What we need is something far simpler and far more powerful, and these are beginning to emerge."
One reason for these new possibilities is that computers have only now become powerful enough that resource sharing can occur across institutional boundaries.
Take the project at CERN in Geneva. "In the past the way people had to handle these things would be to travel to Geneva and spend a few weeks there analyzing the data, or write papers," said Dr. Ian Foster, a computer scientist at the University of Chicago and co-director of GriPhyN. "And now you have community access to the raw materials -- the data, the computations used to analyze the data and generate new data, are all made available through shared community resources instantaneously."
Not only does remote collaboration change the way research is conducted, Dr. Foster said, but it also changes the way scientists view their roles as discoverers of nature's basic truths. 
"Working in a collaborative fashion like this requires people to adjust in a variety of ways," Dr. Foster said. "It concerns learning to be open and sharing things with your colleagues in the belief that the final benefit you will gain will be greater than if you don't."
Dr. Foster sees a number of ways in which Internet-based collaboration concepts being developed in less commercial settings can be applied to business. "Increasingly, businesses attack problems not by themselves but in various teaming arrangements," he said.
One example of highly dispersed but intensive engineering collaboration was the recent design and manufacture of a wireless headset for a new Chrysler minivan.
Alpine Electronics in Detroit, Chrysler's audio vendor, sent the job to Recoton, a consumer electronics company in Orlando, Fla., which in turn hired Aptec, a product development company in Ormond Beach, Fla., to design and engineer the headset for high-volume production. The headset was then manufactured in South Korea and the headset's circuit board was produced in the Philippines. 
The companies involved in the project, which began in June 2000 and was completed in May 2001, held their meetings in a virtual conference room that allowed them to view, manipulate and annotate three- and two-dimensional models and data. 
The best part of the project, said Tom Morris, the chief information officer at Aptec, was shaving nine months and $250,000 off in the process. The reduction of travel contributed most to the savings of time and expense.
At the same time, Mr. Morris said, remote collaboration requires a different mindset. "You have to behave differently," he said. 
In traditional design projects, he said, "one team gets their hands on things, and then they throw it over a wall to another team. But when they're all brought together concurrently it's a different culture, and that cultural aspect can be something that's really tough to overcome." 
Still, observers like Mr. Schrage see the Chrysler headset project as part of a fundamental shift for the carmaker. "Now it's not about approving specifications," he said. "It's about interacting with ideas" as a group while the specifications are being developed.
Another example, more elementary than GriPhyN and the Chrysler project, is Freeverse Software, which creates computer-based card games for the Macintosh.
Ian Lynch Smith, the president of Freeverse, said that for the seven years he had been running the company, his programmers had been working remotely. This practice, Mr. Smith said, drastically alters the way he interacts with them. Because the everyday banter that comes with working together in one office is missing, he said, it is important to establish a strong rapport, which Mr. Smith tries to do through e-mail messages.
"The relationship you develop makes all the difference," he said, "because you're not getting the facial expressions, you're not having incidential conversations about their dog."
Mr. Smith shuns elaborate Web-based collaboration tools, preferring instead to keep the technology straightforward and simple. "The simpler the tools, the better, which means e-mail is the crux of it," he said. Mr. Smith said that the lack of a physical presence inspired creative solutions. In lieu of regular meetings, or even conference calls, where people discuss tasks at hand, Mr. Smith sends to-do lists to programmers, who in turn send back a "build," or new copy of the program.
To send files that are too big to be easily added to an e-mail message, the company maintains an internal server, giving access only to those programmers and artists working on projects for Freeverse.
THE internal site is also used as a convenient place to put backups of what people are working on, he added. "If the programmer in Nebraska's machine dies, we'll have a backup here in New York," Mr. Smith said.
Two Freeverse programmers work from Bucharest. Mr. Smith said that in the nearly three years he had been working with the Romanians, he had yet to meet them, or even speak with them on the phone. All their communication is conducted through e-mail and instant messaging.
Dragos Alexandru, one of the Romanian programmers who runs his own software company, said he had also used a Webcam for videoconferencing with other clients. 
One particularly innovative but deceptively simple move for Freeverse has been to put up a Web page for bug tracking for the company's most recent product, an animated set of card games called Colin's Classic Cards. The company has 60 people testing the software and reporting bugs to the Web site, which is open to all beta testers.
Freeverse and GriPhyN may be worlds apart in their levels of sophistication and complexity, but they share what is perhaps the most rewarding aspect of a networked world, one that hews closely to Dr. Licklider's original vision: the ability to take part in work that would be inaccessible otherwise. 
Dr. Paul Avery, a physicist at the University of Florida and the project director of GriPhyN, said the fact that the project was Web-based made it more universally accessible. "A big part of this is including people who would normally not be invited to the table to make decisions," he said. Dr. Avery said that this point was brought home to him after an overseas visit last year during which he met scientists from poorer countries. 
He was impressed by the caliber of physicists "who simply can't afford to do some of the things they can do in richer countries," he said. "So, the ability to participate as equal members of a collaboration is a hugely important thing."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ECONOMY; 
Staving Off a Recession When Only Old Scripts Are at Hand in a New Age

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 

 BODY:
With daily doses of bad economic news pointing to the first recession in more than a decade, government policy makers face increasing questions about whether they have the resolve and the proper tools to bring about a quick recovery.
 Just as the terrorist attacks required the United States to fight a new kind of war, economists said, the government faces an economic downturn that does not match previous scripts and that so far has not been particularly responsive to the combination of tax cuts and aggressive interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve Board. 
 Yet while the economy seemed to be crumbling from the delayed effects of a one-two punch -- the bursting of the 1990's bubble followed by the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11 -- Washington was dithering.
Even as the latest statistics showed that the economy had contracted over the summer and that unemployment had surged by half a percentage point in October, to 5.4 percent, the two parties in Congress and the Bush administration sank more deeply into an ideological bog over how to respond.
Republicans pushed their plan for another round of tax cuts that would largely benefit companies and upper-income people. Democrats pressed for an approach that would give most help to the unemployed and those with lower incomes, and would rely in large part on increased government spending. 
President Bush repeatedly called on the parties to bridge their differences and act but offered no new proposals of his own and defended his focus on tax cuts.
By the end of the week, they were clearly aware that their inability to get something done left them at risk of being seen as part of the problem rather than part of the solution.
"We're seven weeks after the event," said Richard J. DeKaser, chief economist at National City Bank in Cleveland, referring to the attacks, "and they're still debating."
"It is getting late," Mr. DeKaser added.
It is not just Congress and the administration that are under pressure.
On Tuesday, the Federal Reserve will meet, and analysts are almost unanimous in predicting that it will cut rates for the 10th time this year. The Fed has already slashed its benchmark federal funds rate on overnight loans among banks to 2.5 percent from 6.5 percent this year in an effort to stimulate economic activity by reducing borrowing costs.
Interest rate policy works with long lags, and many analysts said the Fed would ultimately prove as effective as ever, a position also held by Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman. But so far the rate cuts have not had as much effect as expected, some economists said.
In any case, they said, lower rates may not be the right remedy for the economy's major problem: overinvestment by businesses in computers, telecommunications equipment, machinery and other capital goods. 
With demand for their goods and services eroding rapidly, companies are unlikely to borrow to finance more capital spending no matter how low interest rates go.
"It's a very different business cycle," said William Dudley, chief domestic economist at Goldman Sachs, the investment firm. "It's an investment boom-bust cycle, and the bust that's followed the boom has created significant imbalances that will take time to be corrected and that are not easily remedied by monetary policy."
Just how different a cycle this is will be determined in part by how far-reaching the aftereffects of the terrorist attacks prove to be. 
Already, policy makers are trying to determine how much effect fear of further attacks and concerns about a drawn-out war will have on consumer and investor confidence. 
They are examining whether the improvement in recent years in productivity, or business efficiency, will be wiped out by the costs of tighter security and less reliable transportation. And they are waiting to gauge the effects of a likely worldwide recession while speculating about the possible effects of further potential economic shocks like a sharp rise in oil prices.
Publicly, administration officials continue to be upbeat, holding out the possibility that the economy could avoid a technical recession by growing in the fourth quarter and suggesting that in any case the recovery is likely to come fairly quickly next year.
"It's too early to tell" if the United States is in its 10th recession since World War II, said R. Glenn Hubbard, the chairman of the White House Council of Economic Advisers.
Mr. Hubbard said the onset of this problem was atypical in that it did not originate in an often repeated pattern in which inflation gets out of hand and the Fed overreacts by pushing interest rates too high. Inflation this time around has been almost dormant.
Yet if the onset of the problem has been different, Mr. Hubbard said, it is nonetheless playing out in a classic pattern, with weakness spreading from manufacturers through the rest of the economy. There is no reason to think the economy will not also recover as it typically does, he said.
"The dynamics of recovery are likely to be fairly similar to what we've seen before," Mr. Hubbard said. "I have no reason to believe policy won't be very effective, both monetary policy and fiscal policy."
The policy choices on the table in Washington are fairly orthodox. 
Republicans say cutting taxes on companies will reduce pressure on employers to slash jobs, create an incentive to buy equipment soon instead of delaying and help restore confidence and wealth by supporting corporate profits and stock prices. Cutting all income tax rates, even for the wealthy, would have much the same effect by encouraging job creation and hard work.
The point of an economic stimulus package, said Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican minority leader, is "not to give folks a check for today, but to give them a job for tomorrow."
But Democrats said there was no higher priority in a downturn than helping unemployed people put food on the table or maintain their health insurance. If taxes are to be cut, they said, the main recipients should be Americans with low and moderate incomes.
"We should be helping those who need it the most, not those who need it the least," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic majority leader.
To the degree that there is any thinking outside of the political box, it is coming from the ideological wings. Conservative supply-siders want far more sweeping tax cuts than anything getting serious consideration in Congress. Liberals want public-works-style spending packages, everything from child care to highways, with a particular focus on projects that could help improve domestic security.
Politically, tensions continue to run high. In the latest twist, Republicans have started turning on Mr. Bush's point man in negotiating a stimulus package, Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill. 
Enraged by a public suggestion from Mr. O'Neill that the tax-cut bill the House passed last month was "show business," intended more as a political statement than a serious policy proposal, some conservatives have called for Mr. O'Neill to resign.
Asked last week whether Mr. O'Neill should stay on, Mr. Lott said, "That's the president's decision," and added that Mr. O'Neill "needs to be careful with how he says what he believes."
The Senate Finance Committee had tentatively planned to push through a Democratic stimulus plan this week. Then Republicans said they might file as many as 72 amendments to the bill in an effort to tie it up in the committee. It is still unclear how the logjam will get broken. 
Analysts said public pressure will ultimately motivate the politicians on both sides to stop squabbling and come up with a credible response to the deterioration of the economy.
Kim Wallace, a political analyst at Lehman Brothers, the investment firm, said people have been willing to give Congress and the White House a reasonable amount of time but are now growing impatient.
"That reasonable period has been overextended in the eyes of most people," Mr. Wallace said. "It only feeds into the notion that Washington has outlived its usefulness at this stage in the crisis, and that's a dangerous place for an elected member to be a year out from an election."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ELECTIONS; 
Local Candidates Everywhere Focus on Terrorism

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 

 BODY:
In Pennsylvania, David Wecht, a candidate for State Supreme Court judge, laments in a television commercial that his baby son's "world changed forever" on Sept. 11.
 In Detroit, Gil Hill, a candidate for mayor, is running a commercial in which a local citizen says, "We live in a different world now -- safety can no longer be assumed." 
 And in Virginia, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York solemnly recalls having lunch with Mark L. Earley, a candidate for governor, just a day before the Sept. 11 attacks. Mr. Giuliani says that if he could vote in the governor's race there on Tuesday, "I would vote for Mark Earley." 
Seeking to reach voters who have been numbed by terrorism, candidates in more than 25 media markets have produced roughly 50 commercials that directly or indirectly refer to the events of Sept. 11. Rather than highlight local matters like whether to increase highway tolls or what to do about waste treatment, candidates are emphasizing their qualifications to protect the public. They are lacing their advertisements with American flags and the faces of firefighters and police officers.
For Republicans running for governor in New Jersey and Virginia and for mayor of New York, it is not President Bush but Mayor Giuliani, still enjoying adulation for his response to the attacks, who has become the politician of choice to endorse their candidacies. 
In all, candidates in Tuesday's elections have spent more than $10 million on commercials related to terrorism, according to a study by the Campaign Media Analysis Group, a research company in Alexandria, Va.
"After Sept. 11, people hit the reset button on what their campaigns stood for and went to messages on domestic security," said Evan Tracey, president of the Campaign Media Analysis Group. "Even at the City Council level, a lot of these candidates felt the best way to connect with voters was to piggyback on current events."
The risk is that voters may question whether the candidates are exploiting the tragedy for their own gain. They might also wonder what relevance terrorism has in contests for City Council in cities far from the attacks, including Baton Rouge, La., Knoxville, Tenn., and Birmingham, Ala.
"If you can link yourself to the flag and respect for firemen and policemen and all these symbols of Sept. 11, it is to your benefit," said Ken Goldstein, a political scientist at the University of Wisconsin who is conducting a study of political advertising. "On the other hand, it's pretty close to bad form to explicitly tie yourself to these symbols without people thinking you're taking advantage. Are people going to resent politics being brought into what happened seven weeks ago?"
In Illinois, Corinne Wood, a Democratic candidate for governor next year, was criticized as insensitive by Republicans for broadcasting a commercial that showed images of the flag and of the World Trade Center erupting into a fireball, followed by an image of the Sears Tower in Chicago. Campaign officials said they had decided to use a commercial that did not feature those images. They insisted that the more inflammatory version ran only by mistake several times in Springfield.
In the version that was intended for broadcast, Ms. Wood says, "I won't give in, not to terrorists, not to a struggling economy."
Most other campaigns around the country have stayed clear of videotape of the World Trade Center or the Pentagon.
Shirley Clarke Franklin, a Democrat who is running for mayor of Atlanta, points to endorsements from the police and firefighters unions in a commercial that features the flag interspersed with faces of local fire and police officers. The words "courage," "valor" and "trust" pop up on the screen. Ms. Franklin appears only at the end. "I am honored and humbled to be endorsed by our police and firefighters," she says. "They make us proud."
Ms. Franklin's campaign manager, Kasim Reed, said he had agonized over whether to invoke Sept. 11 even implicitly. "We did give it a first, second and third thought," he said. "Anyone who's running a campaign in this time would agree that it's very challenging to be focused on electoral politics. We decided that rather than use the endorsements in a traditional sense, our ad would be a tribute to the men and women who keep us safe."
But before the Franklin campaign broadcast the advertisement, Mr. Reed said, he sought feedback from more than 50 voters around the city. "We asked them very frank questions, if they felt the ad was appropriate or whether a line of propriety was being crossed," he said.
In his race for the Supreme Court in Pennsylvania, David Wecht was also careful not to go overboard. There are no images of terror in his advertising -- just the candidate holding his baby son in his lap and standing in a marble courtroom.
"On May 19, 2001, Alexander Wecht was born," Mr. Wecht tells viewers. "On Sept. 11, 2001, his world changed forever. The battles to make Alexander's world safe won't only be fought in faraway lands; they'll be fought in courtrooms, like this one in Pittsburgh."
In New Jersey, the campaign of James E. McGreevey, the Democratic candidate for governor, has included a commercial featuring images of police officers and firefighters. "For all of us, the terrorist attacks were incomprehensible," Mr. McGreevey says, adding that "in these tough times, we're also seeing America at her best."
A few candidates have dared to refer to the terrorism as part of attack advertisements. In the New York mayoral race, Michael R. Bloomberg, the Republican, ran an advertisement quoting his opponent, Mark Green, saying, "I actually believe that if, God forbid, I had been the mayor during such a calamity, I would have done as well or better than Rudy Giuliani." The advertisement ends with the word "Really?" filling the screen.
Not all politicians, particularly incumbents, have been timid about invoking the images of terror for constituents.
"The opportunity to get publicity is overwhelming," said Representative Mark Souder, an Indiana Republican. "I have not been up to New York, but many members did live feeds back when they were there. There's an insatiable demand from the public, and unless you're saying off-the-wall things or can't speak well, it gives you a bounce."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE LAWMAKERS; 
Seeking a United Voice on Capitol Hill

BYLINE:  By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Nov. 4 

 BODY:
Representative Nita M. Lowey of Westchester was sounding exasperated the other day as she tried to get a point across at a gathering of her New York colleagues on Capitol Hill. But they simply would not let her get a word in edgewise.
 "Let me finish! Let me finish! Let me finish!" Mrs. Lowey finally exclaimed. 
 Even in Washington, a city of big egos and strong wills, New York's Congressional delegation has long stood out for its bickering and backbiting. But that day on Capitol Hill captured, in many ways, the intense jockeying that has erupted as New York's lawmakers seek to distinguish themselves in the effort to deliver federal aid to New York in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks.
Normally, such a situation could be shrugged off as more of the same from a bunch of pushy New Yorkers. But these days, much is at stake. Lawmakers agree that New York's case for more federal aid could be undermined unless the delegation's members begin to speak in one voice.
As New York's senior senator, Charles E. Schumer, recently put it: "We're not going to pass anything unless we are all united. That means Democrats and Republicans. That means House and Senate."
The back-and-forth -- kept largely behind the scenes -- has been intense, with New York lawmakers on different, if not competing, tracks. Not only do they seem divided over who is doing the talking for the delegation, they are butting heads over what strategy to use to squeeze money out of Washington.
Perhaps most important, leading New York lawmakers are at odds over whether to take the White House to task publicly for not delivering the entire $20 billion that President Bush promised to give New York in the days following the attack.
The Bush administration has sought to disperse the aid piecemeal, saying that New York would get the money as it was needed. But that has caused a split in the delegation over whether the administration and its Republican allies in Congress can be trusted to keep their word without public pressure.
"There's no question that you have two voices coming out of the delegation," said an aide to one Congressional member from New York. "It's really two different camps."
One includes Mr. Schumer and the state's junior senator, Hillary Rodham Clinton, who have seemed reluctant to antagonize the White House, and have offered words of encouragement for the administration. This side contends that positive reinforcement, not criticism, will do more to move the administration in New York's direction.
This group also argues that it makes no sense to bicker with the White House over money, particularly when New York has so many other things it will need from Washington, like an economic-stimulus package to revive Lower Manhattan.
"You don't want to waste time fighting over the $20 billion when you could move on to other things," explained a Congressional aide from New York. "Why make that an issue?"
But another camp feels that conciliation is the wrong approach. This group is made up of House Democrats from New York who seem skeptical of any promises that Republicans make these days, particularly since conservatives on the Hill seem to be looking for any reason to deny aid to New York.
They say that the White House and Congress should be forced to deliver the money now, before Congress adjourns. Their main concern is that the state's needs will be eclipsed by other pressing matters, like the war in Afghanistan.
Representative Gary L. Ackerman, a Democrat from Queens, recently offered the best summation of the position. "Anybody who knows anything about Washington knows this: that when you get a commitment that you got the money, it doesn't mean that you got the money. You got the money when you get the money. Otherwise, you don't got the money."
The differences between the camps spilled into the open at the Capitol Hill meeting that Mrs. Lowey and other members of New York's delegation attended. Billed by some as a show of unity, it became so unruly -- with lawmakers talking over one another -- that several aides expressed dismay.
"What a disaster," one aide said. "It was ridiculous."
The fray grew so raucous that Mrs. Clinton stepped in.
"Can I just read the law?" she said, somewhat pedantically.
Mr. Schumer and Mrs. Clinton tried to maintain a positive tone, saying that there was no reason to doubt the White House pledge. "I don't think there's an issue of whether we get $20 billion," Mr. Schumer said. Mrs. Clinton chimed in, "Absolutely! Absolutely!"
But that view met with skepticism, during and after the meeting.
"You've got happy talk from the senators," said an aide to a New York City House member. "On the House side, we're much more realistic that if we don't get this money now, it will become a tougher sell later. If we keep being forced to come back for small amounts of money every time we need it, we'll eventually be told no by the Republican leadership."
"We don't have the benefit of working in a Democratic body that tends to be friendly to New York," the aide continued. "That's the bottom line."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Despite backroom differences, Senator Charles E. Schumer led New York's delegation, including Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Representative Charles B. Rangel, right, in a show of bipartisan unity. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: A Nation Challenged 

 BODY:
 Securing a Base

THE STRATEGY -- Tajikistan and the United States are moving toward an agreement that could lead to American military strikes against the Taliban forces from the territory of the Central Asian republic. An American inspection team has arrived in Tajikistan to examine three former Soviet bases to see if they are still usable. A1

The Investigation

THE MONEY TRAIL -- Investigators traced nearly half of the estimated $500,000 that paid for the hijackings back to the United Arab Emirates, a tiny Persian Gulf nation with a free-wheeling financial system. A1

PICTURES FROM AFGHANISTAN -- The Taliban took 26 foreign journalists on a tour of Kandahar, the regime's spiritual center, to see how ordinary life was still going on. B5

THE ARAB LEAGUE -- Senior Arab officials meeting in Syria said Osama bin Laden was waging a war against the world and does not represent Arabs and Muslims. B5

The Home Front

A PLACE TO WORK AND RELAX -- Since being transformed into a wartime president, George W. Bush has been spending more time than he ever imagined at Camp David, the presidential retreat in Maryland. A1

THE ECONOMY -- With all economic signs pointing to a recession, government policy makers face increasing questions about whether they can bring about a quick recovery. B1

POLITICS -- Candidates up for election on Tuesday are lacing their advertisements with American flags and the faces of firefighters and police officers in an attempt to convince voters that they can protect the public from terrorists. B6

OFF THE GRID -- Most people living in the backwoods of northern Idaho cannot think of any way life has changed since Sept. 11. A8

Rescuing a Sick G.I.

A RISKY MISSION -- An Army Special Operations soldier was rescued from northern Afghanistan after falling ill while helping rebel troops. The Pentagon said his illness was not life-threatening. B1

THE REBELS -- American jets pounded Taliban positions along the country's far northern front, as rebel troops appeared to take their first steps toward mounting a ground attack. B3

GROUND FORCES -- A senior Northern Alliance official said a six-person team of American military personnel had landed in rebel-held territory just north of Kabul. He said the team inspected a new airstrip and would carry out covert activities. B3

Spoiling for a Fight

THE OPPOSITION -- American planes dropped food and ammunition in southern Afghanistan to a tribal leader, Hamid Karzai, who could emerge as the hero of the resistance if he succeeds in toppling the Taliban. B2

THE RAIDS -- Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld, after flying over part of Afghanistan, said that American attacks had not dislodged the Taliban's power and must continue through the Muslim holy month of Ramadan. B4

The Biological Threat

PUBLIC HEALTH -- The recent cases of anthrax infection have done more than years of reports and warnings to convince Americans that the nation must get ready for a large-scale germ attack. They also have strained the country's public health system to its breaking point. B1

SMALLPOX VACCINE -- The United States is looking for scarce anthrax vaccine overseas in case lingering production problems cannot be resolved at an American factory. B7

MORE SPORES FOUND -- Trace amounts of anthrax spores were found on a package that NBC News sent at least a month ago to Mayor Giuliani's chief of staff. B7

Aftermath in New York

THE DETAINEES -- The government has revealed virtually nothing about the hundreds of people detained since the terror attacks. But the death of a Pakistani man in a New Jersey jail cell last month forced officials to talk publicly about the man's arrest, detention and death. A1

HEADLINE: Too Tall? Not at All, Tenants Say; 
Mass Exodus Is Absent at Skyscrapers as Anxiety Drops

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
New Yorkers have long been willing to pay a stiff premium to live and work in tall buildings that provide panoramic views of New York Harbor, Central Park, the Brooklyn Bridge or the thicket of Midtown skyscrapers.
 The higher the better. 
 But that spirit has been severely tested over the last seven weeks. Many commercial and residential tenants who prized their lofty perches in the city's skyscrapers before the attack on the 110-story World Trade Center reconsidered their choices after the disaster. 
But now, tenants and real estate brokers said, the anxiety levels have begun to subside.
Business executives say that while some clients are afraid to visit their offices, there has been no mass exodus from skyscrapers like the Empire State Building, which has regained its status as New York's tallest tower. Only 4 of the 880 tenants have left the 102-story tower since Sept. 11, according to the building's manager, Helmsley-Spear, while 4 new tenants signed leases and 8 others renewed. 
Commercial tenants at the 58-story Met Life Building on Park Avenue at 44th Street, where evacuations of the adjacent Grand Central Terminal put many on edge in September, say life is getting back to normal.
And condominium sales in the city's tall towers are picking up.
"At the end of the day, people come to New York for the views," said Stephen M. Ross, chairman of Related Companies. "People are always going to live and work in tall buildings in New York."
Mr. Ross and his partner, Apollo Real Estate Advisors, are developing luxury condominiums in what sales brochures describe as "two 80-story crystalline towers," which are part of the huge AOL Time Warner complex under construction at Columbus Circle. 
Fourteen people signed $60 million worth of contracts after Sept. 11, accounting for nearly half of the 33 condominiums sold since sales began in August, according to Susan de Franca, a senior vice president at Related. The company is awaiting signatures on tentative contracts for another 22 apartments worth a total of $153 million, she said.
Because buyers have to put down 10 percent of the sale price upon signing a contract, Mr. Ross said he saw the sales as a vote of confidence in the future of New York and the cachet of tall buildings.
Louise M. Sunshine, the marketing agent for the condominiums, said: "The view becomes an important part of why people pay these prices. They're not thinking about terrorists. They don't want to live on the second or third floor."
To emphasize that point, the sales office for the project is on the 53rd floor of the nearby Carnegie Hall Tower, whose glass walls offer views of Midtown, Central Park and much of Westchester County. 
The views from the condominiums in the new Columbus Circle towers come with a hefty price tag. The price of the five full-floor penthouses atop each tower start at $25 million and jump by $1 million per floor.
"The height of the building was very attractive, and the view that encompassed not only the park but the city," said a New York doctor who spoke on condition that he not be identified. 
On Sept. 13, he put down a deposit on a condominium above the 60th floor that cost more than $5 million. "My only concern about the attack was, oh gosh, what's going to happen to real estate values?" he said.
Ms. Sunshine said she expected sales to reach $300 million by the end of the year, about $100 million less than she had anticipated last August. The attack on the trade center, she said, has many New Yorkers putting off major decisions. About half the buyers in the last seven weeks have been foreigners, she said. 
Donald J. Trump said the attack had not affected condominium sales at Trump World Tower, the glass skyscraper on First Avenue that looms over the United Nations and the surrounding neighborhood. 
"We've had absolutely no repercussions," Mr. Trump said.
The developer had marketed the building, which rises 861 feet above the street, as the tallest residential tower in the world. But in a sign of the times, the developer has abandoned his characteristic use of superlatives, at least for the moment. "It's not the tallest building," Mr. Trump said. "It's 72 stories tall."
In an inflationary flourish that has become common among developers who charge a premium for views, Mr. Trump used to promote the building as a 90-story tower. At Columbus Circle, the towers will rise a lofty 750 feet above the street, or 53 floors. But by the developers' numbering system, the top floor in each tower will be the 80th.
With residential developers once again extolling the virtues of tall towers, commercial landlords say that normalcy is returning to the market.
But Jonathan Marks, a lawyer whose corner office is on the 79th floor of the Empire State Building, is not so sure the stratospheric views are worth it anymore, not since the attack on the World Trade Center left him wondering whether his landmark building might be the next target.
"People in this building are definitely nervous," Mr. Marks said. "There are two lawyers here who are scared to death to come to work."
Three floors down, Richard Aryeh, president of Lionheart Enterprises, a real estate company, said that two of his six employees had quit after Sept. 11 out of fear.
"It's such a good building," Mr. Aryeh said, "but at the same time there's such an uncomfortable feeling here."
Many commercial tenants in trophy towers had talked about decentralizing their operations immediately after the terrorist attack. Steven Ross, chairman of Vornado Realty Trust, one of the city's largest landlords, was only half kidding when, six days after the attack, he told three dozen of the city's top brokers and developers of a weird "inversion" of the market: space on the second floor is suddenly more valuable than space on the 60th.
John P. Maher, senior vice president at C B Richard Ellis, a broker, said that corporate tenants became more comfortable in the intervening weeks.
"Or course," he added, "if we keep having events like Sept. 11, who knows what's going to happen?"
The events at the trade center did not deter Marsh & McLennan, the insurance company that had eight floors near the top of the World Trade Center, from leasing the top floors in the 45-story office tower at 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street.
Jack Brod, president of the Empire Diamond Corporation and a tenant in the Empire State Building for 70 years, said he had no second thoughts. He said he was in the building in 1945 when a twin-engine B-25 crashed into the 78th and 79th floors of the building, and that did not faze him.
He said some customers had been nervous about coming up to his 76th-floor office. Two weeks ago, a woman drove into Manhattan from Long Island and asked his manager, Gregory Merdemian, to bring two $75,000, 8.5-carat diamond rings down to her Lexus on Fifth Avenue. He did so. She was afraid to go inside. Mr. Brod is not.
"I'm not nervous," he said. "It doesn't bother me a bit."
Nathan Dershowitz says he is still weighing whether to move his small law firm off the 79th floor of the Empire State Building. He said employees had been plagued by anxiety and the inconvenience of new security measures at the building.
"There is a level of anxiety that interferes with the staff's efficiency," he said. "But I very much want to stay."
But there are some tenants downtown who can no longer bear the views, no matter what floor they are on.
Joelle Tutela had loved living in a high-rise at Battery Park City for the last four years. But her apartment window on the 22nd floor of Gateway Tower now offers a bird's-eye view of the smoking ruins of the World Trade Center.
"It was a constant reminder of how devastating the event was," said Ms. Tutela, a high school history teacher. "You can't roam around freely anymore."
So after enduring security checks, acrid air and a lengthier trip to work in New Jersey, Ms. Tutela made what she described as a traumatic decision to move to the 19th floor of a building on First Avenue at 39th Street.

GRAPHIC: Photos: A majestic view, like the one from the 53rd floor of Carnegie Hall Tower, is still selling. (Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times); At the Empire State Building, only 4 of 880 tenants have left since Sept. 11. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Half a Commander in Chief 

 BODY:
America seems to be governed by two presidents. The George W. Bush who is commander in chief has been keeping the country united at a time when the war in Afghanistan has run into problems. But the George W. Bush running domestic policy is an entirely different person, less a leader than a narrowly focused politician. If America is to fight terrorism within its own borders and conquer the economic recession, the commander in chief is going to have to take control at home, too.
 Americans trust President Bush's leadership on foreign policy because his direction has been fair and nonpartisan, rising far above the ideology on which he campaigned. He has steered clear of political grandstanding, consulting Democrats as well as Republicans, and ignoring the hawks in his own party who have been demanding a wider war. On the home front, however, Mr. Bush acts as if he still cannot afford to alienate the right-wing leaders of the Republican Party and the big business and energy interests behind them. 
 Initially, Mr. Bush sent the appropriate signals to Congressional leaders to work together and produce legislation to rescue the economy, stiffen laws on terrorism and increase airport security. There was also a good initial response on Capitol Hill, where Democrats and Republicans cooperated to produce a criminal justice bill on terrorism. In the Senate, the two parties crafted a bipartisan approach on beefing up security at airports that included expanding the federal work force to handle the job. Then Mr. Bush abruptly backed an ideological approach pushed by House Republicans who could not stomach the idea of increasing the number of federal employees. The Republican bill squeaked through the House last week, prompting cheers of partisan joy at the White House.
It was sobering to see Mr. Bush throw himself into the lobbying for a victory that is important only to one wing of his own party, while undercutting Republicans who had worked in the Senate to fashion a bipartisan approach. The end result will be to delay, or endanger, the passage of any airport security bill, and to reduce Mr. Bush's credibility with Democrats as an objective mediator.
Even worse is the president's failure of leadership on economic stimulus. While urging Congress to work fast, Mr. Bush has guaranteed a legislative impasse by backing a bill that does nothing to help the immediate economy and gives out all but a fraction of its benefits to corporations, especially in the energy field, and to the wealthiest taxpayers. 
The next issue requiring Mr. Bush's leadership relates to public spending. Of the $40 billion set aside after the terrorist attacks of September, only $7.7 billion is to be spent on homeland defenses, including airports, bioterrorism protections and improved safety. It is becoming increasingly obvious that this money will not be enough. A crash effort has to begin now to secure all transportation links, not simply airports, and to upgrade security of the nation's water supplies, food and nuclear facilities. There also needs to be a serious look at giving Tom Ridge's Office of Homeland Security real budgetary and operational authority over the functions now scattered in dozens of agencies.
When Democrats argue that money for these items should be attached to spending bills going through Congress now, the Bush administration wants to wait until next year, apparently because it feels the nation cannot afford the additional costs. But if that is the case, how can we afford multibillion-dollar tax cuts for corporations and the highest earners in the country? The nation needs its commander in chief to step in, and set priorities that meet the urgent current needs rather than one party's election promises.

HEADLINE: H.I.V. Practices Face Grim Financial Times 

BYLINE:  By DAVID TULLER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 5 

 BODY:
Let's say you're a primary care physician with a large number of H.I.V.-infected patients. Until a few years ago, almost all your patients died; now, with new medications, many are doing great, and you know you're making a difference. There's just one small problem: your practice is going bankrupt.
 What do you do? If you're Dr. Jeff Goodgame, you fret about your patients, meet with financial advisers and wrestle with your conscience. Then you close up shop and accept a job as a manager in the research department at a drug company. 
 "I loved the private practice, but I could see the handwriting on the wall," said Dr. Goodgame, who left his Miami practice two years ago and moved to New York to join Pfizer, the maker of Viagra and Prozac. "My accountants were telling me, 'Why are you doing this? Why are you beating yourself to death?' "
Even as new drug combinations have helped H.I.V.-infected people live longer, a growing number of the doctors treating them are struggling to keep their practices afloat. In San Francisco, some physicians with large H.I.V. practices estimate that their annual incomes have dropped to the $70,000 to $90,000 range, from $110,000 to $120,000 five years ago, even though many work more than 60 hours a week. 
And in the past few years, said Dr. Stephen Becker, one of San Francisco's leading AIDS doctors, economics has played a role in persuading about half a dozen of the city's 25 or so private practitioners specializing in H.I.V. to close their offices. "That's a large number of doctors leaving private practice in this fairly small city," he said.
Not surprisingly, Dr. Becker and others blame managed care, particularly health maintenance organizations, for the problem. Many H.M.O.'s pay primary care physicians like Dr. Becker the same flat monthly fee, called a capitation rate, for every patient, healthy or sick, in a practice. When someone with a major illness is referred to a specialist like a cardiologist, the specialist is reimbursed at a much higher rate.
But many H.I.V. patients receive almost all their treatment from their primary care physicians. And that means their doctors receive the same low rates -- sometimes as little as $5 a month -- for an H.I.V. patient who has an appointment every six weeks as for someone with the occasional cold.
As a result, many doctors turn away new H.I.V.-infected patients, or at least those covered by H.M.O.'s. "It's getting harder and harder to refer people to doctors who will accept them," said Tim Teeter, of the San Francisco AIDS Foundation.
Even as managed care has taken hold, the advent of protease inhibitors and other drugs has made H.I.V. treatment more expensive and complicated. Current care requires frequent lab tests and regular monitoring of elaborate drug regimens. Monthly per-patient costs in services and lab work can easily tally several hundred dollars to more than a thousand. In some plans the lab costs come out of the doctor's monthly payments, making it harder for doctors with many H.I.V. patients to earn a living.
"The medical management of these patients has become increasingly complex, so physicians are unable to see as many patients," said Julia Hidalgo, president of Positive Outcomes, a consulting firm in Annapolis, Md., which specializes in the financial aspects of H.I.V. "And if the rates do not increase to address the level of complexity and frequency of visits, clinicians are not going to be able to break even."
Dr. Howard Grossman, a New York primary care physician, says his H.I.V. patients make up about 40 percent of his practice but take up 90 percent of his time. He is trying to avoid what he wryly calls "going over to the dark side" -- joining a pharmaceutical or managed care company. But he has not given himself a raise in 10 years, he said, and he was recently forced to reduce his nurse practitioner's hours to half time.
With so many patients taking dozens of pills a day, Dr. Grossman often spends his evening hours writing and faxing prescriptions. He calls all his patients back to discuss their lab results, which can take 10 or 15 minutes per conversation. "I'd like to see lawyers not get compensated for their phone calls to clients," he said.
One way to address the problem, say some physicians, is for the medical profession to formally recognize a specialty in H.I.V. medicine, which could put pressure on insurers to provide higher reimbursement. Although two groups of AIDS doctors have been working on establishing criteria for defining an H.I.V. expert, gaining official acceptance of a new medical specialty is an extremely cumbersome process, and there is no indication that it will happen any time soon.
Health insurers say that they are not generally aware of the problem and that, in any event, it is up to doctors to negotiate the best rates for themselves with insurance plans. But some industry representatives acknowledge that the system works best when primary care doctors have a wide range of patients, not when they have a disproportionate number of sick ones.
"The system was created knowing that the practices being capitated would have a spectrum of patients," said Bobby Pena, a spokesman for the California Association of Health Plans. "It does make for an interesting dilemma if you have doctors who call themselves primary care but are taking a large percentage of specialty patients. I don't know that anybody has come up with the best answer for that."
